My experience has been mostly from personal reading and studying of the Dao de Jing and the Yi Jing as well as the psychological approaches that incorporate buddhist and daoist fundamentals (mindfulness; Jungian analysis).

column25: As a young religious scholar, I feel like I have to be the party pooper by bringing up the social constructionist theory of religion -- an argument made powerfully by Talal Asad and Timothy Fitzgerald. The points that Asad makes are larger social constructionist ones and I can understand why Prof. Slingerland specifically declares from the outset that he wants to avoid such a tangled mess; if we press up against strong social constructionism it may limit what we get out of this class. But Fitzgerald has a much more limited argument, that using the *word* "religion" generally hurts us more than it helps us, strictly from a rhetorical point of view. After all, it is an English/European word that lacks a meaningful parallel in Chinese (or Japanese, Sanskrit, etc.); it was born out of early modern Christian sectarianism and the failure to establish a universal church.So, the idea of religion we adopt in this class, as a cultural standard with a "soteriology", may actually be inspiring us to impose a sort of Protestant imaginary onto ancient China. Keep in mind that religious studies often assumes "religion" to take the form of a "system of symbols", after Geertz. But can we really say that Warring States Taoism was a "system", or that its "soteriology" promises rewards of a similar kind to Christianity? Might it not be better to consider Taoism as some loosely related propositions about language and the mind, something like what you might hear from cognitive scientists if you get them drunk and ask them to share their wildest ideas about human nature? Perhaps if we keep that image in our heads, we might conclude that the word "religion" does little to help us understand what the ancient Chinese were thinking.However, I get the larger point -- that Chinese thought makes exciting propositions which run counter to all of our modern assumptions about how a good life is lived.

It's very interesting regarding Aristotle's ethics, and whether he genuinely developed such independently, or that the technology had migrated west.I think the latter. Aristotle's theory of Elements is almost exactly the same as we see documented in the Yijing [Book of Changes]. I think his notion of ethics was received as opposed to internally developed.Furthermore I think the energy he placed into the works of Homer, was due in that for elite readers, with the correct keys, it was possible in a form of ancient cognitive science, to free up from the conceptual shackles of dualism and to treat the text in an embodied manner. That was done using principles that in the west few people knew about or understood; which to this day remains the case.Aristotle did not come up with them, nor did Homer, they came from China, in my view.

I don't know if I am in favor of this expanding of the meaning of "religious" or "religion". On one hand I see the problem with tying religion to deities or supernatural beings, as  enough systems of "meaning giving" either behaved as, or quickly turned into, religions (the kind with supernatural beings). It makes it easier to discus and compare these normative belief systems without getting bogged down in discussions of religion versus non-religion. On the other hand I do think that it is usefull to make a distinction between systems that hand down rules given by a deaity, that have to be obeied because a higher authority orders it, versus systems that don't believe in such a higher authority, and try to devine rules in other ways. Don't you run the risk of making the defenition meaningless if you include "everything" (that is, every meaning giving system) in it?It will be interseting to see how this is presented in the course.

column25: Hi I am Erika from South Africa. I work as a senior investigator at the office of the Public Protector South Africa (Governmental Ombudsman Office) in Bloemfontein capital city of the Free State Province.

Plenty of food for thought here, but I'm struggling to see which model might be operating in different scenarios.  For example, suppose a tragedy strikes and you contemplate suicide.  You desist out of a Kantian-type notion of duty to your remaining family (Kant also claiming that you have a duty to yourself).  Yet hasn't this notion of duty ('cold') been taken on board to the extent that it's become part of your 'hot cognition'?  You don't have to deliberate long and hard about it Ð you 'know' without thinking that it's 'wrong'.  Thus, from what I understand here, desisting from suicide has become a virtue.  And then again, almost without having to think about it, you 'know' what harm your action might do to others, i.e. you're aware of the consequences.  Is this an example where the 'cold' cognition has  become 'hot'?Also, although in some societies suicide might be seen as a kind of affront to the whole community, and indeed was illegal for centuries in some states, someone who desists out of duty to their family might be said to be acting almost for reasons of kin selection, rather than out of adherence to an ethical system or their society's values.

It has only been a few hundred years since my people were hunter gathers. While we had chiefs, they could be male or female, and the people were not under their thumb. Yes we looked at the "Big Picture" confirmed by stories and traditions passed down. Were we the same as other tribes, no. While tribes shared many common cultural characteristics, each had things which made them unique.So I don't see how ALL hunter gatherer societies can be lumped together as having a common mindset.

The purpose of science is to continually investigate, not to establish facts. To illustrate, you do not need to take anyone's word concerning gravity.Do an experiment yourself. For example, check tomorrow to see if you can float above the Earth's surface unaided.Scientists can and must be questioned. Scientists are the biggest doubters of their work and that of their colleagues. Science relies on evidence and a healthy scepticism. On global warmimg, study the evidence. Environmental scientists have studied the available evidence, and most are convinced that things are hotting up on our planet.Formal religions, in contrast, rely on faith, that is, believing on no good evidence or even against the evidence.

I agree on the importance and open-mindedness of the scientific method and describe myself as an atheist. Nevertheless I am uneasy at such a sweeping put-down as that there is 'no good evidence' for faith. I don't really see how science can ever prove in its own terms that there is no creative force at the basis of physical existence even if none of the explanations offered by the existing world religions are satisfactory. Meanwhile I think we need more empathy with the countless humans who have chosen to have faith and who have created valuable human institutions (as well of course as many negative things). Their belief has created facts.

I find it fascinating that Chinese thought considers the control of water as evidence of civilization. Water is this relentless entity that can wear down rocks over long periods of time. Chinese thought also covers vast periods of time--in contrast to us newcomers in the West, who hardly have a sense of history and are focused on the latest fads. Controlling water is dealing with the most powerful and enduring aspects of the natural world.

column25: I don't think you can really classify the Greek philosophers as newcomers, and I'm not sure current Chinese consumers are any less attached to their fads than westerners.Interesting that the Chinese who were early on forced to control water still tended to regard floods as reflecting on the Emperor's lack of de, rather than his failure to train up enough hydraulic engineers.

I think that as soon as science moves away from the directly observable and into the theoretical realms it becomes a religion or system of belief rather than fact.  The evolution of science mirrors human evolution in that it also has become divided into hot cognitive and slow cognitive models - but it would, wouldn't it, being a human product.

I tend to think awareness is system 2, or cold. Awareness is a perception, so wouldn't that exist in the mind, rather than the body? But if, as you said, it's outside cognition, where is it? It must be hanging out with the tongue we try to hold. I like your observation about emotion as a hot cognition, but how the thoughts and sensations of that emotion are a cold cognition.You know when you become so emotionally hurt that your mind can't take it anymore - you cry or have some sort of physical release (screaming at the top of your lungs on the peak of a mountain) - then you have this brief moment of peace. Maybe you realize you can handle it, it's not that bad, you'll figure it out, etc. But there's that moment of peace - is that Wu Wei?

If I recall correctly from a Psychology class I had a couple of years ago, unfortunately, yes, that is exactly what ego-depletion means.The more concentrated one's mind has to be to resist psychological temptation, the less one can concentrate later.Interestingly, judging from this first week, it looks like this class is going to spend a lot of time exploring the concept of doing without explicitly concentrating (Wu-wei), both in classical Chinese philosophy and modern psychology, so for those looking for ways around ego-depletion, that might be a motivation to stick with it.

I interpreted the cold model as something like Legalism, where people are forced to suppress their heartfelt beliefs in order to obey the laws. (We see quite a bit of this in the United States today.) In the cold model, the laws will never really be "internalized" as you say because while people will be careful to behave the right way when they are being watched by someone who might use the law against them, they might behave a different way when they are out of the law's prying eye.The warm model, in contrast, is closer to the learning of the heart-mind as expressed by Wang Yangming, or the belief in "rulers, not rules" found in Warring States thought. Xunzi expressed it in this way: "The sovereign rules, and with his right rule comes right views. The sovereign is a bathtub, and his people are like the water. Water follows the shape of the tub. If he is a round tub, they will be round, and if he is a square tub, they will be square." It may be difficult to understand how this warm model is meant to work, considering that there is no such thing as absolute monarchy in the world we live in today.I guess my conceptualization of this places the heart-mind in warm cognition instead of cold cognition.

@evelyn11:I would say even theoretical science (which, to be technical, all science is - "theory," in science, just means a model that is used to describe reality, so even "If you drop it, it falls down" is theoretical, but I understand what you mean) is distinct from religion, because it relies on falsifiability - there are things that can be observed by someone with a hypothetical model that would force that person to change fundamental principals of that model.There's nothing that will really force you to change fundamental principles of religion, because religious truth is hard to observe, and it's pretty easy to reason around difficulties.

I've got a chapter on this question in my What Science Offers the Humanities (Cambridge 2008), strict Popperian falsifiability doesn't quite accurately describe what's special about science, although as an ideal it plays an important role. What seems special about science is that it's always seeking feedback from the world, has institutions and practices to reduce bias as much as possible, and (as SFDurrant observes) being committed to the idea that we are *not* establishing facts, we're just muddling along with the best current model we've got (and "best" being defined pragmatically in terms of helping us predict and deal with reality).

It looks a lot like Providentialism to me. I'm sure you're right that it acts as a post-hoc justification for the winner's victory, but it might also nag at the back of the Emperor's mind, constraining him from doing anything too risky. For example, maybe you don't want to send your army on that dangerous trek to defeat a foreign power because if it loses it's going to look like the Mandate has been forsaken. For a committed rebel, this must surely be encouraging: if something huge goes wrong for the ruler, you can step out and claim that the Mandate has been lost.

Based on what we learned about Wu-wei so far, I would say that it is indeed very possible to care about the world when in Wu-wei.I would say that people such as Martin Luther King and Gandhi seemed to be exhibiting characteristics of Wu-wei - they were very much absorbed in and sincere in their causes, and, at least in their biggest moments, were not considering themselves or - unfortunately, for both of them in the end - their own safety. And, at least from an outsider's perspective, they seemed to have done so "effortlessly." (However, I haven't read their autobiographies, so I don't know if they ever mention some explicit state of mind analogous to "Wu-wei" - I'm not saying they, particularly, *were* in Wu-wei, but I'm showing what caring in Wu-wei might be like)And man, did they have De. They had De like nobody's business.

The lecture undertook to explain what was taken as a factual observation: that Chinese tradition is collectivist, while other traditions are individualist.  That's the lecturer's observation, not mine.He infers that the reason for this difference is that around 4000 BC, in part of China (but presumably not very much elsewhere in the world) there was settled, large-scale collective agriculture, such as rice farming.  My point is that for 90% of the time homo sapiens has been on earth, there was no such agriculture.  Thus, during this long period of evolutionary time, it would follow that we were culturally and maybe even genetically tuned to individualism rather than collectivism.

With this new definition I will happily call myself religious because I have a very clear set of rules that I live by. Also my parents were Marxists but didn't belong to a communist party at any stage. I always say that Marxism was their religion, and I also say that capitalism is a religion. So I've actually been following Prof. Slingerland's definition all this time. The difference between religion and philosophy for me is that philosophy is more open-ended, still seeking as it were. There's a part of me that is still seeking, but as I get older, the part that 'knows' what I value is by far the stronger.Thank you very much for helping me to clarify this.

I just recently had a discussion with someone about how my life was going. I explained that many times in my life that everything seemed to flow and things seemed to "work toward a greater good" so to speak. But it seems that lately, especially on my extended stay in California, that everything I did or wherever I went, it was out of sync, or just a beat off from anything turning out right. It was getting quite aggravating, and the more aggravated I got the worse it seemed to get. I believe I was experiencing a serious lack of De. It makes a lot of sense.

It's all a continuum. There isn't such a thing as a purely "hot" model or a purely "cold" model in practice. Everyone is somewhere along that continuum and if they're closer to one end than the other we start attaching labels.Daniel Kannemann, who invented the idea of System 1 and System 2, used the image of being asked the question "what is 2 + 2" and then the question "what is 37 x 17"? You don't think about the answer to the first question. You simply know that it is "4". You must stop and think about the second; do some calculation; maybe check your answer; certainly take some time before you say "629". Thus, System 1 and System 2. However, I know some kids with developmental challenges who can't even understand the first question and others who can only do it with extreme effort. I can't do the second quite as quickly as the first but if they're two digit numbers I can beat a kid with a calculator every time. It is almost purely System 1 for me. You might not be able to do it without a pencil and paper. The next person might need a calculator. Thus System 2. I met a women in my undergraduate days who could multiply five digit numbers as quickly as I do two digit numbers. Someone beat her using a calculator but their answers differed. It took her two seconds to point out which key the calculator operator had pushed in error. Multiplication for her is system 1. A purely virtue model might assume that you just know what is right and do it without thought. Confucius allowed you to be taught the right way and required that you think about the right way so that you would know to simply act in the right way without thinking. Zhuangzi wanted you to be "spontaneous" like Butcher Ding but even the good butcher admitted that it took him time to cultivate the spontaneity of his skill. Mozi required carrots and sticks to encourage you to think correctly and to not think incorrectly. Sunzi wanted you to look at things "objectively" which seems to involve very ration thinking to me. Qin Shihuang just used sticks. It's a continuum. No one is purely one model or the other. I urge not getting stuck on the labels but seeing what each actually said; comparing them; and attempting to place their ideas along a continuum.

I paint and write poetry. I write about the things I see. When I just write from the heart, that is am clear about what I want to say, it happens with seemingly no effort and I often feel that someone else is almost dictating what I write. For me, this seems to be a state of Wu Wei. I am most happy with the result if I don't overthink the result. If nothing captures my imagination I don't try to find something to write about. With painting I am much more self conscious and have to really work at relaxing and not trying too hard - I am still learning the skills that will eventually lead to a state of painting Wu Wei, at least I hope they will.Some roses so fecundThe senses they floodA bare stalk nearbyHas a bleak little bud

The experience of wu-wei is definitely alluring on an individual level, when you feel so in sync with everything and everyone that you are no longer conscious of yourself.  But can an entire group of people be in wu-wei?  What if we get a whole sports team so tapped into the moment that each player can seem to read every other player's minds?  Or if a jazz ensemble gets into the zone and improvises great riffs of each other?  Is group-level effortless action also a type of wu-wei?

I think it is not the ultimate goal - the goal is probably to keep up the society running without any major issues -, but of course this can be an outcome. It really just depends on where you 'store' the rules. In most European countries we drive on the right. This is the law, and since we are doing it for such a long time we internalised it so deep we dont have to think about it.Then you go on a vacation and visit the lovely English countryside and decide to rent a car. The law says, you must drive on the left. Pretty damn hard at the beginning, but you stick to it, otherwise you might get a fine from police, get arrested, or kill yourself.Nobody is really trying to teach you (that's the driving school's job), government just set up a rule and they dont care how quickly you adapt or where do you store this - it is just easier for yourself if you keep it in your hot system :)

In the UK we are about to enter week 5 of series 10 of the hugely popular TV reality show Strictly Come Dancing (US equivalent: Dancing with the Stars). It is the Prof's Salsa experience writ large.Each week the Celebrity contestants (paired with a professional dancer) strive to learn a new dance and every Saturday they perform what they have learnt for evaluation by judges and voting public. The following day the lowest ranking couple is dropped from the competition. During the week, a daily update programme commentates on their progress in training.At one level, the show is shallow and camp: who wore the most dazzling outfit, who had a "wardrobe malfunction". At another, it is a sustained exporation of Wu-wei and De: how the least successful must become more natural. And the paradox is ever present: the harder they try the more that transcendental performance eludes them. You can catch up with this on YouTube.Even more crass, is Strictly's competing show The X-Factor... and yet, and yet, doesn't the X-factor (that indefinable charm) explore exactly the same topic?Maybe Wu-wei (what is it, how to get it?) is a larger preoccupation of Western thought than we recognise? What do you think?

Hi - I am from Boston, MA and am a semi-retired CPA.  I have always wanted to learn more about Chinese culture and history because I believe that I could benefit greatly from knowing more about a society that is so much older than my own. I look forward to learning with all of you.

I vaguely know the *Li Ji*, *Zhou Li*, and other texts are probably Qin-Han instead of the traditionally claimed Early-Mid Zhou, but am curious: aren't they reasonably valid texts to inform us ancient Chinese practice?And beyond that, what other texts are considered most revealing?An interesting aside--not a challenge, but a difference in teaching: After teaching Confucianism and Daoism by reading primary and secondary texts, annotating, discussing in seminars, etc, for five years, and *still* not ever feeling like my students (16-18 year-olds) "got" it, I decided to explore the opposite approach last semester: **"Practice travels better than thought."** Students read PJ Ivanhoe's *Confucian Reflections: Ancient Wisdom for Modern Times,* Chapter 6 ("Attention to, Awareness of, and Care for the Everyday"), and then did a three week "Self-Cultivation Project" aiming to embody--to *practice*--the "attention, awareness, care" every moment of those 21 days. They journaled it, following Zigong's "three questions I ask myself everyday" in the *Analects*.End-of-course evaluations were largely *very* enthusiastic (you're always going to have your "can't paint walls of dung" students). And the insights coming out of their mouths in discussions, compared to those from prior years of reading texts only, where also far more piercing.Just an interesting share on "thoughts or practices" questions, between teachers. (One of the students in that class is now at UBC, by the way. I told him to take your courses.)
column35: "Thoughts travel better than Practice": Reflections and a Question

Actually, in practice, social stability is probably maintained by a combination of both.  Imagine a game of chess.  The rules that determine how a pawn, rook or knight move and attack other pieces are part of the "cold" system.  Yet, there are norms such as turn-taking, not moving the pieces when the other person isn't looking, or not turning over the board if you're losing, that are part of the "hot" system.  In the first, you decide the best course of action and follow it after reflection, but in the second, it's like you don't even have to think about the best course of action to comply with it.  While you have to think about whether or not to take the enemy's bishop with your queen, you would not have to think about not tossing the board - that would probably not even cross your mind as an option.

column25: Being raised in the southern United States, and bred on the flood myth of Noah in the Hebrew Bible, I was blown away the first time I encountered the Chinese flood narrative, with its ancient naturalism and innocence: no angry deities here, no humans deserving punishment. Just a river in need of engineering, a government needed to organize that engineering, and hard-working, intelligent humans needed to devise and execute that engineering. And to think this myth is contemporary with that of Noah (though yes, Noah seems a derivation of a much older Babylonian and Sumerian myth).
column35: When Floods are Just Floods: Archaic Chinese Optimism and Innocence

As Prof. Slingerland notes, one can be impressed by the effect of the pictographic system as what I call a "bridge *across* languages" amongst the non-"Xia" tribes of early China without "exoticizing" the script for its imagism. I've long entertained the possibility with my own high school students that China's "Humpty Dumpty" *was* able to "put itself together again" after the almost 400-year Period of Disunity following the Han due in large part to the script, while *Europe's* "Humpty Dumpty" could *not*, and still hasn't, put itself together again since the collapse of the Western Roman Empire 1,500 years ago. Alphabetic scripts are "tribal walls," not "bridges," as Prof. Slingerland's illustration demonstrated. I can "bark out Czech" by phonetically sounding its alphabet, but not understand a single thing.(Another fascinating effect, to me, of China's system is that it became a "social *wall* between elites with the leisure time--years and years--needed to memorize the thousands of characters necessary to become literate, and the farmers and artisans too busy working for a living to enter the ranks of the literate. Mao inherited a China with less than 20% literacy rate in 1949 as a result of this, arguably.A *third* and final effect, confirmed by my own two-month immersion at age 50 in learning to read and write simplified Chinese, is the *psychological* effect of mental focus and discipline inculcated through such study, *and* the fusion of mind and body required to train the hand to execute the minute strokes necessary to distinguish one character from another, or to simply achieve aesthetic style.**But that Mesopotamian comparison?** It came compliments of French Assyriologist Jean BottŽro, in his wonderful *Mesopotamia: Writing, Reasoning, and the Gods.* He points out in one chapter on writing that the Sumerians, too, started pictographically, but their system diverged onto a different path due to a situation China never faced: the arrival of an *equally or more dominant "foreign" tribe*: the Akkadians. The Akkadian spoken language was Semitic, while the original Sumerian was not.Since the Akkadians came to dominate the Sumerians, the latter were forced to use their script to adapt their pictographs to handle *the Semitic Akkadian names, concepts, and phonemes* on a level of importance rivaling that of their native words. If I read BottŽro correctly, the original pictographic roots of the Sumerian became obscured by the necessity of combining them with sound-components--much like Mandarin script does too, but without the added and fateful complication of representing sounds foreign to those of the original characters.All very muddled, I'm afraid--it's late--but I'm intrigued by this and other questions of Cuneiform/Mandarin script. The materials used to write--brush in China, wedge-shaped reed in Mesopotamia; silk, bronze, and bamboo in China, baked clay in Mesopotamia--also raise interesting questions. On and on....
column35: Geography and Script as Destiny? A Mesopotamian Comparison

column25: I particularly enjoyed the discussion based on Nivison's treatment of *Shang* evidence of *de*. It made me see the famous episode in the *Book of Documents*--"The Metal-Bound Coffer"--in which Confucius' hero, the Duke of Zhou, asked the gods or *Tian* to take his life instead of that of the sick king. I'd always thought this was an example of a *new* humanism of the Zhou! So to discover that it had a place in the Shang ethical framework was extremely eye-opening. I'm off to find Nivison's book to explore more. Many, many thanks.
column35: New Insights on Shang and De for Me!

column25: Would you mind elaborating on Keightley's errors re: Homer? And how and why they weaken his claims?Also, if the case were true that Shang and Zhou China *lack* artworks that *do* focus on individuals to the degree that a great, great number of Greek vases and sculptures do, would you be more persuaded that his claim is more valid than you originally thought?

Simply a thank you for some interesting insights here.Devil's advocate to be less boring: isn't the ultimate release from Purgatory to Heaven the essential difference between Chinese and Christian conceptions of the afterlife, even granting Bossy's claims above?

Do you think the legends would form around founders who lacked a certain degree of virtue, though? (Sincere question, not adversarial--I'm thinking with you.)That George Washington had "de" is evidenced by who was it, George III who expressed such admiration when Washington gave up the presidency rather than declare himself king?As with Washington, so seems to have been the case with Wen, Wu, and the Duke--and the Mandate of Heaven was oddly not mentioned in Prof. Slingerland's transcript, but if I recall correctly, it's been confirmed as a fairly early and thus accurate section of the *Shujing*, which means their "overthrow us when we abuse you" contract *oozed* "de", even if other parts of the tradition ("loyal King Wen" versus actually "martial" one) are false.

I just read the transcript instead of watching the video, and don't find Dr. Slingerland making the claims you ascribe to him. Much of your argument seems more semantic than anything else. Yes, the Zhou court was concerned with Tian Ming, but that doesn't preclude concern with De. And the *Shujing* drips with "sage" actions that enact De, from the Canons of Yao and Shun and the Counsels of Yu to the many narratives about Wen, Wu, and the Duke.As for your connection of Li (ritual) to Fa (law), the debates between Confucians and Legalists on the efficacy of De versus Fa are legion. Ritual is "virtue ethics," not "criminal law." Shame, not punishment; practical education and participation, not coercion.

Agreed, the emphasis on family, ritual, and education are striking.An unfortunate difference--no offense intended, but right under our noses--is that when the Zhou seized the kingdom from the Shang, they pledged to include and serve all the subjects of the land. When the Hebrews seized the Promised Land, they were told to *exclude* (and bloodily) all who did not worship their god. The historical effects of this inclusive Chinese culture and our exclusive Abrahamic ones have followed world history from then to now. To me, the Zhou were superior in terms of ethical humanism.

Hi FiveWillows, I don't know why I posted the above anonymously, but we both read the Keightley piece in ChinaX months ago and my disquiet then led me to post here. The error I remember most vividly was Keightley placing a scene from the Odyssey in the Illiad (Achilles in Hades). But others of his descriptions of those texts simply fdid not jibe with what I learned in HeroesX, which means, at the very least, that the interpretation of the classics is probably a moving target.To me, this feels like poor scholarship -- like if we can't trust him to get the Greeks right, why should we trust him where there is so much less to work from?With respect to whether or not the absence of images bolsters his argument, the further back in time we go the shakier arguments of a non-presence are. So we have bronzes for the Shang, but what don't we have that may counter the collectivism model, but wasn't preserved?So, Keightley may be right, but given the -- admittedly little -- I have read of his, I would rather see other scholars tackle the material and hear from them.

I'm American, but moved to Shanghai from Germany at 40 or so, and stayed for six years. Fell in love with the people of my neighborhood--outskirts, so almost more rural than urban--during that time, found life more pleasant on the daily round level than any other culture I'd ever experienced. But didn't know the history beyond the high school "Asian History" inch-deep stuff I taught while living there (international high school).After a short 3-year stint in Seoul--another Confucian culture, but so Americanized it was harder to tell--I was hired to teach in Singapore. The job? A standalone class devoted strictly to. the. history. of. China.I've taught that epic, from origins to present, eleven times now. During that time I discovered the dna of the culture I so instinctively loved while living in Shanghai. The more I taught, the more I read--including Dr. Slingerland's works--and the more I read, the longer my must-read list grew.At this point I find its culture, values, aesthetic, and history by far the most impressive of all major civilizations (and my college major was European Cultural History--15 years studying it). And its philosophy? As Prof. Slingerland also asserts: it has much superior wisdom that the West would do well to give an ear. I'm hoping China's rise leads to the diffusion of Confucianism, and especially to the West. Daoism too, but just on evenings and weekends. ;-)

I think the point made here is that individualism was not a feature of tribal life, where activities were collective and generally divided more on gender lines. It could only emerge in larger settled societies where there was distinct specialisation of labour and the concept of private agricultural property worked by individual families. So individualism emerged in Greece (and Rome) rather than in China (and other early settled societies) because of the topography, and then so-called Western thought evolved from Greece and Rome into Europe and from there into WEIRD colonies like the USA and Australia (where I live), after the settlers had ruthlessly dispossessed tribal and/or collectivist societies.

In the module 1 introduction, Slingerland asserts that social constructionism is a difficult position to take because "culture so fundamentally varies across the world and across time that itÕs hard to see what the ground for comparison might be" between cultures.But aren't there fundamental commonalities between cultures, such as language, tool use, and a way to transmit information/memes across generations (e.g. stories, dances, traditions, artifacts, et cetera)?At a low level, genetics and the natural environment are obviously important to human thought. The question is: can we study human thought while abstracting away genetics/environment from our theoretical framework? Doing so would seem to require adopting some form of social constructionism.Personally it seems that although genetic and environmental factors (such as hard-coded sex drive or the night and day cycle on earth) do influence human thought, the influence is mostly by way of influencing culture which then influences human thought. This is a mostly sequential causal pathway, with culture between genetics/environment and human thought. In this sense, culture is the 'operating system' upon which higher forms of human thought are constructed. Therefore, we might greatly simplify our discussions by adopting social constructivism and focusing only on culture, while still retaining much of the explanatory power of a model that involves the lower layers of complexity of genetics/environment.Adopting social constuctionism would be a practical choice, not a stance about what constitutes The Truth. After all, it's obvious that both culture and genetics/environment influence culture; however this does not imply that we should give equal weight to both in our framework for studying human thought. In many ways the *gene-culture co-evolution* stance seems natural to assume (because it is obviously true in a sense), but its marginal explanatory power over social constructionism is not large enough to justify the large increase in complexity it adds to our discussions and theories.
column35: Response to Slingerland's dismissal of social constructivism

column25: It is mentioned that people living in rice agriculture tend to be more collectivism-oriented than people living in wheat culture. The reason given is that rice agriculture requires group activity. However, in ancient China, wheat agriculture also demands group activity. I don't know whether wheat agriculture is mainstream in pre-Qin period, but it is possible that wheat agriculture is important at least around the Yellow River area since the climate there is not suitable for rice. So I think people living in wheat agriculture is the same collectvism-oriented as those living in rice agriculture.

@psdimsum Hi, yes I'm also following ChinaX. As you say times happily have changed. I remember my first visit to China in spring 1973 when I went to Beijing to act as an interpreter at an industrial exhibition with my 18-month old Chinese language skills at the ready. It was a lovely spring day and I decided to walk to the exhibition hall from the hotel. Worried about being lost, I carefully rehearsed my sentence 'Excuse me how do I get to the exhibition hall?' and approached a passer-by. The poor man gasped in horror and ran away as fast as he could, leaving me to reflect on the value of my attempts to learn Chinese. It was of course a very tense time in China with strong distrust of all foreigners being actively fomented by the authorities. Even the few exchange students at that time did not acknowledge their Chinese classmates if they saw them in the street because talking to a foreigner got you arrested. It's good that learning Chinese is now becoming more popular in the west and Chinese people are now welcoming and friendly.Helllo Nico,I shall try to be less argumentative and more philosophical on this course!Regards,Doug

I see religion as a means of governing groups of people, which hopefully is for the groups betterment. I see it as a series of parables or stories which are often misconstrued or manipulated to best serve the 'leading body'. My berometer is that if it is fear based, then it is of a 'lower order'. Society unfortunately operates from a fear base as a means of control. Religion which is based on growth, development, betterment of self, up-liftment, with the ultimate intention of a free willed 'good' person, is in my humble opinion of the 'highest order'. Any religious studies, will have very beneficial teachings and messages with powerful guidelines, it all depends if it is used with the intention of either developing or controlling it's 'congregation'. Another element of religion I look out for is JUDGEMENT - The thought process which discriminates. I like the term, 'meaning giving system' as it does largely reduce the fear based threatening side of religion and it also removes judgement as it is based on structure, logical boundaries and purpose.

When 'ancient wisdom meets modern science' it may not clash at all because the core tenets of daoism are based on an observation of nature. The left-turns into divination and deism were subsequent to the original thought. I think science is definitely concerned with the universe, the cosmos. We feel the overlay of religion and superstition more acutely today because of the errors and mistakes made over the centuries.

That title of the book I found interesting because while it was natural for early man to be wondering why the sun kept coming and going, I'm not sure that taking that wondering and developing and organizing religions should be called natural. I'd call science more natural because it is the very study of nature and how things naturally came to be, while religions, certainly the monotheistic religions, don't preach anything natural. They preach here's what happened and how you must react and live---not leaving much room for being natural!

Just because the Chinese were more individualistic before they began rice farming doesn't mean they still are now. Experience changes things. Through rice farming, they learned that cooperation was key to survival. So now, in  Chinese society, everyone has a place, and the experience is one of close-knit communities, where individuals are part of a hierarchy and obligated to act one way or the other. Even modern China expects their youth to take part in this--you are *expected* to act a certain way to your elders, whereas youth in the US can treat elders as their friends, etc.I'm still not sure what you're arguing. I don't think what you're saying conflicts with the lecture, but you seem to think so.(This is to AndrewKahr btw. Juust realized that might be unclear lol)

I found this description of religion to be very effective at describing religion. It does not describe various "religions" or "sects" that have perverted the original intent of the religion, mostly the normative guidance tenant, such as jihadist Islamic sects or the Crusades. That being said, I think the literal meaning of philosophy "philo" meaning love and "sophos" meaning wisdom or knowledge is also instructive as it helps guide religious followers on a path to becoming in harmony with the way things should be. We are in our current state due to our lack of a full picture and omnipotence but also due to our free will to choose our own fate. The concept of religion without Gods is interesting as it implies that we are fully capable of fixing the current situation we are in (at least for ourselves) as shown by examples such as Christ or Buddha, but one could also argue that these individuals were not mere mortals such as ourselves. For example, many Christians believe that Christ had a mortal mother (Mary) and an eternal father (God) and therefore had the ability to do things that us mere mortals could not, and thus we deify him as a means for our soterical desires.

(at least in most) Chinese culture , accepting gift is not rude. However, when you accept the gift you must show sincere gratitude and not for granted, whatever the gift is. For example, it is polite to refuse gifts, but impolite to refuse them even if the host insists. If you want to accept the gift but want to show politeness, you can gently refuse at first, then if the host insists, take it and say thank you; if the host takes the gift back right away, it would be the host being rude. Accepting directly is fine as long as one shows sincere gratitude, and if possible, have some of your own gifts for return.

column25: Patriachy or Matriarchy means rule by men or women, respectively.Patrilineal or Matrilineal means family descent  and kinship through the male or female line respectively.Family descent does not mean rule. A society could determine descent and kinship relations matrilineally but the men might rule the family. Historically descent and kinship has been determined through either or both lines but truly matriarchal societies are rare.

I loved the focus on the two-handed business card. It's also true of paying with money. I teach my Western students in Singapore, who rarely if ever venture outside their "little America" bubbles into actual local culture, to simply experiment with giving local cashiers cash with two hands, thumbs-up. (The Malays and Indians do it differently, with left hand palm-down on right forearm, perhaps because of left-hand rituals of hygiene.) I tell them to note the response of the cashier.They invariably report back that the transaction has been transformed from impersonal cash transaction to human one. Eye contact, facial expression, speech all are noticeably warmer. Both sides feel better after this small ritual act.It's like the bus driver story Prof. Slingerland told earlier. And it's so much more palpable and normative in East Asia (I've lived in China, Korea, and Singapore since 2001) than it is when I visit America. This is one aspect of China's rise that I hope diffuses outward, and catches on in our WEIRD culture.

I agree that leaving students to come up with their own curriculum entirely sounds like a case for indigestion. But I also think that learning to be independent and motivated enough to learn or do something on your own time is important, which is possibly what the personalized learning trend is trying to do? (I'm not even remotely an educator, I'm only speaking as a student.)I think the cause of the personal learning bandwagon is from teachers seeing the results of students who already have that drive, for example, teenagers who code their own mobile apps. These are students who, through the Internet, have more opportunities than ever of pursuing their own interests online, and bringing that into the school or the local newspaper. And so the teachers think, "How can we make more students like this?" I don't know what people who are on the personal learning bandwagon are advocating, but making space for students to complete a (rigorous, supervised) project of their own, on any topic they want, I think is pretty cool. In this case, I think the actual learning of the subject matter is less important than creating the drive--the learning will come in time, as a result of that drive.Supplanting general education entirely sounds crazy to me, though, because it's such a foreign idea.Anyway, I'd love to hear your thoughts. My boyfriend is interested in education policy and he supports personalized learning (I don't know enough to have an informed opinion), but I think he would agree that learning is not the antithesis to creativity, but the launching point for it.

A quick add. You write:> it's odd to hear a western academic arguing that the western tradition doesn't include historical research, study and cooperation with other scholars, but only autonomous thought.> > That is this ideal that we have  inherited in the West, that proper knowledge, reliable knowledge is something that you've verified for yourself using this kind of internal reason that you have. I reviewed Prof. Slingerland's transcript, and can see why you might paraphrase it as you do. But I don't think it's likely that he's unaware of "the Shoulders of Giants" and all of that. He seems to be characterizing our Western view of traditional thought and individual creativity. Relevant clips from the lecture:> The idea of the importance of traditional forms for thinking properly is I think a little bit weirder to us. So we're very much believers in creative thought, especially in the modern West. What we value is people thinking on their own and thinking freely and coming up with ideas out of nowhere. So if you want to think about modern Western attitudes toward thinking, I think they're perfectly captured in the Apple slogan, "think different," right?--Note that this describes popular culture today. It's his introductory frame.He then turns to the Enlightenment, and after quoting Descartes explicitly stating he is starting from scratch in his search for knowledge, adds:>There's very good reason for thinking this is a very stupid model of how we think. It ridiculously exaggerates the power of the individual human mind. We are cultural animals. We're social animals. Most of the way we think is shaped and properly shaped by our cultures and by things we've learned from the past. So this Enlightenment ideal I think is inaccurate. >And actually the Confucian model is a much more accurate picture of how the way in which we think is a result of the creative apprehension of traditional learning. So it's not passive. We're not just going to memorize stuff and not use it, not think about how it applies to our lives and we don't synthesize it. --Provocative stuff, for sure. But Descartes *did*, after declaring independence from traditional Christendom's worldview, *cogitate his way right back to its God*. This is pretty clear evidence that even when we try to "think outside the box," we're fooling ourselves. Descartes *was* inaccurate in his claim that he was a "free thinker." Take it further and you see Deists tweaking, not escaping, monotheism, and dozens of other examples pointing to the reality that that "flame of Enlightenment" burned *within* the container of its traditions.
I hope they agree. :)

The fate of Confucianism is fascinating, parallels that of Jesus very much. He died fearing he was a failure in 479 bce (traditional). Legalism, Mohism, and Daoism all treated his traditionalism--very reasonably--as silly utopianism and wishful thinking.Qin ended the Warring States Period in 221 bce. Its Legalist government burned Confucian texts (saving copies for the imperial library, mind you--they just saw totalitarianism as necessary while consolidating the Qin peace, arguably) and executed dissident scholars (traditionally told as "burying them alive," though there's reason to doubt that detail).Qin was overthrown by Han in 200 bce. Han founder Liu Bang was said to have literally urinated on a Confucian's hat to show his disdain for these effete bookworms. It's hard to imagine how much lower the hopes could get for Confucianism than that. Maybe using the Analects as toilet paper? Oh, but that was invented only later in the Han!Anyway, Han Emperor Wu--reigned 141-89 bce--favored Confucianism as the Imperial ideology. A stupendous moment, apparently motivated as much by inner court politics--Wu needed a rival power base to offset a threatening Daoist faction, I believe--as by appreciation for Confucianism.Jesus died on a cross. Some messiah. Nero burned Christians as streetlamps generations later. Fed them to lions for fun, on and on. Roman elites laughed at and ridiculed Christian beliefs as a) ripoffs of Egyptian, Greek, and Roman cults, and b) a religion for slaves, old women, and illiterates.300 years later, Roman emperor Constantine needed a power base--particularly fighters in his army during a civil war--to offset powerful rivals. The large population of "slaves, old women, and illiterates"--especially the slaves and illiterate males--proved useful for those needs. He favored Christianity.East and West, Confucianism and Christianity both see failed spiritualities triumph for political reasons. And both, arguably, perverted the original vision of the spiritual founders. Jesus' teachings were perverted into institutional Christianity, Confucius' into State Confucianism.History's interesting that way. And I think I got most details right. Would love any corrections or complications.

I got this from Simon Fraser, which seems interesting:http://www.oocities.org/paideusis/n1ms.htmlWhich advises:The first layer of the Yi is probably over three thousand years old and consists of the hexagram symbols (Lynn, 1994:2). The second layer consists of the ZhouYi text or Zhou Dynasty Changes, written around 820 B.C. (Shaughnessy, 1983:49). The sixty-four hexagrams are arranged in a puzzling, apparently non-logical sequence (Figure 4), and together, the text and symbols provide a system for conceptualizing, contextualizing, and engaging change. The third layer is the Ten Wings Confucian Commentary which includes the philosophical ground for understanding the cosmological principles of the Yi system. This material was initially compiled in the 4th century B.C. (Lynn, 1994:2).

I agree that great ideas, theories and inventions are not just there in the head of sole people that were totally disconnected from others and thereby the only ones to come up with innovative achievements.The history of inventions can clearly teach us that often at several places, distant from each other, at the same time or at least timely close to each other, inventions came up, without others being able to see a direct link between the different inventors (before the times of ever-working global networks).Of course the link is Ð roughly Ð the societal web (let me call it that way), the circumstances of the time, and the very needs and insights that have been shaped and that invited certain developments to come.So far and even further I follow the notion to doubt the immense importance that we in the West give individuals, and see more value in collectives and collaboration instead, which is my very professional position also.But I think that there are many examples of intellectual and technological progress which had to do with people, for good reasons feeling detached from (big parts of) society, being alone and even enjoying it, who came up with novelties, and for that not even embracing to follow common rules, but rather breaking them.What I want to say is, I am not yet willing to dedicate myself to Confucianism and collectivism, which would be difficult anyways as I was influenced differently all my life, but I welcome the opportunity to learn about the potential clearly coming with them, as well as combining both worlds as far as possible and reasonable.

@dougma, The difference is more semantic than real, I'd argue, between Copernicus/Galileo and Descartes. The Scientific Revolution was the *prelude* to the Enlightenment, part of the same "starting over" rejection of the medieval Christian culture that framed my claim: Medieval Christian tradition was bankrupt, and the Renaissance started the "trash it and start over" counter-culture. Sci Rev and Enlightenment are just two further sub-headings under the "Early Modern" main heading.The Western Zhou, being instead exceedingly humanistic and rational, were traditions worth preserving, not trashing, as Confucius rightly appreciated. If the Mandate of Heaven, a "Divine *Responsibility* of Kings" ideology, is not clear (and very Voltaire-ish, I might add) political philosophy--and the sumptuary codes and ritual order not social and economic philosophy to boot--it's hard to imagine why not. And again, Kongzi wasn't unquestioning about them, as you claimed.So I suppose we're at the "agree to disagree" stage. If I patronize, it's only because your characterizations of the Western Zhou texts--not philosophy done in Western modes of discourse (but then, neither was much of Plato)--and of Confucius' relation to them seen in the *Analects*, seemed both wide of the mark and defensively indignant in response to Prof. Slingerland's claims--to the point of painting them as sensationalism instead of substantive. It's a vista worth looking at for a while before drawing such a conclusion.Anyway, apologies for the perceived "patronizing," but it was a bit of a case of tone mirroring tone. I'll try to police it next time around.

Interesting close. I'm sleepy now, but will try to be coherent :PI think I see "modern culture"--and by that we mean WEIRD, yes?--as almost a contradiction in terms. Your plural "patterns" sort of hits why, to me: a culture is unified. Interesting!  And it's important to remember that these rituals are only introductory signs of your social competence and character.  By exchanging the money or the business card in the correct manner, you establish that you are someone who can be dealt with on a common basis.Although, as a born-and-bred Singaporean, I do have to say that sometimes it is awkward to see non-locals trying to imitate local rituals, as sometimes the ritual may be improperly executed or used in the wrong context.  The improper appropriation of a ritual can raise all sorts of angst, and while we appreciate others trying to fit in and to acknowledge local culture, cross-cultural interactions naturally take place in a landscape fraught with all sorts of hidden landmines.  Though maybe the Confucian Junzi would be able to effortlessly navigate all such minefields?

Hi FiveWillows,Once again, you've started a fascinating discussion!  I remember back when the Ministry of Education in Singapore posited a new tagline, "Teach Less, Learn More," it sparked off quite a furore.  How is teaching an impediment to learning?  What exactly are we removing from the teaching, and what more is the student learning exactly?  Is it a slippery slope to "Teach Nothing, Learn Everything"?I guess part of the question lies in what we think is the purpose of education.  Is it to mould and carve the raw material into an exemplary person?  Then you'd need to know what constitutes an exemplary person, what methods are good carving tools, and what people are really made of - and you'd need to tolerate quite a bit of wastage in the form of people who don't make it to exemplariness.  Is it to allow each person to achieve their full potential?  Then you would be providing a buffet of tools to the person and allowing the person to choose the aims to pursue with those tools - but then you'd subscribe to a radical sort of egalitarianism where all aims are equally valid.

There are many similarities between the Chinese philosophy of Confucianism and the religion of Buddhism, in India. In general, confucianism seems to share a lot of similarities with lots of other religions. It would be very interesting if there was a lecture sheding light to these aspects.

As far as Confucius is concerned, the only classics we're sure he was referring to are the Book of Documents and Book of Odes (he quotes from them and names them). It's almost certain that the Book of Music wasn't put in its present form until the Han, and the Liji (Record of Ritual) is also probably mostly Han, although some of its chapters clearly circulated as independent texts in the Warring States (we've dug some up). The early parts of the Book of Changes are probably quite early, but it's debated whether it was a classic recognized by Confucius (despite the legend that he composed the 10 Wings commentary, almost certainly not true), although recent archeological discoveries show that a form of it was circulating in the Warring States. Confucius supposedly assembled the Spring and Autumn Annals, a history of his home state of Lu, but this is also probably legend.

Hi Iris,Thanks for the kindness. I'm glad to meet someone who gets the clean pleasure too :)As for Five Willows, it's from a beautiful little self-portrait  prose piece by Tao Yuanming (Tao Qian), a great poet from early medieval China. I love it, and also love what willow trees do for China (they have *de*, to sound silly--but it's true):> THE BIOGRAPHY OF MR. FIVE WILLOWS>Mr. [Five Willows] is a native of I know not what place; nor does anyone know his name or surname. There are five willows beside his house, and therefore he is so titled. He is quiet and talks very little; he cares little for fame or money. >He loves reading, but never seeks to know the exact meaning. Whenever he comprehends a passage, he is so enraptured as to forget his meals. He is fond of wine, but, being poor, frequently cannot afford it. His friends and relatives know this, and they sometimes invite him over for a drink. He always finishes the wine, determined to be drunk. After he gets drunk, he retires, without caring where he finds himself. >His surrounding walls are bare and tattered, and do not shelter him from wind and sun. His short jacket is torn and patched; his bamboo-basket and gourd [used for rice and soup bowls] are frequently empty. He feels unperturbed nonetheless. >He often writes to amuse himself and to express his feelings. He forgets all about gains and losses, and thus he finishes the span of his life.>The commendation says: "Chien Lou [ancient hermit] has a saying: 'No grief at poverty and humbleness, no eagerness for riches and honors.' These words can be used in praise of this man, who enjoys drinking wine and composing poems.... Is he a man in the reign of Wu Huai [legendary ruler]? Is he a man in the time of Ko Tien [Iegendary ruler]?

This lecture reminds me of a discussion in Christian theology about the relationship between a Christian and the biblical laws or commandments. If I recall correctly from my introductory philosophy class in college, this thread runs from the Epistles of St. Paul, through Augustine and to Martin Luther.The idea is that the letter of the law, by specifying what is prohibited, actually teaches people how to do prohibited things. And if a person obeys the law only because they wish to avoid the penalties that come from breaking the law, then they have in fact already internalised the prohibited act and are restraining themselves by exerting their "cold" cognitive control over their baser desires. However, if a person really believes in the spirit of the law, then they internalise that spirit and instinctively act in accordance with the spirit. Since the spirit also gave rise to the law, a believer automatically acts in accordance with the law.In the first scenario, obedience is the product of external coercion, while in the second, compliance is the result of one's own volition. In the former, penalties are essential to guarantee order, while in the latter the letter of the law itself becomes superfluous to people behaving well.
column35: Coercive Obedience to Law vs. Internalised Compliance with Law

I agree with AndrewKahr.Individual questioning exists as the primary method by which a society may test the validity of its beliefs and is thus essential to the subscription of any philosophy.Accordingly, a lack of adequate skepticism may result in the perpetuation of even the most ridiculous or self-damaging of ideas, as exemplified by the scenarios AndrewKahr has given.The danger in this kind of ideological conservatism lies not only in that it fosters the indefinite continuation of possibly inferior ideals but also in that it suppresses, and in Confucius's case, totally eliminates the chance of improvement of any kind.The underlying assumption in Confucianism is that the traditions, thoughts, actions etc. of the Zhou kings are superior to those of any other group, and although that may seem to have a great deal of validity in the chaos of the Warring States Period, it ultimately loses its credibility in the face of a whole wide world of philosophy in which an indefinite number of future innovators will accordingly conceive of an indefinite number of better ideas.Now that it has been put into perspective, the idea that nothing in our world will ever surpass the ways of a few primitive kings really seems a bit laughable.Nevertheless, the Confucian ideal of education is certainly valuable as the development and consideration based on the thoughts of previous thinkers ultimately bears more potential than the musings of a single individual; however, this by no means mitigates the importance of independent thought and healthy skepticism.

Perhaps Confucius had a deeply instinctual knowledge of the human mind -- that the brain naturally inclines toward and thrives on learning and that as the mind/brain is stimulated and focused, it builds up only to relax in a 'default mode' - a resting state which is still 'activated' - see current neurological research on default mode network. In other words, fMRIs are showing the reciprocal brain activation systems are not all 'learning' and not all 'resting' but are in a dynamic relationship all the time. He is working with what he has observed about human beings.

It makes sense to me - very much so. A society may be deemed 'multicultural' but within it most people follow a sub-culture: some following a traditional religion which imposes normative beliefs, rituals and other behaviours; some following a new trend in beliefs, rituals and other behaviours for a while until a more attractive trend emerges; some working out their own beliefs, rituals and other behaviours. And everyone thinks that they're the only ones on the right path.

Nicholas Christakis and James Fowler in their book "Connected: The Surprising Power of Our Social Networks" make the point that we are influenced not only by our friends, but also our friend's friends and even our friend's friend's friends.  The level of influence drops with each degree of separation but it does not get close to zero until four degrees of separation.  The point is that we are influenced by a lot of people we do not know and this scientific research ties into Confucius' point that virtue can spread throughout a society.

There are lots of subgroups within all groups. One of the points of difference is whether someone can be brought into the group. My father was raised in the Anglican Church (Episcopalian/Church of England). My mother was raised in a rather strict Presbyterian household. When they married, the aunt, with whom my mother had lived for ten years, refused to come to the wedding because it was a "mixed marriage". Most people don't think that way but some do. I've heard of a Catholic priest refusing a marriage because the bride was not Catholic. He would not marry them even when she converted. Most priest would marry them without question on this point. The Japanese have special words for anyone born outside of Japan. It applies equally to non-Japanese and to child born to parents of Japanese ethnicity. Most people do not refer to "gaigin" because of it's pejorative connotations but some do.

I've noticed a bookshelf in the background of some of the videos and one comes to mind from the topic of discussion. From the blurb, ''Originally published as the second volume of *The Tao of Painting*, this book is the first translation into English of the *Chieh Tzu Yuan Hua Chuan*, or *Mustard Seed Garden Manual of Painting*. Part I of the Manual (The Fundamentals of Painting, Book of Trees, Book of Rocks, Book of Jen-wu), first appeared in 1679. In 1701 the publisher reissued Part I and added Part II (Book of the Orchid, Book of the Bamboo, Book of the Plum, Book of the Chrysanthemum) and Part III (Book of Grasses, Insects, and Flowering Plants; Book of Feathers-and-Fur and Flowering Plants; and two books of additional examples). The great popularity of the Manual is attested by the more than twenty editions published in China in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The present volume is a facsimile, with translation, of the Shanghai edition of 1887-1888, the first lithographic edition and the one which provides superior examples of the brushwork, always a matter of primary concern in Chinese painting. There are over 400 examples of brushwork, ranging from the single stroke of a blade of grass or a flower petal to the composition of a tree, village, or mountain. These examples help not only to clarify the text but also to enunciate the principles and standards of the *tao* of painting and to demonstrate how the traditions were handed down from period to period.Mai-Mai Sze has provided an introduction, chronology, and a valuable appendix in which the basic terms of Chinese painting are analyzed and illustrated by means of their ideograms and, in many cases, the earlier pictograph forms. Born in China and educated in England, France, and the United States, Miss Sze is a writer and painter. Her paintings exhibited in London, Paris, New York, and in a large retrospective at the Addison Gallery of American Art, Andover, Massachusetts.''In Zhou tradition, perhaps reading this is somehow teacherless, traditionless self-directed learning? My experience of Chinese art is often tapestries and paintings found in Chinese restaurants but you really have to know what you're looking for when buying for investment. The arts of making paints, brushwork and such have dwindled given changes to lifestyle and pastimes. I would imagine setting a whole day aside in village life or monastic pursuits often gives way to electronics and electronic media.

What is intensely interesting here is that Zilu is not shown as meeting a solitary hermit sitting on the bank of the river, but rather a pair of people who were not idle, but were working (very inefficiently) together.Confucianism is seen as "collectivist" and involves applying active, directed effort towards self-perfection and towards contributing to the group, under direction.  Modern society, to the contrary, is viewed as individualistic, adapted to the self-centered individual--who in general succeeds through effort, a work ethic.So, these primitivists, unlike early monks in the desert, reject "civilization," but regard work as normal and needed, and human collaboration or interaction as useful and desirable.  The legendary hippies were communalists who criticized the individualist society from which they sought to separate themselves.  While some were willing to work hard on a farm, others preferred some form of meditation.Thus, when we contrast the primitivists and the hippies, each against the society which he rejected, we see that the parallel between primitivists and hippies may not be such a compelling one.  The hippies, unlike the primitivists, were self-consciously more rather than less communal than the surrounding society, and they were often less rather than more oriented towards work.

From the Daodejing, we hear that the Way is lost, hence we have Benevolence and Kindness, and Laozi's view seems to be that in order to restore the way, we have to lose Benevolence and Kindness. However, I somehow think that this has confused the cause and effect. The reason we have words to describe Benevolence and Kindness is because the Way is lost, and simply by forgetting or "unlearning" Benevolence and Kindness will not get the way back. I tend to agree with the Confucian view and that by internalising ourselves with Benevolence and Kindness, perhaps firstly via rituals, then perhaps we may return to the Way. But then through human nature, we get complacent, and lose it again, and this follows the yin-yang cycle and is in line with the Daoist thoughts...All very fascinating to me.
When you talk about hippies, remember Charles Manson was a hippy.

I wonder how far the two men featured in the Analects text can really be regarded as typical of primitivist communities, rather than as caricatures. Harnessing yourself to a plough might on occasion in Chinese (and other countries') histories have been forced upon one but it would hardly have been a strategy of choice, particularly in a culture where, for example, rice farming required a collective effort. Laozi suggests not using horses for war but doesn't suggest not using them at all. He seems to envisage a simple life, rather tailored to the intellectual seeking a quiet life free from both external and internally generated stress. The dense metaphors and paradoxes suggest the work is aimed at intellectuals. This surely argues as you suggest a need for a certain level of social organisation as implied also by the acceptance of the notion of a king.I'm not a north American and am perhaps a little more sceptical of the idea that modern society is tailored to individualism. Socialist and communist traditions argue against this model and, after all, individualists wouldn't get far if nobody built the roads. This of course is the inevitable argument against modern-day hippies, basically that they are free-loaders on a rich developed society. So I'm not sure I see all that difference between the primitivist impulse then and now.

I actually don't think this is a caricature at all. There's a passage in ch. 12 of the Zhuangzi which describes virtually the same behavior and conversation, clearly relishing how manual labor throws modern men for a loop:> Zigong traveled south to Ch'u, and on his way back through Chin, as> he passed along the south bank of the Han, he saw an old man preparing> his fields for planting. He had hollowed out an opening by which he> entered the well and from which he emerged, lugging a pitcher, which> he carried out to water the fields. Grunting and puffing, he used up a> great deal of energy and produced very little result.> > "There is a machine for this sort of thing," said Zigong. "In one> day it can water a hundred fields, demanding very little effort .and> producing excellent results. Wouldn't you like one?Ó> > The gardener raised his head and looked at Zigong. "How does it> work?"> > "It's a contraption made by shaping a piece of wood. The back end is> heavy and the front end light and it raises the water as though it> were pouring it out, so fast that it seems to boil right over! It's> called a well sweep."> > The gardener flushed with anger and then said with a laugh, "I've> heard my teacher say, where there are machines, there are bound to be> machine worries; where there are machine worries, there are bound to> be machine hearts. With a machine heart in your breast, you've spoiled> what was pure and simple; and without the pure and simple, the life of> the spirit knows no rest. Where the life of the spirit knows no rest,> the Way will cease to buoy you up. It's not that I don't know about> your machine - I would be ashamed to use it!"> > Zigong blushed with chagrin, looked down, and made no reply. After a> while, the gardener said, "Who are you, anyway?"> > "A disciple of Kongzi."> > "Oh - then you must be one of those who broaden their learning in> order to ape the sages, heaping absurd nonsense on the crowd, plucking> the strings and singing sad songs all by yourself in hopes of buying> fame in the world! You would do best to forget your spirit and breath,> break up your body and limbs - then you might be able to get> somewhere. You don't even know how to look after your own body - how> do you have any time to think about looking after the world! On your> way now! Don't interfere with my work!"> > Zigong frowned and the color drained from his face. Dazed and> rattled, he couldn't seem to pull himself together, and it was only> after he had walked on for some thirty li that he began to recover.

If one accepts the definition of religion presented by C. Geertz originally in 1966:Religion is (1) a system of symbols which acts to (2) establish powerful, pervasive, and long-lasting moods and motivations in men by (3) formulating conceptions of a general order of existence and (4) clothing these conceptions with such an aura of factuality that (5) the moods and motivations seem uniquely realistic. ÒReligion as a Cultural System,Ó in The Interpretation of Cultures (New York: Basic Books, 1973 [1966]), 90.Then the view that Philosophy is a subset or system of religious thought becomes a reasonable proposition.  Indeed, any system of thought that presents some sort of ontological claim can be viewed as such.

ÒSo the Analects is a record of this guy who thought it was his job to save the world.So he really-- and it's a religious mission.  So he really believes he is on a mission from tian.So Confucius is inheriting from Western Zhou thought this idea of a supreme diety, tian-- heaven.We're going to translate this term as heaven.  So he really believes he is on a mission from tian.a supreme diety, tian-- heaven.  Heaven has sent him on a mission to revive the culture of the Zhou.Ó---Prof. Slingerland,  Mod 2.1, Confucius and the Analects.CouldnÕt possibly agree more strongly with this assessment of the Confucian mission.  What disappoints is how little time is spent on any of the MasterÕs more universal ethical statements in any of the modules.  For instance, Fingarette, in Confucius: The Secular as Sacred (New York, Harper Torchbooks, 1972), 53 Ð 54:Acts that are li are not just rote, formula conforming performances; they are subtle and intelligent acts exhibiting more or less sensitivity of context, more or less integrity in performance.É an act may be seen as more or less ren if we see how this person does it, and more specifically whether it reveals that he treats all persons involved as of ultimately equal dignity with himself by virtue of their participation along with him in li. This concept that all persons are of equal dignity, that they are always entitled to oneÕs very best, whether the recipients of these actions are appreciative or not, is one of ConfuciusÕ great innovations and requires emphasis.  As the Master states in Analects 12:2, ÒWhen in public, comport yourself as if you were receiving an important guest, and in your management of the common people, behave as if you were overseeing a great sacrifice.Õ Do not impose upon others what you yourself do not desire. In this way, you will encounter no resentment in your public or private life.Ó  Still later in Analects 15:24, the Master states, ÒIs it not Ôsympathetic understandingÕ (shu )? Do not impose upon others what you yourself do not desire.Ó  Here I think the English concept of empathy is meant by shu; the idea of being able to see and feel the actual circumstance of others and respond in a meaningful and appropriate fashion.  These concepts, I believe, were intended as a corrective for what he viewed as the moral problem confronting him and his followers:I should like to say a word about ConfuciusÕ image of moral evil.  In fact the description of these evil tendencies which impede the achievement of the good is strikingly similar to the diagnoses made by the prophets, wise men and philosophers in all the high civilizations of this period.  The unbridled pursuit of wealth, power, fame, sensual passion, arrogance and pride Ð these themes figure centrally as the source of Òthe difficulty.Ó Schwartz, The World of Thought in Ancient China (Cambridge, Harvard University Press,  1985), 83.These problems are still our problems; his answers to these problems are the source of much of his appeal for Non-Chinese readers everywhere.  More focus should have been given to these issues.

The Free Will Defense to the Problem of Evil is well known and has problems including:1. Free Will & Compatibilism2. Some horrible things in this world are not the product of human free action (e.g. natural disasters)

The back to nature argument is an excellent heuristic which has been written about by Nassim Taleb:*"Now, for mathematical reasons (a mechanism called the ÒLindy EffectÓ), linked to the relationship between time and fragility, mother nature is vastly ÒwiserÓ so to speak than humans, as time has a lot of value in detecting what is breakable and what is not. Time is also a bullshit detector. Nothing humans have introduced in modern times has made us unconditionally better without unpredictable side effects, and ones that are usually detected with considerable delays (transfats, steroids, tobacco, Thalidomide, etc.)"*In his explanation anti GMO movement, Prof. Slingerland conflates the absence of evidence for evidence of absence. In the case of GMOs where there is systemic risk, a lack of observations of explicit harm does not show absence of hidden risks.More on this here:http://arxiv.org/abs/1410.5787Taleb, N. N., Readx, R., Douady, R., Norman, J., Bar-Yam, Y., 2014, *The Precautionary Principle (with Application to the Genetic Modification of Organisms)* arXiv 1410.5787
column35: The scientific reasoning behind anti-GMOs & the back to nature argument.
