I see. idiomb, my greatest interest is in Yijing. Not from a mystical/divination perspective, but from a factually based perspective. It seems most fascinating.What are your views on that? Do you have any interesting related links?I've picked up some aspects with Shou Gua, that seem to link well with some western classical metaphors. Also Dante [marsh, mountain, et al.].I've seen that if you use a system of image pairs of the related key words, such as in Dante, it seems to add another syntax dimension. I found the same in Homer, and Pindar.In Homer its quite pronounced. A corpus linquistical collocation and concordance with keys words associated with trigrams, then computing them, seems often very much in line with the underlying narrative. What I am saying is that I am using the trigram pairs, as one would with Chinese art, but in literal analysis on symbolism, particularly in Homer and Pindar, as well as Dante.I've come to the conclusion, such is known, but possibly kept 'secret' such as by fraternal organisations [Kabbalah and so on]. I seem to have got quite advanced, but I'm very much on my own with it.By the way, I accept what you say on the above.However using the antonym parsing method of the "titles" I mentioned do present a very interesting and most fascinating perspective. I did this with both the Dao and Yijing.The notion of metaphoric tension between both works crossed my mind, and was further illuminated by the antonym parsing method, which in my view lights up the whole matter, with much greater clarity, and more of universal perspective. If I had to make a bet, I'd say its a "hidden in plain sight matter'. Those that promulgated the works did so in the knowledge, that only those that worked such out would be worthy of it. Which would have been quite a clever idea of theirs.

The primitivists' desire to return to small-scale agriculture seems to be  utopian but perhaps unrealistic.  With agriculture, there is the possibility of famine; a harvest may fail or get eaten by pests.  Therefore, it would always be prudent for farmers to grow more than enough to just meet basic needs. So the primitivists saying they don't want to increase productivity seems strange.  Might this not threaten their very survival, if they had 'returned to the land'?Similarly, they say they want less people.  But do they want to limit family size, or do they want the 'surplus' population to die of starvation?Peasants who work the land through no choice would probably welcome the use of the plough.  Professor Slingerland says these primitivists were probably from the elite class, and they seem to have idealized the 'simple life' without following through their arguments to see the possible consequences.  Although they say that it is the ruling elite causing starvation, might their own ideas not have the same effect if brought to fruition?
column35: Satisfying the desires of the belly?

column25: I think one troubling implication to come out of the theodicy problem is that if God is omnibenevolent, then it follows we are already living in a maximally benevolent world. After all, an omnipotent deity could theoretically create an ideal world in which everyone still gets to exercise their own free will, *and* nobody ever falls to or suffers at the hands of evil. That we don't exist in such a world implies it either is not possible, or that we are mistaken about omnibenevolence in some way and such a world would be less ideal that the one we already have. To look at the myriad evils that obviously plague our world and still believe *this* is as good as an omnipotent and omnibenevolent creator could possibly make it is thus a hard pill to swallow.  The same kind of problem comes up for both the Daoists and the Confucians, I think. If the Daoists are right and people are already perfectly good, naturally omnibenevolent you might say, then how could evil culture and evil people emerge at all? But if the Confucians are right and people are naturally coarse and prone to baser instincts, then how did the sage kings of old overcome their natural coarseness and just happen to stumble upon omnibenevolence without the benefit of a Zhou culture that preceded them?  Despite the cleverness of our qualifications, when faced absolute theological doctrines such as omnibenevolence or the perfection of Zhou culture, I think the only way to resolve any contradiction to our own perception is to resort to faith. At some point a true believe has to stop questioning the will of God, the emergence of the sage kings, or the ontological framework of the primitivists. The perennial problem for the true believer, of course, is that this falls flat as an argument for convincing those who don't happen to share your faith.

Both the Daoists and Confucians talk about being a good person, and the Daoists about being natural. But was there any concept of 'evil' in the same way we have in Western thought?And was there any concept of consequences if you weren't good and natural? The idea of Tian (heaven) seems to be different to Western ideas of heaven and the afterlife, was there an opposite, a hell type place? Would these ideas of good and evil have made any sense to someone in the warring states period?
I definitely agree with both of your points Andre.

Honest, like unhewn wood.    I prefer Charles MullersÕs Translation:Straightforward like an uncarved block of woodThis concept is deeply linked to what is stated in chapter two, Òand practice the teaching that is without words.Ó  Restated in forty-three, ÒThe teaching that is without words.Ó  This wordless teaching is the only approach to that which is Òstill and indistinct, it stands alone and unchanging,Ó presented in chapter twenty-three.  Still and indistinct, not still but indistinct, and this wording is very significant.  These lines lead one to realize that most of us, in our day to day existence, interact within and to our environment in a completely culturally conditioned fashion.  We see what we have been trained to see and nothing more.  Laozi instructs us to Òmanifest plainness. Embrace simplicity.Ó  Muller translates these lines as Òsee the origin and keep to the non-differentiated state.Ó  When one is made aware that what is being translated here as ÒsimplicityÓ is in fact our friend, unhewn wood or the uncarved block of wood, one can feel how the thought being presented is the Ònon-differentiated state.Ó  What is a non-differentiated state?  Here this state of consciousness is an awareness of Òthings, beingsÓ in a manner that is not mitigated or influenced by language, the wordless teaching.  This awareness is always still **and** indistinct because the consciousness is not busy trying to separate and label the individual components that make up the experience.  An awareness of, an appreciation for the thing, the being as it is in itself.  A tree (in keeping with the wood theme) is a Òtree,Ó but if all you see is a ÒtreeÓ then you do not see it at all.  Colin Tudge, noted botanist, writer and lover of trees wrote:ÉBut the essences of nature will not be pinned down easily.  In the end all definitions of nature are simply for convenience, helping us focus on the particular aspect that we happen to be thinking about at the time.  There is no phenomenon in all of natureÉthat does not take a variety of forms, and that cannot be looked at from an infinite number of angles and each angle gives rise to its own definitionÉ The way that we define natural things influences the way we treat them Ð whether we speak of wildflowers or of weeds, of Mrs. Tittlemouse or of vermin.  But in the end nature is as nature is, and we must try with different degrees of feebleness, and for our own purposes, to make what sense of it we can.  Tudge, The Tree (New York: Random House, 2006), 5 Ð 6.Lengthy quote, I know, but I like it, rather, and has much to offer regarding the above discussion.One last thing I must state, if one wishes to experience the wordless teaching, one must not hold to any purpose.  To really experience a tree, see a tree, one must experience only its purpose, its long slow life, its song and nothing else.

This is the point I also want to make. Some people can prefer to living in a simple, primitivist way, only satisfying their belly's needs. They can sustain their life without technology. Yet some people can be/become greedy and aggressive and would invade the people who live in a primitivist manner. Such is the paradox of living a primitivist life. It is the same with individuals. Some people desire a simple life but the world requires people to be greedy and competitive or else people would fall behind and be exploited by others. It is the paradox of historical development.

My problem with GMOs is that they are overwhelmingly created by transnational corporations (e.g. Monsanto) in order to make more money. Instead of allowing poor farmers to save seeds from their own crops that have proved to thrive in the local conditions, a whizz-bang improvement is introduced, e.g. a crop that is resistant to a pesticide produced by the corporation, and then by various means (fair and foul) it systematically replaces the 'natural' way. So the farmers become dependent on the GM seeds and also on the pesticide.This is social engineering rather than a technical advance, especially since the 'scientific' testing is controlled by the corporation, and this leads, among other things, to the sort of issue referred to by Brian above.

Why do so many champion alternative learning methodologies, is the question that needs to be addressed.  The simple answer to this question is that many of us were damaged, badly damaged by the institutions and methodologies that traditionalists defend.  Most classrooms in the traditional school setting are simply coercive situations where thinking is not rewarded, questioning the givens are often brutally and sternly punished.  Unless these traditional institutions can alter themselves to become less coercive, more student friendly environments, they will become a thing of the past.

Chapter Thirty-Seven Nameless unhewn wood is but freedom from desire. Without desire and still, the world will settle itself.For me the word "still" here is as significant as the phrase "without desire." I'd be interested in knowing the etiology behind the Chinese word as that could tell me if I am reading something into the word that is not there. As my state of knowledge rests in this moment, I see the word "still" as depicting the kind of stillness that comes from deep presence in the moment. The mind has stopped chasing desires and is now clear and "still."  Only when mind settles into stillness, will the world do the same.

After the Warring States period, Daoism became increasingly mystical, and focus shifted from ideological primitivism to occultism (with all of the rituals that entails - I've browsed a copy of the Yi Jing translated by a Daoist with explicit details on how to read the book, including, among other things, which direction I should face when consulting it).Buddhism arrived during the later time, so it makes sense that Zen is more influenced by later Daoism than earlier Daoism.

I'm a primitivist too, but, having once had a bad experience with dope cookies, I eschew the drugs. On the other hand, neither of those two statements is really true because I rely on prescribed drugs in order to keep from despairing and/or becoming a hermit.My own interpretation of 'human nature' is that there is a spectrum of human nature, from a very few people whose nature and nurture will overwhelmingly lead them to act with good will to others, to another very few people whose nature and lack of nurture will overwhelmingly lead them to act with bad will to others. Most people are somewhere between the two - as in a 'normal curve'. In small, egalitarian and interdependent societies people of bad will were comparatively easy to ostracise for the good of the community. But the development of large-scale agriculture, private property and eventually nation-states led to large, hierarchical and attenuated societies. In these societies it is all too easy for people of bad will to seize control by force, and then seek further power by conquering smaller societies. That is the paradox - how we human beings can have the best of both worlds. How can we leave behind the isolation and often rigidity of small groups without sacrificing their internal connectivity and collectivity? How can we encourage creativity, diversity and helpful technological advances without becoming prey to the sociopaths among us?

I made the mistake once of inserting myself into a conversation in the check-out line of my local Whole Foods between the cashier and a customer talking about how horrible GMOs are, and how you should never change anything that Mother Nature made, etc., etc. I pointed out that every single item in this guy's basket was the product of intensive selection, by human beings, over the last couple thousand yearsÑlow tech GMOs. The conversation didn't go so well, and now I keep my opinions to myself at Whole Foods. I'd like to see some evidence that the kind of big leaps that GMO technology makes possible are different, in principle, from the changes you can get just through intensive, selective breeding: maybe there is a case to be made that the former are more dangerous for some reason, but I've yet to see any evidence. The argument ad Montsanto also strikes me as a red herring: we can separately critique the practices and values of large multi-nationals (which are often horrific) without conflating it with the danger, or lack thereof, of GMOs as a technology. There's also the elitist, First-World bias that bugs me a bit: I can afford to go to Whole Foods and buy locally-produced, non-GMO foods because I'm in the economic top 1% of the global population, but especially as climate change accelerates and places that used to be able to produce crops can't produce crops anymore, a lot of people who don't live within reach of a Whole Foods may die without the kind of radical leaps in drought-tolerance or salinity-tolerance that only GMO technology can produce.

We discussed Theodicy, the problem of evil, in our MIT philosophy class. But, before I start in on that, I would like to share a joke I wrote:Student: "We are discussing Theodicy in the Chinese thought class?"Other: "Chinese? Theodicy? I could've sworn Theodicy was written by a Greek."All right, I hope you enjoy that. We discussed the problem of evil as an argument against the existence of an omniscient, omnibenevolent, omnipotent God. The response to the problem of evil which did the best job was the "No Best Possible World response," which asserts that for any world created, there could always be a better one that could have been created. God simply had to choose among many worlds which all could have been better. I think that a response to the problem of unnaturalness is that people may be forced to develop unnaturally. People are born naturally. They begin as children and behave as such, more naturally and in wu-wei, until they develop the mechanisms for cognitive control. Problems occur within the environment, which make society more complicated, and places are created in society. The places in society give rise to more complex problems of unnaturalness, and so an "unnatural (written)" soteriological structure is needed to bring back naturalness. Basically I am positing a response of a causal nature, "If we had not become unnatural, then we would not need a soteriological structure to discuss. The good of the structure tends to outweigh the unnaturalness in society." The other response is constitutive; "If the were no unnaturalness, we could not appreciate naturalness." If I am not mistaken, the Way comes from something natural. It would seem that the best response to the Theodicy problem from the daodejing would have to be constitutive.

China under Xi Jinping seems very interesting in this mix for his explicit appeals to ancient Chinese philosophy as alternative approaches to taming these hegemonic elites.)

The "Great," which "arose before Heaven and earth," reflects for me the Mahayana idea of Buddha Nature which "stands alone and unchanging" and which is our essential nature before it is named and/or conditioned. In my Zen studies I have read that Buddha nature was translated as "dao." I think the phrase, "forced to give it a name" is significant in this passage in view of the idea in Chapter 1 - "that which can be named is not the dao." There is a similar idea in Mahayana, that language won't touch the reality of "the great." but if we are to bring those who can't "read" the dao in how we live our lives, language, though inadequate is essential. I love the phrase, "The Way models itself on what is natural."

Beautifully put, davyddew1!  I only hope that I will have a similar experience someday, perhaps with a lover or a child.  I remember coming across something like the idea of meta-conscious awareness of everything, that deep sensory activation that you describe, in "Our Town", the play by Thornton Wilder.  In the stagings that I have seen of this play about the life of a family in a small town, the bulk of the scenes are staged with minimal props and set (sometimes the floor plan of the family's house is marked on the surface of a black stage by nothing more than masking tape).  It is only when the protagonist has progressed to old age and is about to die that suddenly perception is fully opened and the final scene is a re-enactment of a family meal that we had seen before, but this time with a sumptuously detailed set.  The sensory effect on even an audience member with no experience in such awareness is strikingly memorable.

I've been looking into Buddhism recently. Though I think you're correct, that we are all impermanent, what I took from it is that dissatisfaction is the nature of humanity. We are happy with something we buy one day, and then the next day we get used to it, and then the next day we want something different. It's not just the objects themselves that are impermanent--it's our feelings for the objects and how we view them, and the place they have in our lives. It's kind of this tragic thing, where we buy things to make us happy, and eventually we become dissatisfied with them when the next big thing comes along. Not that it only applies to material things, that's just the easiest example to grab.

[Edited to change the title because I realized this post had become something...different after I'd posted it aha]Taijiquan is a great example of 'yielding to overcome.' I think another, pretty directly analogous, example is when you're arguing with someone. Yielding to them--considering their points seriously, understanding where they're coming from--opens up the discussion so you can then guide them to see where you're coming from and what you believe. It doesn't necessarily mean they'll be convinced, but it's a lot more productive than shouting at each other. In this sense, I think yielding is an underrated skill. How many people actually listen to each other when they argue?Somewhat of a digression:I practiced Taijiquan for a while (disclaimer: I'm awful at it--you need to practice it very seriously for a very long time before you can actually use it martially. In a sense, you have to achieve wu-wei in Taiji to even use it at all) and a lot of the motions and ideas behind it are similar--you collapse around the attack, so they only meet empty air. "Re-directing" is a term commonly used in talking about Taiji, but I think it's more about making empty space where the other person is trying to hit you (you're not actively shoving at the person's fist). That in itself is enough to put you in the position of strength for a counter.So I'm not sure if there is a conflict in being weak to be strong. I think maybe it's an issue of wording--in Taiji, you aren't being "weak," just like when you consider someone else's point of view in an argument, you aren't being weak. Maybe "in control" and "not in control" is better? You do not control the other person's movements, but make room for them. In this way, you gain control. It's hard to say what I think of this without making the same crazy paradoxes that we're hearing in lecture hahaha. I think it's something you have to be shown and try yourself to get. Or maybe it's better to say, it's not that you gain control, but when you make room for an attack, your adversary loses control.Hee. Maybe it sounds like I'm dancing around the issue, and going the same way as the Daoists. But to me it makes sense.

The Wegner "irony of effort" research seems to shoot holes in Confucianism, but for two reasons I would challenge that conclusion:1. Ritual practice after long enough becomes effortless, so the "trying to relax" paradox would presumably only fit for a novice on the Confucian way. It would become "second nature" at some point. "Effortless."2. Wegner's research is probably based on a sample of WEIRD subjects. If so, is there any reason to extend its findings to non-Western humans? Chinese ones, for example?It's also difficult to hear the final claim in the lecture--that by embracing the lower side of any dyad "you actually get the thing you want." I've never seen DDJ as advocating wanting much, or being driven by desire.But it's complex, since composite. And when it addresses rulers, much more visible. But for the average seeker of "sageliness," I see the DDJ as diagnosing the problem as "you want to get things," and prescribing as a cure to "stop wanting" (and, contra the "pessimistic" interpretation, to be at home in whatever moment and place you're in).

Mozi criticizes Confucian standard of de/virtue as subjective and arbitrary. Yet his standard of yi/righteousness comes from heaven's will. Heaven chooses a group of peole who know heaven's will about what the yi/righteousness is. These people know yi/righteous to which others have to conform. Isn't this arbitrary?How can these people know heaven's will? In Confucianism, sage or gentlemen determine what is right or wrong. Is Mozi's idea of the mass people follow what the bureaucrats declare as right different from COnfucian idea of the people following gentlemen? The difference I can see lies in the mechanism the functions in the two sets of moral codes. In the Confucian set, gentlement cannot use coercive measures to force other to follow. In the Mozi set, coercion and reward are implicit in it. Other than this difference, what are other differences? Can Mozi's standard of righteous ness be objective as Mozi intends to be?

column25: Does it? I would think that Mozi would only say "thank you" if it could be objectively demonstrated that the wealth and well being of the community was increased. Thus, he wouldn't say "thank you" if the bus driver wasn't going to hear it as it would be ineffective.  I wonder if Mozi would say "thank you" at all as it doesn't increase wealth. You should be doing something because it increases wealth so why would Mozi "thank you"?

I can sympathize with statements about spending too much on one's children. I have an empty house with a room full of outgrown and abandoned toys which await hypothetical grandchildren or a trip to Value Village. But there are limits to the measurement of the benefits. At what point does Mr. Singer's charity stop? The benefits of water to a community are truly immense and to be generated wherever possible but what about the costs associated with the water attracting a military insurgency to the village because there's water there? What about the cost associated with the toy-maker not being employed or the truck driver not having to deliver the toy to the store or the store employee not being employed because the store's sales are decreased? At what point do I stop putting aside money for an unemployed retirement where I will need someone being charitable to me? Mr. Singer's arguments are laudable and persuasive but still fall short. Perhaps that's the fun of philosophy. We've can only generate answers to the questions. We can never actually answer them.

As to "impartial," Mozi focuses on impartiality between potential recipients of one's material aid, NOT on "give all your money to the poor."He's quite insistent that a "good" official needs to have a high income and live very well in order to impress the common people.  Sacrificial giving and humbling oneself aren't on the agenda.  The king has to be the wealthiest man.In this he points in a dramatically different direction from Singer, a distinction which I don't feel the lecture adequately recognized.

I think he's a bit broader than you're painting him in that he seems to argue that if you want to encourage a general lifting of standards you need appropriate rewards for high-achieving individuals so that everyone seeks to emulate them, or obey them as necessary. He doesn't talk solely in terms of financial reward but also status. In any society high-achievers are surely more than simply 'vocationally motivated'? Doctors or judges for example enjoy a high social status and I would argue that for many of them this is part of the motivation.

Only if you define them as such. As a Mohist can you kill philosophers? Sure, it's easy. Simply exclude the title "man" from the definition of philosopher.

Hi all,I queried one of the top experts on Mozi, Prof. Chris Fraser at University of Hong Kong, about this, and here is his response:Thanks for this. The student's question touches on core features of Mohist thought -- features that remain interesting in ethical reflection today, I think. One core point is that the Mohists don't exactly argue for promoting the benefit of the state, per se. They argue for promoting the benefit of "all under heaven," and their examples of the sage-kings' deeds clearly indicate that "all under heaven" includes foreign tribes. This point reflections their universalism: right and wrong are determined by the consequences for everyone, not just us. A second core point is how the anti-war arguments reflect the Mohist conception of dao. As they see it, dao is a path that can be practiced and promulgated regularly and consistently by all. To them, isolated counterexamples don't rebut the argument that wars of conquest are contrary to a state's own interest. They think history shows that wars of conquest usually end badly for the aggressor. Even if there are a few exceptions, the general point stands. And how can we be sure we'll be one of the exceptions?The student's remark about civil war brings up another interesting point. Because of their notion of "all under heaven," early Chinese political thinkers have only a vague, slippery conception of a sovereign state. In practice, political entities like ancient Qi and Lu acted as independent, sovereign city-states, each with its own network of subordinate cities and towns. But in principle, these states were parts of "all under heaven," subordinate to the (powerless) Zhou emperor and to Heaven itself. So a war between them in some respects resembles a civil war, and a military offensive to punish an aggressor is partly like invading another country, but partly like a domestic police action. I have a survey of early Chinese just war theory here, if anyone is interested: http://cjfraser.net/site/uploads//2014/09/Fraser_JustWar_Sept2014_single.pdf

By our standards punishments from ancient times are barbaric, yes. But I'm not sure if the people who lived then saw them as barbaric.And I think that Mozi would share your doubts about productivity of surveillance, that's why I think that he'd be against it.

Perhaps Mozi's view is not purely objective, but it is at least more objective than the view of Confucius. Where Confucius measures yi by intuition, Mozi measures yi by a chosen standard. I think the main difference is that Mozi has defined his standard, and Confucius may have a less-defined standard that could be subjective in certain cases.

The important thing to note is that Mozi's argument is that it is prudent for a citizen to believe in ghosts. This is analogous with an argument of Pascal. He argued that it is prudent to believe in God, because believing in God has a higher expected value than not believing in God. He explains by saying that by believing you are taking a sort of bet. The expected value of the outcome of the bet is equal to all the values of possible outcomes multiplied by the probability of the outcomes. Calculating in that manner, and taking the value of eternity in heaven to be infinite, as well as taking the value of the godless life to be finite, it is most practical to believe in God. Pascal's Wager is a great analogy for this Mohist concept of supernatural surveillance.

Having just being introduced to the character of Mozi, I may not be able to bring to the table discussion as in-depth as that shown in the discussion topics pinned this week (thoroughly worthwhile reading). A quote attributed to Mozi from Wikipedia, ''What is the purpose of houses? It is to protect us from the wind and cold of winter, the heat and rain of summer, and to keep out robbers and thieves. Once these ends have been secured, that is all. Whatever does not contribute to these ends should be eliminated.'' -http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mozi (2014)   From this, I would entertain the thought that Mozi would yes, be in favour of surveillance. Specifically, I am not sure if he would classify Harvard classrooms as a house of learning or if surveillance, rather than aggressive warfare, promotes pacifism. Focusing on his view that large music ensembles are a waste of resources detracts from focusing on more applicable teachings that aren't today so wild and preposterous. I'm of the view that it isn't particularly a core concept that underpins his teachings that serves in detracting from his character and credibility.   I'm of the understanding from the discussion that he holds in his views a concept of ghosts of deceased persons and spirits? Would those against surveillance be of the same opinion regarding divination? I am unsure of its specifics with regards to Chinese astrology, though one discussion mentioned China advancing faster if it had focused on 'Western scientific principles' which I believe would detract from their traditional models of study. I do not think it unpossible that a convergence of ideas in future cannot happen not unlike the studies involving monks, states of meditation and various states of brain wave production monitored in laboratories. Peering into the crystal ball could be claimed as an invasion of privacy, I'm sure I've heard an old wives' tale of how one can percept when someone is concentrating on thinking about you.   I am curious as to whether Mozi had court wizards in his employ influencing his decisions. From the discussion, he would have standard punishments and additional punishments from the spirit world that today would be described as barbaric. My question is if he had shamans in contact with spirit and dream-worlds as described in this course who dealt punishments on his command?

Hi Shasta girl. What you say makes sense. From following this course and the ideas it provides; I think the nature of things, the essence - is what it is at a certain time and from a certain perspective. And all perspectives and times are just as valid as each other one. For example is the nature of a willow to grow, or be a bowl. Well the nature of the tree as it is small is to grow, if it gets the chance. As it grows the tree is fine, but it will change the course of the river (that's what willows do). That might be great for things that want a river to slow down and change direction - but evil for things that want the river to run fast and stay in that direction. Change happens, like for people, we want change (the Desires of the Eye). Then the willow grows old and dies and could be turned into a beautiful bowl - artistic people will like that - so 'good'. But people who are cold would rather it be fire wood. Both are good. And all these things are the willows' true nature. It's essence. It's essence is growth, change, beauty, warmth, decay .... growth. etc

@andrewkahr I just realised you were the original poster, was about to click the follow button for the email update.''Result for sure is that attendance would go up and happiness would go down.''Do you not have a class attendance policy at Harvard University? Happiness is subjective and linked to neurochemicals in the brain. Some people might get a buzz out of the austere halls of Harvard.

Harvard does not have a policy requiring attendance at lectures.  They did require this in 1650 (when average student age was 15), but dropped it somewhere along the line, at least 50 years ago.  Individual instructors can grade as they please, and in small courses, for instance seminars, they may in effect require attendance.The great irony is that the villain in the "secret camera" scandal is Prof. (Dean) Bol, who has put enormous personal commitment into MOOCs (China X).  He was pursuing the entirely contrary theory that "attendance at lectures increases student engagement with the course."  For me, having to go through the rain or snow at an inconvenient hour, scribble like crazy and then try to decipher the notes that I'd throw away after the exam--all that maximized resentment, not engagement.  "This is like high school."  Sections made it worse.  "He'll notice if you're not there."Bol is playing both sides of the street.  Maybe he wants to be President of Kalamazoo College.

Hi folksI remember being labelled an "emotional thinker" in my youth (in the context a girl friend that the critic thought was a poor choice) and being deeply shocked - it was intended to be (and I took it as) the most damning condemnation.Years later - in the role of management consultant - I remember deeply disappointing the chief executive who was my client by not supporting a decision of his that I was hired to study. Now it seems obvious to me that I was there to provide the post-decision rationalization that would help him sell his preferred actions to his organization. Back then, I thought I was hired to provide the dispassionate, objective, purely rational, fact-based analysis of the situation that my (traditional) Consulting Firm took pride in claiming to deliver. I thought my willingness to reach a conclusion that differed from my client was occupying the moral high ground.Descartes error - and my mistake - might be summed up in the assertion that "opinions are not facts".Heigh ho. "Wisdom is what you've got left when you've forgotten what you know" (Ioan Tenner).Kind regardsGeoffrey

While the Mencian/Humean model of morality as based on sentiments and gut reactions does seem to get a lot of empirical support, I think the great attractiveness of the utilitarian and deontological approaches is the claim that morality can be universal, i.e. the standard of rightness does not vary according to the particulars of the circumstances or actors.  If we must rely on our sentiments to establish morality, then isn't morality just a subjective feeling?  After all, we know that sentiments are not universal.  Then isn't morality just the social norm that happens to predominate in any particular place and time?Another concern is whether or not there can be any grounds for "rights" if morality is not universal.  If morality is a matter of social norms, then you will have a grave risk of a tyranny of the majority, against which individual rights would be no defense, since there is no universal moral foundation upon which individuals can claim their rights.

After the Examination system was stopped in 1911/12, the notion of universal thinkers was in effect removed, and as with the west we have moved on to specialist individualism.The Chinese Classics provides an exceptionally strong knowledge, and reasoning matrix, that in my view does not exist in the west, certainly not in mainstream education.The value in the well educated, skilled, universal thinker would be in effect that under the correct circumstances they would never be downsizing. ![enter image description here][1]  [1]: https://edxuploads.s3.amazonaws.com/14160387487562459.jpg

If we have this education, we "know" what to do in any situation.  If we fail to do, that is our test.  In my understanding, without spiritual education, working in perfect harmony with science, we will continue to be "evil" (selfish), by nature.

I think the bystander effect is also part of the inner-urban effect, and even (showing my political bias) the capitalist ideology which is infecting China as well these days. It surely wouldn't happen in the small town where I now live, because community is still more important to most people here than trying to be a winner in the commercial rat-race.
Our ability to exist in a large city is a result the attainment of WARM -  hot/cold negotiation.
column35: WARM - holds our ability to exhibist

column25: I really like this Levi-Struss quote N19. Thank you for sharing it.

As someone who absolutely knows that my rationalising comes after my emotional response, and who has been extremely influenced by Singer's beautifully expressed and argued points of reason - particularly in his book, *Rethinking Life and Death*, I wholeheartedly agree with Brock's point and with your response Professor. Thank you both.

I think this is where the concept of expanding circles comes in. It's not a case of feeling ***exactly*** the same degree of care for a stranger as one does for a sibling. Rather it's a case of expanding the circle of people for whom one feels care to ***include*** a stranger - not as equal to your sibling but as also worthy of care, particularly if one has it within one's power to act with care towards this person.
Thanks for this perspective Benc123.
Hi IainThank you for your comment.Unfortunately, I do not understand it. Please tell me more.Kind regardsGeoffrey
I think Warm Cognition with social interaction..

I think this is the right answer to the question by Dougma. Mencius does not say we only have 4 moral sprouts. The other organs do have their desires - animalistic tendencies. The heart mind suppresses them if the moral sprouts are nurtured.

Geoffrey, In my view the most powerful tool in the Chinese classical toolkit, to which Confucius shows us the way is Change Theory. Change Theory deals with the optimisation of cause and effect in human situations, and human interventions from a universal perspective. It works on the basis of metaphor.In modern society we have specialists in the main, not polymaths. Change Theory is central to the polymaths tool kit.Thus following the Classics, and fully understanding Change Theory, in theory one would optimise every given situation, which would give a geometric progression of good decisions, consolidation and leverage, where you or the organisation would grow steadily, and strongly with deep roots, and tall branches like a tree.We haven't been discussing Change Theory, but Confucius sends you there if you look. He sends people to the Classics.I suppose we don't discuss Change Theory because firstly not everyone gets it, and secondly those that get it, don't feel the need to tell everyone about it? I am not sure in this regard. Most likely because its an early summer, night situation. Or, eye square.I've made some posts related to it, especially the one on metaphor....You internalise the Classics and then, if you have do so correctly, you will have exceptionally powerful skills, especially management, but also perception.

Hi folksAgain, there are many parallels with today's management thinking. On Mencian Wu-Wei, the Prof says:> You've got to build up step by step. Once you get to the end result,> though, once you reach the stage where you've really perfected it,> Mencius thinks it then runs itself.> > So this is Mencian wu-wei. At the end, he says, once you've fully> cultivated the sprouts, he then switches to these other metaphors,> nature metaphors. He says it's like water flowing downhill. You can't> stop it. It's like wild beasts running into the open.> > One of his metaphors is once you really get this thing going, it's> like a wild beast spotting an opening, presumably one that's being> chased. It could just take off. And it takes off into the open spaces.> So it's your natural tendencies really being unleashed. It's like a> flood.This is a perfect description of the "complex adaptive systems" phenomenon of "emergence" ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emergence ). Examples include the self-organising behaviour of ant colonies, the stock market, cities, the human brain, open-source software and bureaucracies.If Chinese philosophers sought to effect change in long-established, highly-traditional organizations then no wonder they'd be interested in wu-wei/emergence.Wikipedia is possibly the most frequently cited example of emergence (Microsoft, remember, blew $100 million on developing a computer-based encyclopaedia Encarta and failed - while Wikipedia cost nothing). Thus, for a management example, Don Tapscott in his book "Macrowikinomics" advocates leveraging the phenomena of web sites like MedHelp and PatientsLikeMe to surmount the ghastly impasse of the US's dysfunctional Health Care System. http://www.huffingtonpost.com/don-tapscott/macrowikinomics-time-to-s_b_780540.htmlOld hat.Kind regardsGeoffrey

I'm an American living in Shanghai and a video of this kind of behavior goes viral every few months. Whenever I talk to my Chinese friends about it, they usually say that they want to help strangers, but they have been taught that they should not get involved because the person needing help may be attempting some kind of scam.  In these instances it seems like the sprout of compassion has been stunted rather than cultivated.I found this article on NPR about the most recent example. A foreigner on a subway in Shanghai fainted, and everyone around the guy tried to get as far from him as possible, evacuating the car at the next stop. [NPR: Why Did Crowd Flee Shanghai Subway After Foreigner Fainted?][1]Reading it just now, I had to laugh at the last line of the story. "As more young Chinese are exposed to the world, Yan expects them to continue to adopt a newer, more modern notion: empathy." I think Mencius would take exception to the characterization of empathy as being modern.   [1]: http://www.npr.org/blogs/parallels/2014/09/01/344033379/why-did-crowd-flee-shanghai-subway-after-foreigner-fainted
The relationship between disgust sensitivity and social responses was interesting. This TED talk reinforces that. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5YL3LT1ZvOM
Thanks davyddew for this very clear presentation of Karen Armstron's argument. I agree completely, as I outlined much more briefly in my post on Emergence in the 5.9. Discussion.

this may be a stretch, but I wonder if many people smoke to watch their breathÉ I am not a smoker, but when I watch others smoke, they seem to pause from their situation, just to watch the smoke and sometimes adjust their posture for the next intake.
LizConnor, you are very welcome. It is one of my favorite quotations ever.

I'm finding this very interesting if a lot to take on board; especially as I've almost finished Paul Bloom's 'Moralities of Everyday Life' MOOC, and he seems to end with a different conclusion.He argues, if I've got this correct, that empathy, disgust, etc. do come from the gut/heart.  Although different cultures have different moral codes, there are some universals, such as a ban on arbitrary assaults, protecting children.  But he thinks that we aren't, necessarily, naturally nice to strangers.  Whereas evolutionary psychology can explain kin selection and reciprocal altruism, it doesn't explain the extension of kindness to strangers.  To explain why we should do this, we may need to use reason.  So, to go back to Mozi, we don't 'naturally' feel like impartial caring; a consequentialist approach is needed.So, according to Bloom, sometimes empathy, for example, can lead us to an immoral act.  We will take action for one person who is close, or whose picture we see: and this may be at the expense of other people who are either more distant or who are anonymous as far as we are concerned.  Bloom therefore concludes that 'the existence of reason, of rational deliberation, makes moral progress possible.'See, for example:http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2013/05/20/the-baby-in-the-wellAt the moment, I'm just trying to keep an open mind!

I'd lean toward parallel development. If I remember rightly there are references to prana and pranayama (breath control) in some of the *Upanishads* that date to a pre-Buddhist period in India, for example, the *Chandogya Upanishad*. Likewise in the *Mahabharata* there are references that imply that breathing practices were well established at the time the *Bhagavad Gita* section was written.  (If you follow the chronology presented by Georg Feuerstein in *The Yoga Tradition* then he places the composition of the *Gita* between 500 and 400 BCE and the probable date that the Buddha's teachings were first systemised as 483 BCE).

On the nod to the Dalai Lama, if you have not, check out Chogyam Trungpa's book Shambhala: Sacred Path of the Warriors that presents skills for "us" as individuals - and then as a healthy collective, to steer without dictating religious doctrine, healthy(er) interaction of humanity without religious doctrine/jargon/lecturing negativity.  And while we see the chaos in the middle (b)east as unresolvable - the embarrassment of every single government in the not so warm/fuzzy religious laden area, it is our individual efforts going forward - elsewhere, out of politics ...unless there is a politician, official or ambassador logged in under a trendy blurb, our individual purpose(s) - where each of us reside, that we can look to enhance/poweri-up/provide-great-ways-to live together, your own community radius.  We, collectively, in class and outside of class - college class or trapped in a subdivided class system, that can present answers by explaining intellectual steps to create a way to get whats is needed for healthy existence.  Some may need a either a hand-out - food for example, or a hand-up, equal pay to be able to buy more food for a family. smarter path so those that need healthy steering can see - or hear, what may be helpful to them. Regarding the UN, they have a brutal uphill battle. The G8, G9..G20..22..24 (etc), they can talk all they want and structure programs but whether the masses  - aka -"The G147+ zillion human beings on the ground follow suit with environmental or human dignity/regard matters is a task for us locally to motivate others to talk about, get on board and be generally positive about what needs to happen. Its very easy for people to discount the UN's efforts due frustration, I occasionally take a look at the UN website to see what the particular sub-divisons are up to and the simulcast of meetings.  Emma Watson got a lot of flack for speaking up about men getting on board about women's issues. There are incredibly great men around but there are slackers when it comes to equality. I will use me as an example. I am discriminated at work and making far less than I should (have a degree in the field I will no longer work in shortly, I hope).  I have had far more than 2 attempts at rape. But in 1989, a male boss said this "I am giving you a 12" raise to catch up to the boys." Now, in 2014, i am being shortchanged again because years later - at a new company, I am low-balled (again) in a 'male-dominanted' industry because not much has changed there. (I am leaving the industry shortly, cutting my losses. And so, do they win by having me leave or do I win by getting better pay in another industry? Not a win-win, a loose-loose really.) Men can help women get raises when they are low, often men are often is a position to make that call.  Men and young men - to be proactive, totally deserve to not end up in jail for violence or anything else for that matter. In the HeforShe campaign the UN is look for a billion signatures of commitment for non-violence with respect to women - and men and youth, of course. Its an effort, not an easy one but what is the answer to the violent world. Its us = men and women, that can work more close, equally and humanly on local and world issues.A non-violent world would truly would be great. We can all use that. We are the answer.  The educational platform put forth here, on-line (Edx....)  puts us all on a better platform to achieve it. Pow-wow proactively and the pessimists can choke on their typical failure to enact positive change.Well, that was far more than I intended to write but my laundry doesn't mind mind the wait.

I do not understand that Levi-Strauss quote. Would someone please explain or paraphrase it for me.What is "develop...all at once"? Does that mean "evolve simultaneously" or does it  mean "understand and deduce a theory with one burst of insight"?What is a "sector"?  Is that a portion of humanity, a particular society, or is that a portion of human mental abilities?Thank you

So, thinking of those in prison, for example, we may have more sympathy for those from a very deprived background: less for those from a more privileged one.(It seems that Mencius would have regarded a robber as a human - either one whom the world has treated harshly, or one who has not nurtured his moral sprouts.)

These appear to be parallel developments, since we don't have any evidence of direct contact between India and China until around the beginning of the Common Era. The breathing practices in East Asian Buddhism probably stem from whatever they were doing in early China.
Thanks.

I think the notion of the Gentleman adept in the classics and practising the values and morals in broad terms setout therein would have in Chinese terms universal morality.That is because the Chinese Classics provides universal schematics to human life and human intervention.The proof of their effectiveness in society and culture was the Examination System.In my view it is impossible to understand the thinking of ancient Chinese without understanding The Changes which by many consider it to be the most influential book in world history, which in my view it is.If you have never seen or heard of tennis, its unlikely you can learn it from a book. If you have no knowledge of The Changes you know almost nothing of ancient Chinese thinking, save for a few western labels and categories.The universal schematic is in the Changes. That is why The Gentleman sends you there. Without the Changes you do not understand Chinese art or literature. Without the Changes you:Do not have the wind in your ears.Your thinking is in the northwest and southeast.You are a cloud on a mountain.You are like the eldest daughter and her father; you think you know what is right.Fire and earth, the Gentleman does not feed you with a spoon.To get to sea in early autumn, one must go to dragon mountain; take the horse east, by sea and wind.When you get to West Marsh, circle your ear, where noon is a circle.For those that fail to understand they will always have strong thighs.Here is some direct guidance from The Master:ÒReal knowledge is to know the extent of oneÕs ignorance.ÓÒThe Superior Man is aware of Righteousness, the inferior man is aware of advantage.Ó ÒHe who learns but does not think, is lost. He who thinks but does not learn is in great danger.ÓÒHe that would perfect his work must first sharpen his tools.ÓThere was a reason that Confucius pointed the way to the Classics. The world from there is divided into those who go and who do not. Then from those who go, who understand and who do not. Confucius then only worked with those who understood. Gently illuminating.The mother of clarity.Thus if you do not know, or understand such, consider by allegorical comparison, that the only computer system you know or have ever heard of is Microsoft Word. You can type and write essays, letters and so on. Learning the classics in the manner Confucius prescribes leads to an ah-ha moment, when you realise that Microsoft Excel is embedded as well. It's all in the metaphors. The metaphors make up a key word algebra.If you are not conducting yourself within the universal moral schematic you are in intellectual Chinese terms a barbarian. Good behaviour is an educated choice. Bad behaviour is either a lack of education, or a lack of moral fibre. [Remembering that universal morality does not mean something everyone does, it is something that people choose to do, which brings universal harmony].

Environment or community? I think you can be in a bad environment, get out of it, and flourish. However if you are in a "bad community" such as a despotic regime getting out of that is much harder. However to get out of a bad environment and flourish in a community, one needs support, acceptance and association with the community. If that is not granted, then life is difficult.
"How to treat strangers nicely is one of the biggest challenges in contemporary Chinese society . . . "More evidence that this is not a 'natural' tendency, unless the culture encourages it?
Thanks ... I have read Trumpa's book.
There is a solid article in the New York Times, Nov.14, by Austin Ramzy. He interviews one of the Master's descendants.

The "source" of free will appears to be the main point in question, additionally, in order to answer that query we must get nit-picky about the terms "free" and "will." I want to turn the order around and answer it with "will" first, next "free/freedom," and finally "source.""Will" is simultaneously expressed as a non-local/universal quality or fundamental element of dynamic existence; without "will" no creation on any level nor sustenance of any created thing or event exists. Simultaneously, "will" is expressed in the finite or local sense through "intention." So, we do not have, possess or own "will;" however, as finite human beings we are certainly an aspect of the universe (simultaneously infinite), and subject to universal will. We misinterpret our unique ability to impart form to dynamic willful energy through "intention" as being the whole of "free will." Our intention to search for form in that which appears formless and impart and sustain dynamic creation is natural to the human condition. Living as finite creatures, what we have is an aspect quality of the greater whole. Intending to practice our living as finite or infinite or both is completely determined by universal "will" which simultaneously creates through outer and inner environment."Free" as regards "will" is free of good or evil. Good and evil are benchmarks we create in order to impart form to existence as we perceive it. Further, "will" as non-moral power survives within a homeostatic universe; it is only free within limitations that provide for the sustenance of existence: thus, we or the ego feels the "will to survive." So, "will" does not occur in a vacuum of absolute freedom while it must work as an aspect of infinite existence.The "heart" of the matter, what is the heart of "will," is arguable into infinity because like all qualities, elements and events that may appear finite, the "source" of "will" is infinite. "Do we have free will and what is its source?" can be further explored in the koan, "What is the sound of one hand clapping?" or an Eastern philosophical statement, "A mountain is not a mountain, then again, that is exactly what it is." As the query suggests, this was covered in Mencius' Ox Mountain that was simultaneously not just a mountain alone, but also part of a larger community or whole which was also part of an even larger whole.
I'd say you expressed it very coherently, LisConnor.  I found your analogy between modern complex society and the introduction of monocultural agriculture especially illuminating--thank you!

Interesting news item on British news program Newsnight this evening.A study by Dr Molly Crockett et al at UCL shows people would rather inflict more pain on themselves (via electric shock) than on strangers for money. Showing people seem to be altruistic when asked to inflict pain on others. We seem to naturally care more for others than ourselves in this context? Support for the sprout of empathy/ compassion/ benevolence? Interesting in light of what we have been covering on the course so far.No link to the TV show up yet, but this link below summarizes ithttp://medicalxpress.com/news/2014-11-people-profit.html
column35: New electric shock study supports Mencius?

column25: My understanding is that we all are born with free will (not different levels of free will per se, but simply free will) - we all have the power to CHOOSE.  I don't believe the different levels of capacities handicap our free will.  We all are responsible for our actions, whether they are good or bad, regardless of big or small capacities.  Everyone is held accountable for their actions - which, as I understand it, will be known in the next world.  According to Baha'u'llah, the latest in the line of Divine Teachers, speaking about what we can expect once we die and particularly the one with "psychopath" behavior:  ÒThe souls of the infidels [those not following the Way], however, shall Ñ and to this I bear witness Ñ when breathing their last be made aware of the good things that have escaped them, and shall bemoan their plight, and shall humble themselves before God. They shall continue doing so after the separation of their souls from their bodies.Ó Here is one writing about those who sincerely strive to purify their hearts and actions will experience at the moment of death:  ÒBlessed is the soul which, at the hour of its separation from the body, is sanctified from the vain imaginings of the peoples of the world. Such a soul liveth and moveth in accordance with the Will of its Creator, and entereth the all-highest Paradise. The Maids of Heaven, inmates of the loftiest mansions, will circle around it, and the Prophets of God and His chosen ones will seek its companionship. With them that soul will freely converse, and will recount unto them that which it hath been made to endure in the path of God, the Lord of all worlds.ÓAt the same time, those who sincerely strive to walk the Way should not judge those who are committing harmful acts because we don't know know what our own end will be:  ÒHe should forgive the sinful, and never despise his low estate, for none knoweth what his own end shall be. How often hath a sinner attained, at the hour of death, to the essence of faith, and, quaffing the immortal draught, hath taken his flight unto the Concourse on high! And how often hath a devout believer at the hour of his soulÕs ascension, been so changed as to fall into the nethermost fire!Ó  This really is serious - keeps us ever-so conscious.I understand that every single one of us will, in the end, be held responsible for our actions, whether we were conscious in this life of our behavior or not.  The aim in this life...is to become conscious.  If at the end of our life we have nothing but "poor" behavior - bad, harmful, terrible actions...then it's clear that we missed the boat - missed the true purpose of life, and that is a sad thing.  Yet, that is what it is.  Do we want people to miss the boat?  No.  There is really more to this question, much more.  It is a subject to study in itself.  This is a beginning of why we should, we must - pay attention to the many intuitions and signs and messages that we receive on a daily basis...to choose which way to go, to do the right thing in any given situation.  If we sincerely seek to know the right way, we will be guided to it.  Day after day, year after year - we are given infinite number of "assistance" to see and choose the right way or wrong way.  So many people ignore the plethora of instances of truth; or, the intuition, the heart has become so deadened in their heart...they are totally and absolutely lost.  They need help to see.  But wee are not responsible for whether they awaken and see.  We all need help to see. That is why we should be of service to each other - to care for each other, even those who appear very lost.   This is my limited understanding.

Human rights and justice are legal concepts. There is nothing spiritual about laws. Laws are quite often biased towards certain groups of society, such as for example most Banking Acts. We can make the notions of what is right and wrong a spiritual matter, and that is what happened in the past. Mankind created myths to explain the chaos around him, and these became religions. However there is no universal system that solves the world. The universal system explained in the classics in a manual for personal, family or community actions, conduct and intervention to help in a universal manner deal with life. That however only works effectively if large enough numbers are participating in the same value sets and schematic.There still remain and always will, the forces of darkness, and the forces of light. Where light tries to conquer dark, and vice versa.In practical reality a whole unified, global humanity, all co-operating together doing what is fair and right, has never happened in history. However for long periods of history China was the largest and most powerful country, and it held together well, in my view, due in part to Confucian values and standards.Thus learning Confucian values and standards is an excellent reflective tool for comparative analysis in life. But, like all things it has its own limitations.

Let's say that the king replied to Mengzi: "You are a clever man in making me aware of the compassion that I felt for the ox, and of the compassion-sprouts in my heart-mind.  But to tell you the truth, Mengzi, I also enjoy meting out cruel punishments to those who challenge me, and to those who I think might challenge me, and those who do not bow low enough in my presence . . . to mention just a few. That's how the great kings before me ruled so successfully.  So enough of this talk about growing sprouts and extending feelings . . . Now I suggest that you repeatedly bow very low on your way out the door."I personally believe that compassion and cruelty coexist in human nature, starting at a very young age. How would Mengzi respond? Would he not have to resort, e.g., to abstract arguments for justice, or utilitarian arguments about the most effective ways of leading a state?
Beautiful, and very relevant example, thanks for that. I vaguely remember that passage from my undergrad days.
Zhuangzi is going to make precisely this argument in Module 6.

Confucian values indeed are admirable, commendable, and useful.  Human rights and justice may be legal concepts, however consider, itÕs spiritual qualities, virtues, that underpin their successful application and implementation - compassion, love, forgiveness, truthfulness, etc., and these qualities can be taught and cultivated along with an attitude of learning, skills to research oneÕs own community needs to create and implement appropriate responses, and many other skills regardless of cultural context.

I've noticed the attribution of 'free will' to bad/unethical behavior is being supplanted by the neurobiology of sociopathy - http://www.medical-hypotheses.com/article/S0306-9877(06)00104-6/abstract -- It seems to me that without understanding the internal, neuro-architechture and physiology against behavior, we are always blaming the 'executive function', the frontal cortex, when in fact, there are are brain anomalies which do not permit the person to feel sympathy or compassion, or at least to create the ground for sociopathic behavior which can be made worse by substance abuse, etc.
I agree too.  Such a great topic - door after door after door opens.

I had written a rather long reply Geoffrey, but then I made the mistake I generally do and detoured to check out your link re 'emergence' from MIT's Centre for Collective Intelligence - and my reply promptly disappeared! Anyway the key I've discovered from various heart-breaking incidents in my longish life is what I referred to above: regarding the stranger as ***worthy of the kind of care that you have within your [emotional and economic] power to give***.An example of course is following Peter Singer's example of tithing by donating to selected NGOs - which I can easily do without risking the hardening of my heart.BTW Thanks very much for the various links that you've contributed to assist the emergence of a collective intelligence.

Shastagirl--Your background sounds as though it is in Western science. My background is in Eastern philosophy. We both seem to have an interest in therapeutic method. May I restate your above argument and see if I have correctly understood you? I want to say that I don't feel physiology or environment may supplant one another. Both make demands of one another and  create changes in one another; perceived or direct--for sociopathy and finite personality it is all real. Example: In the master/slave model, one may be born genetically predisposed to clinical depression; however, depending on one's formative environment it is possible to become either the master of or slave to predisposition. If we seek a cure using the same "parts" model that we utilize for study, will we affect a cure?I think that Mencius would argue against a separation of physiology (neuro-architecture)and environment. I see Ox Mountain as an argument for wholistic vision, and that this vision individually is the most favorable way to bring about collective change to the community issue of the Waring States.

I am from San Jose, California, U.S.A.  I am a licensed acupuncturist and primary care provider in Campbell, California. I was initially drawn to Chinese medicine through Chinese thought and philosophy, particularly the Tao Te Ching and the I Ching.  I continue to enjoy the study of Classical Chinese medicine, Chinese philosophy, modern philosophy looking at Chinese philosophy, ontology, and philosophy of mind.  This class was recommended to me by a fellow scholar and so I thought I would spend a little time here to enjoy the discussion, the reading material and the re-stimulation of this subject for myself. Thank you for organizing the materials and making it available to all.  I am very appreciative and honored to study with you all.

As humans evolved to live in extended families and small tribes, so our behaviour developed to include kin selection and altruism, i.e. forms of  what we would view as morality.  I think.  So I suppose you might say that the 'end' of morality is to ensure that we can behave in such a way as to ensure co-existence (although in evolutionary terms it would be to aid the survival of our genes).  What I wonder is where the further development of ethics came from, if it wasn't necessary for survival.  Presumably this was part of cultural evolution, and helps to explain why, although there are some moral universals, there is also a lot of variation across cultures in some aspects of morality.  As to the 'ultimate salvation', I don't know, but I've noticed that although the Chinese philosophers we've studied so far all seem to refer to 'heaven's will', the focus seems to be very much on improving life in the here and now. I'm not sure why only consequentialists would want a more peaceful society. I like these lines from the *Daodejing*:'Peace and quiet are the highest ideals; A military victory is not a thing of beauty. To beautify victory is to delight in the slaughter of human beings. 	. . .  	Military victory is associated with the rites of mourning.' (Chapter 31)

Thank you and I'll wait for your response. To be honest, I did a risky move by submitting so close to the cutoff. I was doing some last-minute edits right on the message box since I had a few minutes to spare. It was a grave mistake on my part. I understand completely though if I can't submit my essay anymore.

It would be great if you posted a survey where we could choose which of the wise men's advice we decided to follow. From reading answers for assessment, it was interesting to notice that not all of us chose the same, so I was wondering what would be the percentage for each.

Balance:  I look at Mozi - and Peter Singer, and see what our physical/material input can indeed make happen. However, the act of providing what is needed to actually make that happen will need actually ooze from those with partial or impartial care. As we learn philosophy, no sage is absolute perfection yet the good can guide us to actualize our potential to make good happen; I will call it global health. Job wise, I am shifting gears, perhaps I can be one of the grade 2 workers somewhere I an help the world spin better...unless my skills transfer to a grade 1 worker, in which case I could donate more material goods.....hehehe. There are Western philosophers, like Kant, or so wikipedia tells me, that say that humans aren't able to come to any certainty about reality because of the nature of their limited perceptions. He as opposed to Zhuangzi, seems pretty sure of himself. Still though, I imagine Zhuangzi as a pretty confident fella; a hilarious, playful, and easy going kinda guy. But who knows?I would (and am doing so) say that theme of "not being sure" is pretty strong in the inner chapters of the Zhuangzi. Asserting with certainty that time (or whatever aspect of reality) has any absolute quality, some metaphysical or cosmogoginal(is that a word?) a priori philosophical truth statement to it, would seem to be way out of character. And, that he's using logic (beginning of beginning blablabla) in this part, to explain his point that the fact that logic is a faulty arbiter of truth/reality only more stubbornly re-affrims his 'non-position' of 'not-so-sure-d-ness.' That's my take, but I'm not sure if I'm right about it or not. haha. ;)

I saw everything. I was happy. And sad at times, but generally happy. Hopeful. I saw in the wet fallen leaves and the faint smell of the maple in Autumn a world full of beauty and joy. I continued to learn and go through the roller-coaster of education and life, picking up tools to chop up the world. The world divided was better, bite-sized. Chopping and chipping and grinding to a fine powder. Eventually after a good amount of time I saw very little, or so I think now, a world of dust. Choking on dust, wasn't this the goal? I knew everything about the world and it was bad, no I must have taken a wrong turn. How is being right completely wrong? How can I continue to fulfill my responsibilities living in among and from dust? The Autumn breeze brings a glimmer of hope and an awkwardly placed, sophomoric poem comes to an end. Thank goodness, right?

But is it possible to have 'a direct perception of reality'?  An altered mental state may mean that we 'see' things differently, and maybe our mind 'seems' freer, but is this altered perception 'reality' or rather an *illusion* that we're 'seeing reality as it really is'?  Surely we're still bound by the limitations of the neurobiology of our brains?

I guess a fairly strong critique of Mengzian internalism could be launched by looking at Hannah Arendt's analysis of the Eichmann trials and the concept of the "banality of evil". All the Nazi officers involved in the trials for crimes against humanity did not display any "evil" internal intentions, on the contrary they all had the correct "internal" dispositions in terms of patriotism, bureaucratic efficiency and personally were friends with Jews. Rather, it was their complete lack of cold-cognition, "rational" analysis of what they were doing that led to the terrible tragedies of the Holocaust. If people naturally have moral sprouts and following our own internal intuition is the primary way to goodness rather than rational reflection it would seem that's exactly what the majority of the German population did during the Second World War. However, this clearly lead them down a disastrous path in terms of moral consequences no matter what their intentions were.

I've been wondering myself whether there are any early Chinese thinkers who are atheists, but I'm not sure that Zhuangzi is one.  If he were, would he keep talking about Heaven? Professor Slingerland said in lecture 6.7 that 'the Zhuangzian sage is this perfected person that's supposed to get drunk on heaven.  And throughout the Zhuangzi you see this kind of connection between the spirit, and heaven, and release.  You have this thing that's endowed in you, this Heavenly force, and you need to surrender to it and if you can do that, you'll be in a state of wu wei.'  If you were an atheist, wouldn't you refer to human states of being, such as 'flow' (to use a modern term); not a Heavenly force?  I suppose it depends on your understanding of  'heaven', and according to the textbook, tian 'is more like the impersonal processes of nature in the writings of Zhuangzi and Xunxi . . .'  So in that case, perhaps you're right.(Professor Slingerland did refer back in lecture 4.5 to 'the disbelief of his [i.e. Mozi's] age' and a growing agnosticism amongst the elite, so there must be evidence for this.  However, when he refers to Confucius saying, 'Practice as if the spirits are present', I hadn't thought of this until the lecture as a sign of disbelief.  I think there are many people who say they believe in (the Christian) God, for example, but who don't necessarily have a direct experience of their deity.  And again, one could 'believe' in ghosts and spirits, without oneself having direct contact.  So at a religious service, such as a sacrifice to the ancestors, one might act 'as if the spirits are present' even without experiencing that presence; yet still believing.)

Qi is energy. Different forms animate the body and covey interactions between ourselves, others and the environment. Because it has yet to be measured with a piece of Òscientific apparatusÓ Qi does not exist although our vernacular and experience seem to belie its non existence. We describe our energy as being high or low and talk of being more comfortable in certain environments than in others. There are good vibrations and bad and we talk about certain people as lighting up or filling a room with their presence and having charisma. We don't deny having bonds or making connections with friends, family members, pets and loved ones.Fragments of pottery indicate that the Chinese have been interested in Qi for over 5000 years and oral tradition places the Daoists as being involved. While Laozi may be the first Daoists to go public and among the most famous, he was not the first.The primary apparatus used by the Daoists for their studies was their bodies and cognition which they investigated through meditation.  We like to demean meditators as contemplating their navels which may not be far from the truth in the case of Daoists.  The lower dantian, or hara in Japanese, is the location in the midst of the abdomen that controls the Qi that animates the physical body.  There are other Qis that animate emotions, thoughts and Òhigher" activities and still others that bridge the gap between ourselves, the environment and others.Knowledge of the body's energy flows is the basis of acupuncture and Daoists and others still play with Qi through activities such as meditation, qi gong and tai chi.  Unfortunately, as the authors discussed in this MOOC have pointed out, not everything can be easily taught via words.  Somethings have to be experienced, perhaps with a little help from  Wu-wei.
This is the best way (out of the three) to start for children. It's harder to go wrong. Laozi lead to inaction. Mozi lead to materialism.

Hi,I can recommend a few 'Daoist' texts for you. The biggest one is called the Huainanzi. It's an amazing text. It has a lot Lao-Zhuang thinking it, as well as provides a link between Daoism and Chinese Medicine. Chapters 1, 2 and 7 are wonderful. If you want to see how Daoist (as well as other Chinese Philosophies) thought developed I recommend reading the first 8 chapters of the Huangdi Neijing: Su Wen. The early chapters provide a very fascinating view of the human body as well as the world around them and how they viewed it. There is also another group of books called the Yellow Emperors Four Canons, which has a style of Daoism called Lao-Huang which is Daoism with a mix of Legalism. These books were lost and have only recently been rediscovered.Hope this helps,Michael

Hi folksOur doughty Prof's remarks in the Q&A of Module 6 put me in mind of a strange pathology from my bad, old, McKinsey management-consulting days that we use to call MNA/UHB (mind-numbing analysis, untouched by human brain), i.e. the tendency to start a study by gathering every scrap of data and regressing it every which way to gain some insight. Wiser colleagues would shake their heads and say "when you've reduced a problem to numbers, you've missed the point". Nevertheless, those relentlessly analytical, Cartesian thinkers amongst us (who worshipped blindly at the altars of "fact-based analysis", "say it in numbers" and "you get what you measure") would press on regardless (I remember once quantifying the temperature-elasticity of beer consumption!).And yet all that number grubbing did serve a very practical purpose of doing precisely what we disparaged, that is putting the (what we used to describe as) anal, left-brain to sleep so that the intuitive (right?) brain could actually make some sense of the situation. It worked wondrously well for our CEO clients - who usually had a background in accounting and finance - and loved to be stroked with "irrefutable" facts and "unassailable" logic.I bet if those Chinese sages had had computers they'd play the get-the-facts card, too!Kind regardsGeoffrey

The linking of the Freudian concepts of superego and id with  Xunzi's ideas about humans being able to transform their inner 'bad' nature with cold cognition to the point where it became innate, reminded me of the passages about sexual desire and relationships in Steven Pinker's 'How the Mind Works' which I looked at recently in the margins of the course. Pinker is a persuasive writer, and I'm sure that there is a genetic component to sexual relations (as there obviously is to sexual desire), but Pinker seemed to argue that the sexual strategies of our hunter/forager ancestors can be read through into contemporary life, and that this explains male promiscuity. I've often wondered how long the hunter/foragers can take the rap for how we are now, before we evolve away from them. Evolutionary biologists are apt to point out how slight a period of time settled agricultural societies have been with us compared to how long humans have been around, but I've always been sceptical about the strength of this argument. As I understand it Xunzi would argue that men, by consciously telling themselves that chaotic coveting of the neighbour's wife was not a good idea, could reach the point of not coveting. Xunzi a feminist icon?

Perhaps not a feminist but a realist. By persistently telling ourselves we don't 'want' something we can't have, we may finally come to abandon those desires. We come to terms with the futility of 'wanting' or desiring what is not available.
