What is interesting is communist societies suppress religions, so we have natural experiments on using the the socialist workers paradise as alternative evolutionary toolkit to religion+afterlife since 1917, until its demise in 1989.Still i'm interested to know any alternative evolution toolkit to religion, especially for the gentry, not for the elite who understand behavioral economics or game theory (i.e. infinite round of prisoner's dilemma will ultimately reach equilibrium which we call morality, etc..).http://pursuitofchinesehappiness.blogspot.com/2014/06/chinas-missing-models-imagine-that-you.html

Hi folksI am delighted to hear of the research of the Professor's colleagues and am reminded of the way the Dutch Reformed Church supported the Afrikaaner doctrine of Apartheid ( http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/despatches/africa/33032.stm ),an illustration of  how moral conflicts arise when social worlds collide ( http://www.amazon.com/Moral-Conflict-Social-Worlds-Collide/dp/0761900535 ).Thus, for example, the US must surely outgrow its sacred yet egregious notions like American Exceptionalism and Manifest Destiny to ever effectively broker peace in our multicultural world.Kind regardsGeoffrey

The questions concerning what exists, or can be said to exist, how notions can be grouped, or related, their similarities and differences, and precisely how we come to such conclusions, and so on, should concern us.To my limited knowledge and experience, it seems to me, that here, in this instance, we are imposing our own [western] ontology in and on this matter of Chinese Thought.What we are doing is reading our own ontology into Chinese thinking.Thus as westerners we are from a foundational perspective imposing essentially Greek source notions and concepts on the matter.The error being that Chinese Thought was not coming from a foundation of Greek notions and concepts. They had their own.The key to Chinese Thought surely is the methods and reasoning by which they came to their own foundations of thought - Chinese Ontology.Ancient Chinese Ontology it seems came from observation of nature, a highly developed understanding of cause and effect, logic, music, ritual, etc. Of which central to all of such was the understanding of cause and effect - *bagua*, for which there is written evidence such as oracle bone inscriptions, and stone engraving dating before 4000BCE, and thus long before our western Greek-style cognitive predecessors.    If around 1700BCE we sought an essay entitled "The Logical Structure of the World" based on current evidence, the best essay certainly would not be written by a Greek, and more likely [although there are other possibilities such as a Persian, or Babylonian] a Chinese, certainly based on evidence passed down.What is concerning is that by the time the Greek's got to writing, the use of the esoteric was common place with published intellectuals. Aristotle, being a likely case and point.Thus as westerners, perhaps we are restrained in a cognitive box, designed to restrain openness to the foundational concepts of understanding, by a group of people that arrived a few centuries late and more than a few dollars short. Such is the nature of our software, and the intentional esoteric aspects.Thus to apply our western labels must in itself produce a form of limitation on the true overall schematic and true nature of Chinese Thought.
column35: Error - Our Own Ontology Imposed on Chinese Thought

Xunzi believed that morality is purely cultivated, IF so, who is responsible for the morality of the dead thug, the looters and the arsonist.

Political parties in America seem engulfed in a name battle to define moral issues.  Are you pro-life, or are you pro-choice?  Do you want a smaller government?  Do you believe in equality?  Your answers to such questions will depend on the definitions of "life" and "choice" and "smaller" and "equality."  Is "equality" the right of each person to do as well as he can, alone and unaided, in the world as it exists?  Or does it mean an "equal playing field," with manipulations to the world as it exists, in order to achieve that playing field?  I think Xunzi would find American politics repellant not least because of its twisting and shifting of names.

A lot of the discussions in this course seem to revolve around elements that comprise elements of the ongoing nature versus nurture debate, and it doesn't seem like a lot of progress has been made in the past 2500 years (a short slice of time in the hominid time span). Nature is good and nurture leads one to become bad, or nature is bad and one has to work at (or be nurtured) to learn how to be good. Yet the only thing that ever seems to make sense is a middle road. This also seems to call up the metaphors of the authoritative versus nurturing parent and the attempt to promote one concept or the other as the ultimate good, but elements of both will always be immanent.

I enjoyed the most to learn about Han Feizi and the so called Legalists, especially because I want to know how today some of Xi Jinping's reprimands to this school of thought might be understood.**Clear Set of Rules for Everyone**While I can understand many people's wish for clear(er) rules to follow and everybody treated the same way in terms of law and punishment, I also see how difficult that is to achieve.A child that for the very first and probably last time went into a store to steel a single chocolate bar is definitely different from an adult who for the eleventh time robbed a bank brutally. A person that kills another because of greed or envy and hatred can not really be seen the same way as a person who just killed to defend him- or herself.But how to draw the line of right or wrong, without room for judgment, and define appropriate punishments in such a complex world?Who decides, and on which basis?Also Han Feizi states that rulers had to adapt to the times in which they live. Does that mean that laws and punishments had to change over time as well? Again, on which basis?**The Way of the Ruler**I feel reminded of the dystopian novel "1984" by George Orwell when reading about Han Feizi's guide for the ruler's survival and absolute power over his (probably also in Han Feizi's eyes, not her) subordinates. Not knowing if or when "Big Brother" is watching, and punishing you, for me seems to aim into a similar direction.On the other hand I think of Isaac Asimov's "Foundation" series and the "Psychohistorians" that need to prevent by all means that anybody besides the "Foundation" (the secret rulers) could understand the greater plan behind civilisation and its future development.What I learned is that the Legalists have to offer very fascinating thoughts and ideas, but also Ð from my personal perspective Ð potentially quite terrifying ones. Though I also got that it is most important to learn about them to get an idea of a Chinese understanding of the state of law. It is not the same as in Western countries, even if Chinese and e.g. German ministries and legal experts for many years now have worked and still work together in the so called "Dialogue on the State of Law".

Dear Professor Slingerland and China300x team,this MOOC was amazing, and I learned so much that now goes hand in hand well with the aspects that I read about before, experienced myself in China and with Chinese people in my private as well as professional life, and learned so far in Harvard's ChinaX series (also via edX.org).Thanks a lot for that wonderful opportunity, and I hope for more inspiring courses with you to come. Also I will definitely read more about the introduced schools of thought.Best regards,Nico Marzian

Han Feizi's notion that a law should be so clear that there is no need for subjective judgment in its application is a compelling ideal. However, the reality is that laws sometimes contradict each other, and consistency is not universally achievable. What if following the law leads to the production of chaos or a reduction of power? Wouldn't Han Feizi still recognize a proper place for executive discretion and judgment in implementing the laws?
I'm an atheist and I write checks to charities.

If he were administering a state, he would have to.  Virtually every culture, for instances, recognizes that people with very limited mental ability cannot be expected to behave as ordinary people do or to understand the consequences of their actions, and therefore we might say they're above the law.  Also, in cases where it's not possible to draw an exact line, interpretation is necessary.  Does life begin at conception or at birth?  There is no consensus on that issue, and yet we must make decisions based on some line of demarcation.  I wonder if Han Feizi would feel these cases were clearcut, or whether he would propose some mechanism for deciding when a certain law should be applied and when not.  For instance, if you kill a pregnant woman you can be charged with two murders, depending on whether the child would have survived outside the womb; If the child couldn't survive--i.e. in the first or second trimester, roughly--then it's not murder.  But an abortion before the child is viable is considered by many to be a murder.  How would Han Feizi treat this issue?

as professor mentioned - after Qin emperor united China, he killed all schools of philosophers and burned all the books. Qin's terror lasted 12 years, and was replaced by Han dynasty, and Han dynasty cnotinue the same ban, except making Confucianism the state sponsored philosophy. Subsequent dynasties continue this policy, by making Confucianism and only subject for the state sponsored high stake exam for selecting officials... So the lack of new philosophies (or extinction of old ones like Mozi) was a result of the authoritarian state. Look at today's China it's not hard to understand - the only  *ism CCP tries to bring back is, surprise, Confucianism. They also try to promote it globally.

Hi Daniel/LoraleeIf you buy my thesis that wu-wei is what Complexity Scientists call Emergence, then there most certainly is a group wu-wei.That is, complex adaptive systems develop a life of their own based on simple rules in just the same way that flocks of birds migrate in a V-formation.This is what makes bureaucracies so hard to reform: they gain meaning and purpose from resisting initiatives to change them. My management consulting colleagues and I once (only partially jokingly) dubbed this "the 7-Ds of bureaucratic resistance to change": deflect, diffuse, discredit, delay, deny, discourage and dissemble.Having - for my sins - once spent a whole year on an Overhead Cost reduction programme for Royal Dutch Shell in their Head Offices in London and the Hague, I can testify from first-hand experience that the teachings of Han Feizi are well understood and practiced by the Mandarins of Corporate Bureaucracy to this day (or rather, they were back in the early 1980s).Kind regardsGeoffrey

I agree

I also think about the nature of complex systems -- there are both gradual, iterative changes AND moments of sudden bifurcation. And these can be hard to separate purely by observation -- like a sail boat tipping over: it's heeling further and further, gradually moving toward the water, but at a certain moment, it has gone "too far" and touched down on the water surface. It will look gradual, but there is a qualitative difference in the motion of each. Or my own experience of learning to parallel park many years ago(!). I practiced and practiced and practiced ...gradual improvements...until there was an aha moment where it all came together. I don't see the need for an either~or in the gradual~sudden distinctions.

This is the most gratifying MOOC I've ever taken--out of about 20, ranging from Molecular Biology to Algorithms to The Civil War--not to mention MIT Philosophy.The endeavor to connect the ancient philosophers to modern psychological findings is worthwhile. Rightly so.The captious criticisms are trivial and unworthy.

Someone mentioned Confucianism is good for starting out for children..I agree with that..some of the traditions and rituals we may have in our society may look meanging less in our age. But if we can look deeply some of them (not all of them mind you) may have development of certain virtues that is at the root of it. I will give a small example. In my culture, we  were taught that if we stepped on anything with letters (books, paper etc) we should touch the object and then put our hand to our head..a kind of ritually saying sorry and showing respect for that object with letters. When you grow up you know that the book is inanimate and that it wont get hurt if you step on it! But what you are taught to internalize is a respect for letters and learning..Of course you can argue that we can do this even without rituals..and we probably can. But doing these things as a child probabaly trains out hot cognition and this becomes automatic..easier than doing it with reason..I think this course helped me understand many things in my culture. However blindly following culture would be probabaly a bad thing too. So I am not sure I would like Confucius to the exclusion of all others.

column25: I love the *Zhuangzi*, but also find him the most "WEIRD" and thus easy for this American to love. Hello Professor Slingerland So many thanks for a wonderful course. I started somewhat late and then having missed module one to three, did not even notice that the relevant extracts from your book and the main reference, Readings in Classical Chinese Philosophy, are very much in the material. Having bought both the books , I hurried with the objective of eventually making up in the remaining modules and passing. This battle come down to getting at least 28 out of 30 questions right in the final exam. And that nail biting finish eventually went against me. I got only 25 of the questions right. I have discovered that the course material is on U tube too. and that is wonderful. I have immersed myself in the course and am studying both books intensely. Surprisingly, it does appear to me that there may have been much co evolution in the Hindu Faith and Chinese. I imagine that they may have been at the same level of sophistication for Buddhism to evolve in India and then to travel to China. Again the Ramayana , the way it stresses Filial piety appears to be pure Confusion thought. The Mahabharata appears to be somehow introducing a new concept of Rightness and builds on a confrontation within a large family. Somehow stressing " Rightness " comes before the affection for Uncles and cousins. So I will be studying your material for a while. And be the expert who corrects people that Chinese thought is not a monolith and Confucious. Laozi and so on are saying very different things. Thank you so very much ASHOK

One (big) reason why I took this course was to try to get atypical insights (I'm Brazilian) to be a better father to my daughter and a better husband to my wife.In this sense, I particularly found Confucianism to be value-destroying. In this sense, I believe that where I got more value from - especially to pass on to my daughter - was from Mencius AND Zhuangzi. I want to reach out to her moral sprouts and grow them, but also that she doesn't have to be of this world while she is in it. There is absolutely no problem if she becomes a weed or a garden flower, because I take values to be relative. This may sound confusing, but then again, I became increasingly suspicious of words and their ability to describe things... Is there any one who has forgotten words so I can talk with?

The definition of religion that was given in the lecture was interesting because claims of things that exist which are intangible and which provide us with morals and ethics on how to live a "good" life which when adhered to brings about some sort of salvation also includes something so anti-religious (or so I thought) as Marxism! And yet yes Marxism talks about existence of a social order and ways of thinking which if followed is supposed to bring about the salvation of a more equal society! So theism would be a subset of this definition of religion. In Indian philosophy we have atheistic tradition of Charvaka which spins off later into Jainism and Buddhism etc The fact that they later became theistic is another matter.However I dont understand how philosophy too is a subset of religion as shown by the Venn diagram in the lecture. How exactly is philosophy defined then?

I signed up for this course because of Professor Slingerland's assertion that the world's first hippies are from ancient China ... I can't wait to find out more !! ;-DAs for my own background, I'm a "banana" ... born on U.S. soil into a horrifying reign of academic terror, governed by my Taiwanese-immigrant parents.  Luckily for me, I avoided capital punishment in the family home when I was admitted to do my undergrad studies at UC Berkeley, where I sorta got caught up in "things hippie."  By many accounts, the '60s didn't end at Berkeley until sometime in the '90s ... I am thrilled to have been a part of that. ;-DIn 1995, I signed a 2-year volunteer contract with VIA ("Volunteers in Asia" - an NGO based at Stanford University) to teach English in Qingdao, Shandong (PRC).  I was keen to leave the "rich" world and wanted to learn to speak Mandarin (something that my parents never taught us kids).  To the great chagrin of my mother (my father had passed away while I was in my 3rd year at Cal), I had no interest in going to Taiwan because there was too much money there by then.  I was looking for a different experience.So if I fast-forward 20-ish years to 2014, let's just say that I married a Swiss dude who I'd met in China.  And so I now live w/ the hubby in French-speaking Switzerland, where I have given birth to 3 kiddos whose DNA are 50% Chinese !!  E-gads !!Having taken my French language skills and fake "Swissness" as far as I care to take them, I'm ready to get back to "things Chinese" ... therefore picking things up where I left them when I was in my 20s.  My kids deserve to know something about their Chinese heritage before it gets diluted any further ... and I'm up for dishing that info out to them to the best of my ability !!"Xie xie" to all the folks who are involved in the creation of this course !! :-D

On another religious studies type course students were told that religion was 'a meaning-giving system', which humans need in order to give purpose to their lives and to make it appear that the world is not chaotic. It seemed, however, that religion was an admittedly very large subset of these 'meaning-giving systems'. On that understanding, an atheistic philosophy would be a meaning-giving system without being a religion.However, as Dr. Slingerland says, there's no agreed definition of religion, so for this course, all meaning-giving systems would be counted as religions, I suppose. It seems reasonable that in general humans do need such systems. Is this what he means when he states that committing to some kind of soteriological strategy is 'a basic feature of human cognition'?  I would like to know more!

Hi, my name is He Bin, I was originally from China and now living in U.S. doing software for a living. My favorite period of Chinese history is the Spring-and-Autumn Period when philosophies flourished. In recent centuries, China was not doing well, and Chinese culture has been under total assault, not only from contemporary intellectuals, but also from authoritarian regimes. If you live in China today, you would feel there is nothing left of any ancient wisdom and tolerance.I am taking this class as part of personal fulfillment, and trying to find out if there is an answer other than acceptance of today's status of fairs.
column35: In search of a culture renaissance

column25: I'm curious about the role collectivism played on the development of the ancestors concept and that they aren't actually gone; the lack of life and death distinction. It seems the wester/christian idea of the afterlife is really leaning towards the individual's experience. Does the idea of heaven seem to benefit the individual rather than the collective society? I had the pleasure of teaching in China for just a year, and one very interesting thing I found was that they had never heard of the so called "light at the end of the tunnel." That when you die, there's no supreme being waiting for you at the end of a tunnel of white light. Despite a family member of mine having a near death experience and describing the light very adamantly. I believe she had that experience, but to me the fact that the Chinese society had not even heard of the "white light" was proof to me that this concept of an afterlife and how we enter it is very much influenced by the religion or beliefs of the individual. Now I'm curious if near death experiences in China have some sort of ancestral equivalent. Not trying to get anyone riled up here or necessarily have a religious discussion, as I am certainly no authority on that. I'm merely fascinated by the connection the collective society has with their dead.

This is a really interesting topic for discussion! Thanks for bringing it up. The definition we're adopting for the course does indeed encompass some things that we aren't used to thinking of as "religion." Marxism, sports, liberalism, vegetarianism...the list could go on and on. Just a refresher on our working definition: religion involves ontological or metaphysical claims that provide normative guidance and a soteriological strategy. According to Charles Taylor, these claims or systems need not involve gods.Philosophy and religion are for our purposes being considered the same thing because their distinction is largely a product of 18th century French Enlightenment thought. In response to zoeSA's post >> There could be three or four scholarly perspectives on the possible origins of religion (these do not include theological theories). First, there are sociological approaches (Durkheim, Rappaport) Ñ religion reflects social needs and produces societies by enabling cooperation. Second are the existential/motivational approaches (Marx, Freud) Ñ religion reflects our fears and helps us manage terror and uncertainty better than other ways of thinking. Third are the cognitive byproduct theories (Hume and many contemporary cognitive scientists) Ñ religion is a side-effect of several features of our evolved cognitive abilities, such as theory of mind, our ability to detect agency, and our tendency to anthopomorphize the world around us. Fourth is the cultural evolutionary synthesis (Norenzayan), which draws from the other three perspectives and seeks to understand how religious ideas spread and change in populations through cultural transmission.Keep in mind that each approach has its own philosophical assumptions and implications.If you are interested in this issue, check out Lecture 2, entitled "Circumscription of the Topic," in William James's classic book *The Varieties of Religious Experience* (available for free online). What do other people think of the problem of defining religion? Isn't religious studies fascinating?  :)

It is really interesting! In my very personal opinion, (actually, experience, because I have never studied philosophy or theological studies, I am just a curious person that reads a lot!) I have always distinguished religion from philosophy by the question: Do they pray? And with "pray" I mean, "ask" "someone" something, as if believing that your wishes may come true depending on someone else«s will (a God, for example. or as in Latinamerica, people pray to the pachamama or mother earth). Any other framework that only gives normative guidance but without claiming the existence of a metaphysical world, I would just call it a doctrine or "way of life", as with veganism or any ism. However, I believe that any person could create their own "religion" by just strictly or blindly following any set of rules "religiously", believing that this set of rules are the truth and any belief contrary to this normative is completely wrong. I don«t know if I«m making myself understood! : )

It's caused me to identify my Western bias as well.I've been taking ChinaX here at EdX, and learning some of the history and basis of Chinese philosophy has given me a much greater understanding of modern China. Things that I puzzled about suddenly made sense. I'm hoping this course will continue that.

To be honest, I disagree with the lecturer's definition of religion as a "framework of claims" to "guide you in your life". This is because this appears to be a common description for both religion and philosophy.A good definition should be one that help you to make distinction between two different things in the same class. That is why you cannot define an elephant as "a large animal with four legs". (Because it doesn't allow you to distinguish it with cows, horses etc). Rather, you describe it as "a large animal with a long nose". Although we may never arrive at a perfect definition, but it should at least be clear enough to help an average person to make the distinction.In this respect, I would argue that religion should be distinguish from philosophy according to the way that it is used and organised (places of worship, rituals etc). Therefore, in Chinese, there is a subtle distinction  between tao jiao (tao religion) and tao jia (tao philosophy).

My name is Liz and I'm a retired humanities teacher, particularly interested in how language shapes thought and vice versa. I did a year-long Adult Education course on Mandarin Chinese in the 1970s, but all I really remember from it is that we learnt that the Mandarin word for China, [zhungguo], translates as 'the middle kingdom'. Now I find that in wikipedia the translation given is 'the central country', which is much less intriguing. Well, it's not strictly true that this is the only thing I remember. The most significant thing I remember is the understanding that semantic tonality was beyond me. And that was enough to put me off trying to learn the language any further.But I'm still fascinated about the developments in Chinese culture over the centuries / millennia, especially since China has been comparatively isolated from European-based cultures for much of that time. And also of course because it seems to be well on the way to overtaking the US mainstream culture as the one dominating the world.

Hi Everyone,I'm Cherie.  I live in Colorado.  Taking the course because I've always had an interest in Eastern Philosophy and similar topics.

The early Chinese conception of xin ("heart-mind") is complicated, it clearly is the locus of what we'd call both "hot" and "cold" cognition, especially in the earliest periods of Chinese thought, but as we'll see, by the end of the Warring States it's become increasingly "cold", although still the source of some "hot" (or luke-warm) moral emotions. The "two systems" are useful heuristically, but they are intertwined in the brain, and it's not surprising they overlap in folk conceptions as well.
Yes, "soteriological" as we're using it has no specifically theistic connotations, it could refer to a kind of impersonal harmony with the universe

I think that's where the powers of virtue come in. If you use the cold cognition to do so called "good" in a situation, after repetition and experience it should eventually become part of your hot cognition.Although I imagine there are many challenges to overcome, the main one being fear. Take the example of decent human beings who walk past a man dressed as homeless who clearly collapses from some health issue. No one comes to his rescue. Now dress the same man in a suit and voila - "Sir, are you okay?" So how does the Cold cognition overcome fear to do "good" might also be interesting.

It's plain that the Mandate has considerable resonance in Chinese thought, but it's always been a bit of a conundrum for me. If we compare it to the 'divine right of kings' in some western societies it seems to carry a greater normative weight, so I can see it provides a handle for the philosophers, but did it ever carry resonance for potential rebels? Are there examples of people thinking I'd love to be king but sadly old so-and-so has got the Mandate so I'd better back off. In effect when dynasties fell it eventually became accepted that the winner, however dubious morally he might actually be, would have the Mandate. Even the Mongols who slaughtered uncounted numbers ended up with a Yuan Mandate. So was the Mandate in political terms more than a post-hoc justification for the Zhou and for successive usurpers?
I agree, virtue can become automatic if done overtime consciously.

But if you train that out of the system, now you have another problem.

I find the connection between religion and philosophy interesting because it mirrors my own belief that science has become our culture's new religion.  We do not question its tenets; we never get up in the morning and decide not to be subject to gravity today, for instance.  It is immutable.  Further study will enlighten us further.  Those who practice it and produce its pronouncements cannot be questioned.  Global warming is a scientific fact, we say.  If you deny it, you are just crazy.  Based on science's "facts," we alter our ways of life: we give up cigarettes, switch from beer to red wine, dine on snapper instead of filet, choose hairsprays that are not aerosols, and eat broccoli.  Certainly science changes.  At one time red meat was considered good protein; today it's bad.  At one point, drinking simply led to alcoholism; today it promotes gut health.  But all religions must be similarly flexible.  Jesus was supposed to return in ... when?  a hundred years?  a millenium?  And when he didn't, his believers simply stretched out the time frame, because the "fact" of his return had to remain unquestioned, else the religion would have faltered.  Who'd believe in a dead Savior, after all?I'm interested to see how the course answers the question of why we must have such religious or quasi-religious systems and what would happen to us if we didn't have one.

I am not a musician, but I've experienced some of wu-wei while I was learning piano many years ago. I could play one piece that I loved over and over, for over an hour (my usual daily practice was 45min). I was always reluctant to practice, but that was one of the extreme exceptions. These are some other times I've experienced wu-wei:- trying to lose weight. My friends & I have found out that it's way easier to lose weight when you don't care about it, I guess because then you're not stressing out over it or thinking too much about food or wanting the guilty pleasure of eating more than you should.- meditating. Ugh. It's hard to rein in the mad monkey mind.- Weeding in the garden. It's great when the sun is outside and you can smell the plants and dirt.Oddly enough, I've been able to feel wu-wei when dancing in public or speaking publicly/being interviewed after practicing enough. I don't think the Prof is talking about hunter-gatherers in general, just how the nature of how the hunting and gathering is done influences societies and the way they think. There are several misinterpretations in the video that I wish to address.  Zhou dynasty followed the ritual in order to maintain the Tian Ming (mandate) rather than the De.   In fact, the phase Tian Ming was mentioned several times in the Book of Songs and the Book of History.   The word De was popularized by the Dao De Jing resumably written by Laozi.   Laozi was a legendary figure, which could be born in the later part of Zhou dynasty or during the warring state period.Another point is the misintepretation is to refer Li as only ceremony or ways governing people behavior.  In fact Li is a set of rules or protocol governing all daily human activities.  As such, Li is very much related to law.   Per LiJi (Book of Rite), there are five types of Li. 1. the rituals of celebration, marriages etc.  2. the rituals of funeral, resolving dispute etc   3. the rituals of the military.  4. the rituals of entertaining guests, diplomats.   5. the ritual of growing up

I think the "implied pressure" is not from science, it's from a separate belief that living longer, preserving resources, etc is "good". For example, the scientific conclusion might be that you can get Ebola virus by doing A, B, C. It would be a separate belief system that says you living longer and not hurting other people is "good", that makes you want to avoid A, B, C.

I agree. Scientists accept the models of our universe that predict the universe's behavior best (i.e. our model of gravity predicts what will happen if you jump off a cliff better than any other explanation, so it is accepted). If and when evidence builds to modify or provide an alternative hypothesis, that one will be accepted -- which doesn't mean that the previous model was not helpful to describe the world when it was used. In this way the colloquial use of the word "fact" doesn't really describe scientific facts, so there is tension when the model changes.

Actually, Kantian deontology is an interesting case: arguably (Kant wouldn't like this, but the contemporary philosopher Joshua Greene has made the case convincingly) the basis of the "duty" is a gut reaction, a hot reaction, that you then unpack and weigh against other hot reactions in a relatively cold way. Greene argues that only utilitarianism is completely cold and therefore rational; I think the "values" that you're inputting into the calculus actually come from emotions too, but this is a complex issue.

There is no intellectually honest way to have philosophy as a subset of religion in a Venn diagram.  Is all the work in political philosophy, logic and aesthetics a subset of religion? Each religion offers a world view which is taken on faith and is studied more than questioned, by its followers - a light in the fog - whereas philosophy questions and dissects ideas to the point where it - is a walk on slippery rocks.I appreciate the point made that a few hundred years ago as part of the enlightenment philosophers were trying to create an ethical and purposeful world view that was outside of the Catholic church and that is an example of where philosophy and religion overlap, but to understand this region of overlap it is also important to contrast the differences.

Really, if you give up that easily, you probably didn't exercise much cold cognition in the first place. The cold, logical mind would very well know that *"'Just one cookie' is the beginning of a slippery slope, and I know I might not actually feel motivated to go to the gym later."*The cold mind, as I understand it, actively resists the hot mind when it is doing something it knows as "bad" or "unreasonable," like eating the cookie. The cold mind never goes along with the hot mind when it becomes "unreasonable." Thus any "rationalizing" is coming from the hot mind, not the cold one.In this case, I'd say the hot cognition has more or less complete control in the end. If the cold mind was a part of it at all, it was only as the losing belligerent in the war of the diet.

> "Isn't the ultimate goal of carrots and sticks to internalise specific> laws and follow them without much thought?"Not as far as I am aware. In cold ethical systems, it is never assumed that people will ever follow the rules in an internal way. It is always assumed that people will "think about the repercussions." If people do end up internalizing the laws of some system, well, that's great, but it's not really "expected." At least in western society, we make laws to keep people from doing bad things, not to make people good on the inside.In contrast, in hot ethical systems, making people good on the inside is the entire point.At least, that's how I understand the difference.

For perspective, Thales was a bit older than Confucius, and Plato and Mencius were contemporaries!I think that saying westerners have no sense of history is very unfair. We are, in fact, very preoccupied with our Greeks and Romans, the foundations of our own nations, our religious histories, and even the histories of our cultural ancestors (the fertile crescent civilizations and Egypt, for example).Even in everyday life, I can't tell you how often I hear people appeal to tradition or history.

I'd guess, in terms of the thinking we're considering, a person with internalised hot virtue would kill instinctively in such a case, but would naturally control themselves if someone stole their parking spot.

You might be interested in Jason Ananda Josephson's book *The Invention of Religion in Japan* (2012). Josephson demonstrates that there was no word for "religion" until the late 19th century, and he traces its creation as part of diplomatic interactions with Europeans and Americans. Nevertheless, this does not mean that there were no ontological systems that provided normative guidance and soteriological strategies in Japan before 1873. In fact, when Christianity first arrived in Japan in the mid-16th century, many thinkers considered it to be a heterodox sect of Buddhism!

Remember that we are defining religion as a system of ontological claims (not necessarily theistic) that provides normative guidance and a soteriological strategy. Is there a philosophy that does not fit that definition? Things that fall outside "philosophy" but are still inside "religion" might include the cultural bundles of beliefs and behaviours that we are accustomed to calling religions. For example, something that fits the definition above but relies upon a revealed scripture, inculcates dogmatic beliefs in a deity or deities, prescribes dress and dietary restrictions, etc.
I'd recommend the work of Susan Haack, Ian Hacking and Larry Laudan on this topic (all advocated of pragmatic models of science)

> So it seems that whichever way you move toward wu-wei, you are using> cold consciousness.That, I imagine, is the "Paradox of Wu-wei." Fortunately, it sounds like that will be one of the central themes of the course, so I'm looking forward to that.As of my current limited knowledge, it does sound like there is some kind of "investment" involved - trading some cold thought now so that you don't have to use cold thought later.> Is there a way around this?I honestly don't think we need to find a way around that initial period - or that it's even possible. We don't need to *completely* abandon cold thought. Cold thinking, as the professor said, is a very important part of being human. But it could be useful to not have to rely on it.
Precisely: exerting cognitive control in one instance impairs your ability to exert it in the next, although there is a big debate about why this is so (what mechanisms are involved).

Actually, both Mozi and Hanfeizi would see floods as resulting from precisely this: the failure of the ruler to train enough people, or pay them well enough to attract good people, etc. We haven't got to them yet, not all the thinkers in early China bought into this de idea.

This issue of emotions and wu-wei is an interesting one, we may have time to talk about some passages in the Zhuangzi that suggest the wu-wei sage experiences emotions as we all do, but then can just let them go and move on. And certainly feeling the right emotions at the right time (righteous anger when presented with immorality, etc.) is at the center of Confucian wu-wei.

All of the early Chinese thinkers believe that the truly wu-wei person will be fully engaged in the world, for the Confucians this would clearly involve engaging in politics, dealing with injustice, etc., for the Daoists it's a little less clear. One weakness of the Zhuangzian vision, for instance, is that it seems supremely unconcerned with issues like social justice, etc. But wait till we get to Mozi, social justice is his main thing. (Although he doesn't care about wu-wei)

We are discussing God in the MITx Philosophy MOOC. One interesting topic is the Fine-Tunig Argument for the existence of God. The argument uses inference to the best explanation to claim that since there is not a comparatively satisfying explanation for the fine-tuning of the cosmological constants, the idea that God adjusted them to be life-permitting is the best evidence for them being so. It concludes that the constants being the way they are supports theism. I appreciate Dr. Slingerland's explanation of how certain philosophies are religious in nature. Sagan was probably referring to Plato's teleological ethics, where universal objects, and even people have a Telos, and ultimate end or goal. Plato would have argued that the slave most likely is in his position because of his Telos, which possibly could have been driven by his particular mind-body makeup. Slavery is engendered in social circumstances, which is why it fits very well within the distributive model of Plato's preferred arrangement of Natural Aristocracy. Natural Aristocracy is a distributive model which does not correct for social circumstances or natural talents, but it does include the Difference Principle, which makes it such that, as Rawls explains, "the expectations of the most favored are just if and only if they result in better expectations for the least advantaged." Slaves would certainly be the least advantaged in Natural Aristocracy. Plato made his Teleological argument quite possibly to guard himself against having to drink the hemlock (like Socrates). Essentially the Teleological argument purports that slaves are, more or less, naturally predisposed to be in that social position.

Perhaps we might need to distinguish between science as a methodology, and scientism as an ideology? The former, to me, is but a largely normative-free tool. We may realize that smoking is bad for our health because of science, but science does not necessarily dictate that we quit smoking because it is morally right (some people might value smoking more than their lives, and there's really nothing an epidemiological tool in and of itself can do to deter them). Normative or soteriological arguments would still be made by people drawing on a wide range of philosophical, religious or ideological ontologies interpreting the facts on the ground, rather than the facts' normative value being evident in and of itself.However, scientism (defined here as "science as the absolute and only justifiable access to the truth") can be a "religion" under our class definition: makes the metaphysical claim that there is nothing beyond what's observable (i.e. the metaphysics of no metaphysics), can potentially have normative judgements if taken to extremes (for instance, Sam Harris's Moral Landscape argues that statements of morality are fundamentally scientific statements), and has a bit of a soteriological prescription (to spread science and rationalism, replace religion and abstract theory).

The Greeks would have been more likely to take up Chinese bronze casting technology, which they didn't do, than be swayed by philosophy.

Based on this lecture I was inspired to try to analyze zen ethics in terms of the three models of ethics presented. Zen practitioners commit to sixteen precepts: three of them are based in deontology and ask that we develop a sense duty towards (take refuge in) Buddha, Dharma and Sangha; three of them are based in virtue ethics and ask that we integrate three values (Cease from harm, do only good and do good for others); ten of them specifically tell us how not to use body speech and mind to realize the previous three, and are similar to, but not the same as,  the ten commandments.  Like the commandments they are maxims, but not ones that were dictated by an external deity but ones that arose out of experience of living in community and watching how conflict and suffering arise. They are primarily based in consequentialism.  IÕm not saying that the three sets of zen precepts donÕt mix the ethical system, just that each set has a predominant orientation.  I am wondering if my analysis is reasonable.  Any comments?

It is quite a problem! Just as you say about Indian languages, as I understand it, there is no sound in English which is exactly equivalent to chi/qi and therefore, no Romanised letter which makes an exact translation.As an example, I was at school with a girl who was a Cantonese speaker. She taught me to count, but there was one number (5) that I just could not pronounce. It's almost "mm" but not quite. For example, listening to the prof saying "Xia" I heard something which I would spell "sha" or even, "zha", rather than "shia".

Once as a twelve year old hanging out at the tennis club early on a Saturday morning I was invited to warm up with the top three men players at the club who didn't want to wait anymore for the number four player. I had prepared for such a opportunity with several years of lessons and many thousands of balls being hit in practice and up against a wall. I had been prepared with constant parental chastisement about how to act around adults and show respect and be polite. But all of this was for naught as I was too scared to hit the ball ... until my partner got angry with me and yelled at me to "stop thinking and just hit the damn ball". I never played tennis as well again as I did in that next ten minutes. I didn't think about how hard the ball was coming or how fast I was having to move I simply hit the ball hard and ran fast. In skill based activity such as this the practice and preparation are certainly needed. However, during the actual execution the idea is to simply know where the ball will be and to find yourself in that place swinging as hard as possible and then to not think about the years of training at all. It's not unlike what Yoda told Luke Skywalker ... There is no trying to do. You either do or you do not do. Such is a state of wu-wei.

I guess some religions believe salvation waits till death and other religions believe salvation happens in life, ie it'll save you from your current destructive path. I think that either could be the case in a theistic or a non-theistic religion. Salvation is therefore a concept not dependent on a god.However, does all philosophy aim towards salvation?? I was under the impression that this was not necessarily the case. Metaphysics, for example, aims to understand the nature of existence (am I right?). Will that knowledge save us? It could lead to an answer for salvation when used by someone else, but does the knowledge itself save us and is the philosopher working toward metaphysical answers necessarily participating in a religion? Are all philosophers motivated by salvation?I can much more easily accept a vin diagram of philosophy and religion that overlaps, but not one where philosophy is completely inside the religion circle. (At this point in my understanding, which is subject to change. Am I placing too much emphasis on salvation in the definition of religion?) I am willing to go with it for purposes of this class, though. I guess the point of the definition is for us to think of these Chinese thoughts and practices as religions and I am okay with that.

Although Christian beliefs might appear to be very different, with death seemingly bringing a profound change, as Professor Slingerland says, there were in pre-Reformation times in Europe, for example, other folk-type beliefs running parallel with official Church doctrine.  I like this line from Bossy, who has been talking about the mass for the dead, and the idea of souls in purgatory being purged by fire.  'Meanwhile the common-sense view was that the souls of the dead would naturally be more or less where their bodies were, in the churchyard, and suffering rather from cold and wet than from excessive heat.' (Bossy, 'Christianity in the West 1400 Ð 1700', p. 30)  Duffy, however, argues that 'traditional religion' was not a system of superstitious folk beliefs; and writes that the cult of intercession for the dead [to lessen the time a soul spent in purgatory] could be seen 'as a means of prolonging the presence of the dead within the community of the living . . . ' (Duffy, 'The Stripping of the Altars- Traditional Religion in England 1400 - 1580' p.303)  In other words, whether  'official' doctrine or no, it seems that ways were found to maintain a relationship with the dead.  Perhaps, with the 'invention' of purgatory, there was not understood to be such a sharp divide between life and death.And I think the idea that the dead maintain the same kind, or at least some kind, of relationship is probably fairly widespread.  For one reason, we apparently tend to think of them Ð dead loved ones Ð in a similar way to how we think of those who are alive but absent.  See, for example, the work of Dr. K. Mitch Hodgehttp://mitchhodge.orgfree.com/publications.htmlMight this be the 'gene-inheritance' aspect, whereas different understandings of the after-life are part of 'cultural inheritance'?  Another cultural difference from the early Chinese understanding was the belief that those suffering in purgatory, the ordinary dead, were in need of the living.  It was only the 'special' dead, i.e. the saints, who might be petitioned and prayed to.

Pinyin is a Romanization , transcribing Chinese(Mandarin) pronunciations into Roman alphabets, not "Englishization". Therefore you will see that vowels are pronounced more like (in fact many are identical) to Latin languages. Pinyin is like creating a new alphabet on the basis of standard 26-letter system. It seeks compromises between  common western pronunciations and standard Mandarin pronunciations. "q" and "ch" are two different pronunciations in pinyin. In our videos the prof refers "q " as a "ch" pronunciation because for those who haven't learnt spoken mandarin ,this is the closest pronunciation, although in fact quite unlike. Also as for the pronunciation of "de", it does not sound like "duh", be "d" plus a prolonged and rounded "ughr" with chins moving. There's no perfect way to pronounce these sounds accurately using English pronunciations. So to transcribe the pronunciation, one could either create a new alphabetical system (Pinyin and Zhuyin), or use "international phonetic alphabet", which most people don't read.
Pinyin has limit within Chinese spoken languages as well. It fails to spell the pronunciation of "2" (er) in many northern mandarins, not to mention that it is unable to spell most dialects.

I now see this as an example of hot conditioning, since it's an almost automatic response that I seem to have no control over--I just do it.  But that's not normal for hot cognition, so I'm assuming that such an altruistic action comes as a result of my cold cognition training my hot cognition.  But as I can remember no instances of anyone telling me to do this, and many people telling me not to, so my rational cold cognition can't be teaching this action to my hot cognition.  Any suggestions, readers?  (NB: I'm a woman, and I've chased and confronted men.)

Surely hunting is a cooperative activity? Maybe not on the same scale as agriculture, but each member of the party would have a specific role to play. The scout would not expect to carry out the kill for example.I don't think it is possible to say that individualism is the default setting for humans. It is just as possible to argue that in the earliest days of our evolution, we had to cooperate to survive, but at some point along the way people discovered that they could benefit from self interest.The lecture never stated that before large scale agriculture there was no collectivism,. In fact, quite the opposite."So it seems clear in the earliest thought.....that the individual is tied up with their social role.And they're honored and they're valued morefor their role.... than as some kind of distinct, unique individual.""So this collectivist, this idea of thinking of yourselfas part of the collective, is probably morethe default way people have historically thought about themselves"Early humans were capable of both collectivism and individualism, of making a choice between the two, but in China, due to the nature of rice agriculture, collectivism came to be favoured, whereas in WEIRD societies the type of agriculture which developed allowed individualism to flourish.As for "the luxury of not having to live on plantations", whilst this may be true for you and me, it is not true for many people across the world. Many people in the world live in slums and on rubbish dumps. In the USA there are tent cities, Perhaps this luxury is the ultimate expression of an individualist world view?We are still just as much " under the thumb" but it is the thumb of the government, law, and more recently, banks and corporations, rather than a blood relative. That's a much bigger thumb!

As I understand it, wu wei means acting in accordance with the dao, the way of the universe, which applies to all living things.So a spider spinning a web is acting naturally and spontaneously, doing what spiders do, so that is wu wei. If this spider decided to spin the best web ever, she would strive to meet that aim and this would no longer be wu wei.Not sure that I can answer with regard to your example of a computer programme except that a computer can't act any other way than is in its programming, my computer can't decode to work extra hard on one particular activity, nor can it try not to try, unless that is in its programming. But I really do like the idea of a wu wei computer.

The conception of the afterlife which Socrates discusses is certainly based on the Odyssey, but the account of Socrates in *Phaedo* might give you a better understanding of the soteriological reward of ancient Greece.

Priests in ancient Egypt were very powerful and influential with sometimes hereditary positions, there is a clear distinction between the priests and the pharaoh - the pharaoh was actually looked at as a god; indeed he was the political and religious leader of the country but just like Queen Elizabeth II being the Supreme Governor of of the Church of England - you would not call her a priest, its more of a formal role. Also on artifacts only the workers or peasants are shown in groups while gods, the pharaoh, priests, leaders are always magnified, more detailed.

I think it might be useful to create a sort of hierarchy of ontological and metaphysical claims to sort out this web of what is and isn't religious in the western sense, and seeing if western beliefs can operate within the same framework as ideas such as Dao or De.  Just like how belief in psychology doesn't force you to abandon Christianity or vice versa (to my understanding). If the beliefs we're studying are on different rungs of the ontological ladder, then one belief shouldn't cancel the other and they aren't mutually exclusive. If beliefs in God and the Dao sit upon the same rung of that ontological ladder, however, and they can't be held simultaneously and remain coherent, than the ideas operate within the same plane of ontological beliefs and deserve to be categorized as such.  This is highly subjective of course to the person in question who holds the beliefs whether they contradict or not.  And many beliefs might be compatible with another belief without that second belief corresponding in compatibility. Still, it might provide a little order to the madness.

Close observation of water ... the action of rivers, the Yellow River ... yielded a knowledge base for ancient people resulting in incredible and still-functioning irrigation systems. To the extent that people were observant and respectful of the power of rivers especially, their civilization survived. In addition, the mysterious power of water is a source of beauty, poetry and transcendental thinking. Like wu-wei, water seemingly derives its power without form.

column25: There is, though, the radical system which groups words into general categories--the hand radical, the person radical, the mouth radical--and also a general pronunciation/sound element that's sometimes helpful to beginners in guessing how to pronounce a word.

Inuit culture, a hunter gatherer society,held the small family/clan group to be more important than the individual, and in fact, would allow individual elders, whom they greatly revered, to choose to remain behind when the group's survival was at risk. I lived in the Arctic among these people and found that they had the most developed form of consensus decision-making that I have ever encountered. They achieved this by deep listening. During council meetings, for example, I noticed long periods of silence after someone had spoken. Then the speaker would resume talking. I also noticed that before another speaker offered their ideas, the first speaker would say the word, "Taima."  Later I found out that this means, "I have finished speaking." In this way each person in the group had space to fully express themselves, reflect on what they had said, *without interruption*, and then continue. Based on the input from ALL individuals, sometimes in large group and sometimes in small groups, a group consensus was taken. In this way, the decision was truly a group decision. See my article http://www.loudzen.com/skydancer/esangha/inuitcon.html

I disagree with Dr. Slingerland; I believe that religion is encased in philosophy, and not the other way around. The difference between the two is that religion offers a guideline for people on how to live their lives under conditions maximum certainty, while philosophy offers a guideline on how to live your life under conditions of maximum UNcertainty. For instance, there is no religious doctrine, principle, etc. that can provide us with the answer of what shoes to wear for the day. We are uncertain, so we turn to philosophy and ask a series of questions such as, "is it raining," "will I be walking a lot," etc. Philosophical questions are the same questions asked in religion, in my opinion ("how should we live our lives," "what exists," etc.).I've read through many other posts and have not seen anyone disagree with philosophy being enveloped in religion, so I thought I would just share my thoughts.

column25: Food for thought - Adrenaline response - "fight or flight" response, a hot cognition behavior. Also, several who just can't seem to manage confrontation under any circumstances.

column25: When I was watching the video I noticed that when the Yangshao shaman's grave was mentioned, there was a specific note about a dragon being depicted on the right and a tiger on the left, both made from shells. I'm currently following an EdX course on Historical Relical Treasures and Culture China from TsinghuaX, and this week's topic was early Chinese astronomy. In this lecture, there was a mention of a Xishuipo Neolithic tomb where a similar dragon and tiger had been found. The corpse was buried with its head facing south, and to the east was a dragon (so on the left of the body, respectively), and to the west a tiger (so, right), both depicted in shells. Later research of this tomb pointed out that rather than being merely decorative, these animals were probably references to the astronomic system (more specifically, the east and west 'palace') used at that time. By placing shells, bones, three accompanying sacrificial burials and the animal images in a certain position they were able to reproduce the cosmos as they knew it then. Of course I might be completely wrong in thinking that rather than shamanistic decorations, these two animals might've been references to astronomy, but I just thought I'd repeat the information I'd gathered here because I thought it very coincidental that they're so similar, even if the positions are reversed (then again, the archaeologists that discovered the tomb were equally confused as to why the corpse was buried with its head towards the south, so maybe they were just terrible at placement :P). So, since I posted this as being a question, my question is: Is it possible that rather than being spirit animals, the tiger and dragon accompanying the Yangshao shaman are actually depictions of the eastern and western palace in astronomy? Or is the fact that their positions are reversed proof that that's complete nonsense?

![enter image description here][1]I find the institutional model's focus on "carrots"--*rewards*--as problematic for inculcating pro-social behavior as the more obvious drawbacks of the threat of the "stick."Case in point from a personal connection: I'm a teacher, secondary school, 15-18 year-olds. The goal of improving students' skills is perversely affected by the "carrot" of good grades for things like "honor roll" and class rankings--valedictorian and so forth. Rather than instilling a drive in students to show current skills in order to identify areas needing growth, the grade carrot instead encourages them to do that unvirtuous thing called "cheating." And the stick doesn't deter this because it's so easy to cheat now.The same "carrot" of individual happiness (generally measured by material gain today) leads respectable adults to *calculate* whether breaking the law is a "price of doing business" when gains from tax evasion, fraud, and other antisocial behaviors outweigh the penalties of the stick.This points, to me, to the ultimate problems of virtue in the West. Our education of the young trains them, through its Institutional Model, to value skillful dishonesty, and grooms them to see adult success in similar terms. It seems clear a different model of schooling that employs the Commitment Model and Virtue Ethics would be a change for the better.Scwewy carrot!  [1]: http://ecx.images-amazon.com/images/I/418uPERdKZL._AA160_.jpg

I think it is a interesting question. My two cents:In 'Acceptance and Commitment Therapy' (ACT), a Cognitive Behavioural Therapy of the third generation (doesn't that sounds cool), that essentialy fuses cognitive therapy with mindfulness, awareness is seen as a background presence. Or using a metaphore, it is the chessboard holding the different (sometimes conflicting) pieces. However it is always just what it is, a chessboard, no matter if the white or black pieces win. Or a metaphore I came up with, awareness is like the television screen. It does not care wether there is a crappy Stalone movie on or a beautiful Mozart concert. It is just there. The funny thing is I have been reading about Buddhism a lot and practicing it, but I nowhere found a better description of 'Buddha nature' or 'Big Mind' (the background awareness) then in the book about ACT by Stephen Hayes 'Get Out of Your Mind and Into Your Life: The New Acceptance and Commitment Therapy'. It eloquently describes the nature between language and suffering (with all sorts of excercises) and basically says you should give up the struggle to get what you want: in this case mental health, sounds a lot like trying not to try :)Anyway the link between the above and hot/cold cognition is not clear but I thought it would add to the discussion.

Tian Ming is not "Divine Right"--that's something feudal kings in European Christendom and early Modernity were given by Rome's Heaven. Tian Ming is "Divine *Responsibility*." Basic contract: If and when we abuse the people, kill us. The *Shujing* says it well: "Heaven (Tian) sees through the eyes and hears through the ears of *the people*." Confucius was dazzled by the Western Zhou for understandable reasons. Caring for one's family, or for those with whom one perceives a specific genetic relationship, is readily distinguishable from the collectivism that the lecture attributes to the people in the river valleys of China around 4000 BC.  Collectivism relates to a group that are not specifically "kin."  Confucian moral imperatives relate to the society or the state and not only to kin.The lecture suggests that the WEIRD are not collectivist, whereas modern Chinese remain collectivist, and relates this to the experience around 4000 BC, to which, it is stated, there was no analog in the lives of peoples in other parts of the world, less suited to mass collective agriculture.
There has been no suggestion that hunter-gatherers engaged in "cold" thinking in obtaining food.  They had no "place in society."  There was no "society."

Those groups are tiny compared to the collectivities in the Chinese valleys to which the lecture refers.  A few people getting together, an ad hoc hunting party that might share the spoils unless the strongest makes off with them, is not practicing collectivism.  Collectivism does not correlate with democracy, council meetings or the like.  Hitler and Stalin ran collectivist social structures, as did Mao.  It is typified by putting the interests of a large group of people (with no perceived specific genetic relationships) ahead of those of individuals, families or any smaller units.

The lecture starts from the observation, or claim, that Chinese today are more collectivist than WEIRD, and seeks to explain that by the assertion that the ancient forms of agriculture appropriate to or advantageous in these river valleys in China engage much larger number of people--hundreds, thousands of people--in common endeavor than is the case elsewhere.If you disagree with either part of that, by all means speak up.

If this doesn't conform with your preconceived notion of collectivism, that doesn't make the point any less valid.

Hello, All!My name is Mark, and I am a practitioner of Chinese medicine. I currently live in Florida in the United States. I recently graduated a 4-year program in Chinese medicine in Portland, Oregon.I'm most interested in this course because I want to be excellent at Chinese medicine, and the medicine is unable to be totally extracted from the culture in which it grew without doing great damage to it. For that matter, why would anyone want to extract it? Chinese culture, especially from the Warring States period, is really cool! My school focused on what we termed "Classical Chinese Medicine," which involved deeper involvement with some of the early texts of the medicine (Shen Nong Ben Cao Jing, Huang Di Nei Jing, Shang Han Lun). I've been deeply influenced by Lao Zi and Zhuang Zi, like I see others here have as well! Like others here, I'm also an avid practitioner of Taiji Chuan. It's always great to delve deeper into the roots of the things I play with, so I'm thankful that this class exists. In addition, I'm planning to move to Chengdu, China for a year beginning February, so I'm interested in developing a broader view of Chinese culture over time, and understanding the roots more deeply so I can observe the branches better once I'm there. :-)

You understate the value of stories and traditions which govern early cultures.They define our spiritual beliefs and form of government.The traditions and stories of my people closely parallel those of ancient China, and may provide an insight to the beginnings of Chinese civilization as well as developments and history of my own culture.

The same type of collectivism and consensus decision making was found among my nation, the Weapemeoc, and we were not a small nation, but had 25 tribes, some that numbered in the tens of thousands, and others of only a few thousand. The early cultural groups of China were probably close in size and structure to the Weapemeoc at the time of first contact with Europeans.

Individualism existed, but was shaped by structure of the society. If a Sachem of a tribe (North American Carolina Algonquin) wished to make war, but did not have the support of enough members of his tribe for it, he could ask that men from other tribes join him.Men that did so acted as individuals, and they were not considered to be acting on behalf of their tribe. Men were not as closely tied to an individual tribe as women were, unless they were of the line of Sachems which governed the tribe of course.Individual achievement in war or the hunt gained a man honor, but so did sharing the fruits of such achievements with the needy bring him much honor as well.So individualism was more common among men than the collective clan structure of tribes, as clans were groups of related females and their children. Thus I think both individualism and collectivism both served a function in early cultures, although my people are just one example of how this might work.

The contrast between eastern and western rituals is something that I'm still getting used to. For example, in China, when you have a guest over or you are eating something in front of company, it is polite (ritual) to offer them some out of consideration, and then it is ritual for the guest to refuse, also out of consideration. If you have a guest over, you offer them a drink, and the guest refuses (though they may ask for water instead). In the US, if someone offers you something, you take it if you want it, which to Chinese people seems so rude! Haha, there may be exceptions (I'm no expert on Chinese culture), but this is the way I was taught and it has been ingrained in me from an early age, so I still find the US ritual weird. But I think, in the US, if you are offered something, and you refuse it, you may be seen as stand-off-ish, because it is usually a sincere offer to share, or because accepting someone's hospitality is part of western ritual? I grew up in the US and this is something that (obviously) still trips me up hahaha. It's interesting how cultures clash and combine in different ways, when you inherit more than one of them.

As I never met Confucius myself Ð of course Ð and neither studied his documented thoughts and deeds extensively so far I can only guess. My feeling would be that he might not have opposed diversity per se (Didn't the "China" of his time already consist of several ethnicities, no matter if united or not?), but maybe he rather was solely opposing the pure lack of proper rituals.I think of our today's societies, where more and more nations consist of people with diverse cultural backgrounds. When leaving out unfortunately still clearly existing problems of prejudices, xenophobia, racism and antisemitism or other similar isms, all those people should get along well with each other as long as everybody follows the common rules (i.e. laws, accepted behaviours, duties etc.) of society.Though, when Confucianism can be seen as a religion, Confucius' opposition today might rather aim on the lack of proper religious ritual, like Ð if he were a Westerner and a Christian Ð for instance in previously Christian cultures, when people do not pray each day and join the evening service or the Sunday Mass, to "be on good terms with God" (This is not my belief so please excuse me for simplifying here).I come to this conclusion because, when I understand it correctly, it was the fact of the Zhou practices not being followed any longer in the right way (minor aristocrats doing what only the rightful king is allowed to do) that the Heaven somehow assigned Confucius to go on his mission to change the overall situation. In this case China would then get back to be in good terms with the Heaven.
column35: Was Confucius Against Diversity or Against Pure Lack of Proper Rituals?

Yes as it was mentioned before Confucius appears to be on a mission from Heaven. I would agree that Confucius does not seem like he would be against ethnic diversity, but as a man who has a sense of Western Zhou nationalism, he would tend to be culturally conservative. I think he cared most about restoring the proper ritual practices from the Western Zhou. I don't think, for instance, it would have mattered to him what a person looked like; if the person practiced proper ritual, they were in the right, and if they did not, they were in the wrong. My question is if Confucius had been employed by a ruler, what sort of tasks would he be doing? Would his job merely have been to advise the ruler on courses of action and to perform rituals?

The point I was trying to make with my own post is that Confucius has never been read as an "anti-diversity" preacher, by anyone in the history of China. What he attempted to preserve were more universal concepts of tradition.

Hi Sova,The best method is to read the items in the Required Reading *before* watching the videos. So, for Module 1, you should read all three excerpts from *Trying Not to Try* before watching videos 1 - 5, and and the excerpts from *The Book of Odes* and *The Book of Documents* before watching videos 6 - 9. For Module 2, you should read through all of the Required Reading after watching the introduction video, but before watching the main lectures.We have not matched page numbers from the Required Readings to specific lectures, as you requested. However, as we move forward, you will find that Prof. Slingerland always cites the book and passage number of the quotes that he refers to. Therefore, as you watch the lectures, you may find it helpful to occasionally pause the video, and find the full passage he is talking about in the Required Readings.Finally, each lecture *does* contain specific additional readings listed in the Further Readings section. For example, the Further Readings for Module 2, Lecture 2 can be found [here][1]. You can use these to do your own research about any topic that you found particularly interesting. Beneath many of these Further Readings, you will see short descriptions, which will help you know what part of the lecture they're about.Hope this helps!Robin  [1]: https://courses.edx.org/courses/UBCx/China300x/3T2014/courseware/108e3b942b2b4fd98caf4cb2151733c5/14d0d7efa8f240aeb638c98401debf0f/

Confucius certainly wasn't against ethnic diversityÑhe believed that he could go and dwell among the Eastern barbarians (even them!) and transform them with his virtue. But there is still only one proper culture for human beings, that of the Western Zhou. In this regard, the Chinese sense of cultural specialness (as exemplified here by Confucius) has always been fundamentally open to everyone: anyone who makes the effort to acquire Chinese culture can become "Chinese", as opposed, say, to traditional Japanese conceptions of specialness, which are inherently racial (they are descendants of the Sun Goddess, and you're either a relative of hers or you're not).

If there was no mass agriculture, requiring people with no known genetic relationship to collaborate for the benefit of the collectivity, then there is no parallel.  Fact is that nowhere in North America did the geography favor such agriculture.

You are arguing with the professor, not with me.He makes it clear that in his opinion, mass collaborative agriculture, for instance rice farming, led to greater collectivism than had previously existed.  Previously would mean earlier settled agriculture without mass collective farming, an hunter-gatherer.Maybe it's hard to imagine that individuals and small kin groups went out and hunted and ate small animals, and, more important, picked whatever edible plants they could for themselves and their families.  Maybe also 10 or even 100 people occasionally killed a lion or elephant, but that was not in the mainstream of hunter-gatherer existence, and the numbers of people involved were tiny compared to those who cooperated in rice farming.I lack the knowledge to make the claim that "my tribe" did this or that, but that would be irrelevant anyway.
Hi Josie, what you say is interesting...it means that most things are by default in Wu-Wei. The only way to be out of Wu-Wei would be to over-think what you're doing, then?

Hi FiveWillows, that's an interesting point of view! In that case then Wu-Wei is the default state of most of the universe, and us humans are the only species unfortunate enough to have so much self-consciousness that we lose our default Wu-Wei. But if humans do achieve Wu-Wei, then would that state of Wu-Wei have a greater value than the default Wu-Wei, since it was achieved against all odds?

The question is about what rituals look like in the West.  I think (1) being honest in answers and (2) sharing opinions in conversations can be described as "rituals" that are culturally valued in the West, and ones not part of ritual in China.  (I'm from America and have lived in China for 15 years.)  What I have experienced and often observe is when a Western person talks with Chinese person, in China, and there is very little understanding on the part of both people of each other's culture or "rituals", a great wall of confusion and even hurt emerges.  One a side note, I'm finding the course vital for the work of unity and social justice at the global scale; it's not just a course for those who have "interest" in the subject of China.  The more we learn about each other's culture (and history), the more we can see the beauty of each - the West and East - and how we are destined to come together in one close embrace.  One of the most important things to do, I feel, is for each one of us is not to think "our" or "their" culture is "better" or "worse" than the other.
In addition to being an adviser to the court, I think he'd be connected with the Ministry of Education in some way, teaching the rituals of proper behavior.

I can see that that in Confucian philosophical terms there is the theoretical possibility that anyone can become a proper human being by embracing the 'way', but I see a big gap between this and a claim for fundamental openness. The special cases cited - Japan and Jewishness - are indeed special but it seems to me you could easily demonstrate that other religions are equally open to converts, and there are, as NMarzian suggests, other cultures and nation states happy to embrace incomers willing to integrate. Nor do I really think that one can easily equate Confucianism with  Chinese 'culture' in this way. . During the early decades of the communist period China was renowned for an obdurate hostility to foreigners,even those willing to buy into Chineseness. For good or at least explicable reason perhaps, but it at least demonstrates that there is plenty else in the Chinese cultural mix than Confucianism.
