Most Native American tribe have a matriarchal clan structure, which gave women considerable say in tribal politics. Some tribes like mine also had hereditary chiefdom (monarchies), however men and women were equal and either sex could be Sachem of a tribe. So various native tribes of North America are unique, but do share some similarities, but overall tended to be matriarchal societies.

Professor Slingerland has some good knockabout lines about what we tend to believe or do in the west, and I appreciate he needs to be concise, but I was given pause by the suggestion that in the modern west art is 'something you do on the side, an optional extra'. I certainly don't see it that way, and I would argue that western educational and even governmental organisations place a high value on art, both in the formation of character and for living a full life. In many areas art has a tendency to be an elite pursuit, but that would hardly be a great disincentive for Confucius. Isn't this an area where he is quite close to modern western views?

You've provided a handy crib for the final questions!I think (but then of course I've been brainwashed by the Enlightenment) that it's odd to hear a western academic arguing that the western tradition doesn't include historical research, study and cooperation with other scholars, but only autonomous thought. Surely our views are formed both by our upbringing and our education and it's only when, as Kant puts it, we leave our nonage that we start to apply reason. Confucius deliberately narrows his learning to arbitrarily-chosen texts from a past dynasty without troubling about their morality or veracity. He is specifically looking for an unquestionable model, which leads me to wonder whether his interest is more political than philosophical.

> 3.3 The Master said, "A man who is not *ren*Ñwhat has he to do with ritual? A man who is not *ren*Ñwhat has he to do with music?"*Ren* as touchstone. Even *if* one is doing Zhou ritual and listening to Zhou music, without *ren*, it's still barbaric.

We can also see how WU Wei works in public speaking. When you are presenting your ideas in front of a crowd, lecturing a large group of students, etc., you have to be yourself, forget about fear and feel relaxed. Otherwise you will lose your confidence and care too much about your performance. I think this video is illuminating and provides me a new angle to see Chinese philosophy. Many thanks!

There's a lot of evidence in the Analects that Kongzi was something of a skeptic about the existence of ancestors and spirits.* I love this angle. It opens onto the view that Kongzi held the rituals as important for their *secular* effects--harmonizing individuals into an elegantly choreographed, pro-social society--while being analogous to an "atheist" all the while.**It makes sense for China. The rituals *are* communal at heart--and even the invitation to the ancestors to come and enjoy the food, wine, music, dance, and family togetherness serves the pro-social function of *expanding the sense of family beyond the living/dead divide,* and embedding the living in a much vaster canvas of secular time. Now picture an atheist in a Christian country (or any Abrahamic one, possibly), saying, "I don't believe in God, Jesus, the Resurrection, or Salvation--but it's *essential* that we keep going to church to perform the Mass and observe the Liturgical Calendar." Since the ritual here connects *not* human to humans, but one individual human soul to the Trinity and Eternal Heaven, it *doesn't* make sense to me, and couldn't serve, the way Kongzi's rituals did, to civilize a declining society.This is one of the most relevant aspects of Confucianism to our times, for me. It points to the possibility that religious rituals need no metaphysical or dogmatic underpinnings to better society, and at the same time make it more enjoyable, through a different kind of "church service."--*cf. relevant passages from the *Analects* below. **And I'm aware this is not clear-cut, so just play with the *possibility* that it's accurate.--**Confucius as "Agnostic": Supporting Passages from the *Analects***(note: These are from Simon Leys' translation, simply because they're easier to copy/paste from my files.)2.18 The Master said: ÒZilu, I am going to teach you what knowledge is. To know when you know something, and to know when you do not know something: that is knowledge.Ó5.13 Zigong said: ÒOur MasterÕs views on culture can be gathered, but it is not possible to hear his views on the nature of things and on the way of Tian.Ófrom 6.22 Fan Chi asked about wisdom. The Master said: ÒSecure the rights of the people; respect gods and ghosts, but keep them at a distance -- this is wisdom indeed.Ó7.21 The Master never talked of: miracles; violence; disorders; spirits.11.12 Zilu asked how to serve the spirits and the gods. The Master said: ÒYou are not yet able to serve men, how could you serve spirits?ÓZilu said: ÒMay I ask you about death?Ó The Master said: ÒYou do not yet know life; how could you know death?Ó3.12 (Slingerland transl.) ÒSacrifice as if [they were] presentÓ means that, when sacrificing to the spirits, you should comport yourself as if the spirits were present.The Master said, ÒIf I am not fully present at the sacrifice, it is as if I did not sacrifice at all.Ó

column25: @DanielLeong,Great question. If I hear you right, you're saying "Human wuwei is to be out of tune with nature. They do it effortlessly."In the best Zhuangzi way possible, I laugh as I think. You're clearly on to something with some truth in it.But then I think of Climate Change, and our "rearranging deck chairs on the Titanic" response to its threat to bring an end to civilization for, at extreme estimates, several thousand years (see Brookings Institute's "Climatic Cataclysm," 2009), and from that point of view I think I'd answer our default wuwei is over-valued. We need to get back to effortless balance with nature, imho.
It's a great practice. It helps you be more aware of moments you wouldn't think much about otherwise

@Barbra9, like you, I'm an American who's lived in Confucian Asia (China, Korea, Singapore) for 14 years, so I hear you. If you haven't read PJ Ivanhoe's recent "Confucian Reflections: Ancient Wisdom for Modern Times," I think you'd enjoy it. He tends to imply--and I follow him--that there's much the West could stand to adapt from Chinese culture, perhaps because in many ways Confucian culture *is* "better." It's an interesting challenge to entertain. Much of it is persuasive, to me.
Yup, Dougma, I agree. I think Confucius' intent is completely understandable, but his rigidity is a turn-off.

Yes! Definitely agree, I think both have a lot to offer, and this course *is* helping, at least me, to understand my eastern heritage and habits a bit more. And hearing other people's input is helping me sort out some of my cultural confusion :PBeing honest and sharing opinions--yeah, I'd say that's a big difference. I almost always give nondescript or indirect answers to questions, and I think that really throws people off hahaha. It's actually something I didn't realize I was doing until recently. Edited to add: @FiveWillows, it's funny you say that, because I think I value western culture more! I think the West's openness and tolerance is a great thing, and its emphasis on individualism means that people can pursue their own desires (which results in more creativity). I have no idea which culture, or if there is any culture, that is objectively better, just my own thoughts.

I'll add that the American South, my native culture, shows aspects of this ritual warmth--but with the sad caveat that it too often applies only to those perceived as "white, straight, and Christian." (And I said "too often," not "always.")

If you're an artist or someone who is simply interested or knows a lot about art, you *do* come think of art as the expression of the creator. But most people don't fall under that category.To be fair, I think a lot of (contemporary??) China thinks the same way when it comes to art, or maybe values it less (my only source for this is being Chinese-American). Confucius may be a bit of an outlier here.

One of the most questionable trends in Western education--I teach high school--is the "personalized learning" bandwagon. "Let the students decide what they want to learn. Down with traditional canons of learning."I'm aware of the pitfalls of canonical learning in the West. But to celebrate letting fourteen-year-olds decide what their education should be? Given that freedom in other forms of cultivation--diet, for example--would surely see an increase in chocolate for breakfast, lunch, and dinner.The distressing thing is that adult educators are actually championing this. We're so unmoored from any sense of *a* proper Way our young should develop, our educational authorities are now essentially throwing up their hands and saying "let them decide." **Worse still,** these same "innovators" are also rallying for kids taking online learning--"personalized and self-paced"--instead of learning alongside others, in relation with a flesh-and-blood teacher to guide and respond as they learn.Think of all the lone students of the internet--or even of canonical texts--unguided by teachers who can help them evaluate the soundness of all they read.And Òto think without learningÓ (2.15)Ñ-I prefer "think without studying" in this instanceÑ-seems to point to those who celebrate ÒoriginalityÓ and Òcreative, outside the boxÓ thinking.I read the Òwithout learningÓ as, more precisely, Òwithout studying traditionÕs storehouse of thought.Ó Go ahead, re-invent the wheel. Odds are, the original wheel is better-designed because generations of thinkers ÒlearnedÓ from earlier wheel-designers.

(Has someone already asked this?) I think of de with the same wariness that I think of karma--I think it's often true on the small scale, but not sure about the large scale, such as kings with de being able to rule whole kingdoms peacefully.  Though I can think of some possible examples of people with de--Mother Theresa, Mahatma Gandhi, the current Dalai Lama (well, I guess technically he was always the Dalai Lama, if you are Buddhist).I think de is true if you are actually familiar with the person. But when the person is as remote to you as the ruler of your country, does de have the same effect?

@Dougma, consider the two respective traditions faced by Kongzi and the Enlightenment. Christendom was obviously untenable intellectually (Copernicus and Galileo, Inquisition), socially (corrupt and caste-based church officials of the First Estate and Vatican), politically (Divine Right for degenerate kings, Divine Law based on dogma, not justice), on and on. Of *course* the Enlightenment said "trash it all and let's start from scratch--with a bit of Platonism and Aristotelianism thrown in."Before turning to Kongzi's inherited tradition, let's review your characterization of it:> Confucius deliberately narrows his learning to arbitrarily-chosen texts from a past dynasty without troubling about their morality or veracity. He is specifically looking for an unquestionable model, which leads me to wonder whether his interest is more political than philosophical. Any reader of the *The Book of Documents* knows it is political philosophy of the first order, by no means "arbitrary," and of astonishingly impressive morality--especially given that it was contemporary with the far less ethical and historically verifiable *Hebrew Bible.* Only a grounding in its political *and cultural* views--particularly on *music*--can open on how non-"arbitrary" the *Book of Odes* was as a second anchor to civilizing culture.If you open yourself to reading those two works (and also notice that Kongzi by no means took an "unquestioning" stance toward them, as a careful read of the *Analects* clearly demonstrates), you should find it easier to entertain the idea that Kongzi's tradition deserved the opposite of the trashing so deserved by medieval Christendom; it deserved nothing short of defense and revival.His interest was not "*more* political than philosophical." It was both, and more, equally. The political model of Yao, Shun and Yu, and of Wen, Wu, and the Duke, encompassed good governance, healthy ethics, justice, refined culture. It's far more rational than you seem to understand. (And the Enlightenment, by the way, was very, very influenced by Jesuit and Dominican reports of China's political system and its Confucianism. There are books on this.)

@asifwecanchoose, great response. It's the extremists--who do exist with increasing frequency--who scare me.I agree to your view of a blend, with guidance and rigor, and balanced with the traditional "pastoral" confidence that we adults should expose youths with certain fields of knowledge and understanding regardless of their personal preferences (my principal called "not knowing what you don't know" "second-level ignorance," which I liked, and which applies here).I think the dilemma involves the erosion of any traditional "core curriculum" that comes as the "opportunity cost" of personalized learning. Whatever non-traditional learning is added requires the removal of part of that "core."But to add to the irony, our "core" is so "vessel"-oriented--"become a tool for some job so you can make money doing something you don't love"--that it's of questionable value in cultivating efficacious adults in the first place. Homo Economicus and character education are two very different things.But again, the "learning by doing" example you give with your coding course is well-taken. It does inculcate certain virtues, for sure. I just wish more social and ecological virtues (yes, climate change is an urgency I think our kids should be shaped to deal with), instead of economic ones, were cultivated as well.

The philosophically meaty sections of the Changes are mostly Han, so I'm dealing with them in this course (we've also got to make choices...)

Is De just another way of saying someone has Charisma & emotional intelligence? Which certain leaders and public figures have as well as some individuals you meet in everyday life.In the case of Kings and rulers and China during the Dynasty eras, it could be they had these qualities or could it be more like modern day North Korea, where the population are told the leader is almost supernatural and to disagree would be suicidal.This is not to say that certain individuals do seem to have something 'special' about them. And others can be altruistic without being charismatic.

@asifwecanchoose: I think it's a question of degree. Very complex stuff, and I'm groggy from an all-night study session, but shorthand:Individualism is surprisingly strong in Confucianism and Daoism. This comes clearer when the individual's creative relation to the traditions (think calligraphy, poetry, opera, etiquette, music) is encountered in the traditional writings. The Tea Ceremony host is another great example: *within* the traditional role is a vast range of individual expressive freedom--"creativity." Ditto calligraphy. TS Eliot wrote an essay called "Tradition and the Individual Talent" that I've entirely forgotten in my decades since reading it in college, but now want to return to in this context.Tolerance in Confucian East Asia is also--especially in religious terms--far stronger than in monotheistic cultures. Outside of revolutionary millennarian cults rising in China's history with rebellions that provoked military responses, Confucianism and Daoism show no tendency toward the religious warfare that the West has seen from Joshua's Biblical times to the Crusades of Medieval (and, some would argue, contemporary) times. Tibet and Xinjiang, some will counter. I'd rebut that these are domestic political challenges--separatist movements that any government would resist (cf. American Civil War)--and not religious intolerance. Individual freedom of speech and expression? *Less* tolerated in today's China (and Singapore and Korea), but *far more* tolerated than the Western media suggests. Complaints against the government are common in Chinese social media. Calls for its overthrow or the end of the one-party system, being (reasonably, in my most charitable moods) interpreted as "treason," are not tolerated. But that takes us to questions of politics and national sovereignty.And I would rather live in a society that did not allow Mikki Anaj or whatever her name is to pollute our children with songs like "Anaconda." That's the Confucian in me. Culture *does* shape society, so an individual's freedom to fill it with degeneracy is not a simple matter to me. But it's complex, like everything else in our age. :P
Yes, the junzi is moral in a completely wu-wei fashion
The mindset in early China exemplifies the maxim "The good of the Many outweighs the good of the one."

One girl, 16, did calligraphy and taijiquan. Another did Chinese dance. They also dominate our school orchestra disproportionately, compared to the Western student body. One piece of anecdotal evidence.

It does sound like charisma, doesn't it? Some differences seem to be that we think of charisma as an innate quality, not something that can be learned, while de is something that is achieved through Virtue. Charisma is also kind of a neutral trait, while De is this idealistic idea that "If you are Good, the people will follow you," which is why I thought of Gandhi. I guess it's the idealism that makes me doubtful hahaha.

I'm American, but China has been home for six years and extended weeks-long culture visits multiple times per year since. I have high school nieces and nephews in the States.If art is *making* things--doing it--it's much more central to lived life than in America. And by no means only for the elite. Chinese farmers are amazing in what they can make. Paper-cutting is a great example, but so is the artistry of their food presentation, knot-tying, woodcarving, and many other folk arts. They also dance, sing, and play bamboo flutes, perform in folk ceremony ensembles requiring little advanced musical training, on and on.(Man, do they sing freely, loudly, and often. I told a couple of aunties over dinner at my taiji school in Wudangshan last summer, in my toddler Mandarin, "Chinese sing so much! Americans never sing the way you guys do. We're too self-conscious." An auntie answered, "We like to drink, and we like to sing!" I loved her. China is to me the Italy of Asia. Pure gusto for life.)One major cultural cause seems pretty easy to identify: they're less rich than Westerners, so they can't buy their diversions. They have to enact them themselves. Another is that "old"--tradition--is not "old-fashioned," "uncool," the way it's been in the West since Madison Avenue discovered advertising "the New!" and disparaging the "old" was a way to increase sales.

The more I look at that statement:  "Who is able to leave without going through the door"  the more I feel that it has been misinterpreted.  These interpretations remind me of many of the interpretations of bible passages.  Many different opinions.

Sorry about tardy response, Geoffrey. Gatto is interesting--years ago I spent a few weeks sounding him out. Sometimes he sounds a bit too anti-state for my tastes, but on the other hand that depends on the quality of the state education system. So I take that back: the "kidnapping" of the child by state schools, *when inhumane*, is unfortunate. But in our Western culture, where "traditionalism" so often means "religious home-schooling" in all its anti-scientific glory, I'm not as confident that families can educate their kids with any better effect. So I've just slid from "bad state" to "bad family" because of "bad tradition." I find it hard to be a Conservative about most American traditions.I would find it very, very easy to be a Conservative in a culture with wiser traditions. That's why I have no problem with Confucius' conservatism. I've read the Confucian Classics. I see why he insisted they were curative to the Eastern Zhou's decline.I'd trust my kids in state schools with values and practices like that.
So how would you have it interpreted?

What, as a modern woman, should I take away from Confusiansim if the original conception was exclusive to women?  When younger, if I read something that used male pronouns or the characters were male, I always assumed that meant me, too. I have learned that this isn't actually the intent in many cases. My gut reaction is that the lessons are just as applicable to me, but I wonder if I really should believe that if I am to understand the true nature of the philosophy/religion. Second question,Did Confucius believe that women couldn't be perfected? Does that mean they can't be Chinese, and by extension human? You mentioned his views very briefly in this lecture, so I'm wondering if I'm understanding that right.

column25: Dr. Slingerland brought up in the introduction and initial module that religion served humanity during the transition between smaller packs of clan and kin based groups to larger, complex societies filled with anonymous interactions by providing a normative framework beyond kinship and reciprocal altruism. He also said that no where in history or present day has there been such a radically unrooted lifestyle structure as in North America, where individuals are encouraged and expected to separate from their hometowns and families for perhaps their entire lives. I wonder if by extension this means that "WEIRD" people are in great(er?) need of a normative framework like our course's definition of religion, and how this will converge with the increasing secularism of the West.What is anyone else's thoughts on this?
column35: Do "WEIRD" people need religion more than ever?

Many translators have started rendering terms like "junzi" as "exemplary person", for instance, and otherwise tried to render the texts gender-neutral. This is historically inaccurate, but in terms of what Confucianism can mean for us today I think we can re-understand it in a way that better fits our modern sense of gender-equality. Confucius himself didn't seem to believe that women could become junzi, but he also thought that we should practice only Western Zhou ritual, and we're obviously not about to do that. I think many of the important take-home lessons of early Confucianism can be applied by any of us to our lives today independent of the original historical context.

How interesting that you raise these questions. There appear to have been exceptional women in every period and country who have managed to defy what was expected of them as the norm in relation to education and ability. Most did not have the tenacity or wherewithal to step outside the norm. How fortunate are we (those who are able to participate in this course) to be able to study as broadly and deeply as any man and assume that we will attain an understanding of the material and be able to apply it in our everyday lives as much as any man. Unfortunately there are women in some countries where this is still not possible and perhaps even prevented. Regardless of when a body of knowledge devoted, it is always a matter of access to the knowledge not whether or not we can attain mastery of it that matters. Even in his time surely not all men could master what Confucius proscribed either.

My first thought was that people instinctively find or create a group to belong to (religious or secular).  Supporters of a sports team, for example, create a society  in microcosm with their own dress codes, language, future goals (the success or their team), rituals etc. They create transient alliances with other teams in situations where the victory of a particular team with also benefit their team...

How frustrating that my post got lost in a technology glitch trying to submit it but I will try and paraphrase what I wrote.My post was in relation to dress. The correct form of dress was very important to Confucius - in what it told those around you and of course what you believed yourself to be. Some cultures still adhere to strict forms of dress probably for similar reasons and are viewed negatively if cultural norms are not observed. I would just like to reflect that western dress in particular has become so varied and stretched so many boundaries that it mostly no longer communicates a norm. I don't advocate uniform dress but we have lost a powerful tool which once communicated a lot about a person eg judges, lawyers, doctors used to dress appropriate to their roles in some cases but hardly do today. It is more far reaching in that many of us favour unisex clothing of tops and trousers (jeans), 'outlandish' clothing is more acceptable, and so on. There are hardly any norms any more. What impact is that having on communication within western and Asian culture? I believe we also use dress to communicate who we are but what are we now saying to each other? Perhaps Confucius had a point even though it seems incredibly pedantic now.

Once again, I met a striking similarity between Chinese concepts and Javanese ones, especially in the concept of "wen". Prof. Slingerland had elaborated further that one can "become Chinese" by acquiring "Chineseness", by internalizing its culture and practising it. The Javanese has similar views: they see their values and code of conducts as THE proper way of being cultured, being proper human being. The Javanese had a saying that foreigner or even a Javanese child who is not acculturated enough in Javanese way be called "durung njawani", literally meaning "had not yet Javanese". And they use that term "njawani" or "being Javanese" referring to generally "cultured people". So everybody had chance to being Javanese, such as German jesuit priest [Franz-Magnis Suseno][1] who became Indonesian citizen and studied and practised Javanese culture deep enough that the Javanese people themselves had fully accepted him as a Javanese person. And, although a bit trivial (but might be important), I found similar tendencies in how the Chinese and the Javanese usurped foreign vocabularies into their language, not just merely loan-words. One could say that the words are being "Chinesized" or "Javanisized" (sorry, this is an entirely made up words of my own perhaps).Now I'm wondering how cultural interaction between Java and China had actually been. It is known that Chinese merchants (and influences?) had been present in Java since at least 600-800 CE, but there's no record of their direct influences, and instead, we Javanese more often linked our roots back to Hinduism, and earlier, Buddhism. (yes, in Java, Buddhism had arrived earlier than Hinduism)  [1]: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Franz_Magnis-Suseno

I agree, and would add the "visual *de*" element touched on in PJ Ivanhoe's *Confucian Reflections: Ancient Wisdom for Modern Times* (I think Prof. Ivanhoe taught Prof. Slingerland). Ivanhoe cites studies of hospital interior design that show that drab, institutional design actually makes patients less healthy, while visually pleasing design improves patient health.What the humans surrounding us wear--how they strike our eyes--seems a similar case. James Howard Kunstler, a human geographer and former Rolling Stone journalist who blogs at Kunstler.com, often pillories American adult male fashion, in particular, for its eyesore, juvenile, "walking advertisement" style: NFL team on chest, baseball team on cap (sideways!), big goofy tennis shoes, long shorts, etc. He mentions how refreshing his trips to Europe are, where young males seem to understand that "looking like a respectable adult" is a socially enhancing thing.Random add: I was in Thailand years ago, and the King was seriously ill. The Thai people love their king, and to help him heal, they all wore yellow the week I was there. Bangkok was a sea of pedestrians as yellow as a sunflower field. Anyone can become a junzi, but it takes time.Analects, 2.4:The Master said, "At fifteen, I had my mind bent on learning. At thirty, I stood firm. At forty, I had no doubts. At fifty, I knew the decrees of Heaven. At sixty, my ear was an obedient organ for the reception of truth. At seventy, I could follow what my heart desired, without transgressing what was right."

Of course Enlightenment thinking did not throw everything overboard - you wildly exaggerate and distort western intellectual history. Did the Enlightenment abandon Copernicus and Galileo or the Renaissance? One can make a case that Descartes' cogito was the introduction of subjectivism into philosophy and argue that that was a negative development, but he does not by himself represent the Enlightenment and its consequences.You instruct me, a little patronisingly I felt, to open myself to the Book of Documents and the Book of Odes, and assert that 'Any reader of the Book of Documents knows it is political philosophy of the first order..'. Plainly it is vitally important and fascinating source material about early China and a gold-mine for scholars, but we do not know why it was written or, in the case of parts of it, when, and to describe it as political philosophy seems to me to be stretching a point. Its adoption by Confucius and other philosophers has often meant it has been incorporated into their philosophies, but the very fact that they can disagree about it suggests to me that it itself does not offer a coherent philosophy. As far as the Book of Odes is concerned it is equally fascinating as a source, and contains some beautiful poems, but I cannot see it as necessarily iconic - were no worthy poems being written  or collected after the Western Zhou? Of course there were. This is my difficulty with Confucius - he is didactic rather than forensic and tends to be dismissive of everything he cannot locate in the Western Zhou. I acknowledge of course that we have comparable difficulty with sources about Confucius as we do with earlier texts. I'm sorry you think I don't understand the political wisdom of Yao and the rest, but I shall continue to regard them, whatever their historical existence may have been, as the products of China's philosophical tradition not its progenitors. I don't have any major problems with anything Professor Slingerland said. I think he is providing an interesting course for a wide variety of people and this requires him to look for attention-grabbing strategies to connect the subject, which is little known in the west, with the modern world. I doubt he really thinks an Apple slogan encapsulates what 'we' think, but it's a useful image.

Hi,I am going to respectfully disagree (in a very confucian way, because I only know of this theme that which I learned in this course) with the given meaning of "ren". Although I'm probably wrong I hope that my point of view may help to understand this concept, if not with my argument, at least with a discusion.In the video ÒrenÓ is described as a innate harmony among the different virtues, or like a kind of internal joy. Although I think these interpretations go in the right direction, in my opinion, they are incomplete.I think that "ren" is the hot version of cold logic and I think that I can support this claim on three reasons:First Confucius makes special emphasis on thinking when you are learning, to avoid a simple memorization of the rituals. In my opinion this leads thowards a search for a logical structure and coherence among all learned material. In the case of rituals, this can only be archived through a perception of the emotions involved in it, because, otherwise, it would look pretty ridiculous and make not logical sense at all. So, through this concius acknowledgment of emotions, a link between the cold and hot parts of the brain is stablished.Second, as I see it, this process not only will lead to an explicit internalization of virtues, but also to an implicit internalization of reason and logic. Therefore the total result will not only be a spontanius correct behavior, but also, when confronted with new situations, a quicker process of internalization; until a point when the internalization happens also spontaniusly. This spontaius correct intuition will be percive as an extrange order within the external world, because the concius mind will not be abble to pinpoint the exact line of reasoning. At this point the reward for reflecting on the self will move from an external one, the desire of acquire social skills, to an internal one, trying to understand this extrange order within the external world, and this conects with my third reason.My third reason is that Confucius phylosophy has as ultimate goal to adquire ÒrenÓ. However this concept is presented as vage and mysterius, almost magical. I think that this is done intentionally in order to guide the apprentice toward this concept when confronted with the Òstrange order of the worldÓ. This will help him to see that, in reality, is a Òstrange order within himselfÓ and how he adquired it. At this time he will be abble to beging to **explicitly** internalize reason and logic, or adquire ÒrenÓ. Although Confucius did not write about how this can be done in his lesons, he said:"I will not open the door for a mind that is not already striving to understand,nor will I provide words to a tongue that is not already struggling to speak.**If I hold up one corner of a problem, and the student cannot come back to mewith the other three, I will not attempt to instruct him again.**"

To give to high-school students complete liberty over their curriculum (or their diet!) when they have only ever experienced traditional teaching is clearly a recipe for disaster. However, I think that by cultivating creativity and an interest for learning from an early age, it's possible to have responsible kids who can make very enligthened choices about their studies. I'm thinking here of the Montessori method, for instance, which gives both a lot of freedom and responsibility to small kids.Personally, my education was... a disaster. The classroom was the room I spent time bored to death between my learning sessions at home. I've always learned by myself (or rather with books and, yes, Internet), by following an exemplar: my dad. I think he recognized that the "apprentissage" (which means **both** learning and teaching, in French) is actually done by the student, not the teacher, and so he simply let me have access to the tools of learning, without forcing them on me, just by using them himself. Today, what interested me the most at that time (foreing languages and literature) has become my job, and "formal" education has had very little to do with it.Then again, that's only my experience, each kid is different. Some may need outside structuring, others manage to construct it internally. There's no one-size-fits-all in education, I think.

Agreed, S. And it all depends on so many variables==quality of curriculum, pedagory, teachers, students, more. I hated school too. But taken to an extreme, the personalized learning thing almost blends into "dropping out with a diploma."I think what impelled the original post, and didn't come out successfully, was the erosion of the bond between youth and tradition. When each generation is in its own silo, it's hard to see how there's anything resembling culture instead of mere passing fashion and trend.

As we enter discussion on ritual, I am beginning to teach two Zen students how to conduct daily ceremonies at the Creston Zendo. I'm interested to see that the ritual which has been passed on to me from my Zen teachers and which was formalized by Keizen Jokin in early 14th C Japan, is so rooted in the teachings of Confucius. Yesterday when I gave a dharma talk on the state of mind and body during the enactment of the daily ceremony rituals, the language and views expressed in Module 1 and in Lecture 2.1 were of great help. I was able to talk of why we ask people to dress in a respectful manner when they come to the zendo, to follow what we call zendo etiquette (having to do with bowing and sitting standing and walking posture) and to follow ritualized movement patterns when offering incense or leading sutra recitations. I was able to dicuss the limitations of memorizing movements and timing through cold cognition then performing them by imposing cold cognition on body and mind in a rote kind of way. Instead, I was able to suggest that the students let go of trying to "get it right," and become wu wei so that during the ritual, de has space to enter. I was also given a language with which to express the idea that every action in daily life can, if done with awareness of ritual (organizing pens on a desk, cleaning tools etc.) can be done wu wei and raise the mindspace of de.Thank you.

Socrates, in the Helenic tradition used questions and dialog to construct logic and knowledge through Eros (a kind of universal force that unites, like love for example). Ò Plato's Socrates is searching for knowledge and immortality through an application of the philosophical method, one that relies on a conception of Eros and propagation. For Plato's Socrates, it is through Eros that ancient Greek paideia educates in matters of arte (Virtue), but eros is not a passion for kleos (glory) or for a beautiful young man.Óhttp://scholarcommons.usf.edu/etd/2806/

FiveWillows.  I believe your are mistaken as well.  Some concept in Chinese culture cannot be translated into English.  Spontaneity and wu-wei means very very different thing.  It is not a play of word.  Spontaneity is inborn and do not require any effort to acquire.   Wu-wei needs cultivation (the so-called trying not to try). We need some rigor in analyzing Chinese culture and cannot simply use our free interpretation.   Virtue in the Chinese Ru (Confucianism) means the five qualities I mention.  De is not one of them.   De though mentioned in confucianism , is not as fully acscribed to as is in Daoism.As for the third point, taking the two expressions as being said at different stage of Kongzi's life is incorrect.   The Book of changes described and predicted how the world changes.   That is why, "When I reached 50 years of age and study the Book of Changes, I will not make any major error" as described in Book 7 and "At 50 I understood heaven's mandate...." as described in Book 2 do not contradict one another.  It is the interpretation that "Kongzi understand "things so perfectly he now no longer had any doubts" that causes concern - making a humble historical sage into an arrogant person.

I can't help but ponder on the concept of 'once you know the rules you can break them'. Until we can absorb a set of cultural ideals, rules or rituals, understand and use them, we can't truly know the why of them. It's only then perhaps that deep reflection and thinking on possible changes that may be beneficial to our own life, family or wider social structure should be attempted. Confucius appears to do just that with the Western Zhou traditions. Surely most people seek a way to live comfortably and peaceably within their own culture and that means learning the cultural norms before adding the layer of individualism.

I also directly thought about learning to drive a car with manual gear change, but from a slightly different perspective:When I learned driving, I was taught that I had to listen to the gear sound and shift only when the gear has been driven out. That soon became an automatism of which I never had to think about again.But quite some years ago now I had to actively relearn the process of shifting, as the old way is wasting fuel and causing quicker wearout, and one rather should change the gear earlier. So again gear shifting became part of my cold cognition, before I was used to the new way, and it was in my hot cognition again.I see that kind of mastering things naturally as highly desirable, when one wants to be good at what one is doing, like for instance behaving properly and well in society, for smooth craftsmanship, performing art or music, doing sports and more. But not everything can follow automatisms, or can it? Sometimes one is simply not prepared, due to new situations. And while the automatisms might still help to orient quicker, you could need to even surprise yourself to get to a solution.

I think the difference between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, although popular in Western psychology, is really quite untenable when I think about it. It seems to rely more on our value judgements about what types of activities people should value in themselves rather than anything profound about people's motivation. For example in the case of chess, why should the child's motivation for playing chess based on getting candy be more extrinsic than playing chess for its own sake? If the child get intrinsic enjoyment from eating candy and the child has authentically decided that the most enjoyable way to get the candy is to play chess, wouldn't this be an example of intrinsic motivation? And conversely if the child is playing chess for the sake of learning and challenge and expansion of logical facilities which could arguably be attained through for example solving maths puzzles instead, isn't this an extrinsic motivation rather than an intrinsic one? At the end of the day, you can always trace the cause of an event further and further back and the point at which we stop and say now the activity is "intrinsic" seems to be  arbitrary to me...? What do you think?

I like the idea of the art of archery, and how it relates to finding "the mean." Finding the center of the target is like finding the center of balance within yourself. I recently took up the sport of curling, which also has a target for scoring. The closest team wins points, and it is far less individual that the practice of archery, but I think it could be analogous to Confucian cultivation in some respects. For example, there is ritual involved in the game, for we begin each match with a handshake, and by wishing each other, "good curling." It keeps the game, and the people more friendly toward each other. Delivering the stone is closest to the sort of self cultivation that archery provides. You have to line up your shot and use the proper weight to get the stone where you need it to go. As a sweeper, you have to be aware of the weight that the stone has after it is released, and you have to watch the skip to make sure you are sweeping at the right time. The team who finds the proper balance should come away with a win. Does anyone think this is good? Have I left anything out?

But I could not experience this expansion of mental relaxation and as a result physical rejuvenation until I learned the very precise forms of movement. At the same time, also is my experience in China, as of yet, there is little to no "breaking of the rules" to find new discoveries, though in some parts of the highly educated areas, the door for this is opening.

What would be the difference, I wonder? - "between virtue as something you can practice when you have the occasion and simply something that you simply have to do continuously".  Aren't they, in fact, the same thing?  In both cases, we act on virtue; to act on virtue continuously in all occasion.  That, to me, is the ultimate aim - spiritual development, virtue development, moral development...at all times, with all people, in all occasions.  What do you think?

The Sanzijing is a good example of the Song neo-Confucian orthodoxy that was very much influenced by Mencius, but at certain points has little connection with (or actively contradicts) the Analects. I'll talk more about this later in the class.

Yes, although I wanted to argue against neo-Orientalist ideas of the Chinese as radically different and holistic, they certainly had a much more embodied view of cognition (and therefore an empirically more realistic view of cognition) than, say, post-Enlightenment thinkers, or Plato. But you can find this kind of embodied view, too, in Aristotle, Nietzsche, or the American pragmatists. So it's not strictly an East-West thing, it's about what's been emphasized most recently.

That last point was the same point my friend made about the issue. I was carrying on about how Kongfuzi must have considered women to be subhuman, since he was convinced they were not capable of being jungzi and this Dao was what separated humans from animals. My friend pointed out that many people at that time could not attain that state even with access to the knowledge. Kongfuzi himself was humble about his own ability to reach this ideal state, and he probably didn't think of himself as subhuman. This perspective somewhat placated me.I also share your relief at being born into a society where women have equal access to knowledge and education. While Western society still has areas to grow, it's got its good points.

A Denver Confucian--non-Asian--pushes back against the "rigid" stereotype of Kongzi here:> 6.5 When Yuan Si was serving as steward, he was offered a salary of nine hundred measures of millet,4 but he declined it. The Master said, ÒDo not decline it! [If you do not need it yourself], could you not use it to aid the households in your neighborhood?Ó>Most commentators explain that the disciple Yuan Si was appointed to be steward of ConfuciusÕ household while Confucius was serving as Minister of Justice in Lu. Again, this is probably not historically accurate, and it is more likely that Yuan SiÕs employer is one of the Three Families. Some commentators see the point of this passage to be simply that, once one has accepted a position, it is improper to decline the salary that goes along with it, but there is probably a bit more to it than that.>Reading this passage together as a partner to 6.4, and seeing it in light of the many injunctions against seeking office for the sake of material benefit found in ConfuciusÕ teachings, the disciple Yuan Si no doubt expected to be praised by the Master for declining to be paid a salary.>The point of ConfuciusÕ response is that the proper course of action cannot be determined by a simple formula, but should be the result of careful reflection and consideration of the needs of others.>Based on Yuan SiÕs one other appearance in 14.1, as well as later legends that sprung up around him, he seems to have been one of the excessively ÒfastidiousÓ (juan ) who Confucius complains about in 13.21: his obsession with remaining unsullied prevents him from effectively engaging with the world.>-what strikes me here is the flexibility of the Master. The way can't simply be reduced to an easy formula. We have think and feel what is the best course in any situation.And Belgian Sinologist Simon Leys also pushes back on the "rigid" stereotype in the "Introduction" to his translation of the *Analects*:> modernity of Confucius is an aspect which, paradoxically, non-Chinese readers may perhaps be in a better position to appreciate. The only advantage that can be derived from our condition of ignorant foreigners is precisely the possibility to look with a kind of unbiased innocence at this book--as if it were all fresh and new. Such innocence is denied to native readers. For them, the Analects is [a mere] Òclassic" (xvi- xvii)....>Over the centuries, the official Confucian cult has created a conventional image of the Master, and as a result, many people have tended to imagine him as a solemn old preacher, always proper, a bit pompous, slightly boring--one of these men who Òpush moderation too far.Ó In refreshing contrast with these common stereotypes, the Analects reveals a living Confucius that constantly surprises (p. xviii).Those surprises come most easily when reading scholars such as Robert Eno, Roger Ames, PJ Ivanhoe, Henry Rosemont, Jr., and our own Dr. Slingerland. They've looked at Kongzi for decades, and have so much to show us. I've only looked at him for five years. Kongzi is probably my favorite thinker of all time--and I spent four years as a Western philosophy major and grad student. Only Nietzsche comes close to Kongzi for me.

Yes, I talk about this a bit in Chapter Two of Trying Not to Try: in the absence of formal, society-wide frameworks, yet needing frameworks of some kind, we modern secular people cobble together frameworks out of bits and pieces of some older religions (a little Kabbala here, a little Buddhism there), sports-team affiliations, brand affiliations, and then lifestyle tribe identifications (hipster, soccer mom, etc.)

It's a shame we didn't have time in Module 2 to talk about Zigong, whom Confucius dismisses at one point as a "vessel" (in contemporary idiom, a "tool"). This is because he has mastered the virtue of "zhong" (in the Analects, something like role-specific virtue) but not "shu" (sympathetic understanding, or flexibility). The perfected junzi has both, and it's clear in the Analects that Confucius thought shu was the harder of the two paired virtues. One this topic, see P.J. Ivanhoe, ÒReweaving the Ôone threadÕ of the Analects,Ó Philosophy East and West, 40.1 (January,1990): 17-33.

In Lecture 2.6, much is said about the Confucian model of internalizing virtuous behaviors. This includes going for the mean - not too high nor too low. In his Nicomachean Ethics, Aristotle also talks about internalizing virtues such that they become second nature to us. He also talks about the golden mean - having the right amount of a virtue. For example, having too much generosity makes us a spendthrift, and having too little makes us stingy. Therefore we shoot for the golden mean. Confucius lived approximately 150 years prior to Aristotle. My question for Professor Slingerland is: Is it possible that Aristotle somehow had access to the Analects of Confucius, or were these two philosophical systems developed independently?Also, am I being a little too unlearned in believing that these two systems are very much alike?

In the course Prof. Slingerland talks about Confucius and the Ru teaching the classics.These being the book of odes (songs), and the book of documents (history). According toLittlejohn R.L. 'An Introduction to Confucianism' ....the Ru practiced the six arts or the six forms of learning, with one of each embodied in the six classics.  The six classics being the classic of poetry (songs), of history (documents), of rites, of music, of changes, and the spring and autumn annals.  Am I missing something?

@NMarzian I confess to having a bit of a splenetic response on hearing the word 'we' in intellectual discussions. I think it's true that individualism is an increasing force in western culture, but, as the Professor I think noted in an earlier lecture, it may be more marked in north America than the rest of the west. That said it remains interesting to grapple with the undoubted sharp distinction between the Enlightenment and Confucian systems.My visceral reaction to 'we-ism' also led me to wonder about how individualistic westerners really are. Contemplating the lecturer's example of the Apple slogan I mused on the number of advertisements we see that urge us in just this way to demonstrate our individuality by buying the mass-produced article which all our peers are also buying. Are all the admen closet Confucianists seeking to insert their products into our 'hot' cognition?Nothing against Apple of course - I couldn't do the course without them!

I don't believe he was speaking for himself -- for his personal image or popularity. I believe he was speaking for and at the behest of the police department, which would have benefitted by improving its public image (thereby improving confidence in the police force (if we wish to be generous with respect to motivation...)) and possibly by helping the homeless through the contagion effect we are learning about. The officer may have chosen to speak for one or both these reason. Or he may not actually have had a choice -- he may have been ordered by his bosses.

The New York Times just published an article that hits on exactly what I'm getting at above:> G.G..: How can you be an agnostic and still claim to be a Catholic?>g.g.: Because, despite my agnosticism, I still think itÕs worth pursuing the question of whether God exists, and for me the Catholic intellectual and cultural tradition has great value in that pursuit.>G.G.: Still, I donÕt see how you can find a place in a church that claims to be the custodian of a divine revelation, when you donÕt believe in that revelation.>g.g.: The fundamental revelation is the moral ideal expressed in the biblical account of ChristÕs life. Whether or not that account is historically accurate, the New Testament Christ remains an exemplar of an impressive ideal. Engagement with the practices (ethical and liturgical) inspired by that ideal is the only requirement for being a Catholic. Beyond that, historical narratives and theological doctrines can at least function as useful means of understanding, even for those who arenÕt prepared to say that they are true in any literal sense. Some believers may have experiences (or even arguments) that have convinced them that these doctrines are true. But religions Ñ even Catholicism Ñ should have room for those who donÕt see it that way.>G.G.: So it seems that you agree with most of your interviewees Ñ believer and nonbelievers Ñ that practice is more important than doctrine.>g.g.: Yes, and I agree with Kitcher that the greatest obstacle facing atheism is its lack of the strong communal practices that characterize religions. People need to believe something that provides a satisfying a way of living their lives, and most people need to find this in a community. So far atheism has produced nothing like the extensive and deep-rooted communities of belief that religion has.>http://opinionator.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/10/13/notes-on-an-unanswerable-question/?_php=true&_type=blogs&_php=true&_type=blogs&_r=1&Interesting, but I still can't see how the practice of Christian rites and liturgies hold a candle to the more social and this-worldly alternative of the Zhou rites Confucius advocated.

We would like to apologize. The answer choices for this question are indeed confusing. This happened because some of our questions were originally composed with lettered choices, but the edX system does not use letters, and it randomizes the answer order. We did not have time to adequately re-word this particular answer set before the Module launched.Here is an explanation: the quote in the question reflects a certain type of philosophy, relating to human nature and our tendency to rely on external teachers. The question is asking whether the quote looks like something from Confucian philosophy, something from European Enlightenment philosophy, something from BOTH these philosophies, or something from NEITHER of these philosophies. I hope that clears things up a bit. In the future, please post questions like this in the Questions for Staff thread.-Robin

This sounds like a reasonable argument to me. In our common usage, however, "intrinsic" and "extrinsic" motivation simply relate to the most immediate effect of an action. With regard to a child playing chess for candy: because candy is the immediate motivating outcome, and candy can be obtained in many other ways as well, we say the action is extrinsically motivated, even though actually eating the candy is pleasurable in its own right. With regard to a child playing chess to improve technical problem-solving abilities: yes, I would also agree that this qualifies as an example extrinsic motivation. Ideally, all of our actions *can* be traced to some intrinsic satisfaction (otherwise, why are we doing them?), or at least perhaps to avoidance of that which is intrinsically dissatisfying. We just use the term "extrinsic" as a heuristic for thinking about the quality of the immediate outcome.

The Governor of She declared to Confucius: "Among my people, there is a man of unbending integrity: when his father stole a sheep, he denounced him." Confucius said: "Among my people, men do things differently: a father covers up for his son, a son covers up for his fatherÑand there is integrity in what they do." (Analects 13.18)
Or the same reason Al Gore needs a mansion.

So, if earlier, universally respected thinkers, tell us that the sun revolves around the earth we should--offer sacrifices to them, or what?  And anyone who disagrees should either be immolated or hurled into the wilderness?  Or should we just consider such people sub-human?I don't believe there was thinking or knowledge at any time that should be accepted uncritically.  So, I disagree with Confucius.The lectures pass over very lightly Confucius's attitude towards women, but it's reasonable to think that it's reflective of Zhou thought.This in itself--setting at zero the intellectual potential of half humankind--is enough to discredit all the rest, or at least to show that every word needs to be weighed with extreme skepticism.Actually he, set at zero the value of much more than half of humankind, namely, everyone who wasn't "Chinese" in his thinking (in addition to all women).One result: "100 years of national humiliations," starting in the 1840's.  Because nothing in the Odes and Histories was seen as calling for actions that could accomplish the Industrial Revolution in China.  And the humiliations ended only when the examination system, the focus on the Odes and Histories--and Confucianism as a whole--were pushed firmly into the background.

You didn't really flesh out the problem. Why does it matter whether the sun revolves around the earth, or vice versa?If you want I can pull up just as many examples of original and novel thinkers living in Confucian society. Medieval Korea was an extremely Confucian country and they were able to out-maneuver Japan in naval warfare. Meiji Japan hardly abandoned their commitment to Confucianism when they modernized and knocked away their unfair treaties. You've simply brought up examples of bad practice, but you are failing to go back to the actual principles at hand.

There are so many ways to express "You're welcome"--and a million other forms of etiquette and ceremony--that I don't see "rigidity" as a necessary assumption when thinking about ritual. People that say "You're welcome" rigidly, in fact, don't strike me as "ren."

@takh, sorry, but I'm having a hard time understanding the "When I reached 50 years of age and study the Book of Changes, I will not make any major error" because of the verb tenses. Maybe I misunderstood you the first time around because of that too. "When I reached" means the speaker is older; "I will not" means it hasn't happened yet. More translation problems :)

With resources like MOOCs and Khan Academy home schooling need not be so bad.Baroness Warnock argues that families have to be the ones to inculcate ethics because schools do such a poor job of it. http://vimeo.com/10841193As an MIT business gradute and (to my shame) an ex-McKinsey consultant, I have some sympathy with this. MIT has only just made ethics a part of its core MBA curriculum and even then it uses the "Giving Voice to Values" methodology which IMHO doesn't go far enough (sometimes you do have to get litigous).Interestingly, Warnock argues that we have "to separate morals from religion and to re-inject the language of morality in daily life".

Matthew Stewart makes this point in his critique of the contemporary religion of management: The Management Myth (you get the flavour of it here - http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2006/06/the-management-myth/304883/).

Many thanks for that. I'm afraid I can't reciprocate as my knowledge of China's early history comes from generalised sources, most recently a history by J.A.G.Roberts and the Cambridge Encyclopedia of China.I'm not sure we know enough of the history to know why the Western Zhou fell but, not being a believer myself in the Mandate theory to explain the demise of dynasties, I'm content to think it was likely to have been overthrown by external forces, Like you I see no point in criticising the Zhou for being expansionist, but regimes which extended themselves in the north-west were always vulnerable to a combination of nomadic invaders and dissident Chinese rivals. Pines' thesis that the Zhou emphasis on kinship ties (which according to Roberts is supported by burial practices) suggests that the Zhou may have needed or wanted to protect the interests of a wider swathe of society than just the royal family, but I find it a bit of a jump from there to calling them humanistic.Mencius of course is part of the idealisation of the Western Zhou after the event as is Confucius. I guess we can't know how much of Confucius view was evidential some two hundred years after the fall, but I suppose it ultimately doesn't matter in the light of the fact that the view of the Western Zhou as a golden age became a fact just because so many accepted it. As far as the role of popular welfare as a measure of good government is concerned, it is perhaps a truism that regimes which negatively affect popular welfare anywhere in the world ran into trouble and the history of peasant revolt in China demonstrates this to have been true in China. Confucius seems to recognise this but whether it topped his list of requirements for a ruler is a bit unclear to me. Mao of course would have put the Zhou in the category of feudal rulers who by definition didn't care enough. I wouldn't call Confucius a gullible romantic, but he may still have attached his own ideals onto a convenient hook.
Confucius acted according to heaven's way and therefore what he said was correct from his point of view. It's the same as the fixed values from religions.

Nietzsche and Confucius as favourite philosophers? Sounds like an interesting combination since they are both quite different in their opinion of what the right thing is to do. Nietzsche wants people to act egoistic and Confucius wants them to act (and feel) altruistic. Or do you like Nietzsche for his description of the way people think about morality rather then the Ÿbermensch part?Both have good argumentations of course, but I'd like to hear your opinion on this matter.

Hi FiveWillows,I agree - when I was growing up, I was under the consistent impression that Confucianism was all about rule-bound behaviours and rituals, but it struck me that the Analects frequently warns against rigidity and obdurateness.  It would seem that the Confucian framework does include leeway for people to employ different means to achieve the "junzi" state and Goodness.  Indeed, it seems to me that people in a state of Goodness would naturally just behave in line with ritual, and they would do this without feeling that the ritual requirements are a burden.The way that Prof. Slingerland differentiates between conservative and modern cultures also strikes me as a bit strange.  I would have thought that what differentiates a conservative culture from a modern one is not that the former emphasises the dominance of a single cultural pattern while the latter values difference, but rather that the former emphasises cultural patterns from the past while the latter values newness in cultural patterns.
What are the Classics mentioned by prof?
It could also be related - Isn't it true that from music, one derives joy?

@Liannedj, I should have put Nietzsche in past tense. I still admire his mind, literary style, wit, and much more, but his ethics? Not so much. He was a great physician diagnosing Western cultural, social, and religious history, but not so great at prescribing the cure--extreme individualism and "creativity." (That simplifies him, but doesn't distort him, imho.)Kongzi (balanced by so many other Chinese schools of thought) was an equally gifted pathologist, but a far, far better therapist than Fritz. As I see Kongzi, he teaches "extreme sociality" that is at the same time "creative" and "individualistic"--but again, harmonizing with other individuals, not always playing solo.

This is all over our focus on "hot/cold? and Confucian virtues.(Source: http://dish.andrewsullivan.com/2014/10/25/the-psychology-of-heroes/)>The Psychology Of Heroes>Katy Waldman cites new research on the subject. One finding? Heroes tend not to over-think it:>>In a study out last week in the journal PLOS ONE, Yale researchers recruited more than 300 volunteers to read statements by 51 contemporary Òheroes.Ó These men and women had all received the Carnegie Hero Medal for Òcivilians who risk their lives to save strangersÓ; the experimenters wanted to know whether they had acted without thinking or after exerting Òconscious self-controlÓ in order Òto override negative emotions like fear.Ó>>The volunteersÑand a computer algorithm, for safesiesÑanalyzed the medal winnersÕ statements for evidence of careful thought, or of unpremeditated action. Overwhelmingly, they found that day-savers rescue first and reflect second. As Christine Marty, a 21-year-old student who wrested a trapped senior citizen from her car during a flash flood, said, ÒIÕm thankful I was able to act and not think about it.Ó Study author David Rand noted that people playing economic games are similarly less likely to share resources when they ruminate about their moves, but more generous when they donÕt take time to consider strategy.>Waldman goes on to note previous studies that shed light on the thoughts of altruistic risk-takers:>>In 2005, researchers ran personality tests on 80 Gentiles who risked their lives to shelter Jewish refugees during the Holocaust, as well as 73 bystanders. Two interesting commonalities arose among the ÒheroesÓ: First, they were more likely to embrace, or at least tolerate, danger. Second, they were more likely to say they interacted frequently with friends and family. These findings expanded on a classic 1970 study of 37 Holocaust rescuers, in which researchers determined that the helping Gentiles were animated in part by Òa spirit of adventurousness.Ó (Related but more prosaic: Studies suggest that Òsensation-seekingÓ is positively correlated with the willingness to give blood.) In 1984, scientists John P. Wilson and Richard Petruska determined that Òhigh-esteemÓ college studentsÑthose who believed they were worthy and competentÑmore often rushed to aid an experimenter during a simulated explosion, while Òhigh-safetyÓ students, driven by a need for security and the desire to avoid anxiety, were less likely to lend a hand. In the realm of smaller, but still substantial, risk, 74 percent of kidney donors interviewed for a 1977 study said they put great faith and trust in people, compared with only 43 percent of non-donors.

column25: Of course, I daresay we appreciate the effort!  Just that it may come across as a bit off...your Singlish example is a classic case.  "La" is quite nuanced and can't be used everywhere, and most local speakers seem to just have an instinctive grasp of where it should or should not be used.I'll give another example from my experience as a foreign student in New York City.  I found that a reliable way to make people nervous is for me to try to talk or act "ghetto" (eg. fist bumping).  As a Chinese person, this comes across as awkward or even as politically incorrect.Perhaps the kind of radical openness that you point out in mainland Chinese culture stems from a strong sense of identity and self-confidence?  After all, Chinese culture is much more established and older than Singaporean culture or even US culture, and this may let them tolerate higher levels of "inappropriateness" or "ineptitude" without the niggling insecurity that threatens younger cultures.

This is a great point. For the case of this police officer, he may or may not have been ordered to speak, but I'm sure you heard this week about the Canadian Parliament's sergeant-at-arms stopping a shooting inside his Parliament. I was deeply moved by this video of the sergeant-at-arms getting a standing ovation from all the MPs:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Iu5XX-OTuncWhen I was watching this, I noticed that he was neither smiling nor waving, and in fact was scarcely even acknowledging the applause. When I saw this, I thought "this is the essence of wu-wei." (It makes sense that a sergeant-at-arms would be well-versed in ritual propriety.) It seems to me that wu-wei has something to do with taking a course of action and feeling it was right regardless of whether one is praised or blamed for it.There's a Confucian parable about this as well:> Wang Yangming was informed, on one occasion, that his advanced troops had been> defeated; he calmly continued his discourse. Shortly after, he was> told that, in the later developments of the battle he had become the> victor. The commander remained as calm as before, and did not, even> then, change his discourse.Emperor Meiji actually did the same thing during the Russo-Japanese war. He never celebrated the Japanese victories.

Yes, as I mentioned, virtue-oriented, "hot" ethics played an important role during various points of Western ethics, most prominently in Aristotle, and all through the Middle Ages. After the Enlightenment, though, cold-cognition, rationalist ethics became dominant.

@takh@fivewillowsBasically I think there is not big misinterpretation of the passage "when I reach 50...when I reach 60...". In the Analects 7.8, Confucius says, "I will not open the door for a mind that is not already striving to understand, nor will I provide words to a tongue that is not already struggling to speak. If I hold up one corner of a problem, and the student cannot come back to me with the other three, I will not attempt to instruct him again." Also in Analects 15.16, he says, "I have never been able to do anything for a person who is not himself constantly asking, 'what should I do? What should I do?'" These emphasize that the students have first to be wanting to learn then Confucius would teach them. Yet this contradicts the notion of ***wuwei***. If a person doesn't feel like learning and is both lazy and coward, Confucius requires him to be first willing to learn then he would teach him. This simply requires this guy to try to be willing to learn. This then is not spontaneity, not *wuwei*. So lots of people don't meet this requirement and will not be taught and would not learn anything. Yet Confucius maintains that all male persons can reach the status of gentlemanly virtue. This is even bigger contradiction. So how does Confucianism solve this problem of making these people who are not willing to learn be willing to learn spontaneously/in a *wuwei* manner? Here emerges another contradiction. If the people can be willing to learn in a *wuwei* manner, do they still need to be taught?
column35: paradox of wuwei and trying to learn in the analects

column25: I see de as having the ability to act in a state of "goodness" with no view as to the outcome other than achieving the good intended. Having de suggests that the person is already in a state of Wu-Wei and hence their actions are entirely appropriate to the situation and the correct thing to do. Is that instinct or learned behaviour? Some people seem to be born good, others learn goodness.

> 12.1 Yan Hui asked about Goodness.The Master said, ÒRestraining yourself and returning to the rites constitutes Goodness. If for one day you managed to restrain yourself and return to the rites, in this way you could lead the entire world back to Goodness. The key to achieving Goodness lies within yourselfÑhow could it come from others?ÓYan Hui asked, ÒMay I inquire as to the specifics?ÓThe Master said, ÒDo not look unless it is in accordance with ritual; do not listen unless it is in accordance with ritual; do not speak unless it is in accordance with ritual; do not move unless it is in accordance with ritual.ÓYan Hui replied, ÒAlthough I am not quick to understand, I ask permission to devote myself to this teaching.Ó I think this thread of thought is much more dominant throughout the reading.  He associates goodness with returning to the rites.  He is saying that only through this specific culture and observing its practices can you return the world to goodness.  I also think that you are misinterpreting the first quote, and the second seems rather petty when compared to the rest of the work.  IMHO the first quote you bring (1.12) up is actually a great example of what the professor was talking about in Wu-Wei and De. The harmonious ease is like the Wu-Wei. He is saying that you need to stick rigidly to ritual in all matters, but this alone is not enough.  You must do it with Wu-Wei and do it for its own sake.  It seems to me he is saying you need both Wu-Wei and rigid ritual to become accomplished.  It also seems like you interpret it as saying not to stick rigidly to ritual, but perhaps you should read it again.  Look not just at your bold sentence, but the passage as a whole.  What do you think?

Apropos the Australian "Tall-Poppy Syndrome", I well remember how the whole country rejoiced when it won the America's Cup. Shortly after, the skipper of Australia II (John Bertrand) published an excellent book "Born to Win" on the sports psychology required to win against the odds... and was immediately vilified for doing so. By sharing the perspective of the person at the helm, he was perceived as claiming the victory unto himself and so depriving the nation of its sense of achievement.

Peter Drucker ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Drucker) - who is frequently described as "the founder of modern management" - made a similar point: you can make an effective executive out of just about anyone (they needn't be especially smart or charismatic, for example), integrity is the only indispensible pre-requisite:"A man (or woman) might know too little, perform poorly, lack judgment and ability, and yet  not do too much damage as a manager. But if that person lacks character and integrity Ð no matter how knowledgeable, how brilliant, how successful Ð he destroys. He destroys people, the most valuable resources of the enterprise. He destroys spirit. And he destroys performance . This is particularly true of the people at the head of an enterprise. For the spirit of an organization is created from the top. If an organization is great in spirit, it is because the spirit of its top people is great. If it decays, it does so because the top rots." (I don't have the full citation but I think this quote is taken from his series of talks and books entitled "The Effective Executive")Which is, of course, why Americans observe the corruption of their Congress (dramatised in Kevin Spacey's performance in House of Cards) with such dismay,  and why Baroness Mary Warnock (a renowned ethicist) said the dearth of political ethics evidenced by the ubiquity of the UK MP's expense scandal made her ashamed to be British (here is that link again http://vimeo.com/10841193 )Warnock's prescription is to re-inject the language of morality into everyday life... which Netfix certainly did with House of Cards. Interestingly this was faulted for not being serious enough ( http://www.hitfix.com/whats-alan-watching/house-of-cards-season-2-in-review-it-gets-weaker-the-more-you-watch ). But at least the discourse was prompted.

Yes, I imagine that pedagogy as practiced would fall between the two extremes, or may oscillate between them (so the "self-directed learning" vogue may pass sooner or later).  It would be interesting to think about what criteria you could use to measure the appropriateness or goodness of fit of an education paradigm to a real situation.  How would you know if your education system has become too paternalistic or too laissez-faire, and that it's time to change course?Actually I attended one of the Special Assistance Schools, The Chinese High School, which got additional government support to transmit "Chinese" cultural values along with the usual curricula.  I'm not sure whether TCHS was consciously drawing from a curriculum by Tu Wei-Ming, but there was a lot of emphasis on nurturing a well-rounded character, capable in the sciences, arts, athletics and humanities, and there were even additional classes in calligraphy, the Chinese tea ceremony, Chinese dining etiquette and wei-qi.  I've heard people criticise the TCHS approach as too conservative, regimental and "cheena", but as someone who went through it, it didn't seem especially effective or onerous at the time.  It was still vulnerable to the usual criticisms faced by schools everywhere: spoon-feeding and rote-learning vs. innovation and creativity, building the intangible character of a student vs. an emphasis on paper qualifications etc.

I played a lot of chess in my youth, though never encouraged by parental or other bribes. A desire to win by crushing the opposition (highly Freudian interpretations can be deployed to skewer an adolescent male here) probably qualifies as pursuit of an extrinsic good, but I gave it up as too time-consuming in my early twenties. Yet still I have an appreciation of the beauty of chess and can delight in following the world championship or playing through a sequence which leads to a beautiful move. Haven't I achieved an intrinsic good?

I'm in Taiwan and what I've noticed is that the Taiwanese are far better with lyrics than with music.  It seems like lyrics are king here, but 90 percent of the songs are love ballads.  There are quite a few tv shows here that test participant's knowledge of song lyrics, and I'm always amazed at how well the participants and my friends know the lyrics.  But, it also seems like there is a much narrower range of music here.  There are many classic songs that everyone knows.  I'm often frustrated with how similar the music here is.  In America, there are classic songs, but there is just so much more variety, and when I start listening to the expansiveness of western music, it's like a breath of fresh air.  I think the Taiwanese are much more concerned with lyrics than with music, and I've had quite a few conversations with Taiwanese friends where they have said lyrics are more important than the composition of the music.  And I really can't think of a single song in Taiwan that has long instrumentals.  Edit:  I guess what I'm trying to say in this incoherent, inarticulate mess is that Taiwanese seem to be less passionate about music.  I've met very, very few who live and breath music like my family and various friends do back home.  So while more people are willing to sing here, fewer actually LOVE music and have an interest in a broad variety of music.

Ah yes, that's the rub.  If you disobey your father you are not *ren*, but if you obey your father and in so doing you commit a crime or harm someone, then you are not *ren*.  Thus, a bad father condemns his children to non-*ren* status regardless of the children's behaviors and choices.  And since Kongzi believed most men were not very *ren*, it seems that culture could not advance.  In fact, it would deteriorate, as each bad father would have several or many sons, none of whom could become *ren*.  How was this prevented or circumvented?

Prof Slingerland's response about not obeying a bad person, or one who could do harm to others, raises the question of how to decide what is bad or good, and who gets to decide.  If the individual gets to decide, then ritual is not being followed and a culture could collapse into individualism in a moment, whenever a son decided not to obey his father.  So how does one draw the line, Prof Slingerland?
