Not saying that he was flaunting it, I agree other factors could have played into his decision to participate in the interview.  So if he had genuine motivations for the interview then I would again say it was genuine (that is not for us to know).  Instead of worrying if he was genuine, just go out and create your own genuine acts of kindness.  Is it genuine to give those people praise or is it genuine to accept acts of kindness as normal and participate in committing true acts of kindness?  Maybe when you start paying attention to it and participating in it you will realize there was more of it going around than you thought.  Or if you think the world needs more of this kind of behavior then go give the world more of it.  I'm not preaching, I need to get off my arse and go hug a hobo haha.

Part of the ritual function is to provide a 'social glue' that allows people to negotiate unfamiliar or uncomfortable interactions.  The ritual provides both a script, and an internal sense of control and confidence - which allows people to act from a calm observant state, rather than an uncertain, unstable and emotional state.  You can dislike the other party's religion, politics, ethics and personal practices, but still use common ritual behavior to negotiate social transactions.  And, you can use your understanding of proper behavior to forgive, or rise above, someone else's less than perfect behavior.Apparently most rulers and communities didn't share Confucius' strong feelings about 'proper' behavior, because he spent his life traveling and looking for a patron.

What are the psychological mechanisms behind it?> It's polite to hand something to someone with two hands and receive it with two hands, and not doing this is very shocking. What I like about this is just how intensely you can come to feel emotions that are completely culturally shaped by practices... (from the subtitle of *lecture 2.3* ) > Dollars, chickens, whatever: Frank's insight was that even very basic social interactions cannot work unless there powerful emotions lurking in the background, keeping everyone honest. (from book *Trying not to try*)
column35: How do practices shape emotions culturally?

column25: I think that some people are ignoring the importance of historical context. The European Enlightenment came from the discovery of ancient texts (maintained for centuries in Middle Eastern libraries) that called into question the rigid dogma and excessive punitive policies of the Roman Catholic Church. Of course people had to start thinking for themselves, as well as learning from other models. But the Enlightenment also led to excesses, such as splitting the soul/mind and body, and the birth of reductionist science which in turn led to the Industrial Revolution and now to the destruction of much of the natural world and rampant inequality in the human world.Confucius, on the other hand, was writing in the time of the Warring States, where there must have been plenty of impulsive actions without regard to the lessons that leaders might have learnt from past leaders. Today we have something similar, with 'The new World Order' declared by the US collapsing all around us as another kind of warring states cause havoc. Even though I was in favour of progressive learning and teaching throughout my career as a teacher (and don't regret or forswear this), I look back on my study of the classics at school and University as the foundation of my current thinking.As for the woman question, it seems to me that Confucius was concerned with learning and thinking in ***public life*** rather than in private life, and since public positions were then filled by men, I think it is quite fitting that he doesn't see himself as providing paragon models from which women could learn to think.

Hi William,I have notified Prof. Slingerland of this question.As for my own understanding, while things may vary based on the different schools of thought we're investigating, I tend to agree with your interpretation. In early Confucianism, Heaven (*tian*) granted *de* to a ruler when he sincerely applied his mind and actions to following the Way, as discovered and practiced by the ancient Zhou kings. Having brought his mind perfectly in line with the Way, he was also able to act in a state of *wu-wei*, effortlessly achieving good results all around him. Was the source of his success ultimately *de* or *wu-wei*? Perhaps we might simply say that his power stemmed from his *de*, but he acted in *wu-wei*. They go hand-in-hand. Thus, at least with regard to Confucianism, I would agree that the more *de* one has, the more capable one is of being in the state of *wu-wei*.Best,Robin

I have tried to read the Analects several times but have abandoned that project because I found them impenetrable. This lecture, series along with the thoughtful discussions, has opened them up to me in a way, that I imagine, will facilitate my reading of them in the future. As mentioned in my introduction, I'm conversant with much of the Chan Classical literature from the Tang and Song Dynasties and with Zen literature from medieval Japan, but I've never seen the Confucian influence on the material so clearly as I do now. I'm expecting that the same will be true of other sections of this course. I'm looking forward to a reread of the not only the Analects but also of Chan/Zen writings when this course if over - especially Dogen's *Eihei Koroku*, which, as it did with Ryokan, has already moved me to tears with its brilliance and compassion. I know that Dogen studied with a Confucian teacher early in his life and I find it hard to imagine that Confucian values would not have influenced his spiritual development.

Remember that Confucius is proselytising throughout the warring states, advocating a change in leadership style in favour of seeking non-military power, and exaggerating his argument in an attempt to have leaders try another way. The fact that he didn't secure a position with any of them indicates that the warring leaders also had trouble with his idea that 'everyone becomes loyal to and follows a person with *de.*As with Jesus, Mahatma Gandhi, Martin Luther King Jr and Nelson Mandela, all of whom could readily be described as having *de*, his success was very limited. But their message has another kind of power through the ages. Perhaps the time for *de* will come some day, and all these leaders will have played their part.We can only hope . . .
So will I - it's a fascinating field of study.

In terms of the nature of the Way there are opposites for everything. Thus from the 81 Chapters, each must have an opposite giving 162?This in turn explains the Mystery. The Mystery being what is the purpose of life and what comes after life, if at all. The latter no one has a verifiable answer to. The former are the realities of the interventions that humans make in the chaos around us.Thus part of the puzzle was set out, the other part "hidden in plain sight".As the text book chapters have not been named I used titles from the RL Wing translation, and considered the oppose as follows:The Beginning of Weakness	1	The beginning of powerUsing obedience	2	Using polarityKeeping senses	12	Controlling the sensesContracting identification	13	Expanding identificationThe exterior of the tao	14	The essence of taoThe power of blunt force	15	The power of subtle forceUnskilled in the absolute	16	Knowing the absoluteThe way of ignorant influence	17	The way of subtle influenceGaining instinct	18	Losing the instinctsReturning to complexity	19	Returning to simplicityDeveloping dependence	20	Developing independenceKnowing the collective effect	21	Knowing the collective originFollowing the chaos	22	Following the patternUnsteady attitudes	23	The insensible/sensible	35	Sensing the insensibleConcealing the disadvantage	36	Concealing the advantageThe weakness of disirelessness	37	The power of disirelessnessPower with motive	38	Power without motiveChaos in leadership	39	Oneness in leadershipThe way	40	The wayMastering accuracy/clarity	41	Mastering the paradoxKnowing obedience	42	Knowing polaritySubtle weakness	43	Subtle powersThe power of needing more	44	The power in needing lessUsing fullness	45	Using emptinessKnowing insufficient	46	Knowing enoughCultivating outer knowledge	47	Cultivating inner knowledgeThe art of action	48	The art of non actionClosing minds	49	Opening the mindThe art of prospering	50	The art of survivalThe power of biased support	51	The power of impartial supportReturning to ignorance	52	Returning to insightThe divided path	53	The undivided pathRemoving a universal view	54	Establishing a universal viewThe power of contending	55	The power in not resistanceThe power at the end	64	The power at the beginningThe danger in ignorance	65	The danger in clevernessThe power in high profile	66	The power in staying lowThe power in tyranny	67	The power in compassionAggressive strength	68	Non aggressive strengthEscalating	69	neutralize escalationKnowing the tao	70	Knowing the taoKnowing the cure	71	Knowing the diseaseThe inappropriate perspective	72	The appropriate perspectiveThe Abnormal Way	73	Natures wayNatural authority	74	Unnatural authorityConstructive leadership	75	Self destructive leadershipThe power of independence / Fulfilling dependence	80	Fulfilling independenceThe unevolved way 	81	The evolved wayIn so doing we create a universal schematic to how things actually are + should be, where each chapter then has an equal and opposite pair, and each pair represents the beginning and end of a continuum; or perhaps are opposite on a circle? I think I like the circular notion.

Yin and Yang, though only mentioned in the Dao De Jing (Chapter 42), and that chapter perhaps gives us the best understanding about Daoist Cosmogony. Daoism isn't about opposites, but it uses them to show that the world isn't black and white. In DDJ42 it explains that the Dao births One, One Births Two, Two Births Three and the Three birth Everything (10,000 things/Wanwu). Why is this important? Well, Yin and Yang aren't absolutes, there are just two ideas to express things. DDJ2 explains how there can only be beauty if ugliness exists, but by those two existing it allows all the possibilities of the beauty-ugly spectrum to exist. With your idea of the circle, and the image that is used to represent the Dao (Taiji tu), there exists Yin within Yang and Yang within Yin, which shows they aren't absolute and opposite pairs, but rather have each other within them. DDJ42 can also be used as a metaphor for human life, as Two gives birth to a third, which is Yang (Man) and Yin (female) gives birth to a third (child). In the Huainanzi Ch 5 it explains why 3 is an important number, 3x3 = 9 and 9x9 = 81. A fair few other important texts in the Lao-Huang have 81 chapters too.Just a different perspective.

The comparison of the characteristics of the philosophies of the Primitivists and the Hippies is interesting since both exhibit a back-to-nature emphasis combined with the view that conventional society is corrupt and corrupting. So the solution is to drop out.Both movements also occurred at times when the social structures were relatively fluid.

The last video segment reinforces the idea that the Primitivistswere reacting, at least in part, against the death and destruction caused by the elite-led wars between the States. Confucianism was attacked as representative of the elite's views - an elite responible for expanding the conflicts towards total war. The extreme conservatism of Confucianism also made it an obvious target.The Hippies were mainly young, and were subject to the draft to fight in a cruel and unecessary war in Vietnam, which fuelled their revolt against "the establishment".

Hi Folks,Many apologies for the video error. It seems that Prof. Slingerland had some trouble uploading it correctly. It should be viewable now, so please let me know if you are still having trouble viewing it.In general, Prof. Slingerland films the concluding video during the weekend after a Module has launched, responding to questions in the discussion forums that have come up between Tuesday and Friday. Sorry to hear you missed the deadline. While we are unable to grant extensions, please do not worry too much, as you only need a total score of 60% to pass the course, and you can also complete the Peer Assessment Assignment (to be released with Module 3) to replace your lowest quiz score. For future quizzes, please note that the deadline is listed in UTC military time format, so 06:59 is 6:59 AM. UTC stands for Coordinated Universal Time, which is the same as Greenwich Mean Time. You can convert it to your own time zone here: http://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/converter.html. I have also made the suggestion that our technical staff implement a real-time "countdown" clock function, to prevent this sort of confusion from continuing, but so far it is unclear whether or not they will be able to manage this. There are two passages in the Analects showing Confucius giving more value to the internal value of virtues than money, i.e.,  6.11 The Master said, ÒWhat a worthy man was Yan Hui! Living in a narrow alley, subsisting upon a basket of grain and gourd full of waterÑother people could not have born such hardship, yet it never spoiled HuiÕs joy. What a worthy man was Hui!Óand  7.16 The Master said, ÒEating plain food and drinking water, having only your bent arm as a pillowÑcertainly there is joy to be found in this! Wealth and eminence attained improperly concern me no more than the floating clouds.ÓThis shows how a person can be in harmony with the joy of the internal value of virtues despite the hardships of material lives. However, does Confucius have a reason for why the joy of the internal value of virtues overtake the value of material life?

Another fascinating video clip.Moralists, defined as people who are actively and dogmatically interested inthe morals of others, are a plague.The Daoist injunction not to talk about morals is very interesting.In the West, Wittgenstein for one, held that morals could not meaningfully be talked about.

As I was reading the Dao De Jing, I got very much surprised by the lack of any footnote about the concept of the "Enigmatic Female", and I would love some more information on it:The spirit of the valley never dies;She is called the ÒEnigmatic Female.ÓThe portal of the Enigmatic Female;Is called the root of Heaven and earth. It seems to be pointing out to a sort of Mother Goddess/Creator, from which the Way would come out. Is there any archeological and/or textual evidence in China about that, like we find in Europe and the Middle-East?

It is notorious that people, especially adolescents, have trouble with prohibitions, i.e. negative commands.I do not know if this has been studied carefully but I bet that the command:"Come home early", is more likely to be effective than, "Don't be late".

I think that by starting from the lowest, you allow yourself to grow and develop (I seem to recall the Daodejing embracing the baby as the model to follow). Whereas if you're at the peak of your powers, the only way is down. This is taking the derivative to the meaning of life, much earlier than Newton and his differential equations.

I haven't read Mitchell's version, but I know that LeGuin's version was "translated" using the same process, by comparing many versions together. In LeGuin's case, however, it is completely assumed.I wouldn't know about the scholarliness of her work, but as always with LeGuin's writing, it's a beautiful read.See for instance Chapter 40:You don't have to go out the doorto know what goes on in the world.You don't have to look out the windowto see the way of heaven.The farther you gothe less you know.So the wise souldoesn't go, but knows;doesn't look, but sees;doesn't do, but gets it done.Compared to:Without going out the door, one can know the whole world.Without looking out the window, one can see the Way of Heaven.The further one goes, the less one knows.This is why sagesKnow without going abroad,Name without having to see,Perfect through nonaction.
column35: Ursula LeGuin's version of the Dao De Jing

column25: Hello, ni hao.  Welcome.  We are happy to learn with you.
Yes, I agree with you, the question was unclear.

If one uses the definition of religion presented by C. Geertz originally in 1966:Religion is (1) a system of symbols which acts to (2) establish powerful, pervasive, and long-lasting moods and motivations in men by (3) formulating conceptions of a general order of existence and (4) clothing these conceptions with such an aura of factuality that (5) the moods and motivations seem uniquely realistic. ÒReligion as a Cultural System,Ó in The Interpretation of Cultures (New York: Basic Books, 1973 [1966]), 90.Then the view that Philosophy is a subset or system of religious thought becomes a reasonable proposition.  Indeed, any system of thought that presents some sort of ontological claim can be viewed as such.

I'm wondering if we know much detail about the lives of the primitivist communities beyond what can be gleaned from the philosophical texts. It is interesting that contradictions seemed to sharpen, perhaps  as Confucianism became more embedded and in response to the violence of the Warring States and the Qin's far from gentle 'solution' to disunity. It's a much later period but I'm intrigued by the comparison with Russia where after the social dislocation of the 'Time of Troubles' in the seventeenth century and the imposition of a rationalist state order, disputes about liturgy, with a strongly philosophical undercurrent,  caused major social schisms and the formation of dissident communities who set off into the northern forests to establish austere working settlements, a tradition which persists in Russia today, while hippies seem to be fading from the scene in the west (or at least in my bit).Something of the sort happened in England after the social disruption of the Civil War, when movements such as the Levellers and the Diggers sought a form of rural egalitarianism. Social motivations are clearer than in the case of the Chinese primitivists however. Landlessness presumably wasn't much of a problem in China after the depredations of the Warring States period.

If one uses the definition of religion presented by C. Geertz originally in 1966:Religion is (1) a system of symbols which acts to (2) establish powerful, pervasive, and long-lasting moods and motivations in men by (3) formulating conceptions of a general order of existence and (4) clothing these conceptions with such an aura of factuality that (5) the moods and motivations seem uniquely realistic. ÒReligion as a Cultural System,Ó in The Interpretation of Cultures (New York: Basic Books, 1973 [1966]), 90.Then the view that Philosophy or Science is a subset or system of religious thought becomes a reasonable proposition.  Indeed, any system of thought that presents some sort of ontological claim can be viewed as such.
Ditto.
Thanks for the quote. Zigong should not have been so easily deflated. He should have built the machine and demonstrated the ease of use.
I agree. I prefer LeGuin's version too.

LeGuin's translation is terrible, and these kind of ignorant "translations" actively mislead people who are trying to understand Laozi's philosophy. There is a good explanation of this in this article:Goldin, Paul R. "Those Who Don't Know Speak: Translations of the Daode jing by people who do not know Chinese." Asian Philosophy 12.3 (2002): 183-195.If you want to see for yourself how LeGuin distorts her text, look at her "translation" of the last part of Chapter 25. Then look at a real translation.

In this video Prof. Slingerland says that the *Laozi* was "falsely attributed" to Laozi. But we frequently see in the Indian classics cases where texts are written anonymously, by people who do not wish to claim that ultimate truths came from their own personality quirks rather than from Heaven, and then centuries later attributed to some kind of philosophical concept or legendary figure. Is it possible that the *Laozi* came into being the same process? I can imagine that these primitivists, who always seem to be adopting funny names instead of using their birth names, might have written and copied out their favorite quotations on bamboo slips, sending them to each other without attribution because of their desire to be dead to the world. Finally there came to be a received collection, which was associated with a real or imagined primitivist named Laozi.Although I've read a lot of Warring States classics, they always seem to be attributed to specific persons. Is there any historical evidence for a practice of anonymity?

You'll remark that I put the word translation between inverted commas, and that I mentionned that it was something assumed by LeGuin. She says herself that she can't speak Chinese, and that her version is a "rendition" far from scholarly editions. You must not forget that the Dao De Jing isn't just a historical piece and that it's not only *used* in academic contexts, but also for philosophical and spiritual purposes. Honestly, I think your answer is quite insulting.

On the other hand, it's probably Ursula's LeGuin's renderings of the Laozi and Zhuangzi that originally got my into Chinese philosophy as a teenager in New Jersey (I was a big science fiction fan), so there's at least something to be said for them...

There are some fertility figures we've found in the Yangshao culture I talked about in Module 1 (pregnant women with large breasts) that some have seen as evidence of early goddess cults, but that's about the extent of it. Nothing in the written records.It's not impossible that in the Daodejing references to the enigmatic female, etc., we're seeing elements of popular goddess cults re-entering the written record. On the other hand, the powerful shamans we have burials for in the Yangshao culture all seem to be male, so if there was any goddess worship going on it was run by men...
Because the internal joy one gets from loving the Way is lasting, unlike the "floating clouds" of materialist goods

The mistrust of words leads Laozi towards something that seems to me to be close to an isolated individualistic stance: if agreeing something is beautiful inevitably leads to tarnishing it, and we each assign the word our own standard, the word 'beautiful' begins to lose its meaning as a signifier of anything. Yet Laozi does have standards that he thinks are universal: he takes it as axiomatic that stealing is undesirable but why should not stealing form part of the way if individuals feel it 'in the belly'? Hippies have been known to liberate objects from the undeserving rich.
This is a good question. I am more familiar with the Buddhist concepts. What is "Immortality" in Daoist teaching?
I'm wondering whether Laozi and Henry David Thoreau and the hippies of the '60s weren't looking for utopia.  Was that what Confucius was looking for too?

One of the easiest ways for someone who is concerned about gender bias to read any ancient text where this is a problem is simply to use pronoun substitution. For every he, him or his, simply substitute she, her or hers.  May not be historically or culturally accurate but it solves the problem.  I myself make a practice of this with almost any text that I read.

Daodejing would have us close the doors to Society. The doors operate both ways.  Becoming a recluse, within a reclusive village, among other reclusive village invites disaster.  Not knowing what the next village/person/state is doing can be dangerous as not everyone will totally free themselves of desire. What about diseases, Mates/bloodlines? A host of medical questions arise when living in "isolation". Yes, today there are indeed "communities" that live off-the-grid and are interdependent among themselves, but it is rare.  And these communities still interact with the "outside".  While I truly like to think it's a workable philosophy, I cannot accept that it could succeed in the long run.

Confucius believed the Western Zhou dynasty was a "golden age," but because of the particular political structure of dynastic rule, it couldn't necessarily be considered a utopia. A utopia is more communal, so it seems to fit with primitivists. But actively trying to form a utopia seems to be stepping away from "going with the flow," which is rather characteristic of Daoism. So it would appear that the idea of utopia is not really what Confucius and Laozi were thinking, but the fact does not rule out that, from these schools of thought, means could be adapted to utopian ends.

Professor Slingerland mentioned that some Taoists developed arcane practices such as searching for elixirs to guarantee immortality (usually producing the reverse effect). I think this was a later development in the history of Taoism, after the Warring States

I don't know about Thoreau or Confucius, but I lived through the 60's. (I am now 68) Most of the hippies I knew only wanted drugs, sex and rock and roll.Hippies as philosophical intellectuals is a myth.

I picked up a copy of William Scott Wilson's translation of the Daodejing, and he makes an interesting change, switching "nonaction" with "non-fabrication." I have found it to be helpful in considering some circumstances of my own life. I wonder why something happened, and I realize that I might have been "fabricating," that is, trying to make something happen.As far as language is concerned, I am curious as to whether this use of "fabrication" instead of "action" is due to a word which means both "do" and "make." I can understand how this could be. For, in Spanish, the verb "hacer" means both "to do" and "to make." Does the particular Chinese word in question pose a similar challenge?

Indeed, the Daodejing is used for philosophical purposes. But if an ancient Chinese text becomes a personal self-help book to someone in another place and time, who then rewrites it to fit their needs despite not knowing any Chinese, it is harder to justify it as making real philosophical claims that can be discussed alongside the great Greeks, Indians, and Europeans.I do have to admit that I'm biased; re-translating from a language you don't know, because you see a bit of yourself in the text, is typical of what I regard as a thinly concealed arrogance that pervades LeGuin's writing. I have read several of her books and stories but the one that keeps coming back to me is "The Author of the Acacia Seeds".

You make a fair point! I recently was part of an 8-week discussion group on the Zhuangzi and we spent roughly an hour discussing exactly the point you are making (a very long time to be talking about such a short anecdote!). There were several people in the class saying that this was a parable and real people could not have behaved like this. Personally, I'm of the opinion that the Analects passage, this passage, and several other places in the Zhuangzi all show that Daoist-primitivists had a very different conception of a good life than a "freedom" from labor and suffering that fits into the Enlightenment narrative.

Hi RobertI am not so sure that we are all materialistic. There are plenty of examples of self-sacrificing individuals who reject the tinsel and trash of consumerism. Gandhi might be one?But I do agree we are encouraged to be selfish, not least by capitalism. An excellent British documentary series, The Century of the Self, traces some of the forces at work https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLAD989035A4E8883DMore constructively, Allon de Botton is fun on "status anxiety", http://www.theschooloflife.com/blog/2014/06/why-you-are-anxious-all-the-time/ and http://www.ted.com/talks/alain_de_botton_a_kinder_gentler_philosophy_of_success?language=enKind regardsGeoffrey
I always assumed this was about yin and yang!

Ah, the power of labels.  Jim Jones was indeed a Christian, although not in any sense that would be recognizable to most Christian denominations.  Charles Manson was both a hippie and a cult leader.  The second can grow out of the first.

I find it interesting that my "journey" has brought me to a point where I am just now confronted with Epistemology, and that the only knowledge I really have, according to Descartes, is that I am. The realization that most things I conceive to be knowledge may only be justified belief, or something of which I am reasonably confident. It certainly seems that "the further you go, the less you know." So perhaps it is better to "return home and shut the windows." I feel rather compelled to go out to the back yard, walk up to the post that fell over this summer, and set to work, cutting it to pieces with ax and saw. Does anyone else have any thoughts about the Daodejing with regard to the theory of knowledge?

I am still running the iphone 3G, which I never updated to OS 4. On NPR today the discussion turned to the question of why, when the economy is improving, have people not seemed to be pleased by this. The response was that the job creation has not led to an increase in wages. So if the wages had increased, people might be happier. But, as Dr. Slingerland pointed out, people adapt to the wage increase, and return to their unhappy desires. I agree, for I started working a job which allowed me to bring more money home. I bought a new car, which made me happy, and, which I still appreciate, but paying the car loan and insurance causes me to sort of regret the desire for nice automobiles. But at least I get great MPG! Otherwise I tend to be very frugal and not desire with the eye, or at least, to not give in to the desire of the eye.

On that note, I actually don't think Confucians were moralists either -- it says in the *Analects* that "The Master seldom spoke of *ren*" (9.1). There is a strong "Daoist" streak against moralizing language, even among people who were teaching ritual.If we want to talk about body image, the Confucians are really on the mark: "King Zhuang of Chu liked slender waists, and so his court was full of starved-looking people." (Xunzi ch. 12)

Perhaps the hippies of the sixties were of two types - those not part of the drugs/sex crowd who saw a truth of justice, righteousness and as intellectual leaders deeply fought for and yearned for change; and, those who without anchor or base became lost beyond the bounds of morality.  What do you think?
Yes, this question should be remove from the grading. I didn't choose the correct answer because I was sure it wasn't true.

I was also prompted to think of Wittgenstein at the mention of the significance of language. It is not surprising to me that language games could cause people to not remember a face they had seen before.

I am 72 and yes, lived during those years. and I believe both are true, but I feel the true hippies were those who believe in the universal good and wanted to be apart of bring good to mankind.  They were the true Hippies.  I could explain how it all change , but at a later time. not now

The lecture reminded me of Karl Pilkington (some say he is just acting I dont think so). He argues that learning and society actually makes us unhappy. He believes that there is no need for travelling abroad or doing many of the things we do.Link to documentary: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jdnecUl4jYA

The elixir reference certainly explains the reference to Daoism in the Jackie Chan film, *The Forbidden Kingdom*. I studied the Buddhist concept of dukkha. I thought it was interesting that people could become gods, hungry ghosts, and animals based on how they lived life.
Aren't there studies that show that acting happy (smiling, laughing, etc.) can make you feel happier?  Wouldn't this be closer to the Confucian way of thinking?

The problem, if I recall is that God should be a completely benevolent omnipotent being, if that is the case, then how can he create evil, or allow evil? I believe that is the sticking point for most theologians in the relation to God and Evil debate.

column25: Another disparaging remark - "thick as a plank".

I understand some cultures with no written language believe that their collective knowledge is innate. I can't think of the term for it but it is passed down through the generations through the spoken word and there is a sense of not just an acquired knowledge (eg by example, etc) but also a pre-existing collective knowledge which some if not all are born with. I wonder if the "primitivists" had a sense of an innate or collective wisdom and by advocating staying at home and avoiding the "corrupting" influence of other societies/cultures/civilisations they believed that their behaviour and attitude would be more natural and thus lead to contentment and the ability to live in a state of Wu-Wei because they instinctively knew what to do and how to behave in a way that satisfied all basic needs?

Hi EdwardWithout sounding sycophantic I hope, I feel I have to say that am loving every second of your course.Sadly lots (the majority?) of consultants seem to me far too anal/left-brained and mercenary to handle De.But some consultants are motivated by a genuine desire to seek ways to improve the lot of people in organisations. And I suppose Confucius was very much a consultant. One of my heroes is Charles Handy (who wrote "The Gods of Management"). See http://jmbruton.com/images/Handy_Whats_a_Bus_For.pdfOne of my mentors was Ioan Tenner, who has trained thousands of consultants and draws heavily on ancient Chinese philosophy.I would much appreciate your thoughts on his site http://wisdom.tenner.org/He begins, for example, with "Perhaps, some of the greatest sages, like Confucius, Zarathustra, The Buddha, the Prophets of the Bible, Socrates, the Christ, or even Homer and Aesop never wrote, because they knew the danger of wise thoughts being frozen on tablets."Which goes on with his take on the "he who speaks doesn't know"... that is, those-who-know use "the Master's tools" of parable and paradox to ensure that their words "stick to the minds" of their listeners.Kind regardsGeoffrey

Without this income we cannot **finance** the Science, and make no progress as to understand and control our environment. Medical Sciences and Material Sciences brought so many good to this world. And the countries with lower GDP's, in our globalized world, also benefit from this. So it's indeed all about balance (the mean?).

Not a shopaholic, but my eye is drawn to (1) something new, or (2) something that looks like something I already own.  In a clothing store, I tend to see first the things that mirror what I have: a striped long-sleeved tee, a gray hoodie, a wide-brimmed hat, anything lime green.  Initially, I thought this represented stasis; after the lecture, I think it represents a facet of desires of the eye--There's something that resembles what I already like, only *better*.  And I want *better*, so I buy the new thing to replace the less good one I already have.  Is this how it works?

I think I'm fixating a little on the history rather than the philosophy here. Your discussion group sounds interesting - my nitpick aside, the rejection of machinery has a contemporary resonance. Since the Industrial Revolution people have tended to use 'mechanistic' or machine metaphors in a negative anti-human sense. I can't help but think the old gardener a bit weird, but he has a point even beyond his anti-Confucianism.
Round here you're thick as two short planks.

The problem is that if we indulge the eyes of all the people in all the countries with lower GDPs, while not finding a way to blinker those of the first world, there isn't enough 'stuff' on the planet to satisfy us all.
I think you mean moral licensing. :)

I think Laozi is more portrayed as poor. I guess we'll never really know for sure about Confucius, but he seems to have come from the gentry class and his family presumably had property, as did some disciples, so presumably they could draw on private means. Certainly in later periods there was class solidarity among the gentry and a tradition of hospitality. Chinese intellectuals always seem to be able to get their hands on some wine so I guess they didn't live in absolute poverty even if they never got a proper job.

I'm no ascetic, but I never buy new clothes or new machines until the old ones wear out and then I hopefully plod back to the same shop looking for an identical replacement, which, capitalism being what it is, I rarely find. I think one can train oneself not to want new things, but it's not what the current global economic system wants you to do.
You've been reading that Chairman Mao again!
I don't know about the studies you refer to, but wouldn't Confucius have wanted us to improve ourselves to the point where we were happy all the time and didn't need to artificially appear so?

So thank him, you, and the whole team sincerely.Best,William

column25: One thing I've found is that when I retell a dream, the dream seems to diminish and shrink and lose all its flexibility and motion. However, he didn't drop out or become one of the primativists.  Personally, I don't know if this exhibited wue-wei and de as much as representing an example of the paradox we are learning about. In the beginning of the course the professor mentioned that our homophile psy trait was adaptative for the  our human evolution of small groups hunter gatherers of 150 people and that after agriculture we made culture to adapt to a big and anonymous group? For me the Dao is much aligned with this kind of natural psy than the one exposed in lesson 3.4. In another perspective if our natural state is to fulfill exponential demand for recourses to satisfy our endless desires, are we doomed to an apocalyptic end, since we seem to be exaggerating in exploring natural resources faster than they can regenerate?

An interesting idea that there is a reality independent of language. Various shamanistic religions also seem to have the notion that to get at reality the logical brain needs to be left behind. It seems to me that by its use of paradox and obscurity, the Daodejing is hinting at the inability of language and conscious thought to apprehend the underlying reality.

Perhaps the more positive, spiritual aspects of yin yang are related to Buddhist influences. Daoism plus Buddhism becomes Chan (Zen). All is cyclical, everything is in constant flux, everything changes. The Way gives us the means to ride the change with equanimity. The yin yang symbol is also known as taiji and as such is part of the creation of the Ten Thousand Things. From wuji, represented by an empty circle, comes yin and yang that when set in motions become taiji and on and on until we get the Ten Thousand Things.An aside, my spell check prefers Tao to Dao and tai chi to taiji.
Nice catch on a global reflection of these ideas.

Yes. Nothing new until it is worn out and unrepairable. I often wonder if it just because I'm getting older and don't like change that I look for the same machine. I found my washing machine on the side of the road and took it because it was like the one I had.
It appears that both Confucius and primitivists were basing their ideologies on a romanticized concept of the past.  However, this is not uncommon throughout history - in many cultures and ages.

I define GMO's into two categories. If it replicates something that could arise from selective breeding, just shortens or improves the process. I have no problem.When DNA from other organisms produce something nature could not have produced, I am more cautious. I don't label it bad, but deserves a closer inspection and environmental impact studies.

I went "Back to the blanket" for awhile in my youth, as some Indians call the primitive lifestyle our ancestors lived.I had an enormous amount of free time. My traps would supply more food than I needed in a day, and took less than about an hour to check. Hunting and forging father increased food supply, so storing up for winter was not a problem.  Even a small garden would increase food supplies. There is great appeal with such a lifestyle. However it does have its drawbacks as well,it requires you to have a specific skill and knowledge base to do so successfully. But at least I understand why some of my people still prefer to live traditionally.

I am really enjoying the lectures, but the image of the "little housewife" driving the Hummer grated on me. Would the situation be more appropriate if a "he-man" were driving? And how did Professor Slingerland know that she wasn't a professor at UCLA?

I always considered Zen to be a direct line to Daoism. But the Primitivists, early Daoists, seem to reject all ritual and a return to a rural agrarian life.However, in Japanese Zen they appear to be using the repetition of ritualistic behaviour, whether it be dressing in a certain way, having a formal structure in the temple, strict meditation practices like the Mu of Nakahara Nantembo. Or the Tendai marathon monks of Mount Hiei wearing very specific clothes etc - all seems to have more in common with Confucius. Using ritual until it becomes subconscious and they 'break through'. Whereas the Daoists would have said this is all too much effort?!

column25: Without GMO's and other technical advances we would have mass starvation.

The real danger for simple societies is not that they aren't sustainable in terms of their local resources, but that they are so easily over-run by 'greedy' societies. This is in fact the history of human society on our beautiful planet.We are discovering too late (through 'modern science') that this is the human paradox. The few greedy leaders (not many in terms of human nature) just take whatever they can get, while the few simple leaders are generally disposed of and/or appropriated into symbols that serve the greedy leaders, the best example probably being Jesus (Christ) being appropriated into Roman Christianity.The ideals remain but the reality just keeps getting worse and worse.
Yep!

Thanks Robert for linking to *The Century of the Self*. That is a wonderful series because it shows that what we tend to take as normal in today's globalised society was actually created by a masterful extension of Goebbels' use of propaganda to advertising based on indulging the 'self'. If you haven't seen this series, I hope you find it somewhere on the Web.Like Peter, I am grateful for my access to the Web, but I haven't bought a Mac product since they 'went over to the dark side' of exploiting non-unionised workers in other countries and declaring their business 'location' in a tax haven rather than paying their fair share of US tax. I'm currently using a comparatively old iMac desktop computer and it's the way I engage in MOOC after MOOC.The only problem I have with the Web is that most of the huge data banks that have been created are still being powered by a fossil-fuel, and most of the stored data is 'crap'.I see myself as satisfying the desires of my brain as well as my belly, and although these desires are no doubt insatiable (up until now at any rate) they are intellectually and practically sustaining me and other simple-life practitioners and advocates who have been forced into small fragmented groups throughout the 'Western World'.In the circumstances, I'm hoping that the primitivists might approve, however reluctantly.

Hi AngletonTell me more, please.How does Barbara's "smile or die" relate to moral licensing? Making it OK to say "to hell with your 'fighting cancer', I should be allowed to feel unhappy about it"?Kind regardsGeoffrey

This week's lectures triggered a roller-coaster of emotions in me.In Lecture 3, our doughty Prof interpreted Daodejing Chapter 12 ("The five colors blind our eyes./ The five notes deafen our ears. / The five flavors deaden our palates.") as follows:> "So by five, what's going on? You can substitute fancy for five. Fancy> colors blind our eyes. Fancy notes deafen our ears. We don't need> sophisticated culture. And in fact, sophisticated culture confuses us.> It kind of messes up our natural tastes, is essentially what this is> saying. 'The chase and the hunt madden our hearts. Precious goods> impede our activities.'"I was greatly disappointed by this. My background in engineering and mathematics gives me a strong sense of the limits of numbers. I had therefore always taken this verse as the clearest explanation of my distrust of linear, reductionist, quantitative thinking (fact-based analysis, "structured problem solving",  whatever you want to call it). Thus I had seen Chapter 12 as poetic warning that "disaggregation denies the gestalt". That is, as a dismissal of our widespread tendency to number things that we have arbitrarily categorized and arranged into groups when we lack a high-level thought to unite them (as in the "7-S model of organization", the "8-basics of excellent companies", the "7-habits of highly-effective people", and on and on in endless half-baked blogs promising the 7-secrets of success or top-ten tips for this or that).I was forced to conclude that I had got the meaning of this verse wrong.I was therefore greatly relieved by the time we got to Lecture 5, to hear the Prof saying: > "There's a fair amount of work on the interaction of language in, for> instance, perceptual experience, that suggests that language does in> some ways interfere with or overshadow our experience of reality. This> is a phenomenon in social psychology that's referred to as verbal> overshadowing."and to hear JONATHAN SCHOOLER explaining that:> ... "there seems to be some sort of generalized processing shift that> takes place when people describe faces. They shift from a more> holistic, non-analytic mode to a more analytic, verbal mode, thinking> about the individual features. And by shifting into that mode, they're> less effective at recognizing the face they'd seen before."Surely such verbal overshadowing is precisely what Chapter 12 is on about.

Hi LoraleeI guess that depends on how we use language. Poets surely keep their words deliberately opaque, so that we can discover our own meaning in their lack of concreteness - parables and paradoxes that reverberate through the millennia.My old mate Ioan calls this "wisdom, sleeping" http://wisdom.tenner.org/the-fascination-of-paradox.htmlIoan cites> ÒKuang Tze dreamed one night, he was a wonderful butterfly, enjoying> the breeze in the sunny field. Then, he woke up and he didnÕt know any> more: was he Kuang Tze heaving dreamed being a butterfly, or was he a> butterfly dreaming now that he is Kuang Tze?Ó(Chuang Tzu, The Inner Chapters)Kind regardsGeoffrey

I was interested in your comment that the Yin/Yang symbol is also known as the taiji.In trying to find the chinese idea of creation I came up with this theory. In the beginning was Wuji(emptiness), but it was not represented by a circle but rather by anellipse. This morphed into the Yoji(something) which then became the Taiji (the great ultimate or the one). From the one came the two, Yin and Yang, and from the two came the three, Yin and Yang with Yin or Yang(family?). From the three came the 10,000 things(society). So, Wuji, Yoji, and Taiji are all pre-heaven and the rest are post-heaven.This would mean that the so-called Yin/Yang symbol is really a fiction that was invented at a later date. It is the same with the martial art. apparently there was a man running around in china beating up on everyone with this new fighting art. He was asked what he called this art and being a resourceful type he immediately came up with Taiji Chuan (great ultimate fist). How true this all is I have no idea but it sounds good.
But maybe Mao and Pol Pot are both illustrations of ill interpretations of Laozian primitivism ?

Perhaps this is part of the difference between the Analects and the DaoDeJing. Where the Analects charge you with doing things as they are supposed to be in a fixed Ð Zhou- form with little room for interpretation, the DaoDeJing challenges you to make your own interpretation. This also fits with the explanation of the type of cafeteria model of being able to put your own version together based on the different available texts. If seen in this light  LeGuin's way of approaching the DaoDeJing is not that bad. And for seconds: what are the Analects and the DaoDeJing other than the first self help books? How else, in absence of the master, are we able to digest their knowledge?

It is curious; it could be looked at as pride, as it seems Confucius is proud of his resoluteness in his playing.  However, could he have been concerned with who this was, and if it had to do with his recent meeting?

Carl Jung was a Swiss psychiatrist who was one«s of Freud«s students. He basically developed his work in a different direction because he believed that we are influenced not only by our personal unconscious, but also by a broader concept of unconscious force that influence our psychical development, the collective unconscious. He was greatly influenced by the Gnostic Taoist text The secret of the golden flower ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Secret_of_the_Golden_Flower ) about meditation and the Tao is the Main insight for the development of his work.The Yin Yang is a king of symbolic representation of the dynamic of our psyche that generates it«s energy in a entropic manner;  from the resolution of dualities based on inner perception of outer events that needs an adaptative response, that usually presents dissonance of prior experience, self interests, emotions, motivations, values and beliefs.  His libido concept is different from Freud«s sexual energy, the main cause of their disruption, because he thought we are problem solver«s. He flirted with quantum mechanics, he was Max Plank«s friend and supervisor of his depression treatment, because he wanted to understand some strange psychological phenomenaÕs,  like how do people know about relatives death even before they are communicated of the fact. The next short text shows how the Tao can be an insight for quantum physics as well as  the collective unconscious .http://poeticinterconnections.org/2009/05/19/yin-yang-jung/

column25: Taleb is famous for his "Black Swan" theory which deals with low frequency - high impact phenomena. Taleb is also a, very accomplished, statistician so he does know all about Òlies, damn lies and statisticsÓ.... Not knowing about harmful side effects doesn't mean there will not be any harmful effects in the future. It could also mean we have not yet observed these effects because our observation is too short. By the way, natural breeding has led to all kinds of illnesses in animals. Look into the term "inbreeding" and you 'll get the drift of this.But to get a little back on base, the parallel in my opinion is the opposition of anti-establishment / anti GMO / Daoist / É. (fill the dots with your preference) to mindless implementation of non proven or highly idealized techniques, without some sane skepticism on the success rate. It's a call to put trust in your intuition as well as your rationality. IMHO reacting only to the choice of Prof. Slingerlands examples or parallels is somewhat like commenting on the quality of the stone chimes in stead of observing the inner workings of the player.
Throughout the text Laozi recognises a right to property. I suppose because "things" one is entitle to have. What he seems to advocate is that there is no need for too much of such things.

Su Tung-Po, a Sung Dynasty poet, 1036 - 1101 wrote the following:The sounds of the valley stream are his long broad tongue/the forms of the mountain are his pure body/In the night, I heard the myriad sutras uttered/How can I relate what they mean?Su Tung-po wrote this poem after he took up a study of Chan Buddhism, but his early education was Taoist and Confucian. He passed all the government exams and, as Dr. Slingerland has said, succeeded as a government official. When his service was over he retired to a mountain hermitage to do practice. One night he sat up meditating all night long, listening to the sounds of the mountain. The next day he wrote the above poem. "Sutra" is a sanskrit word and describes texts most of which were presumably spoken by the historic Buddha and recorded by his disciples. Here, Su Tung Po is saying that those texts were a crude attempt to describe reality - that the true "sutra" is the sounds of mountains and rivers (san sui) - which, could be translated, I believe, as "nature." If you substitute "the way" for "him" it is a perfect expression of what I see to be the point of this lecture.
Isn't *any* prescription, even one as "benign" as "go for the lower," an attempt to control people's minds and activities?

From the Laozian perspective, one does not attempt to re-inject any language into everyday life.  Language in its objectification of the moment is the problem.  For a true follower of the way, one simply is ÒmoralÓ and this results in positive change in the collective awareness of the moment:They produce without possessing.9    They act with no expectation of reward.10   When their work is done, they do not linger.11   And, by not lingering, merit never deserts them. Daodeching, chapter two.Simple answer to this question from almost all of the historical "spiritual" traditions is no, emphatically "NO!" From Laozi: They produce without possessing.9 They act with no expectation of reward.10  When their work is done, they do not linger.11 And, by not lingering, merit never deserts them.From Confucius: The Master said, ÒI can talk all day long with Yan Hui13 without him once disagreeing with me. In this way, he seems a bit stupid. And yet when we retire and I observe his private behavior, I see that it is in fact worthy to serve as an illustration of what I have taught. Hui is not stupid at all.ÓFrom the Christian tradition, Book of Matthew: When you do some act of charity, do not announce it with a flourish of trumpets, as the hypocrites do in synagogue and in the streets to win admiration of men.  I tell you this: they have their reward already.  No; when you do some act of charity do not let your right hand know what your right hand is doing;É New Oxford English translation.
Quote from Matthew should read: do not let your left hand know what your right hand is doing.

Yield and overcome.

column25: I think this is a good point and it's in accordance with Taleb's argument posted above.
Isn't all language essentially prescriptive? Why would you bother communicating with someone if you have no interest whatsoever in them?

@Barbra9, agreed. Like most--maybe all--counter-culture movements, the original founders were clearly driven by informed motives based on moral and rational convictions (whether their solutions were realistic or otherwise is a different question). When the larger society took note by spreading the news about them, this surely attracted followers less informed, less rational, less moral, simply looking for outlets not offered by the mainstream--hello, "Sex, Drugs, and Rock-n-Roll."All honor to the best of this generation, all sympathy and regret for the worst. 1950s and '60s America, like Warring States China, certainly had its mainstream cultural disorders worth countering, whether by dropping out or trying to change it from within. The parallels are indeed striking.

Minor point re: agriculture in Warring States China. Yellow River agriculture was mostly millet and wheat, not rice. That's more Yangzi and south, where climate is warmer and more humid. (But still, rejecting even animal power does seem extreme. Oxen are "technology"? Sheesh, by that logic, so is the human body pulling the plough.)

And @Avery, I *love* that passage from Zhuangzi, especially this:> where there are machines, there are bound to be machine worries; where there are machine worries, there are bound to be machine hearts. With a machine heart in your breast, you've spoiled what was pure and simple; and without the pure and simple, the life of the spirit knows no rest. Where the life of the spirit knows no rest, the Way will cease to buoy you up. It's not that I don't know about your machine - I would be ashamed to use it!I almost want to replace "ashamed" with "unwise," because this is clearly a reasoned stance. And statistics on how "labor-saving" email and other digital technologies have actually--and perversely--*increased* the average hours worked (in America, anyway) show how very, very insightful was the old farmer.

My title says it all, but I've long been struck by the *long-term legacies* of Warring States China's *naturalism*--whether Confucian or Daoist--and late Roman *supernaturalism* seen in the response of *its* triumphant counter-culture: Christianity.Non-theistic, non-doctrinaire, and without texts claiming "divinely revealed" origins, the Zhou primitivists ("Daoists" and others) only rejected *civilization*, but *not* the earth, *not* human society, and *not* the natural pleasures of the body and its senses. The contrast with the monastic response of the Christian counterculture during its first several centuries could not be more stark.As is also true of Confucianism, for these Chinese dropouts, the secular remained sacred. And like Christianity survives in the Western mind even today, so too does the Primitivists' spiritual connection to "uncarved" nature survive in the Chinese mind today. It's obvious in any public park in any town or city in China, in *Feng Shui*, in the Chinese joy in drinking and singing. There's no "sin" in the senses, though there *is*--and rightfully so--*shame* for those who indulge them excessively or distastefully. A happy drinking bout? No worries! One of life's goods! But one in which you become aggressive, lewd, or sloppy? Shame on you! (Or so it seems when I watch the Chinese drink.)
column35: "Back to Nature" or "Up to Jesus"? Dropouts East and West

column25: The ideal of the 'noble savage' is extremely appealing, as is the idea of a more natural existence.  Unfortunately, however, this ideal is pretty much incorrect.  The idea that nature is 'good' can obviously be disproved by numerous counter-examples - diseases caused by micro-organisms, parasitism, the 'cruelty' of a cat playing with a mouse; midges.  Nature is neither good nor bad, it just is.  http://www.fallacyfiles.org/adnature.htmlThis is uncontroversial.  But even the 'noble savage' ideal is apparently a myth.  How we behave is in part the result of our evolution (the 'gene' part of our inheritance).  And evolutionarily, we are quite like chimpanzees.  In chimpanzee societies, as in human, there is both intra- and inter-group violence.  Furthermore, an argument is made, e.g. by Steven Pinker, that 'we' are less violent now than in previous times.  The institution of the state, however much we may loathe its interference in our lives and its needless bureaucracy, and in spite of massive inter-state violence such as the two World Wars of the last century, has apparently aided an overall decrease in violence.  http://edge.org/conversation/mc2011-history-violence-pinkerAh, all my ideals shattered!  Such is the result of 'learning'!
column35: Wiser but sadder? - The downside of 'learning'

column25: Well, they get this from the Chinese....

In early Chinese thought, as in early Greek thought, there is no concept of "evil" in an active, Augustinian sense: evil as a positive motivation. There is just "badness," a lack of good. People do bad things because they are ignorant, or lack self-control, or are confused about what really brings pleasure. The idea that you start to get in Christianity, that someone can choose to do a bad thing knowing that it's bad, and actively choosing it *because* it's bad, is not something you see in early China.
Maybe not the best choice of image. But I know she wasn't a professor at UCLA because she was my neighbor...

Yes, besides the issue of whether or not small-scale societies are really as idyllic or sustainable as certain retrospective views of them would have, there is the further problem that the history of the last few thousand years is that of larger and larger scale societies spreading at the expense of small-scale societies. In most of the desirable-to-live regions of the world whatever small-scale societies were there at contact with large-scale societies almost inevitably get assimilated or simple wiped out. For the Daodejing authors, though, this would not be a problem, because they have faith that if a ruler could truly embrace wu-wei, his (or her?) de would cause everyone in the world to return to naturalness, so you'd have no more large-scale societies around to cause trouble.

## The Cultural Factor and the "Conservative/Liberal" Dichotomy##**After Office Hours Response**I just watched the Week 2 Office Hours wrap-up discussing this thread, and Prof. Slingerland touched on the research suggesting conservatives and liberals are neurologically "wired" toward their orientations. Interesting twist, though: **If I were Chinese, I would be conservative. But as an American, I'm liberal.**Why? Because I find little in Western tradition worth conserving, so by default align with progressive goals--less individualism, less militarism, less Biblical fundamentalism and the social discriminations of so many stripes that it supports (in the all-too-frequent worst cases), less pro-business and pro-wealth environmental and economic policies. So yes, let's be progressive to leave these behind.If I *were* Chinese, though, conservatism's meaning changes, and because the cultural values of Chinese tradition strike me as wiser, would make me a conservative. I *would* want to conserve many of them: social over individual, responsibility over freedom, education and self-cultivation over pursuit of material wealth, social responsibility in commerce *and* arts, elevation of the educated as "elite" and demotion of the profit-seekers as "base", meritocracy over democracy to assure more intelligent and competent policy and administration, embrace of philosophy instead of superstitions.It all boils down to **specific culture** in my book. The same individual's orientation, "wired" or not, *changes* in different cultural contexts.

Who knows the curious mystery of the eyesight? The other senses corroborate themselves, but this is removed from any proof but its own, and foreruns the identities of the spiritual world. A single glance of it mocks all the investigations of man, and all the instruments and books of the earth, and all reasoning. What is marvellous? what is unlikely? what is impossible or baseless or vague--after you have once just open'd the space of a peach-pit, and given audience to far and near, and to the sunset, and had all things enter with electric swiftness, softly and duly, without confusion or jostling or jam.....Walt Whitman, Preface, Leaves of Grass.  1855.This concept has nothing to do with faith; using St. PaulÕs definition: faith is the substance of things unseen.  No, what we are discussing is a matter of praxis, not belief.  It is all about things seen and about the manner in which something is seen.Regarding your second point; are we Òmeant toÓ seek such understanding?  You, yourself, have already answered this question with an affirmative answer with the examples you have listed above.  To answer further with regard to the praxis under discussion; many ÒspiritualÓ traditions suggest the use of various disciplines that use imaginal focus.  This is not imaginary, rather it uses a specific be-ing as a centering image that allows the individual to slowly, and with practice more rapidly, shift their concentration from the self into the awareness of the other.  The other becomes oneÕs center allowing a new awareness to be birthed.  This is not perception, rather it is a meta-conscious awareness that has no verbal component.  This experience of seeing beyond with its movement into a deep moment of life mindfulness is deep sensory awareness and memory.As an example I will relate an experience of this from my early childhood (age three to seven).  A tree (again this simple image) grew at the edge of my familyÕs front-yard. It was a young pine, Scotch pine to be specific.  It was young enough (its first branches, low to the ground) but strong enough to be the perfect climbing tree.  I would spend hours in this tree, much to my motherÕs dismay and displeasure, for I would frequently come down with pine pitch covering my hands and on my clothes, but she would never scold me for this consequence.  I would perch myself for hours it its topmost branches and sail away to my other home, not a better/superior home, just other.  My favorite days for this sailing were the windiest ones; I would rest in my trees embrace, secure in my perch as a result of this treeÕs growth pattern (four branches growing out from the center, two of which I looped my legs around, one providing my seat and the other the focus for directionality) and I would just sail.  I would feel the wind against my face and hands but also deeply through the trees own movement. This movement would guide me home; accompanied with the trees own voice in concert with the wind through its needles, everything from the softest of whisperÕs to  intense clamorous shouting and we, together, would fly.  This Home was a safe, constant, shifting moment alive to and with every movement of natureÕs breath.  In late autumn when it was the coolest during which my mother would still allow my ascent, she would have to come and claim me from this other home when she was worried for my wellbeing.  I would descend with my own expressed displeasure at this interruption of my journeying, my hands and face red, my fingertips and lips blue but with only the felt experience of my trees shared warmth.During my seventh summer the townÕs planning commission decided our road required widening for greater ease of traffic flow.  Per this plan, My Tree was to be removed.  My grandfather, a town supervisor, was placed in charge of this project.  I begged him to alter the roadÕs course to spare MY TREE, I pled with him, I sobbed and wept to no avail.  The day my tree was ripped from the earth, murdered, I watched silently, shedding tears for her death. For days afterward I would speak to no one.  For weeks longer I would not speak to my grandfather, not even when I was punished for my disrespect of not answering his direct questions.  After one such punishment, sitting alone, crying.  I suddenly had a sense of complete joy and wonderment descend over me: I was suddenly flying with MY TREE again.  I realized that she could not be taken from me, and oh the bliss.  I have never lost that joy nor that way of seeing beyond.

With regard to canons, western or otherwise, they are  all of suspect value.  If the approach to the texts presented is one of some essential litmus test of necessary to be fully human, these must be learned, then the text itself becomes a thing of violence.  If, on the other hand, the texts are presented as valuable because of what is transmitted, but certainly not of unquestionable authority, then the text has a greater chance of opening itself to the mind of the student and perhaps opening the mind of the student to wonder. This process, however, must be one of dialogue not monotonous monologue which is often nothing more than a form of mental masturbation on the part of the so-called educator, offering little of value to the student.Concerning evaluative methodologies, competitive scoring is itself an instrument of terror that often causes pleasant children to rebel and become labelled problem students. Why not use a portfolio system that follows the child/student's course of progress over their educational career, demonstrating their progress in various disciplines over that career. If they are weak in an area or two, their educational career could be continued for a year or two without cicatrizing the student as a failure for life.
Just a suggestion but you might wish to read such scholars as Marija Gimbutas or Riane Eisler for further insight in these matters.

I would say that most of the parallels are less likely to come from libertarianism, which is a peculiarly American notion of individualist styles of thought.  More likely, one can find more similarities within the anarchist traditions, particularly individualist and social anarchism.  Many writers have done this recently.  In addition, I think that attention to anarchism thought does begin to shed light on the paradoxes Slingerland outlines.  Of course we are not natural.  How can we be when the dominant influences in our lives, from an early age, and are not "natural".  And of course we will act a little badly even when we are all moving in the right direction, life is not simple and neither are we.  The point of all this is that we are in a process, not aiming at a final end.  Lao Tzu performs the function of giving some decent, but ambiguous, signposts toward that path, but not clear idea at all of the end result.  What Slingerland calls a paradox is just an ambiguity which results from no one, even Lao Tzu knowing the path for each person, much less for us all.  The end result might not be a simple reversion to some agricultural paradise.  It may be more complicated than that.  For us and for Lao Tzu.

This is a comment on Dr. Slingerland's description of Buddhist impermanence, which, I thought, didn't quite get the concept, especially how it is expressed in the Chan/Zen tradition.In Zen, as expressed by Dogen in 13th century Japan, impermanence means that I am just a temporary manifestation of earth, and if I could fast forward time, I would see myself and all other beings throughout all space and time, rising up and returning to the earth. Everyone and everything, all plants, animals and inanimate objects are nothing more than the earth breathing us out and in. Whoosh - we are here; whoosh, we are not. We enter existence on the out breath; and retreat to non-existence on the in breath. This vast and eternal process of coming into being and then moving into non-being, this taking and losing of shape and form, is impermanence. Once we know how small our bodies are compared to the enormity of the whole process we begin to realize what is actually going on here. On the one hand, impermanence is terrifying. There is nothing to grasp, everything will be lost.  On the other hand it is beautiful. Suffering will pass, like everything else. Once we fully realize impermanence in this way, we can settle into life as it is and realize that the surface of our lives, the particulars, are but a vehicle to express this profound fundamental reality. In this way we come to accept our conditions, as they are, and can reach the ineffable depth of life. That is, "This is my life, I can embrace everything in my life. In this moment, which will pass before I have the time to notice it, I have everything I need to realize the reality of my life. I can stop striving for what is not already here." This is awesome presence!
