In response to question and issues raised try reviewing perspective presented below from Folk of the Earth:The Folk of the Earth (F.O.E.) ManifestoSection I  Who knows the curious mystery of the eyesight? The other senses corroborate themselves, but this is removed from any proof but its own, and foreruns the identities of the spiritual world. A single glance of it mocks all the investigations of man, and all the instruments and books of the earth, and all reasoning. What is marvellous? what is unlikely? what is impossible or baseless or vague--after you have once just open'd the space of a peach-pit, and given audience to far and near, and to the sunset, and had all things enter with electric swiftness, softly and duly, without confusion or jostling or jam?.....Walt Whitman, Preface, Leaves of Grass.  1855.The Earth calls out to her friends.  She cries, screams, shrieks, yelps, hollers loudly for friends to feel her/their mutual need.  Her course is our course and her pulse is fiercely felt, forcing her now into us.  Her hold is complete; no leap of body, mind or soul ever escapes her embraceÉthe whisper of her searching sighs insinuates, plies her caressing kiss, penetrating skin and heart and blood and brain to beingÕs very center moment.  Our being always replies through its own sensing song but seldom, and then but by a few, is the sensed sigh, caress, celebrated in joyous consentience.  Her companions quake to behold her beautyÕs constant munificence.  Mere knowledge cannot comprise the quick gift of this congruent consciousness nor hold the heart of it. The intuited intention tendered in these crying, pulsing, penetrating, searching sighs push her intimates toward deeply felt, careful, conscious engagement.  Engaging the shared being of her fellow few, her now embodies the only path that can be taken home.  For home welcomes all, wearied, wondering, wandering toward the common, only end.  This engagement contends:         Ahimsa; nonviolence is the only mode for livingÉviolence against any is violence against all and against the earth.  Violence in all its forms and practices must be eschewed.  Life is sacred; to act against life denies the common source of all. The pulse is a measure of remembrance; now and now and now is all, no more.   State violence or threat of violence demeans the common existence of all its members; that the individual member must not harm, maim or kill any other but that collectively such acts are enjoined for the preservation of all its membersÕ wellbeing is an obvious contradiction that should require no further elaboration.  Economic violence is the daily continuous violence committed by the wealthy few against the rest.  Their amassed wealth is theirs because they insist soÉ it is regarded by a widely feared authority known as the IRS as unearned and is listed as such on tax returns.  If unearned, how does this alienated wealth belong to this few?  The modes and structures of production and service generate this violence and continue to intensify this violence by their persistence.  Their persistence continues only as a consequence of the laws and conventions that are maintained by the violence or threat of violence that the state insists it has as a right to and from itself.Environmental violence is a direct consequence of economic violence; the few in their largely unhampered drive to amass more wealth refuse to consider or be responsible for the harm their greed does to others and the earth.  Their mechanisms of production belch out toxins into the air, pour out poisons into rivers and streams, devour whole forests and degrade the very soil.  Any attempt to constrain their greed or mitigate their destructive practices is met with shrieks of unfair redistributionism and cries of too costly for sound business practice.  Unfair, for whom?  Too costly, when the continued sustainability of life on this globe is threatened? When the state and the oligarchs collude, disaster for the commons ensues.  The disaster is not theirs alone: the few depend upon the many for so much.  This relationship disturbs the few and they seek ways to escape.  This fantastic denial of their familial need for others to succeed drives their ever greater dependence on resources to insulate themselves from the others they fear.  This fear fuels the fewÕs fervent refusal to acknowledge their own dreaded commonality: their hungers, needs, desires are superior and must be granted their due priority (they, the few, insist).  Their attempts to isolate themselves behind walls of unbreachable security, requires the commitment of an ever increasing accumulation of ruthlessly extorted reserve resources that they feel compelled to hoard as their shield against the many.  This disaster becomes catastrophe when the blinkered state assumes the priorities of the few as just and blindly enforces the privilege of the few as rule of law.  The weight of law becomes the crushing blow of violence as more and more of the many reject the justice met out by the state on behalf of the few and the state is obliged to brutally enforce the letter of the law, suddenly, writ large in the blood of the many pouring through the streets and sluicing into culverts, ditches and gutters.The ruthlessly extorted resources required by the few are obtained by any unfair means of acquisition that can by conceived of by the minds of Òlegal expertsÓ retained by the few for this specific purpose.  These doyens of determined desire willfully delineate as correct, reasonable and ethical any means of procurement for the least possible expenditure of the fewÕs amassed wealth (the one exception to this rule being their own fee for services provided).  They insist, as a matter of course, on exclusions and limitations of liability as the cost of doing business with their clients.  The destruction of watersheds, wetlands or supplies of safe potable water, while most certainly unfortunate are to be allowed but not factored into cost.  Incidental unsafe working conditions that harm, main, or cause the deaths of workers; the client must be free of any liability and such results cannot be factored into cost of doing business with the client.   Exclusion after exclusion and rejection of all culpability for any harm consequent to the enterprise are insisted upon and must be officially sanctioned. The few, now free of all responsibility for injury done, continue to dwell in their paradise of illusion and mirrored expectation while the many are forced to live with the dire consequences of the fewÕs greed, let loose upon them by the very apparatus of the state charged with insuring their safety and well-being.This misdirection of state apparatus results in increasing degradation of all environments, both natural and culturally conditioned.  Homes of wildlife and the people are destroyed, displaced or disappear, seas become deserts, lakebeds drained and all significant resources depleted without concern for future consequences.  The very air becomes a curse, choking all with toxins, noxious gasses and malodorous fumes.  The simple hope of having safe, potable water dwindles to a dream for those without the ready cash (or not participating in a cash economy) for purchasing this privilege.  Wildlife is left to adapt to or perish from the ever escalating presence of poisons, toxins and waste in their now, frequently, uninhabitable habitats.  These habitats, themselves, disturbed, degraded or destroyed, disappear. The recognition of ahimsa and a return to its reasonable application as the central principle for all systemsÕ operation is the only hope that our species possesses as a means for our continued existence on this planet.  Ahimsa, through its skillful practice, will lead to meaningful coexistence with our fellow humans and all other species and will answer the ever-escalating assault on the globe and her people.  The careful, considered implementation of this principle in practice will result in a more equitable sharing of resources, the re-evaluation of all means for ÒdevelopmentÓ and to a more careful and consistent examination of all pursued goals.  Ahimsa is our only way forward.
I agree. Consider the retreat to counter attack, is this not deception? Or the social (dating) situation where you act like you are uninterested, is this not deception?

One difference with libertarians is that although Laozian thought promoted the idea of a free market, they did not think that the market would solve problems. In fact the reason the market should be left alone is so that its small evils (individual sellers) would not turn into great evils (collusion against the government). Laozi probably would have seen a "corporation" as a great evil.

I look forward to knowing more about the explanation why it was so important to bury the deceased king with so much wealth so to get him as ancestor appeased and therefore a good and protecting ancestor. Convincing the ancestor was more important for the good fortune of all than depriving those still living from what could help them in a moment of crisis? Symbolic value was so much more powerful than exchange value? Very different from the world we live in!!!

I guess that it is much more elaborated. I read as the good of one may only be achieved by the good of all. So, there is no room for contrast between one and all because it makes no sense. You simply cannot separate the good of one from the good of all. It is closer to Aristotle proposition of ethics. However, it is different because Aristotle glorifies the one with virtue whereas here the one with virtue does not necessarily stand out of all. His/her recognition as with virtue is not independent of the good he procures for all; it would shine less with the pretense of standing out of all.

I'm confused, please help.  Prof. S. translates 19.2 of the Guodian text as, "cut off cleverness, abandon profit, and the people will return to being filial and kind".  A reading of the bamboo slip and its translations on daoisopen.com, suggests that passage as, "cut off cleverness, abandon profit, and robbers and thieves will be no more".  Similarly, Prof. S. translates 19.3 as, "cut off artifice, abandon reflection, and thieves will be no more", but reading the translations of the bamboo slip suggests something like, "cut off artifice, abandon reflection, and people return to new-born".  Did the professor just mix them up or is there real wiggle room in the translation?  Or is there something else I'm missing?  Thanks for clarifying.

Mao wanted power for the sake of power. I don't think he was influenced by Laozian primitivism or Confucian thought.  He didn't want people to go back to the natural way because of philosophy or religion. He just wanted power over people.  Mao definitely did not want anything to do with Confucian thought because he sought to destroy China's cultural past through the 'Cultural Revolution'.
I also thought about medicine and the medical field concerning the Dodejing. Is pain, suffering, and early death an ok result of doing nothing, not learning?
I agree. What a shame people can't just "tell it like it is" in romantic relationships.

I think that philosophy is posing questions and not really offering any definite answers, while religion is offering only the answers in the form of normative guidance and do not really question reality. Therefore to me there is a big difference between philosophy and religion. Could you please comment on this critical aspect of philosophy that religion does not share ?
column35: Philosophy of Questions and Religion of Answers

column25: I agree! Thanks Prof. Slingerland. The videos are enjoyable and thought provoking.

I would agree too except to say that Prof's point of view is still paradoxical in that it to some extent 'balances' or 'adjusts' our contemporary yin yan 'comfort zone' & I don't think that is a bad thing. It has awakened our discussion of a very deep, paradoxical philosophical tenet that has, in Western society at least, become 'New Age' & bland.As I said, this is no bad thing.

This is how if find myself in respect to the third lecture about daoism... and I am not sure how.Perhaps happends that after reading the Daodejing, the Zhuangzi and the Liezi I have all the daoist ideas mixed into my head, while the teacher is only focusing on the Daodejing. But sometimes through the lecture I had the impression that the teacher wasn't really interested on the topic or was more focused on talking of the daodejing in relation to the confucianism rather than explaining daoism itself.Anyway thanks for this amazing course, I am really enjoying it and looking forward for the next modules.

We are talking in depth about the paradox of Wu Wei, of trying not to try & of knowing/ not knowing, of the danger of over using words... & then going on to write books about it. We have also discussed how science can show that words can significantly cloud our perception of reality... & my intuitive response is to ask, *'what about poetry?'*To me the Dao De Jing is, along with its many other subtle & profound qualities, one of the world's most beautiful poetic works & so I ask again *'what about poetry?'*I'm no poet & not too good a Daoist either but it does occur to me that when we have tried to describe the indescribable, to 'eff the ineffable', it is the poets amongst us that comes closest to success. Isn't that in some way what Lau Tzu is saying? That we must reawaken to this latent simplicity & wonder like a child... like a poet? We must remember that when our found texts were written it was not just 4 or 5 centuries BCE it was also more than 2 millennia 'Before Art' too. In many ways though it is also an 'artistic' archetype that it is both using & trying to describe.I am of course also aware that our modern day concept of 'Art' is riddled with bullshit but I still think its a point worth making & if you feel you can illuminate further ??? I'm listening.

column25: I have read many of the discussions and found them quite profound.  One additional thought I find quite interesting.  Daodejiang is over 1200 plus years old and the issue of today are exactly the same in his day as there are today.  Humanity is stuck in a time warp.  The old adage of not paying attention to history will doom you to reliving same.   The daodejing is at  my bed side like another works of literature, but I admit i get much greater solace from Lao-tzu.
Question, might it be the forest and the trees,

Prof. Slingerland's argument possibly contains too much hard yang energy for some though given the length of his lecture's a softer yin energy can, and fundamentally must, be present. I think, with reference to AveryMorrow's response, a blanket label of all Daoists think 'this way' examples the inadequacies that language may contain as expressed by Prof. Schooler, especially in trying to describe 'duality' if that is the correct term.

a passing thought, there's a common 'Western society' attribution of when describing the yin yang symbol, it's a 'there's a little bit of good in every bad' or something along those lines. I put it forward that the circle is a closed system and the yin and yang are always equal though as one becomes spatially larger, the other becomes proportionally compressed, the total amount of energy in the system remaining the same. At the peak of the yin, the yang is fully compressed representing the dot instead of the idea of the dot representative of only a little yang.

Wayyyyyy more than you want to know about economics!! Please skip if you are not interested in this topic. Better to just enjoy the masterful presentation of Daoism!!Nevertheless, just to add something to the discussion, since it was raised, I have added some links about the battle over the Easterlin paradox.As we are aware, there is a massive effort going on trying to figure out what is happiness, well being, and how to measure it, influence it. Wouldn't Zhuanzi enjoy our craziness! FWIW, as you can see below, it is far from a proven fact that the paradox exists, that income does not increase happiness, well being, definitely in the short run, and perhaps in the long run. Perhaps relative status and  adaptation do not explain things after all.Betsey Stevenson and Justin Wolfers have published quite a bit about how the Easterlin Paradox is wrong:http://www.brookings.edu/~/media/research/files/papers/2013/04/subjective%20well%20being%20income/subjective%20well%20being%20income.pdfhttp://users.nber.org/~jwolfers/papers/NewStylizedFacts(Emotion).pdfHere is Easterlin's responsehttp://www.pnas.org/content/107/52/22463.fullHere is Wolfers speaking very recently at AspenWolfers and Frank at AspenIf happiness can be explained by statuss anxiety and influence, why do low income US citizens not move to Mexico, where they would be at the very top of the economic ladder? Why do middle income Mexicans move to the US where they are in the low income brackets??  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YCV8IPlP-GEpdf of talkhttp://www.aspenideas.org/sites/default/files/transcripts/AIF11_052_econ_of_happiness.pdfHere is a summary of this dialogue in the Atlantic:"I came away thinking the Easterlin Paradox was a smoking wreck, and that pursuit of economic growth remains a worthy objective even for rich countries."http://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2011/07/the-measure-of-human-happiness/241368/An October 2014 study which shows that we experience more negative well being from a downturn than positive well being from an upturn. Thus, the economy may improve but the net result of cyclical swings is that we are at net zero, even though the economy has improved:"On the one hand, a typical reading of the income-happiness paradox suggests that further growth in the developed world is a futile means to the end of improving societal well-being. On the other, researchers who find evidence of a positive relationship between well-being and GDP typically take from this that further economic growth is good for society. Our findings suggest a more nuanced perspective: policy designed to engineer economic \booms", but that risks even relatively short \busts" is unlikely to improve societal well-being in the long-run. Steady positive growth that minimizes the risk of economic contraction seems the most likely route to an improvement in general well-being."http://cep.lse.ac.uk/pubs/download/dp1304.pdfThese articles show that subjective-well-being (SWB) inequality decreases with economic growth, a very important consideration:SWB INEQULITY AND INCOMEhttps://w.scu.edu/business/economics/workingpapers/upload/SWB-Inequality-and-Income.pdfhttp://www.melbourneinstitute.com/downloads/hilda/Bibliography/Working_Discussion_Research_Papers/2014/Clark_etal_Economic_growth_evens_out_happiness_dp1306.pdfThis is an important article that shows the efficiency with which countries use their increased wealth is an important consideration. Thus,the scandinavian coutures are able to achieve higher happiness SWB scores than the US because they use their wealth better. This may explain some of the flattening that apparently appears as high income levels--EFFICIENCYhttp://mpra.ub.uni-muenchen.de/57784/1/MPRA_paper_57784.pdfSigh---the facts are always so very, very elusive--Just my two cents---All the best,  Jisai
Hi FiveWillowsJust feel that if you "substitute fancy for five" you loose a lovely put down of brainless listing and enumeration.It's my pet hate.Yup, both are good.Kind regardsGeoffrey

Hi RackinrollAnother good way to frame it.I remember finding a great cartoon in a music magazine showing a brain surgeon, with scalpal in hand, poised over a patient whose shaved skull was covered in phrenological markings and turning to his assistant with the words: "Nurse, I can't see any emotion in here".Thus in my bad old days endless business change inititiatives - driven by MNA/UHB (Mind-Numbing Analysis, Untouched by Human Brain) of organisation charts - used to be called "counting the brain cells". The structure might be "streamlined" but the culture was left in trauma.Laozi (whoever) knew better.Heigh hoKind regardsGeoffrey

Many of the ideas expressed in the module 3 raised some questions about the influence of the Daodejing in the utopian world of Pol Pot in Cambodia, the fact that many of the passages can be corresponded to what happened in that country raised some red lights in my head.Also I would like to add that usually when I«am discussing some hypotetical "better" world with someone (from Jehova«s witnesses to communists) who have an idealized form of future world view, they usually coincide in terms of what to do with those who can not agree with the new order and the answers can be astonishing violent, they even have admitted the need to use violence for the "greater good". I think that all of us should be careful when learning about a new philosophy or set of ideas since in many times the moral driving to realice them have in some many times led to human suffering and destruction.

Hi damcor10Yes. Isn't it chilling that "being good" so often means "being just like me" and "death to anyone who disagrees". The Christian bible, for example, seems greatly to relish the contemplation of the terrible fate of those who don't take Jesus Christ as their personal savior: separating the chaff from the wheat, the goats from the sheep... "they will be tormented day and night forever and ever" (Revelation 20:10).Kind regardsGeoffrey

Hi 6d61726975737aYes. It is impossible to match the grotesque reality of what it portrays. Where can Series 3 go?Kind regardsGeoffrey

It should be noted that in the Dao De Jing, "Laozi" is very strongly anti-war and state-on-citizen violence. I'm not so sure that the "pressing with unhewn wood" is advocating violence, so much as it is advocating "using" your De to get a person back into line.Regarding your last paragraph, while your point that we shouldn't get so wrapped up in our morality that we start making immoral decisions is true, I'd like to make the counterpoint that, just because some people who have aligned with an ideology/philosophy were violent or immoral, it doesn't mean that the philosophy itself is.Every line of thought has its extremists. If we had to reject every idea that some crazy person was willing to kill over, we would have no ideas left.

Chinese is apparently different enough from English to warrant several hundred different translations of the Dao De Jing on Amazon.com.Seriously though, there is always a little wiggle room in translating to English, even if the translation is from languages as close as German or French. In Chinese, I've heard that it is often the case that there is no easy way to translate a phrase to English, and a little creativity has to be injected into the result by necessity.

This is a very interesting point. Evil is only invoked when there is a need of replacing one order (one dynasty) for another (new dynasty). Shang dynasty was only established by the second king when he managed to overthrow the king that finally was found evil. I don't think it's propaganda but a strong argument to sustain the legitimacy of change and the one that changed not as punishment of humans but as correction by higher up beings (Shang Di and ancestors). The interesting part is that it justifies nurturing virtue and being prosocial

Further to being in state of wu wei is try not to try (or today taken as spontaneity). The course show civilization through water being tamed and used better and sustain more population that give kings more power to enlarge territory under control. In the meantime the issue of governance becomes more relevant and so thinking and acting gets sophisticated. Life is better without conflict and leaders role taken as crucial. Being virtuous emerges as the way to prevent dissensions and contrary to the notions of heroes in the west people in early China attributed it to following the right path (and being prosocial) and earning de (charismatic power) as consequence of accepting guidance from superior beings in the community (ancestors and Shang Di/Heaven). Ming takes a bit further to the heavenly mandate. Quite different from our quest for democratic, humanly mandate that so often proves very fragile!!!
That is how I have learned to read it.
When the dew "falls," it sweetens everything, without discrimination except on that which is covered by  "taboos and prohibitions," cleverness, and laws (Ch. 57).
I don't see how the origins in the daodejing could lead to this.
column35: Laoism as a religion was later associated with mysticism and alchemy.

column25: I agree with Avery. I think that these are two very different concepts. The Bhuddist Samsara is something that you have to get rid of. Whereas the way is something that you have to embrace.

No, I got this mixed up somehow. The last half of 19.2 and 19.3 should be as wardbruce62 suggests. I must have been looking back and forth between different versions and gotten them garbled. Classical allows wiggle room, but not that much! Nice catch wardbruce62, sorry about that.

The desires of the eye that take people to the extreme, causing to themselves and others hardship, most often than not,  are powered by fear. An emotion so pervasive, weÕre so used to it that nobody talks about it. ItÕs the 400 pound gorilla in the room. Nobody wants to acknowledge that we operate almost daily under some sort of fear ÒpressureÓ, and that this is the engine which powers the excesses of the eye.In ancient times, when wars and famine were much more widespread than in present times,individuals had more opportunities to experience the discomforts of hunger, suffering and pain. Non-stop behaviours of hoarding, defending. invading, inventing better weapons for the sake of survival can power any country or village to built any wall of China, accumulate extreme worldwide riches, or stimulate anybodyÕs creativeness to the extreme.  One would say that in modern times, the WEIRD people have not suffered from wars and famine so much, but the excesses continue .  Fear is ingrained in our universal subconscious and/or genes, as result of living on planet Earth.  It gets intensely activated when thereÕs a prospective for competition. Even when weÕre dealing with something as superficial as competing with the Smiths for the bigger Hummer to go to Whole Foods for display; it signals a survival strategy. Intuitively, the counterpart of survival is death.  The desires of the eyes is the Yang expression, and fear is its Yin counterpart.  Using Laozi language: the more fear one has, the more desire it generates. The explanation for why we havenÕt noticed fear around us in our daily lives may be found on Richard Nisbett & Timothy WilsonÕs research and contribution to social psychology.  They have found that in general,  we donÕt know ourselves.  According to them, we donÕt really know the real reason for our decisions.Furthermore, an ongoing MOOC course in edx.org, which seeks to uncover the hidden reasons for our choices, led by Harvard professors Kegan Lahey, is finding that  fear is present- and I dare to say, as the main reason behind  life-long repetitive behaviours.  Check it out by assisting to their forum. http://mindsatwork.com/programs-services/coaching-for-individuals/edx-massive-online-open-courseAs you know, MOOC activities are a quick and efficient way to assess masses opinions, trends and behaviors.If youÕre still skeptical about my point, IÕd suggest you to participate in this course and have some experience of your own and examine your own life motives. See whether your perspective about the desires of the eye persists afterwards, as joining the course is another way to access to the forum.
column35: The desires of the eye - no mention of the universal fear for survival??

column25: I feel that Confucius' comments on Laozi and Laozi's school are true at heart.  Why?Because at that time, it was still possible to escape from cities, govern and empires (or kings whatsoever).  A more "authentic" life was only some (quite) miles away: among the nomadic tribes of nowadays Manchuria, Mongolia, or on the "Far West" of nowadays China.It was still possible to escape from the real of Chinese "cilivized, agrarian, urbanized" world: just running away to societies where people lived still in "prehistory".In that way, I think that insisting on labouring the landfields with no oxen, or insisting on living in tiny, close community is something like a "wishfull thinking" - just so nice.That is the way I would like to know if Laozi had some views on the people living outside the realm of Chinese civilization, if he had some views on those nomadic tribes - which were living not so far away from the villages he dreamed of.Thanks for your collaboration!

Yes, this is what I was thinking as well. And what about the people who do not want to garden or hunt? The dreamers and tinkerers, the art-makers. Is there room for them in a primitive society?I don't think it's possible for a primitive society to remain primitive. Even if, by some miracle, they aren't run over by greedier societies. Innovation and creation is what humans do. The explosion of technology and infrastructure in the last twenty years is proof of that. And I think that it's overall a good thing. Technology isn't the problem (isn't this class itself an example of that?), desire might not even be the problem, but perhaps lack of empathy is, because that's what makes it ok for the 'elite' to abuse lower classes.Bit of a tangent, but these thoughts were running in my head while I was watching the slides. I think the Daoist intention is sweet, but misguided.
HAHA yes.

Yes, I noticed this problem as well. So...what is the correct answer? The lecture (Shang Di does not received sacrifice) or the answer given here of Royal Family, although "living" is not specified. Did Shang Di receive sacrifice or not?

It feels like every generation thinks there's a new, great problem in society that is the source of all evil. And it seems like the culprit is often technology.There is nothing inherently wrong with technology; in fact, technology is often wonderful. Isn't this class proof of that? I believe that technology is the reason many people can make a successful living doing what they love, because the basic needs of life are relatively easily attainable. Technology today is what links almost everyone together on the planet--because along with technology comes knowledge, particularly knowledge of other cultures, which allows us to reach across vast distances and see that we are all human. I don't think technology makes us less human--but more.The problem with humanity is rarely anything new, but often something very, very old--lack of empathy and compassion. Because that's what makes it ok for people to abuse others that they have power over.

The problem right now is that the terms GMOs and Monsanto are highly connected so partly educated almost equate them as in every GMO on the market is owned and distributed by an evil shadowy corporation whose aim is world domination or something along those lines. These companies are not exactly helping their reputation with for example lawsuits for patent infringement against farmers who accidently got some of the seeds on their field by wind, or forcing farmers to buy the seeds every year (although that can be viewed as a mechanism to prevent unwanted effects on the whole ecosystem).So in order for GMOs to stand a chance in public view the link to the companies has to be broken, the seeds should not serve to increase profits but should more or less be public goods. Under those terms I believe with some basic education a large part of general public would be far more accepting of this new technology.

Agreed on most points, though differences of foundations in different cultural canons shouldn't be overlooked simply because they share the labels "canon" and "authoritative." I'm not a strict cultural relativist. I do think the Chinese canon more humanistic and "sage" than many alternative canons, including the West's.And any teacher deserving the title knows the difference between educating--"leading out"--and indoctrinating. Preachers and ideologues do the latter.

Many of the current GMO crops being engineered are either:a)planned to be resistant to a pesticide (eg Roundup) so the pesticide can be sprayed indiscriminately - killing the weed around the crop and leaving the crop alone. This has led to crops saturated with pesticides (human pesticide loads are increasing), pesticide resistant insects, and death of "good" insects like bees and monarch butterflies. Or, b) versions of crops which require much more fertilizer (happily sold by large corporations) and/or more irrigation and therefore large dam and irrigation projects. Both make agriculture more resource intensive and expensive. Not a good approach if you need to feed a lot of people.
Not really, we throw away 1/3 of all food produced in this country.

Appreciating what we do have? I read somewhere that comparison is the source of dissatisfaction. It makes sense--you can go out to a restaurant and have a great meal, but it can be disappointing because it's not as great as the last time you ordered it. Etc.

Yeah. Language is an imperfect tool, but at the same time, it's necessary to our way of life. It's something that writers often struggle with--actually capturing what a thing or concept or feeling is with language is pretty hard.Some books play with the idea that, if you don't have a word for a concept, then you have no knowledge of the concept itself (like 1984, for example, making "good" and "bad" into the same word makes the words lose their separate identities, and nobody can tell the difference between what is good or bad anymore). But I do think you can think without language. Schadenfreude, for example, is a borrowed word from Germany, but once you hear what it means, there's an immediate sense of recognition. And, anecdotally, I often feel like I have an idea, but I just can't verbalize it. But it isn't until I verbalize it that I can really pound it out, so...points on both sides. Ha.
Marija Gimbutas' work certainly opened my eyes on the non-hierarchical 'Old Europe' societies - several years ago now. Thanks for reminding me davy.

Has anyone more insights into possible parallels between the 'unhewn wood' metaphor and the 'unhewn ashlar' metaphor? One is wood, the other is stone depending on worked materials at the time? I am unfamiliar with the schools of thought though, hopefully without being overly inquisitive, am entertaining the notion that 'unhewn wood' is contained in allegory of particular society/societies within China?I find it especially interesting comparing advances in neuroscience to philosophies given the increasingly sophisticated medical imaging technology. Does following certain modes or patterns of thought with applied intent dramatically change the neurological workings of the brain, limbic system etc. that much?My interpretation currently of the 'unhewn wood' terminology is a way of wiping the slate of the mind clean through constant applied thought before eventually engraining itself, or, creating and strengthening neurochemical pathways, by that time the additional teachings and instruction concurrently fashions the mind in a time tested method passed on from generation to generation.

'Jewishness' differs from Christianity and Islam in that it is both a religion and an ethnicity.Jew = person born to a Jewish mother (unless he/she later converts to another religion) OR a person who converts to Judaism.This means that1) An atheist born to a Jewish mother is still a Jew2) Many modern Jews don't look like the Jews living thousands of years ago, because of a) mixing with other peoples (both within marriage and without the benefit of marriage)b) conversions, sometimes in mass: e.g.; at the time of the prophet Mohamed, there were entire Jewish tribes on the Arabian Peninsula.

I just wanted to thank the Instructional Design team for making his peer assignment optional.  It puts a lot of pressure on the quizzes with only the lowest one being dropped, but so far that's working out for me.This is a major concern for me, since my past experiences with peer assignments on two other EdX courses fell far below expectations.  The first was mandatory and although 3 were indeed fair criticisms, the fourth one was exceptionally harsh and bottomed out my score.  I barely passed the class, despite stellar quiz scores.The second one made it optional (similar to this course) and due to my experience in the first course, I opted out since my quiz scores allowed me that luxury.  Afterward, we all received an announcement that due to developments with the process, the team grading decided to drop any peer-assigned grades and simply assign a participation grade, apparently due to similar experiences within the class.I have experienced both good and bad outcomes of peer-reviewed assignments in traditional learning settings, so I understand both the benefits of the device as well as the risks.  But so far in a massive, anonymous setting, I have yet to witness a positive experience.So I just wanted to say I think you designed the peer-reviewed assignment very well in this course.  If I have time outside of my traditional Masters program, I will definitely do it for the reward of intimate feedback.  But thank you for not making our grade dependent on the outcome.

Re mri's and alternative practice and measurable impact see below:Your Brain on Yoga: Calmer, More ContentMED study: mood benefits edge out walkingÕs													09.01.2010 					By Susan Seligson 			 http://www.bu.edu/today/2010/your-brain-on-yoga-calmer-more-content/								A study by a MED researcher has found that yoga appears to beat out the age-old stress reliever of walking in improving mood and decreasing anxiety. Photo by Temari on Flickr												Even the most mainstream psychiatrists might agree that yoga is like chicken soupÑit canÕt hurt. But researcher Chris Streeter has gone a step further toward validating yogaÕs potential to help treat depression and anxiety. In a study recently released in the Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine, the BU School of Medicine assistant professor of psychiatry and neurology scanned the brains of practitioners and found that compared with that age-old stress reliever, walking, yoga appears to be accompanied by greater improvement in mood and decrease in anxiety and a boost in the brain chemical associated with these benefits. In StreeterÕs 12-week study, a group of 34 randomly selected physically and psychologically healthy young men and women were divided into two groups, one that walked for an hour three times a week and one that practiced Iyengar yoga for the same amount of time. At four-week intervals, Streeter used a technique known as magnetic resonance spectroscopy to monitor subjectsÕ levels of a brain chemical called gamma-amino butyric acid, or GABA, elevated levels of which are associated with improved mood and decreased anxiety. She found that the yoga group reported a greater boost in mood than the walking group, with GABA levels matching those improvements. Although the role of GABA still isnÕt completely understood, her study is the first to demonstrate the GABA-mood-yoga connection by looking at actual changes in the brain. BU Today spoke with Streeter about the implications of the study and the future of yoga as a way of treating mood disorders.BU Today: What is the main implication of this study?Streeter: This is the first study when weÕre able to measure GABAÕs relation to yoga. GABA is an important neurotransmitter, which is decreased in depressed people and increased in people who take so-called SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), like Prozac, and itÕs also implicated in anxiety disorders. ItÕs been reported for years that yoga helps people with depression and anxiety, but in this study we took people who didnÕt have any experience with yoga and found that mood scales were higher in the yoga group, and so were GABA levels.Why did you choose Iyengar yoga?The beauty of Iyengar is that itÕs been around for a long time and itÕs pretty rigorous, with really well defined postures. And when you say itÕs an Iyengar intervention, people know what you mean. There are variations in it, but as far as yoga goes, itÕs as consistent as you can get. The other thing is, when people say Òyoga,Ó it could be breathing, postures, meditation, or all of those things. But I had the subjects do mainly postures because I could see them actually doing it.Do you think yoga alone could be a viable treatment for anxiety or depression?ItÕs been suggested. But I would say itÕs not a substitute, but rather an adjunct to treatment. ItÕs an exciting behavioral intervention, but the results here are associative, not causal. ThatÕs a problem, expanding these results to say that doing yoga as a substitute for oneÕs meds is a good idea. ItÕs not. And doing yoga without proper training or supervision is not advised.How does the use of magnetic resonance spectroscopy change the nature of mood studies?ItÕs really exciting. The scan, which we use in conjunction with McLean Hospital, is really cutting-edge technology. Now we can measure what has historically been hypothesized. It used to be that if you could cut the brain, that was how you saw that these abnormalities were organicÑit was not, so to speak, in the personÕs head. But with functional imaging we have this picture that shows, gosh, hereÕs the brain of a depressed person before and after. ItÕs a much harder science.Why did you decide to compare yoga to walking?You really do need a control group. There have been a number of studies comparing aerobic and nonaerobic exercise that show exercise helps ease depression and anxiety. In this study, the walking group clearly had more exercise, and they were very active people. But the yoga group had more improvement in their mood than the walking group.Could yoga be used to treat bipolar disease and thought disorders as well as depression and anxiety?Yoga is probably always a good thing, more helpful than harmful. But some breathing exercises are not good for people who are manic or psychotic. They can trigger a psychotic episode.Is mainstream psychiatry becoming more receptive to yoga as a treatment tool?Doctors arenÕt necessarily trained to prescribe it. But there was a study of using yoga to help treat epileptics. And weÕre getting to the point when weÕre actually getting good data. Yoga research is increasing exponentially.How did you get interested in this research? IÕve been interested in yoga since I was in the seventh grade. I loved the mind-body interface, and yoga is a very interesting mind-body subject. It helps people deal with all kinds of problems.Do you practice yoga?Oh yes. IÕve done a lot of different typesÑashtanga, power yoga, Iyengar.People might misinterpret these results to mean that yoga is better than walking. Can you clarify the comparision?In this study, in this population, walking didnÕt prove to be as beneficial to mood as yoga. It doesnÕt mean that yoga is better than walking in other populations and other situations. Susan Seligson can be reache

I thought the mention of givewell.org was the most significant part of this lecture.When a philosopher like Mozi is discussed, I find myself adopting a kind of liberal aversion.  It also sounds so dry, so institutional and austere.  But maybe, just maybe, we need an external and/or internal voice to remind us to stop philosophizing and get our heads out of our...books...and, as the folks on Madison do so often, instruct us to "Just Do It."  I think that's what the site facilitates.  It clears a great deal of clutter that one might encounter along the Way to giving or caring.While the current list of "top" charities is thin, note that the site will be updated in December.  In the meantime, there is plenty there to provide food for thought and reason (and a concrete means) to act.

Both Confucius and Mozi thought hot cognition was a problem, but it seems Confucius thought hot cognition could be changed by sufficient study of the classics, whereas Mozi did not think it could be changed and therefore should be harnessed by reason.  So Confucius is more optimistic about human nature?  In any event, they both seem to stand against Laozi.

It seems as though there could be a parallel between Laozi's philosophy and the part of the book of Ecclesiastes.  Below doesnt it seem like King Solomon is casting off the 'desires of the eyes?'Ecclesiastes Chapter 1These are the words of the teacher,[a] the son of David, king in Jerusalem.2 Teacher: Life is fleeting, like a passing mist.        It is like trying to catch hold of a breath;    All vanishes like a vapor; everything is a great vanity.3     What good does it do anyone to work so hard again and again,        sun up to sundown? All his labor to gain but a little?4     One generation comes, another goes;        but the earth continues to remain.5     The sun rises and the sun sets,        laboring to come up quickly to its place again and again.6     The wind in its travels blows toward the south,        then swings back around to the north.    Back and forth,        returning in its circuit again and again.7     All rivers flow to the sea,        but the sea is never full.    To the place where the rivers flow,        there the water returns to flow once again.8     Words, words, words! So many words! They are wearisome things;        and yet people cannot refrain from speaking.    No eye has ever surveyed the world and said, ÒI have seen enoughÓ;        no ear has ever listened to creation and said, ÒI have heard enough.Ó9     What has been, that will be;        what has been done, that will be done.    Nothing is new under the sun;        the future only repeats the past.10     One person may say of some idea,        ÒPay attention to this; itÕs original!Ó    But that same idea has already been expressed;        itÕs been with us through the ages.11     We do not remember those people and events of long ago,        as future generations will not remember what is yet to come.12 I, the teacher, was king over Israel in Jerusalem. 13 I decided to seek out and study the wisdom of the ages, of all that had been done under the heavens. I soon discovered the harsh realities of the work God has given us that keeps us so busy. 14 I have witnessed all that is done under the sun, and indeed, all is fleeting, like trying to embrace the wind. 15 There is an old saying:    Something crooked cannot be made straight,        and something missing cannot be counted.16 I mused over it all and thought to myself, ÒI have done great things, and I have gained more wisdom than anyone who reigned over Jerusalem before me. I have contemplated great wisdom and knowledge.Ó 17 I decided to study wisdom and instead acquainted myself with madness and folly. It, too, seemed like trying to pursue the wind, 18 for as my wisdom increased, so did my vexation. As my knowledge grew, so did my pain.

Oh Great! Thanks for getting back to me on it & I'm really glad it struck a chord. Almost their very first lecture introduced the paradoxical nature of happiness; *'Clearly, happiness is popular. But is happiness always good? Can feeling too good ever be bad?'*And much to my surprise, right from the outset the lectures were intellectually stimulating, scientifically sound & genuinely inspiring. I say 'to my surprise' because I had about 5 other MOOCs spinning at the same time & thought it might be a little bit of light relief, a *'walk in the park'..*.Everything introduced in the lectures were presented intelligently & scientifically validated by referenced research but, quite uniquely, there were frequent 'practical exercises' which really allowed you to test any assumptions 'in the field'. They weren't exactly difficult... far from it, they enhanced day to day activities & sometimes engendered joy, spontaneity & meaning. But they certainly weren't a *'walk in the park'!*I never realised previously how difficult it actually is to give food to strangers. Sometimes you really have to work at it lol ;)Your course & theirs have really been the MOOC'd up highlights of the year so far, perhaps more so because I was fortunate enough to be doing them at the same time & therefore benefited from the symbiosis.Congratulations on so-far & I really look forward to your upcoming episodes... **Anyone else out there ???**

The myriad creatures shoulder yin and embrace yang, and by blending these qi, Òvital energies,Ó they attain harmony. (Course text Chapter forty-two, line four.)All things submit to yin and embrace yang.  They soften their energy to achieve harmony.  (Charles Muller trans, chap. Forty-two, lines three and four. 1991.)Myriad things, backed by yin and embracing yang Achieve harmony by integrating their energy. (Derek Lin, trans. Chapter forty-two, Lines three and four. 2006.)The created universe carries the yin at its back and the yang in front; Through the union of the pervading principles it reaches harmony. (Lin YuTang, trans. Chapter forty-two, Lines five and six. 1948)The above translations are of the same passage, chapter forty-two of the DaoDeChing.  This is the first appearance of these two concepts conjointly in the text and yet Prof. Slingerland chose not to mention it in his lecture on the concept of yin and yang.  The symbol, generally referred to as the Taijitu, or the diagram of the supreme ultimate, has its origins, perhaps, in the concepts presented in the text of the I Ching, allegedly of great antiquity.  Per tradition, the I Ching, is a text that even Confucius held in high esteem and regretted not having had more time to study.  The above text (DaoDeChing, chap.42) in all of the four translations would indicate to me that the concept is about the union of the two forces in harmony, not about, ÒThis cycle of reversion É something we want to get out of. And in that way, it actually is similar in certain ways to the idea of samsara and Buddhism, in early Buddhism.Ó  (Slingerland lecture, 3.6).  Per Richard Wilhem and Cary F. Baynes, who translated the I Ching:  The fundamental postulate is the "great primal beginning" of all that exists, t'ai chi Ð in its original meaning, the "ridgepole"É. A still earlier beginning, wu chi, was represented by the symbol of a circle. Under this conception, t'ai chi was represented by the circle divided into the light and the dark, yang and yin,  . É what it posits is simply the ridgepole, the line. With this line, which in itself represents oneness, duality comes into the world, for the line at the same time posits an above and a below, a right and left, front and back Ð in a word, the world of the opposites. (Wilhelm, Richard and Cary F. Baynes. (1967). The I Ching or Book of Changes. Bollingen Series XIX, Princeton University Press. lv)I think the difference between my understanding of this symbol and Prof. SlingerlandÕs is one of focus.  He see the individual halves of the whole in some great opposing round.  I see the line, Òthe ridgepole,Ó and the circle presenting balance and harmony.  I do not say either focus is superior but I do think that the first paired mention of yin and yang in the DaoDeChing references harmony is significant.  On a side note, the Taijitu is usually seen as a good luck symbol in Chinese folk culture and is often paired with the following folktale:Once upon a time there lived a farmer in the three kingdoms of China.This farmer had a son who worked the farm with the help of a horse.The horse ran away one day.The local farmers came and said, "How unlucky, your horse ran away."The farmer said, "Perhaps."The next day, the horse came back, but was followed by a whole herd.When the local farmers found out, they said, "You have great luck."Again, the farmer said, "Perhaps."Another day passes, and the farmer's son broke his leg while riding some of the new horses.The local farmers again came, and this time they said, "What bad luck, your son broke his leg."The farmer repeated, "Perhaps."On the fourth day, the emperor's army were recruiting for the army and because of the son's broken leg, did not recruit him.The local farmers this time said, "What great luck, your son did not get recruited."The farmer again, repeated, "Perhaps."I will always see this symbol as a positive one.

To all who missed the Module 3 quiz:We apologize for our mistake. In the weekly reminder email a typo said: "Module 3 Quiz Due November 4, 2014 at 07:59 UTC." However, in the Courseware section, it said: "Due Nov 04, 2014 at 07:00 UTC," and that was when the deadline actually struck. We realize that many students may have just read the email, and missed the deadline for that reason. To make matters worse, Canada just went through a daylight savings time change, which may have had something to do with why the typo occurred in the first place.We have notified our technical staff, and are figuring out the best course of action. We will most likely be **reopening the Module 3 quiz** this week to give students who missed it a chance to submit their answers.Robin

Yes, I think part of the issue is that a 'traditional' classroom-based approach to peer assessment just doesn't translate well into the MOOC format; the checks/restraints can't be wholly replicated.  For example, the MOOC review is a transient, impersonal thing, so there are less external incentives to regulate your responses - chances are you will never encounter a given student again...  In a classroom when you teach how to peer review you have a sense of who understands/appreciates the process and who needs more input, which is simply not possible with the MOOC peer review process as it stands - the result is that it becomes something of a lottery.  I'm not sure if there are any easy answers.  There's only so much you can do as an educator when you put out your guidance.  The final step involves students (a) internalizing it and (b) deciding that the incentives to act upon it in the manner the educator intended outweigh other impulses (which can range from ticking a few boxes simply to get their own participant marks through to transposing their own ideas/preconceptions on the subject/process).  That said, I do believe that the majority of people enter into the process with a commitment to making it a positive experience/tool for learning.My gut reaction is to take away any external rewards for completing a peer review assignment, so that the only motivation to complete the process is internal, but that opens a whole new can of worms...and doesn't address all of the issues anyway.Apologies if this reads as overly cynical, that's not my intention.

I have been a fan of Peter Singer ever since I read his book 'Animal Liberation' in the 1970's. I respond to his ability to express uncompromisingly moral views with supremely logical and compelling arguments. I have also responded more recently to the proposal in his 2009 book *The Life You Can Save* that we should 'tithe' in whatever way we can afford, although I've picked out my own charities rather than going through givewell.org.I consider I was primed for this behaviour by my parents from the 1940s on. Their 'religion' was idealistic communism, principally based on the maxim: 'From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs'. And I haven't found a better one yet . . .

Mozi's main critique of Confucian taking virtue/de as the standard to judge people is the risk with de of degenerating into neptism and old boy networkism and cronyism. Yet, Confucius explicitly regets neptism, old boy networkism and cronyism. He says, "You need to be a gentleman ru not petty ru." In history Confucians never consider neptism as good. Rather they despise it. There is also plenty of evidence that Confucianism treats fairness seriously.So Mozi's critique of Confucian de as an ideal is not to the point. So how do we make sense of Mozi's critique? My idea is that as an ideal COnfucian de is good, but in real-world practice, this standard face the danger of degenerating into neptism and other ill practices. It is not objective. How do you think?
column35: Isn't Mozi's critique of Confucian virtue/de as standard to judge people rash or oversimplified?

Hi folksOh dear , oh dear, it sounds to me like Mozi is an early proponent of the profoundly destructive management myth that underpins salesforce incentive schemes and union piecework negotiations: "pay me more and I will work harder".So rationally seductive and so fatally flawed.For example, having bumped up doctors pay in the UK's National Health Service, the government has attracted General Practitioners who are not vocationally motivated, so hate the actual job they are required to do and are leaving in droves. See this typical piece: http://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/features/gp-practices-in-peril-doctors-leave-trainees-are-given-wrong-incentives-and-little-time-for-patients-9778473.htmlThus US Health Care which costs about twice as much as anywhere else in the world ranks in quality between 30th and 50th in the world according to the CIA World Factbook measures and various World Health Organization studies.We don't learn.I wonder what the Republicans will make of Obamacare.Shame, eh!Kind regardsGeoffrey

And so for such mutually filial sons to realize unlimited good results, must they not first care for and benefit other peopleÕs parents?I don't think that he says that everyone should be filial relations wiht the state, but that being impartial and doing your job right is important if you want to be truly filial child.

It does not seem to me that there is not that much difference East/West on the socialization that professor seems to imply.  In the West we are also taught to automatically "do the right thing" so every time we encounter a situation we have to think through what to do and "fight out instincts" to do it.  At least this is true for the world I inhabit.The more significant differences between the two seem to me to be the process by which we get there--not the end result.

column25: Perhaps there is no absolute knowable standard.  This is the problem with Mozi's philosophy.  Even if you could find a person who truly had a perfect standard, that person would eventually die, and someone else would take his/her place and perhaps have a different standard.  American presidents might be a good example.  George W Bush was widely approved of and people readily adopted his standards. Then Obama was elected, and he was viewed as exemplary, but his standards and policies were very different from Bush's.  And so Mohism founders on the shoals of reality.

Mozi's statement that the right standards come from Heaven is unavoidable, but irrelevant.  He posits a top-down system, with the king at the top.  If the king knows what's right, it's wise to attribute that to tian.  If he doesn't, then he loses the mandate.  Mozi makes it quite clear that most of the rulers of his day deserve to lose the mandate.More serious is the question of how you evaluate officeholder performance.  Maximizing tax revenue--until the people scream how loud?  Not all the government jobs have to do with taxes.  Yes, doing the sacrifices badly may be objectively evaluable if the boss is on the ball, but in many other jobs--for instance, those involving public works--it's not evident how Mozi proposes we should decide who gets rewarded or punished. Since it's a problem now, I'd have to assume it was also a problem then--which he contributed little to solving.

You paint Mozi as pure utilitarian when he was also a conservative. When talking about funeral rites he claimed that barbarian rites (which included cremation) were deficient, so I'd argue that he wouldn't throw out every social norm and rite just because it doesn't bring more wealth to people.I haven't finished reading Mozi, but I can imagine him saying that pleasantries that don't cost us much but bring happines to others are good, because happy people are less distracted from their work (or they're better at it) and that is beneficial to all.
Spot on!

For me, the objectivity of Mohist ideas have resonance with the concept of science. I just wonder whether China would have advanced much quicker in science if Mohist ideas were more prominent instead of Confucian ideas (which were taken up by emperors in the Han Dynasty).

It rather looks as if he thinks that people are meant to accommodate their desires to the norms established by the 'leader of the district'. He's talking about a fairly low base of material requirements for the most part, and it's hard to see his attitude to more sophisticated desires. I guess future people are catered for by the flourishing of the state, but that he reckons that future problems can be logically fixed at the time.

I agree that he does have a problem about soteriological standards, which he seems to solve by a vague appeal to ancient precedent, but he does have a range of objective measures too. I think I'd nevertheless have been made nervous by the section where he argues that you should basically be a cog in the social wheel and obey your boss, but yet you have an obligation to offer 'proper remonstrance' if your boss is wrong. Easy to lose your head that way.

Isn't he also arguing that the proof of statecraft is shown by its results - if you have a flourishing state, you're doing it right. It can be judged by such measures as GDP, military power or population growth.

Mozi doesn't care whether anyone is happy, he just wants to maximize his three outputs.It's clear he would favor total surveillance, whether the benefits came from the psychology, or the data was actually used.  Today's news, "Harvard Crimson."  A Dean authorized installation of secret surveillance in classrooms for "research purposes, to see the attendance at lectures."  When the secret got out (no, not from Snowden) there was some outrage.Possible uses of the surveillance: punish untenured professors with low attendance.  (Maybe they would deal with this by giving unannounced quizzes.  It's unlikely it would cause them to make their lectures more worthwhile.)  Teachers could use it to punish students who didn't come to lectures--whether or not they expected to be punished for low attendance.Result for sure is that attendance would go up and happiness would go down.

It is similar to what is usually assoiated with socialist thought, except for totally unimaginative.Properly getting rid of music and other creative art, painting calligraphy, etc. it kills human higher level thought. In fact it is similar to what is eing said by the Islamists in the Middle East, and their anti-West rhetoric.

That's what I got from reading him: If the state doesn't crumble then it means that the ruler is Good. And why is he Good? Becuase if Heaven didn't see him as Good his state would crumble and his subjects would die.(I think of Ouroboros when I read Mozi)I find some ideas of Mozi interesting (if hard to implement in real life) but all those parts where he is showing why he is right are kinda wonky. He would like to use pure logical reasoning to back his claims but ends up using his own interpretations of what Heaven wants. I have no problem with anyone using methaphysics as a backbone of their philosophy (as long as I'm not forced to live by it) but masquarading methaphysics as logic just rubs me the wrong way.

You make a good point about the admixture of old custom in Mozi's utilitarianism. It's hard to see what he thinks wrong with the burial practices of Yan and Yiqu, which are a lot more economical than what he proposes. I can't see him buying into the idea that happy people work better though: one's emotional state is surely in his definition irrelevant?

Mozi's argument is more against ostentatious waste than music per se - I wonder what he thought the farmers should get up to in the long winter evenings once they'd finished procreating! Did he reject The Book of Odes as of no use?
He might think snoopers would be better off doing something productive - ghosts are certainly cost-neutral, particularly when compared to NSA.

It seems that MOZI is founder of motinvation theory in East such theoriees flurished later in west such asMaslowÕs                AlderferÕs            HerzbergÕs            McClellandÕs Hierarchy                ERG                    Two Factor            Acquiredof Needs                 Theory                 Theory                   Needs Theoryand sespecially McGregors theory x and y. You can claim that if external rules are crucial, we have to be sure we get them right.But that misses the point.  The rules are supposed to be understood and followed by large numbers of people.  Hence the issue isn't what a proposed rule formulation "really means."  Rather, the issue is how to formulate the rule so that it will elicit correct action from as many of these people as possible.  Mozi knew a lot about human psychology.  We're now guessing that his successors knew or cared about this a lot less.

I think I see how the 'white horse' question can cause debate (though if I'd been on duty he'd have paid the tax) but I'm a little bit confused by the passage on robbers, where the Mohist argument does on the face of it seem a little contrived. How would a Mohist define 'men' in a statement such as 'we should cherish all men'? If Mohists can just change the definition of their category to suit a particular prejudice, such as not liking robbers, their attempt at intellectual precision surely goes out the window? What's to stop me defining philosophers as outside the category of 'men'?

Hopefully the difference between Mohism and Legalism will become clear as the course progresses, but couldn't one argue that Qin Shihuang tried a fairly objective logical way of growing his state and using rewards and punishments, which Mohists might have understood at least (even if they might have had problems with his benevolence)? China subsequently developed pretty fast scientifically and only really began to stagnate during the late Ming.

Isn't Confucian a bit flaky on the borderline between filial piety and nepotism? Though he does subscribe to 'do as you would be done by' suggesting a universal standard,he criticises the man who informed on his father for stealing a sheep. I can see why Mohists can regard Confucian de as so ill-defined as to be effectively subjective.

I was actually amused to see Mozi called a "scientific thinker" in the most recent season of the TV show *Cosmos*. He's not a scientist so much as a categorizer. The chapter where his "scientific experiment" comes from is from a long list of categories and definitions, such as the following:> What is leaning cannot be straight. Proof: A ladder.> > For things to be piled up there must be a support. Proof: A stone base.To achieve a European concept of "science" (which categorically could not have happened in ancient China) they would have needed some radical critiques of this paradigm for describing the world.

No, I agree with Andrew. Surveillance can be used to further the goals of the state, which is the impartial entity (even more impartial than ghosts) that helps distribute food and shelter. Rationally speaking, the state needs to know who to punish.

He's trying to maximize the wealth, population and order of the state. Preferences and interests of any individuals within that state are irrelevant, except to the extent that you can align them with these three desiderata.

There are some similarities, but notice that Mozi is not advocating a completely equal, egalitarian society, he thinks there should still be hierarchy. But in terms of authoritarianism and materialist standards for judging good, as well as the general anti-elite themes, there are some important similarities
The similarities I saw were between Moism and centralised, hierarchical, top-down control, hence my reference to Mao rather than Marx.

Communist idealists are quite different from the people who seized power in the 'communist bloc'. Marx actually saw the maxim I quoted working only when capitalism was gone, while my parents lived it every day, with very little money and lots of volunteer work of all kinds, mainly involving children from families on low incomes. Now I would call them left-wing libertarians, i.e. advocating and practising bottom-up local actions not top-down centralised control, by analogy with Noam Chomsky and Howard Zinn. And, as Avery says, living more like the Mohist theorists than like USSR apparatchiks (although my parents were obsessive supporters of the Arts). I have remarked elsewhere on the apparent foreshadowing of centralised communism in Moism: *Mo and Mao*.

It seems like a contradiction that the Mohists were *against* aggressive warfare and *for* maximizing the benefit of a given state.  In some cases, aggressive warfare is likely to benefit a state, at least in the long term.  So is Mozi really against *civil* war?  Is it that everyone who speaks Chinese is part of "the state," that is, one state, and should therefore be subject to "impartial care"?  Would Mozi be against attacking some nomads and taking their land, or would he consider them to be "people" as much as the people of the Warring States, and thus also subject to "impartial care"?  Would he go so far as to defend barbarians?  I rather doubt that he would.  So where is the dividing line?

SZanussi, you're right, this question was not well formulated. I can see why you went for choice D, Mozi certainly wouldn't think that a weakening of nepotism would be a bad thing; this wasn't quite what we had in mind when we formulated this question, but I can see now why you took it this way. If this were a quiz question, we really should accept either C or D as correct answers.

This is a really good question, and I'm not sure where Mozi would come down on this. My understanding has always been that he believed that, from the perspective of any given state among the Warring States, war would be a bad thing: so many people would die, and so much wealth be wasted, that war by definition is bad. Defensive warfare is merely to prevent war from beginning in the first place. But you make a good point that, from the perspective of some particular, strong state, maybe taking over a neighboring state, or some adjacent barbarian land, would be guaranteed to increase the wealth, population and order of the state. Among the Warring States thinkers I'm probably weakest on Mozi, I'm going to forward your question to a colleague of mine who might have a better answer.

Hi sirui2014I think we are getting back to the point of how can any criteria be objective... because you can always go back a step to ask "how were the criteria chosen to decide those so-called 'objective' criteria?" and then "how were the criteria chosen to choose the criteria to choose the criteria?" until you are forced to say the oroginal criteria were chosen subjectively.The social constructionists would say: "truth is defined socially" and "we know what we know because everybody says so".But our Prof has declined such "extreme" views... so we will see how this all unfolds in the lectures and discussions.Kind regardsGeoffrey

I think your distinction that Marxism only envisaged communism once goods were in abundance is important in seeking points of comparison for the Mohists. Though they accept social hierarchy, they want a basic standard of living for all. They are hardly libertarians but there is a strong socialist strain in their thought.

The fact that people who implemented communist ideals warped them or their meaning so they could achieve the goal they wanted to achieve isn't my point.My point is that this 'From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs' either means that everyones needs will be fullfiled and the amount of work they put doesn't matter, or that everyone will have the same needs which imples some sort of unification of values and discarding those need that can't be unified.I have respect for people who put their own time and money into helping others, but the spirit of the maxim reminds me of the ["Happiness is mandatory!"][1] trope from popular fiction (which is not surprising since it's inspired by real life oppresing regimes)  [1]: http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HappinessIsMandatory

Mozi reacts against Confucianism but obviously goes too far in railing against music. On the positive side, however, he is concerned with the basic material needs of the common person. He also sees war as destructive and bad.He is monochromatic and incorrect to see wealth as the single most important human motivation (if I have read him correctly); modern economists often make the same mistake.

I think Mozi was concerned with the overall benefit for all people (large and small states), as he believes in universial care (jian ai). And the way he saw War was probably that the bigger state wins (in the long term), but overall the world loses (not a zero-sum game, but a negative-sum game).
Mohism does show a proto-science; for example, in the Mo Jing. Also, some Mohists were tolerated despite their unorthodox views because they became excellent seige engineers.
Yes, all objects, including the objects of mind (thought, perception, emotion) are fleeting.

column25: There are a lot of views that were to be learned from Mozi so far, and some of them even make a lot of sense.But I just have to think about myself and how I function. When I have long work days and weeks, and concentrate on performing as good as possible, getting out the best results, sooner or later comes the point at which I cannot even force myself to go any further. Then I need a rest, go out or travel, listen to music, simply enjoy things, or prop up my legs and read or close my eyes to do nothing.I assume that it is more or less the same with other people, even if there might exist a difference in how long each and every of them can last.A kind of similar problem I see is with punishments as the only way to keep the system running right. Today there are to be found studies which show that in fact rewards often work better than punishments as they lead to people rather enjoying what they do or at least feel easier with it.It would be fascinating to see Mozi being confronted with such findings.

Why is it that it seems as if no single person ever existed in our world history whose beliefs were all good and perfect? There is always to be found something that one wants to reject, while other aspects like Mozi's activism and ideals of being good in defense but not attack can easily be admired. I am not expecting an answer for real, as my question just wanted to get out.My real point is about that doing good while feeling watched and doing bad when unwatched. Once I saw a documentary showing two scenes of ape behaviour in a field test. In one scene an ape found food, and as other apes were close by and could easily see it, it shared the food without hesitation.In the other the same ape seemed to be alone and it looked around and back over the shoulders several times to eventually start to eat secretly and for itself. But after a while another ape showed up, saw that misdeed and directly called for the rest of the group. Before the immoral ape had any chance to get away it was surrounded by all the others and got beaten quite brutally.I am not certain if there was even a third scene, where the ape again was totally alone but this time did not dare to eat without the others. Hopefully I will find a video.

Subordinates not only have to obey bosses they have to watch them and report their every error. Of course Mozi didn't forsee that if official is acting wrongly enough for his subordinates to notice, what would stop him from acting slightly more wrong and let's say killing subordinate who wishes to report that official.I'm pretty sure that I've read some article couple months back about local official in china who kidnapped peteten that was going to Bejing to complain on said official. Sadly I can't find that article now (so much information, but combing through it becomes harder each day) but I thought about it instantly when I read this topic.

Mozi's view of music might be rejected out-of-hand simply by insisting that playing and listening to music are human goods.Alternatively, his view may be combated in his own terms. For example, musicians imply the need for instrument-makers, paid performers, concert-goers (who usually have to pay entrance fees), concert hall owners who receive rent, music programs (which imply the existence of printers), transport (how do the concert goers get to the venue), etc. - all of whom are part of the material economy.
