Andre: McGilcrist has done a very thorough review of the literatures on left vs right hemisphere activity patterns - so the accuracy of his message is grounded in facts and his theory is intriguing and useful from a neuropsychological perspective. I was thinking along these same lines (not so much just the hemispheres, but more generally) as I listened to the lecture. (1) Brain function will always be influenced by practices/activities/context and (2) how we operate in our context (what we pay attention to, what we notice, how we interpret what we experience, etc.) will be influenced by our pre-existing "brain habits". So cultural differences will both contribute to individual patterns of cognition (e.g., attention to figure vs ground) and be the "summation" of individual patterns leading to the emergence of a wider cultural "habit"/ pattern.McGilcrist suggests that some cultures have acquired a stronger dependence/focus on one hemiphere's patterns that the other (e.g., North American/European on left hemiphere extraction of detail vs the rest of the world on the right hemisphere's attention to context and the bigger picture of inter-relationships).Interesting thread to add in - thanks.

I found Prof. Slingerland's comments on the collectivism in Eastern culture vs. the individualism in Western Culture to be fascinating. I grew up in a Chinese family and was born in Australia. The tension between individualism (my values) and collectivism (family values) has been very clear in my own experience. It was beautifully brought to light in the differing scenes of early Chinese bronze vessels of group activity vs. Greek vases.Last weekend I took a trip to Melbourne (from Sydney) and had the chance to see a collection of early Chinese bronze vessels at the NGV (including an extensive collection of artifacts all the way from early Xia up to the Qing Dynasty), as well as some Greek vases at the Hellenic Museum. ![Western Zhou Food Vessel][1]![enter image description here][2]I was impressed in particular by the amount of detail on these Chinese bronze artifacts. I didn't get a photo of the Greek vases at the Hellenic Museum but here's an example: ![enter image description here][3]*Achilles slaying Penthesilea, the queen of the Amazons, Attic black-figure amphora signed by Exekias, c. 530 bc; in the British Museum, London.*Seeing these up close in person really made the distinction clear.QUESTION: What's it like for a Westerner living in an Asian country? Have you experienced a tension between the values you grew up with (individualism) and the culture you live in (collectivism) in your life?NGV: http://www.ngv.vic.gov.au/col/collections/collection-areasHellenic Museum: http://www.hellenic.org.au/gods-myths-mortals  [1]: https://farm8.staticflickr.com/7582/15108365164_941ba23d16_z.jpg  [2]: https://farm6.staticflickr.com/5605/15108365304_74137d2d62_z.jpg  [3]: http://media-2.web.britannica.com/eb-media/39/28439-004-34F7DB18.jpg
column35: Growing up Chinese in a Western Country + Field trip to see Zhou vs. Greek vessels

column25: Hi folksA contemporary datapoint that seems to weigh in on the pro state-music side is Venezuela's El Sistema. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Sistema and http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=amSqQ5XNaGEI wonder if the ancient notion of social disorder is captured in the social decay that today's sociologists call "anomie" ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anomie ) and, if so, whether the hope provided by such musical initiatives can be regarded as a durable and reproducible antidote?Wouldn't every youth orchestra claim as much?I am reminded of the film "Brassed Off" that looked at the role of brass bands in fostering meaning and dignity in the UK's ailing mining communities ( http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6F5vBsY9VZ8 ).Can we find other examples?Kind regardsGeoffrey

I think that Mozi could have a problem with non-spiritual surveilance. People whose jobs are to observe others don't do anything really productive, they just waste their time staring at others. What is more effective from the point of the state: let some people err and have observers do productive work, or 'waste' the time of observers on observing and have couple more workers actualy working?My guess is that he'd be opposed to surveilance as a full time job. He already thought of that and told everybody that you not only have to do your job and obey your superior, but you also have to observe your superior and report his every transgression. From his point of view it's win-win situation: everybody is productive, everybody is observed. Of course he failed to recognize potential downfalls of that solution (who will stop corrupt official from killing subordinate who wishes to report him?) but it shows that this problem didn't escape him completely.
I had similar thoughts until professor mentioned that in his historical context it made much more sense.

AndrewKhar pointed out to me in other thread that "proper remonstrance" is supposed to be private (I assume between subordinate and superior) and discreet.But somehow I can't imagine Mozi the efficiency expert being satisfied with private and discreet remonstration if superior doesn't corrects his way.

It seems to me that Mozi is reflecting on the lower part of the Maslow pyramid. Does this have to do with scarcity of wealth of a very lopsided distribution of wealth in his era? As far as I understood these type of philosophies tend to flourish in crisis situations or situations of scarcely available prime needs for the masses. As soon as physiological and safety needs for most of the population are met, there is more room for cultivation of the self or the arts. In other words: would Mozi have become influential in a society which was thriving and which had a more fair distribution of wealth?

Hey,I'm not sure it's possible to directly link the two, as there's no discussion, or even explicit notion, of proposition in Mohism. What the Late Mohists analyze are names and clusters of names, like white horse, not propositions. They develop an extremely sophisticated system and raise truly mind-blowing problems, but I don't think it should classified as propositional logic. Now, Professor Slingerland has used the notion of proposition in his treatment of Late Mohism. I'd be interested to hear from him on the matter. Asia

To elaborate on the explanation behind the logic of the White Horse argument, I thought it'd be interesting to present Peter Bol's explanation from the first ChinaX course:"So why do you think a white horse was a horse? I would suspect that for many of you a white horse is a horse because you think that a white horse is a member of a set or a category of things called horses Gongsun is fully aware that a white horse is a horse in a sense that we have sets and members of sets and things like this. But he proposes, as he works on, that we actually could understand one way in which a white horse is not a horse, that is if we take white as a color and let's give a color the value 1 and horse as a shape, let's give that the value 2. To say a white horse is a horse is to say 1 plus 2 is 2, which is not possible."
column35: White Horse is Not a Horse--ChinaX interpretation

column25: I guess we can't knock Mozi for basing his rationale on the circumstances of his day. He seemed concerned that all people had access to a minimum standard of living, perhaps a bit like the basic wage or pension if appropriate. In order to do that the govt had to be well run with sufficient wealth being generated to achieve a minimum living standard for all. War would detract from that and drain wealth so order was important. It seems people were expected to contribute to their level of expertise and were rewarded for the same and particularly well rewarded for performance at high levels of govt. As today, if you didn't have the skills in top demand you were denied the big salary but at least you got enough to eat, a roof over your head and were able to marry and have children. Surely that is the least that people can expect of this life and good on Mozi for trying to achieve it. We have history and science to show that nothing stays the same, nothing is that simple and people will be a mix of good and bad regardless of punishment or reward or the best endeavours of others to help them achieve a 'good' life. And that is just the minimum - how long would it take for people to become dissatisfied with "the loaf of bread, a jug of wine and thou" (please forgive any error in the quote) as society changes and they see what the neighbour has in excess of that. Perhaps Mozi was the right man for a while but soon lost his following because of the human nature he was intent on ignoring. We do all need more than the basics and when they are satisfied (basics) we seek more (cultural pursuits, etc) out in droves.

This is a really interesting and fertile interaction about Confucius conservative position. During a period of chaos evolving with extreme positions and apparently no trend to a stable pattern having a reference to a stable period is important. Should all generations to come still use Zhou dynasty as reference or there is a room for reform? Not long along in Western world celebrations were going about the end of History and living in the Future. Isn't this something similar to the disaster announced by Confucius when you lose balance between learning and thinking? And apparently in Western world many people are ready for that and media applaud them as 'cool'. It is the radical world...

Perhaps Mozi realised that total surveillance could end up being totally counter productive and just left it to the spirit world and brave whistleblowers.

Mozi's fundamental ideal for society was hierarchical: everyone had a boss, and was supposed to obey that boss.  The "remonstrance" obligation was a half-hearted concession to a fact that he preferred to ignore: the choice of bosses won't be perfect, and some bosses will be outrageously bad.

This is an interesting thought. It is clear from the readings that Mozi saw that the desires of large states were leading to conquests of greed. In one chapter he talks about how a small state that has plenty of provisions and protection will be able to defend itself well, even from the attacks of a large state. He reasoned that in addition to the defense benefit, the small state with plenty of provisions would not be attacked by the large state, due to the great effort the large state would have to make to take the smaller one. Certainly the warring states period was a time of crisis, so it is reasonable to infer from this fact that Mozi would be so concerned with patterns of behavior which would lead to a state with a surplus of provision, but not necessarily to abundant wealth. He certainly wanted the least advantaged in the state to not be incredibly poor and starving. This is where I compare the consequentialism of Mozi, with the contract theory of John Rawls. Rawls wrote about the difference principle, which provides, with regard to distributive shares, that inequalities of wealth are allowable only if they result in a net increase in expectation for the least advantaged in society. Referring to Mozi, it is this same sort of reasoning which leads Mozi to condemn elaborate funerals. His reasoning is that: Since many resources, which have already been produced, would be sacrificed and buried with a king; and since the mourning period causes people to not be able to produce more resources, it is entirely detrimental to society to allow these practices. For, they cause the state to move farther away from the goal of the surplus of material provisions. Rawls would agree with Mozi's condemnation because the inequality of wealth, and certainly the sacrifice and burial of such wealth, does not benefit the least advantaged in society but rather imposes a further limit on their expectations, which is not just or fair at all.

It may be that human beings just need to have someone to feel superior to.  In the 18th century the Great Chain of Being placed all creatures on the chain, some closer to God (rich people, kings, warriors) and some lower down (merchants) and some yet lower (farmers and peasants) and some near the bottom (beggars, horses, Mosquitos and so on down) and you had to stay in your place or God's order in the world would be shattered.  Everyone had a holy purpose being who and what s/he was, so there was some incentive to be content with your state in life.  Today that would never wash.

It is certainly not true that Mozi is against Music in general. Recall that the title of the chapter is "A Condemnation of Musical Performances." He is indeed talking about the sort of musical performances which require the labor of artisans to make the instruments, and the labor of young, able-bodied musicians to perform the music. He argued that these events wasted resources. He also argued that if a ruler indulged in such performances, they would prevent him from ending his work day late, and returning to work early the next day, which would result in a loss of order in the state. I certainly agree that overpopulation is a serious problem now, but it would be practical to increase the population of a state in the warring states period. For there would be more people to work to expand agriculture, and to defend the state if necessary.

Hi BenC123I wonder if Robert Thouless's great yet neglected "Straight and Crooked Thinking" ( http://neglectedbooks.com/Straight_and_Crooked_Thinking.pdf ) can help us out here.He devotes a whole chapter (VII) to definition and some of its difficulties. I think he would class the white horse argument as crooked thinking: (17) Change in the meaning of a term during the course of an argument and (25)Prestige by the use of pseudo-technical jargon.If so, the custom official should have:Dealt with [it] by getting the term defined or by substituting an equivalent form of words at one of the points where the term in question is used and seeingwhether the use of this form of words will make true the other statement in which this term is used.andby asking in a modest manner that the speaker should explain himself more simply.Yes, that does it.What do you think?Kind regardsGeoffrey

Whenever the ruler of the state approves of something all of you must also approve of it. Whenever the ruler of the state condemns something all of you must also condemn it. Eliminate any bad teachings that you may have and study the good teachings of the ruler of the state. Eliminate any bad practices that you may have and study the good practices of the ruler of the state. If you do this then how could the state ever become disordered?Õ  This is why our teacher Mozi says, ÒIn ancient times, sage-kings created the Five Punishments12 to facilitate good order among their people. These are like the main thread of a skein of silk or the drawstring of a net. They are how the sage-kings gathered in those in the world who refused to obey their superiorsGiven the above quotations taken from Mozi, chapter 11, this master taught the lesson of the totalitarian state.  All are to denounce anyone who disobeys the state or the rulerÕs decrees.   In such a state, the ruler would not need a security apparatus because the people would bring anyone guilty of an infraction to the attention of the ruler for punishment.   The punishments: The Five Punishments are said to be tattooing the face, cutting off the nose, cutting off the feet, castration, and death.  Truly ÒhumaneÓ methods, reflecting, no doubt, true impartial caring, for correcting such disobedience.

Might not some of this increased awareness of, shift in focus toward, the body as part of the method for acquiring enlightenment be the result of a more trade, commerce with the Asian subcontinent?  There is some evidence of contact with this cultural region dating back to at least 1500 B.C.E. There is strong evidence that the yogin of India were using breath control and other physical methods to reach the enlightened state dating back to at least 1000 B.C.E.

In the lecture, it's presented that Mozi's litmus test for whether an activity is acceptable is whether it maximises wealth, order and population in a state, which are in turn proxies for the material wellbeing of the state in general.  However, we can imagine that these three quantities suffer from diminishing marginal returns.  After a certain point, increasing wealth may make the population lazier (since there is plenty of stuff to satisfy wants without working hard), increasing order may foment unrest (since a totalitarian state would involve oppressing some people and motivate rebellion), and increasing population would decrease wealth (since the population must consume more resources to support itself).  In this case, would Mozi support the pursuit of wealth, population and order only up to a certain point, after which they become excessive and unjustified?If so, then when a state has optimised these three quantities, then whatever the people do with the spare time that they have left over after producing the "optimal" level of wealth, population and order can be used as they see fit, right?  Then in such a situation, would Mozi still find indulgences like musical orchestras, cultural output and lavish ceremonies objectionable?
column35: Would Mozi Support Optimising rather than Maximising the Goods?

Point is that they DIDN'T believe in ghosts, which is why he had to defend his belief in them at such length.  Few people who have ever lived believed that some spirit was watching them all the time and would accordingly administer rewards and punishments promptly.  Even a three-year-old knows that life isn't like that.  And Mozi was undoubtedly neither the first nor the last to attempt to inculcate people with that crazy belief.  Because it's convenient for the "superior" to have everyone believe that.  Too bad it isn't possible to make them believe it.

Mozi, like the other philosophers we have studied, had negligible influence on the policies of the kings and dukes of his time, although they shared his belief in a totalitarian state.  He shows no signs of favoring shamans or holy men of any kind.  You can see why.  Recognizing such people would cut across the command structure he envisions.  "Why should I obey the king?  The shaman tells me he's wrong."  Probably same for divination, or any process that would detract from "identification with superiors."

Though Prof. Slingerland regularly uses Peter Singer (along with Immanuel Kant) as a rationalist foil in these lectures, I don't think he's being entirely fair to Singer.I recall reading an interview with Singer, regarding his most influential work, *Animal Liberation*, in which he notes that the portion of the book that really gets people to change their behavior and quit eating meat, was not the abstract moral argumentation, but the visceral descriptions of the horrific conditions faced by animals in modern factory farms.There's your Mencian sprout, developing from a feeling of empathy toward animal suffering to an ethical philosophy of diet, strict vegetarianism/veganism.I think Prof. Singerland is not adequately distinguishing here between normative ethics, which asks what is right and wrong, and moral psychology, which asks what motivates people to engage in moral behavior. One may consistently be a consequentialist or deontologist about normative ethics, and a Mencian/Humean about moral psychology.(For a real-life example, Prof. Neil Sinhababu at National University of Singapore is a Benthamite hedonistic utilitarian in normative ethics, and a defender of Hume in moral psychology.)
Mozi's impartial caring views of the world would prevent him from placing too much emphasis on any one instrument.

But emotionally I honestly would feel disgusted if I have to witness 2 adult men kissing. Would Menzi object gay marriage based on this? I think he would not only vote yes, but would be one of the drafters of Prop.8 if he were a Californian. Has modern day gay rights gone too far in forcing political correctness. What about allow siblings marry as long as they promise not to produce offspring?On the other hand, I have no problem seeing lesbians making out. So emotionally AND rationally I can totally support Lesbian marriage. So let's reach the grand middle ground, legalize lesbian marriage and ban gay marriage. Let's call it Proposition 4, endorsed by Menzi.

Mozi did not regard being a king as unproductive, even though the king didn't produce anything.  Nor did he regard bosses as unproductive, if all they did was boss others.Of course he likewise would not have regarded spies and snoops as unproductive, if their activity contributed to total productivity.

Hi KarenIn my day, John Van Maanen and Ed Schein were the leading academics in this field (see https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/1934/SWP-0960-03581864.pdf?sequence=1 ). Summed up as "capture the group norm" (by paying attention to formal and informal processes by which one learns the ropes of a particular organizational role) because "when you've got them by the balls their minds and hearts will follow".There is a wealth of research cited at the end of this article.Kind regardsGeoffrey

I think in lecture 5.7 of this week there are some exceptionally important points we can develop.Firstly, that Moral imagination = Hope. In fact without imagination hope is impossible. Thus what are the tools of Hope, they must be the tools of the imagination.Where construct of the metaphor is critical, and where moral education comes from the understanding of sophisticated images. Where does Confucius send us to find and understand these? The Classics.This means I think that metaphor becomes a language "above and beyond" the literal construct. Where the combination for instance, especially in pairs provides a meaning.Thus if we take "dark" metaphors, we can have dark clouds, dark mountain, dark earth, dark wood, dark eyes, dark sea.What do these mean? From western literature we can stumble around, but there is little consistency and precision.Whereas with Chinese there clearly is precision, and at a very high level. That is because within the Chinese classics there is a "schematic" as to how that works.In fact from this one might argue that metaphor originates from Chinese, and certainly within western classics such as Homer, many of the metaphors are consistent with the Chinese system.I accept from previous advice that Yijing developed more fully in the Han. However the classical origin dates back much earlier, and can be seen in www.ctext.orgFrom this we see the building blocks of Chinese metaphor, are the 8 trigrams which are as follows [I think this is from a Legge translation of the Classic of Changes]:![enter image description here][1]Where as can be seen each attribute, Ch'ien, Tui, and so on has a range of associated references.Tui was mentioned in the lectures referring to "push" however in metaphor it also refers to lake, or marsh. In the image I think the directions may be wrong as generally I think Tui is associated with West.Thus if we go back to the "dark" metaphors above:we can have dark clouds [K'un-K'an], dark mountain [K'un-Ken], dark earth [K'un-K'un], dark wood [K'un-Sun], dark eyes [K'un-Li], dark sea [K'un-Tui].These compute on a classical matrix, which seems to be attributed from the Zhou Dynasty known as the the King Wen Sequence [maybe form around 1100BCE?]:![enter image description here][2]Thus we get the following:dark clouds [K'un-K'an]= 8, dark mountain [K'un-Ken]= 23, dark earth [K'un-K'un]= 2, dark wood [K'un-Sun]=20, dark eyes [K'un-Li]= 35, dark sea [K'un-Tui]= 45Where the numbers relate to chapters from the Chinese Classics were 8 is about [in general terms but there are a lot of details, as with all that follow] unity, 23 = deterioration, 2 = a natural response, 20 = contemplation, 35 = progress, and 45 = assembling. Which are all specific chapters in the Classic of Changes.Thus the notion of perceptive symbols within Chinese communication, literature and art, is certainly for higher levels of society standardized and formalised. That is the reason Confucius is advising to read the Chinese Classics.Therefore the schematic which is achieved creates what seems simple metaphor, but they are structured and obey laws and rules and from there contain embedded, powerful meanings.Thus following Confucius's advice and learning The Classics, one would learn and internalize these notions. From this point one has an exceptionally powerful cognitive base of cause and effect from which to advance from. What is very interesting is that if one looks at ancient western literature, such as Homer and Pindar the metaphor structures appear to follow the same rules.In Dante this becomes even more obvious, with specific reference to the marsh, the mountain, the abyss and so on. "Dark Wood" combines perfectly with the notion of chapter 20 of The Classic of Changes - something like the notion of contemplation.Thus it appears to me, that classical, certainly ancient western metaphors have their origin in this "system".One thing is for certain, that taking the time to learn the attributes, their computation and relating chapters once internalized, adds greatly to cognitive dexterity. I first realized this reading Homer for the first time a few years ago, as corpus ligustical concordance and collocation shows a very high correlation with key words associated with the Chinese classics, especially the Classic of Changes.Thus in my view, possibly the most important vehicle for advanced cognitive development in Ancient China was metaphor via its classical standardization, and application. Especially as a means of communication with other intellectuals. This seems significant in respect to "how Chinese people thought".   [1]: https://edxuploads.s3.amazonaws.com/14157873315739961.jpg  [2]: https://edxuploads.s3.amazonaws.com/1415788214200885.gif

I have a bit of a problem with Mencius' moral sprouts in that he selects feelings of which he approves, and ignores those, for example those which the Christian tradition named as coveting your neighbour's ox or his wife. I'm not a Christian but I can look inside myself and see the sprouts of such covetousness, which I routinely suppress. However I'm not sure they aren't as 'natural' a part of my make-up as the slight sentimentality I feel on seeing a distressed animal on the way to slaughter, from which I personally can't make the connection to benevolence towards my fellow man, which to me is a totally different response. I cook and eat meat and do, where I can, avoid harming animal life, but feel an absolute ban on harming humans. I agree with Mencius about the child in the well, but tend to see this as human solidarity, which if I think about it in any depth I'd trace back to humans having developed as communal animals. He's simply wrong about everyone having the same tastes, and as many examples can show some people will accept the most humiliating treatment as a way to prolong life, though some do not. Overall it seems to me he strives a little too artificially to justify positions he is drawing from the tradition.

The babies show a preference for helpful external forces, which one might accept as natural in a cooperative species. Babies however also grab things from other babies even if it causes the victim distress. I wonder if any scientific work has been done to establish whether babies have innate selfishness?The monkeys and the ultimatum game do indicate an innate desire for fairness on the part at least of those discriminated against in laboratory conditions. Does the same thing happen with starved monkeys I wonder?

I think you point up one of the problems of Mencius's claims, namely that we are all alike. I'm old-fashioned enough to be involuntarily irritated at anyone, whether heterosexual or homosexual ostentatiously making out in public (I don't defend this prejudice for the old social rites!), but I'm indifferent as to their gender preferences. I happily attended the wedding of two male neighbours, after which I observed a totally appropriate kiss between them with no feelings of disgust. Perhaps like Mencius you are a conservative, but not everybody is, and arbitrarily removing some people's human rights doesn't seem a reasonable move to me.As for incestuous marriage I think it is socially correct to ban it since, except in circumstances where the siblings have been separated since birth, they will inevitably be in a power relationship. Moreover, whatever they might promise, society could not police their reproductive choices.

Hi,I'm confused with the concept of "Heart-mind". Is it really intuition? Do they have "Head-mind"? Seams to me that now we indentify our thoughts with our head and our intuitions with our heart because we know about our brain, but in those days, did they know that you think with the head?
column35: The is not logical mind in the teachings of Mencius?

Re. the Peer Assignment Presumably we're seeking advice from the writings of these three wise men; and then we have to kind of extrapolate from that to what they would say if they were in 21st century Canada, as opposed to Warring States China?  Can/do we then give our response to each, as head of the Vancouver School Board i.e. the counter-arguments (word limit permitting) and our conclusions after weighing up the advice given?Ah.  After re-watching the instruction video, I note that we're told  we're *not* supposed to be arguing about which philosophy is the best.  But surely we/the heads of the School Board need to reach some conclusions?

Hi folksI am put in mind of the recent management fashion for Knowledge Management. This caters to cost-reduction wishes of beleaguered CEO's by promising: > "if you implement our 'knowledge base', to 'know what your organisation> knows', then you will be able to downsize without de-skilling"So I am delighted to discover that Mencius knew better > Mencius 7B5: ÒA carpenter or wheelwright can give another his compass> or T-square, but he cannot make another skillfulÓSpot on. Skills reside in people not books, web pages or databases.Comparisons with contemporary management "science" seem highly relevant to me,especially if Chinese philosophers were indeed concerned with the issues of applied organizational psychology that arise in growing communities.Once again, many thanks to our wonderful Professor for making complex things simple.Kind regardsGeoffrey

If you are indifferent about coveting other people's wife, than you wouldn't be so defensive in talking about it, wouldn't you? Rather you would be asking why shouldn't we be allowed to covet other people's wife? I think what Mencius is saying, we have the ability to distinguish right or wrong because it is intrinsic in our nature. And we more or less agree on what is wrong because we are by nature is good, and thus we are simply in conflict with ourselves when we do something wrong. How we act in reaction to our inner feeling that is a another story.

Yes, by "heart" Mencius *also* means the seat of thought. This is the way the word is used in China, Korea, and Japan.

I was told in recent months that 'China' is a big place, that person speaking to me Cantonese whilst celebrating with a Spring offering. I enquired as to the significance of the three sticks of incense that burned noting the exceptional quality of the fruits also present, I did not though mention this. I thought the comment in China being a big place referred to a subtle reminder that there are quite noted distinguishable differences in those from mainland China.  Is the above information, of which I haven't particularly seen the likes of online, a predominant learning/teaching or is the above information more applicable in certain areas of China. Does this point more towards the more western regions of China or someone the likes of a 'lao-tzu' travelling west. Hi ReadeDavisI think we agree. If corporations abdicate "teaching the ropes" to others it nevertheless still occurs because the novice gains their clues about "what constitutes acceptable behaviour here" through informal socialization processes - which may be completely the opposite to the corporation's intentions.I remember John van Maanen had a wonderful paper called "Rookie cops and rookie managers" that looked at the difference between behaviour taught at Police Academy and the commonsense wisdom learned on the streets, and drew implications for management (John Van Maanen, Rookie cops and rookie managers. The Wharton Quarterly. 1, 1, 1976, 49-55).I can't find any internet link to that piece but I did find a copy of van Maanen's great "The asshole" which draws on the same research http://jthomasniu.org/class/377a/Readings/vanmaanen-1978.pdfThe denial of the importance of talent is evident in self-help drivel like Daniel Coyle's hugely popular "The Sweet Spot: The Talent Code. Greatness IsnÕt Born. ItÕs Grown. HereÕs How". New York: Bantam, 2009I spent seven years trying and failing to play the clarinet and tenor saxophone, with no sense of rhythm and very imperfect pitch. Despite excellent teachers, I was forced to accept my sad lack of talent. When you wish upon a star it matters a great deal who you are.Kind regardsGeoffrey

In the US there are surveillance cameras everywhere.  And all conversations using electronics (such as telephones) are recorded.The former helps to solve a lot of crimes.  The latter is nearly useless because there is too much data for anyone to process.

It would be nice to think that intuition was responsible for human goodness but what happens when someone is sociopathic or unable to work out what is right and wrong? On top of that instruction or teaching through socialisation (ritual,etc) can fail - there are a lot of people in jail - so I sit here astounded that Mencius embraced so whole-heartedly the notion of basic human goodness - there is a lot of it but there is a lot of the converse too. I have been impressed to date by the perceptiveness of the Chinese thinkers without recourse to modern empirical knowledge. But I will read on.

The information in the manner presented above, is not common mainstream knowledge. It takes a very long time to puzzle out, although certain aspects are available.The tricky part is the deciphering and application.I think it is "hidden in plain sight" material that like with Greek *ainos* one needed [or needs] certain skills and qualification to understand. Accordingly, I think it is a delicate topic that needs to be handled with a great deal of respect, and furthermore in line with such respect, it is not intended within the spirit of the system to be freely and openly exposed, in my view.  Confucius more or less points us towards such, but he makes us do the work to understand it more fully. In fact it is a lot of work, but most rewarding.You can find the precise reference form The Classics here:http://ctext.org/book-of-changes/shuo-guaFrom that you can create your own trigram attribute matrix, as the Shuo Gua, explains precisely the associated attributes.The following document explains the matter particularly well from the Paideusis Journal for Interdisciplinary and Cross-Cultural Studies:THE YIN-YANG SYSTEM OF ANCIENT CHINA: THE YIJING-BOOK OF CHANGES AS A PRAGMATIC METAPHOR FOR CHANGE THEORY, David Lam Center For International Communication, Simon Fraser University Vancouver (Burnaby), British Columbia. [I think its easier to read if you download the document].http://www.oocities.org/paideusis/n1ms.htmlI must say that this is one of the most fascinating and wide ranging sets of topics that I have come across ever. I am particularly interested in perfecting The Classics, and skills related to these topics. I hope we can form a group to continue study on this and other topics of interest after the course is completed, such as what Harvard have done with H25, which continues from their HeroesX course on Edx.I would very much appreciate guidance and input in mastering this system. Professor Slingerland makes reference to jujitsu. The above system is undoubtedly jujitsu for the cognition, and then some!It would be wonderful for all of us to work together to unpack this massive topic and exchange information to develop this fully. I think the amounts of embedded information / latent content, is very large. Regarding the source and transmission of such in ancient times, ChinaX Prof. Bol, advised in his Zhou Dynasty lecture that the Zhou passed on certain Chinese texts to "barbarians" in an attempt at intellectual colonization. Professor Puett, in another lecture stated that a lot of aspects of what we consider the facts of ancient western history are incorrect in some instances. The University of Jerusalem on their course on western mysticism related to Kaballah cite its origins in the east.In my view I think central to the transfer through elite circles was the Chaldean Magi / Zoroastrians, which I think is also where Nietzsche intimated [Thus spoke Zoroaster]. From them these elite notions peculated via elite circles in the Mediterranean area.There is possibly a cryptic reference on MIT's History of Global Architecture which may be seen to alluding to such a system from the Russian Steppe region.However TsinghauX - Cultural China Part one, goes into quite a bit of detail and evidence dating origins in China far earlier than for example we read of in the Greek classics on related topics.  I have found this to be a very sensitive topic for some. A particular "red herring" is the relationship to divination in the west, and discussing such systems as a form of horoscope. From my view I dismiss the mystical and look at the facts. The cause and effect relations, and human intervention relationships form something like a science of human situations and human interventions. It is a massive error by some to dismiss the topic, and not look into it in detail.I really do think that those who can master the above "will see the world like it is spinning in the palm of their hand".

using your consciousness to shut down consciousness is not a paradox. it's a desired property of any system. it's common in computer science. for example a parser should be able to parse itself. also qi is not something external. it is the energy you can find everywhere.
Yes, I think the brilliant part of Chinese thought is the fusion of 'close observation of nature' with 'goodness.'

You are certainly welcome to be creative in how you frame your essay. For example, if you would like to speak from the perspective of the head of the school board, that is fine. Part of your essay might then read something like:"Confucius told me [advice]... He said I should do this because [reasons]... However, I'm not completely convinced, as Laozi countered [Laozi's argument]..."As you note, the assignment is not about choosing which philosophy is best objectively, so do not devote too much time to that. Instead, you should argue which strategy is best from the perspectives of the different philosophers. If you are writing from the perspective of the head of the school board, and want to include a brief conclusion on which strategy you actually chose, that is fine.*After the assignment*, if you want to discuss in more detail which one you personally thought was best, the best place to do that is here on the forums.

Hi May, well, we ask that you try to keep your answer to no more than 800 words so that your peer graders do not need to read too much (every student who submits an essay will receive three other students' essays to grade). If you need to write a little extra, I suspect that your graders probably won't mind too much, but it will be up to them as to decide whether or not to deduct marks. If you want to ensure that you receive the highest marks, you should strive to be concise and keep your response as close to 800 words as possible.

Good question. I have notified Dr. Slingerland. My own understanding is that, even during the time of the so-called "Silk Road," which began in the Han dynasty after the Warring States, practically no one made the full journey from the Indian subcontinent to the Yellow River valley. Rather, any traded items were passed on through many way-points along the way. This would have limited possibilities for the transmission of advanced breathing practices, unless they spread slowly through all of the communities in between. It is possible that similar breathing practices co-arose in different places at similar times.

Hi StellaValuable contribution. I started a new thread under this lecture about Descartes Error and Management Consulting before I found your comment.Leading thinkers who attempted to apply your approach would be MIT's Dick Beckhard and Ed Nevis (founders of the field of Organization Development). They recommended a non-judgemental approach to organizational assessment that they described as a "gestalt awareness process", in other words "to make like a sponge". http://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/48026/gestaltawareness00nevi.pdf?sequence=1Kind regardsGeoffrey

Demon and AngelÒFrom this we can see that if one is without the heart of compassion, one is not a human. If one is without the heart of disdain, one is not a human. If one is without the heart of deference, one is not a human. If one is without the heart of approval and disapproval,27 one is not a human. The heart of compassion is the sprout of benevolence. The heart of disdain is the sprout of righteousness. The heart of deference is the sprout of propriety. The heart of approval and disapproval is the sprout of wisdom.28    ÒPeople having these four sprouts is like their having four limbs. To have these four sprouts but to say of oneself that one is unable to be virtuous is to steal from oneself. To say that oneÕs ruler is unable to be virtuous is to steal from oneÕs ruler. In general, having these four sprouts within oneself, if one knows to fill them all out, it will be like a fire starting up, a spring breaking through! If one can merely fill them out, they will be sufficient to care for all within the Four Seas. If one merely fails to fill them out, they will be insufficient to serve oneÕs parents.ÓÉMencius 2A6ÒHere is a person who is harsh to me. A gentleman in this situation will invariably examine himself, saying, ÔI must not be benevolent. I must be lacking in propriety. How else could this situation have come upon me?!Ó If he examines himself and is benevolent, and if he examines himself and has propriety, yet the other person is still harsh, a gentleman will invariably examine himself, saying, ÔI must not be loyal.Õ If he examines himself and is loyal, yet the other person is still harsh, a gentleman says, ÔThis person is simply incorrigible! What difference is there between a person like this and an animal?! What point is there in rebuking an animal?ÕÓ. . . Mencius 4B28	The above two excerpts from the Mencius text clearly indicate that Mengzi was fully aware of humanityÕs dual nature and further that he recognized this dual natureÕs origin.  He recognized that many of the apparently negative aspects of our nature stem from our animal needs and that compassion, disdain, deference and approval/disapproval arise out of the human abilities to reflect upon, predict likely outcomes and choose the correct one.  More importantly, though, he correctly asserted that all humans were born with these ÒsproutsÓ for what we today would refer to as humane and compassionate conduct. Modern neuroscience has proven him to be largely correct in this view.  	For a brief summary of these findings made by modern neuroscience I strongly recommend reading Karen ArmstrongÕs, Twelve Steps to a More Compassionate Life.   In the preface to this work she presents a rapid but intelligent overview of these discoveries and how they relate to the topic under discussion.  With regard to the more negative elements of human nature she states:		There is no doubt that in the deepest recess of their minds, men and women are indeed ruthlessly selfish.  This egotism is rooted in the Òold brain,Ó which was bequeathed to us by the reptiles that struggled out of the primal slime some 500 million years ago.  Wholly intent on personal survival, these creatures were motivated by mechanisms that neuroscientists have called the ÒFour FsÓ: feeding, fighting, fleeing, and-- for want of a more basic wordÑ reproduction.  These drives fanned out into fast-acting systems, alerting reptiles to compete pitilessly for food, to ward off any threat, to dominate their territory, seek a place of safety, and perpetuate their genesÉ.. Homo sapiens inherited these neurological systems; they are located in the hypothalamus at the base of the brain, and it is thanks to them that our species survived.  The emotions they engender are strong, automatic, and Òall about me.Ó (K. Armstrong, 13)After some additional comments and insights regarding these ÒnegativeÓ aspects of the human brain/psyche, she turns to the more positive elements of our human nature and their evolutionary originsThe arrival of warm-blooded mammals led to the evolution of a brain that was able to care for others and thus help ensure the survival of the young.   At first this care was rudimentary and automatic; but over the millennia, mammals began to build nests for their infants and began to behave in a way that would ensure their health and development.  For the first time, sentient beings were developing the capacity to protect, nurture, and nourish a creature other than themselves.  Over millions of years, this strategy proved so successful in establishing genetic lineages that it led to evolution of still more complex brain systems.  This process seems to have been symbiotic.  In order to accommodate these new skills, the brains of mammals got bigger; this meant that increasingly their young had to be born prematurely so that they could pass through the birth canal; the infants were, therefore, helpless and needed the support, care, and protection not only of their parents but of their entire community.  This was especially true of Homo sapiens, which had evolved an enormous brainÉ. But parental affection ensured the survival of the species, helped the young to thrive, and taught humans to develop other alliances and friendships that were extremely useful in the struggle for survival.  Gradually they developed the capacity for altruism. (K. Armstrong, 17-18) And further concerning the quiescence that mammals experience when not engaged in the pursuit of ÒFour FÓ goals:It used to be thought that this quiescence was simply the result of the more aggressive drives zoning out, but it has now been found that this physical relaxation is also accompanied in both mammals and humans by profound and positive feelings of peace, security, and well-being.  Produced initially by maternal soothing, these emotions are activated by such hormones as oxytocin, which induces a sense of closeness to others and plays a crucial role in the development of parental attachment.  When human beings entered this peaceful state of mind, they were liberated from anxiety and could, therefore, think more clearly and have fresh insights; as they acquired new skills and more leisure, some sought to reproduce this serenity in activities, disciplines, and rituals that were found to induce it. (K. Armstrong, 19}Ms. Armstrong also gives a brief tour of the neuroscience that provides the insights into the structures of the human brain that are involved in this human duality: 1878, French anatomist, Paul Broca, discovered a section of the brain that seemed older than the neocortex but not present in the brains of reptiles, he called it, le grand lobe limbique.  1959, American neuroscientist and physician, Paul MacLean, at US National Institute of Mental Health, using Paul BrocaÕs research and his own indicates that the limbic system, located beneath the neocortex, not the hypothalamus, was the source of the electrochemical stimuli that produce the ÒpositiveÓ emotions of compassion, joy, serenity and maternal affection. 1960Ós, American Roger Sperry of the California Institute of Technology demonstrated the differences between our right and left brain: left, center of logic, analysis, precision and cause and effect, right, center of emotion, symbolism, art and music. She also lists in her endnotes no less than twenty additional researchers in the field of neuroscience that have done further research that demonstrate the above linkages.  This modern science helps us to understand that human nature is not inherently ÒgoodÓ or Òbad,Ó that within us there is always a certain tension between these biochemical stimuli that generate our basic, urgent needs and those other biochemical stimuli that generate our ÒhigherÓ more empathetic feelings and actions. This tension generates our sense of free will, of needing to choose between compassionate action or selfish aims.  I do agree with both Mencius and Ms. Armstrong that the ÒpositiveÓ elements of our natures are frailer, require more attention for their full development and that they can be and frequently are short-circuited, crushed and nearly starved out of effectiveness by the secular ÒrealitiesÓ of our world.  I also insist with them that Òthose who have persistently trained themselves in the art of compassion manifest new capacities in the human heart and mind; they discover that when they reach out consistently to others, they are able to live with the suffering that inevitably comes their way with serenity, kindness, and creativity.  They find they have a new clarity and experience a richly intensified state of being.Ó (K. Armstrong

Good point! Also thought this research on toddlers was a bit one-dimensional. Saw a one year old tear out the hairs of his sister, because he didn't get the attention he wanted! About fairness and monkey's, it would be a bit harsh to starve them for the research, but I think there would be room for fairness, only after the first needs as food and drink are fulfilled. I believe Frans de Waal did some more research which proved this point, but I am not sure. There is a story about a monkey who was born without limbs which was nurtured by the rest of the group but this group of mammals had a certain amount of welfare. I think the same counts for human societies.

Professor Slingerland takes me to task for affirming that he sets up a straw man in saying that art, while important to education, is not considered an essential component of forming moral character in the West. I agree that it does not have much of a role in Deontology or Consequentialism.I also agree that the attitude that art is an additional extra is common.Traditionally, however, this is untrue of the views of the elite. Take England as an example. To be a gentleman or lady one has to master many arts. The curriculum in elite schools was based on the quadrivium, which encompassed music. At schools such as Eton there was a tremendous emphasis on learning and speaking Latin, Greek, and reading and debating the Classics, especially poetry. All these arts were considered essential to the formation of a gentleman.In addition, in the philosophies of Nietszche and Schopenhauer art is central to morals.

Reviewing the video about art and morals and the supposed direct link to cutting art from school curricula, I see that no valid argument is presented.Here is an attempted formulation:P1: In the West, art has no intellectual place in moral theory, that is, in the moral development of the person.P2: In education, development of the moral person is paramount.P3: Any subject not directly involved in moral development may be cut.C: Art may be cutThese premisses may be doubted:Regarding P1: What no Humeans? No Nietszcheans?Regarding P2: And I just wanted to be an X (where X is a Mathematician, Astronaut, whatever)Regarding P3: Many other disciplines may potentially be substituted for art in the argument, with the result that they also can be cut.(Educational budget-cutters will appreciate P3).Of course, the misperception that art is an "add-on" is exploited by budget cutters.

Hi folksAbout fifteen years ago, my wife and I took a one-week sailing course in the Algarve, living aboard a 38-foot sailboat. The other couple on the course was strangely reticent about their background. Over the week, it emerged that the husband was a young partner in Goldman Sachs. He was one of those who suddenly became £54 million richer when the Firm went public. They were exploring the possibility of buying themselves a yacht.Moral imagination, it turns out, was quite a problem for Goldman Sachs employees: having rapidly acquired far more than enough money to live on, they tended to give up their jobs, get a divorce or do other erratic things. Consequently they were strongly encouraged to attend free counselling on how to cope with it. To nip those pesky sprouts in the bud?Our acquaintance subsequently set up a charitable foundation to care for the welfare of penguins in the Antarctic - you couldn't make it up! I tend to think that this is a tax fiddle.Kind regardsGeoffrey

On the point about conceptual metaphorical thinking, I've once encountered this fascinating article on the metaphors used by American newspapers during the lead-up to the Iraq War of 2003 to push for a pro-war public opinion. The metaphors the writer lists are: timetables (to add a time pressure), "war is a game" (like comparing Saddam to a petulant child), "making the case/selling the plan" (to justify the war rationally), driving metaphors ("to justify the inevitability of war"), disease/germs (WMDs as diseases, US as doctor remedying the Iraqi disease), and dehumanization. The upshot: through the usage of these metaphors, the public could be persuaded to reframe the war into one that's inevitable and necessary. This is rather controversial political stuff, so I'm just posting it as an interesting literary analysis pertaining to what we've discussed about conceptual metaphors and thinking processes, especially since the writer cites several works by George Lakoff on this topic.For those with access to an academic library, here's the article:http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/17405904.2012.736397#.VGcM4PnF8uc
column35: Conceptual metaphors in the Iraq War

This lecture was really interesting in pointing out that unlike a utilitarian or deontological ethical system that uses strict categories to characterise an act as moral or immoral, virtue-based ethical systems use radial categories to measure the extent to which an act resembles a moral one or not.  A contemporary example of this is trying to imagine if an act is consistent with a moral exemplar (eg. What Would Jesus Do?).However, are there limits to such an approach?  For example, it is assumed that feeling care for one's fellow citizens is the same as feeling care for one's siblings.  The use of the family as a metaphor for the state (eg. family budgetary principles are assumed to apply to federal budgets) is also common.  But can we not argue that after some point, the analogy breaks down?  The care that I feel for my brother is similar to the care I feel for my cousin once removed, which is in turn similar to the care I feel for my cousin twice or thrice removed, which is in turn similar to the care I feel for my friend, which is similar to the care I feel for a stranger - but the care I feel for a stranger is significantly different from the care I feel for my brother.  Is there then a limit to the effectiveness of "pushing" a virtue to apply to newer and more remote circumstances?
column35: Choosing the Moral Thing to Do via Radial Categorisation

Briefly.Morality is a characteristic of a society. It is part of the culture of that society. Culture is the way they do everything and the way they think about everything. Humans reached the point in their evolution where they had the mental abilities to develop a culture for a large society about 70000 years ago in east Africa. They then spread out from there around the world. Cultures diversified and evolved into the myriad cultures that we see in the world today. The evolution of cultures is much like the evolution and diversification of species. The differences we see in cultures is due to adaption to particular circumstances and to cultural drift which is analogous to genetic drift. The similarities among cultures is what they have inherited from the original culture 70000 years ago. The moral aspect of these similarities is what might be called a "Universal Morality".Much more could be said about this. I should write a book.

This is a very interesting topic to study.  My understanding is that, in reality, we have free will only in our responses to things (events, things, people) that come into our path and in our thoughts, feelings, and actions. That we are ultimately responsible for the direction of our lives and for the actions, thoughts, and feelings that we produce in this life.In Some Answered Questions 'Abdu'l-Bah‡ talks about the nature of free will (p. 248-250). His discourse is too lengthy to quote here, but His main points are:1  Good and evil actions (e.g., justice or injustice) are subject to free will. We are responsible for these acts.2 Other aspects of life are forced upon us (e.g., sleep, death, sickness, and misfortunes beyond our control). We are not responsible for these things.3 At the same time, "might and power belong especially to God" and we are therefore absolutely dependent upon God's help.  For example, states of existence (mineral, vegetable, animal, or human) are decreed by God and act as limiting factors on what creatures can become. "Their progress must be in their own state."As human beings, we occupy the highest state, but as individuals we vary in capacity. In 1 Romans 9:21, it is said that God is like a potter who makes "one vessel unto honour, and another unto dishonour." As this is God's doing, it is not for us to complain about our inherent limitations. Rather, we should exercise our free will to develop our God-given capacities.4  Even in this regard, however, "the inaction or the movement of man depend upon the assistance of God." He likens us to a ship powered by wind or steam. The ship's course can be controlled via its rudder, but without the power of wind or steam the ship will not move. In like manner, our "motion" comes from God, but our direction we set ourselves.

Actually I think the concept of 'heart-mind' is closer to what neuroscience is discovering about the way that heart (emotions, hot) and head (reason, cold) work closely together, e.g. a thought shows up in our brain's activity before we're conscious of having it. Also we may think we're making a reasoned decision but it is the emotional impetus that makes us act on that decision.

I agree with inurjaya. The examples of covetousness of someone else's wife/ox and eating meat are examples of the desires of other, lesser organs of the body, aren't they? According to Mencius, the heart-mind is the only organ relevant to the four moral sprouts he identifies: compassion, disdain, deference and approval/disapproval. If we feel them but don't follow them through, it's because they are by definition fragile, and they haven't been nurtured etc.His point about us all having the same tastes in food, music and beauty is much more complex. I think he's really saying that we are all attracted to food that tastes good rather than putrid etc, to music that sounds pleasant rather than just noisy, and to an animal, plant or object that is symmetrical or nearly symmetrical rather than one that is grossly asymmetrical. Perceptions of honour are more about moral consensus, and would obviously be more similar in a monocultural society than in a multicultural society like ours today. But even today I think we would all agree that honourable behaviour is preferable to dishonourable behaviour. We would just disagree on what constitutes honourable behaviour according to the moral consensus in the society and/or social class to which we belong.

And today's researchers are also looking for any indications that even in infants there is something there for future development to build on.

Claude Levi-Strauss has written on the dialectical nature of human culture that negotiates between the tendency to homogenize versus the tendency to emphasize distinction. In his essay *'Primitive' Thinking and the 'Civilized' Mind*, he writes: "You cannot develop all the mental capacities belonging to mankind all at once. You can only use a small sector, and that sector is not the same according to culture."This is a pithy explanation of cultural commonality and variability among the myriad cultural communities that have formed over the centuries.

I think this paradox of wu-wei results from the difference between humans and non-human animals, as referred to also in Genesis when Adam and Eve taste of the forbidden fruit and thus suddenly know the difference between good and evil. That is, humans are the only animals that can be thought of as acting morally or immorally. According to the Theory of Chaos and Complexity, you could say that this moral awareness emerges in human beings, but because we are a comparatively new species we are still in transition from a species without moral awareness to one with full awareness. We have moral sprouts in our heart-mind but are still also driven by the desires of the other organs. Just as the introduction of (monocultural) agriculture made infant plants dependent on human assistance in order to develop, once humans began to live in complex societies and kinship was no longer the binding force, our moral sprouts became dependent on nurturing in order to develop. And as our societies become more and more complex and more and more interdependent, this nurturing becomes more and more necessary. It may not be 'natural', but then neither is an imperial economy (let along a globalised economy) where we are dependent on people who will always be complete strangers to us.I hope I have expressed this more or less coherently, but what I get from the Professor's introduction to Mencian sentimentalism certainly makes sense to me.

I think that for all warring states philosophers the presence of psychopaths was a given and certainly not an exceptional case. They actually lived between warlords, a category that then (as is still the case) shows a high presence of psychopaths. The cause of psychopathy can be internal (born without some sprouts), external (various forms of deprivation, abuse etc. mutilating the sprouts) or (most probably) a combination of the two.An interesting question for Mencius would be at what point (given the lack of some sprouts) a person would no longer be considered human (and could then be treated as such). The Mozians made that choice quite easily by considering even robbers as 'not human': ÒKilling robbers is not killing people.Ó(Mozi 15)The Daoist, at least according to the (probably controversial) analysis of Hans Georg Moeller (in his book The Philosophy of the Daodejing) would treat psychopaths like 'straw dogs' and do away with the aberration by death penalty. But then, in their idealized village-state external causes of psychopathy might be smaller in number as would be the possibilities for a successful psychopathic career (just like ADHD kids tend to do much better on a farm than in a busy city with all its temptations and distractions).

There seems to be something missing here.  What does it mean to be naturally good?  If, like some other mammals, humans lived on their own after a certain age, then there would be no morality.  It is only our interactions with others that necessitate, and therefore foster this. I suppose you could say it's innate, because we've evolved to live in small tribal groups.  If you could imagine a child being 'raised' in total isolation, obviously their moral sprouts couldn't develop.  So the innate goodness has to be developed by the social interactions of the child, whether with family or a wider social circle.If the values of this small circle are dubious, they will be absorbed by the child.  So I question whether Mencius is correct when he says that our moral sprouts want to grow into the full Confucian virtues.  I think our basic nature makes us want to be accepted and successful in our social group, which may mean espousing different virtues.  So, for example, ritual propriety.  This seems to be something we would adopt, in a society where Confucian values, ritual and behaviour were esteemed, not because it's part of our nature, but because it's part of our nature to want to be accepted Sorry if I'm waffling, but just trying to think this through.

@LoraleeM: I think it is interesting that you would mention coveting another person's spouse. I wonder what Mencius would have to say to the argument that since, according to Mencius, "all eyes are the same," then two people could find particular person to be exceptionally beautiful. If the observed person of exceptional beauty happens to be married to one of the two people who appreciate the beautiful one, and the one who is not married to the beautiful one kills the other because of an ill-conceived notion that the act would yield an opportunity to claim the beautiful one, then this horrible act appears to be a result of the human nature of the killer. How can human nature be considered good in this case?

This is a good question.  In my understanding, there is truth that is universal - values, standards that apply to the entire human race.  This is the first assumption of a belief or fact of the universe -- that there are universal standards of truth.  From where does this truth come?  The only possible source from which this universal education could come, as I understand it, is God - the One Shang Tian, Whose guidance is given throughout all time through the Manifestations of God, the Teachers of Heaven.  Definitely not anything or anyone who is "not divine" - Adolf Hitler?  And also not human.  How could it be otherwise?  We are the created, the limited in this limitless universe.  Though limited, we are possessed with enormous potential and creative capacity and purpose - far greater than we can possibly imagine, is my understanding.  (This naturally leads to the question of human and non-human kingdoms and levels of existence, i.e., mineral, vegetable, animal, human, Holy Spirit. This is another assumption of a belief or fact of the universe, that there is a level of existence above the human world.)Today people are "stuck" with the word "God" and find it problematic.  Today, though, we can learn there is new meaning of the word.  God is but one word, it doesn't matter the word - Shang Tian, Heaven, Allah, the Creator, the Ultimate Reality, the Great Spirit, the Universal Source - so many different words, as many as there are people, yet they all refer to, in the final analysis, from my studies, to the same Thing.  This becomes one of the tests for us in the world - attachments to words, concepts, previous knowledge.  According to Baha'u'llah, the latest in the line of the Divine Teachers, we learn that God is "the Unknowable Essence" - we will never know the essence of this Creator.  Yet, at the same time, we are to come to the "knowledge and love of God" in this life, how this is the purpose of life.  So, we can't stop here - this definition leads to other questions.   There have been many wise philosophers throughout the ages - Plato, Kongzi, so many in every culture.Likewise, there have been many universal Manifestations of God throughout time, each with a Teaching according to the time and capacity of the people - some examples, Krishna, Buddha, Moses, Christ, Muhammad and, for today, the Bab and Baha'u'llah.  This is another assumption of a belief or fact - that the Divine Teachers, past and present, have brought an education that was and is universal.  In the future, there will be more.  Eternal in the past, eternal in the future, says Baha'u'llah.  All of Them are the Way and unified in their essence.  It is only through the study of these Heavenly Teachers that we can know anything about God and the universal values for today. According to Baha'u'llah:  ÒThe knowledge of Him, Who is the Origin of all things, and attainment unto Him, are impossible save through knowledge of, and attainment unto, these luminous Beings who proceed from the Sun of Truth.Ó There is a difference, in my understanding of the various spiritual texts, between the philosopher and Manifestation of God.So, we continue onward in study and quest, using all of the available knowledge for us.  We independently seek the truth from whichever source its springs.  This is what both science and religion claim - that truth is one, though infinitely diverse in variations, yet whole in essence. Sharing only from my limited perspective.  In sum, an important thing to consider is how the study of truth using both the systems of science and (all) religion is just like any other subject - physics, math, language, music, and that we must actually study the Words and read, discuss, think, and question. We can't say no to some and yes to others.  We need to know what each of these Teachings say.  Welcome to a serious and fair-minded analysis into the latest of this universal knowledge found in the teachings of the Baha'i Faith - bahai.org.

From my understanding of the lectures so far, Mencius thought that imposing morals from an external source (e.g., institutions / doctrine) would cause harm. Maybe, he would approve of the "correct" kind of institution that would focus on proper forms of cultivation.  He does have strains of Confucianism, however modified and updated, and this would suggest an acceptance of institutions in some form or degree.

The schematics are categorised in my view in terms of human situations for which there are 128 [which the 64 and their opposites] and human interventions for which there are 162 [ that is 81 and their opposites].In broad terms this provides a schematic for all human situations for which one can categorise, assess and reflect. Where for each there is a classical assessment, and a range of classical advice. Where the advice and the nature of the process, seeking the optimal, includes the moral, as it would not be optimal to go against the moral. We release the quiz answers one week after each Module is released. After this point, students cannot take the quizzes for a grade, so unfortunately, people cannot join the course partway through and expect to receive a high grade. The reason we do this, rather than leave the quiz grading to the end, is to keep our current students actively involved, and to make sure they are understanding the content as we go.At this point, it is technically still possible for you to pass the course, although it will be difficult. Every quiz is worth 10% of your final grade, and you need a score of 60% to pass. You have missed 4 quizzes (i.e. 40%), but if you do well on the peer assessed assignment, you can replace the grade on one of those missed quizzes (and score a few bonus points), meaning that you could still score around a 70% total if you do not miss any points on the remaining quizzes or the final exam. Unfortunately, we cannot grant individual quiz deadline extensions or re-adjust student grades. Please let me know if this is clear, or if you have additional questions.

Or maybe naturalness is neutral and neither good nor bad.

Such people are not Gentlemen / Gentlewomen - good behaviour is a conscious choice. Bad behaviour is either poor education or poor manners. Bad behaviour should avoided, and bad people should be disassociated with.If you are gardener you remove weeds from your garden. Weeds are natural, as are flowers. The purpose of a garden is to collect and present flowers, and exclude weeds. The same applies to society. Where human weeds can either be reformed, or punished by removal from society. Thus we created laws in society to deal with gardening, and to keep the weeds out of our gardens. Where as communities we are good at identifying weeds, and by disassociation seek to keep them out of our gardens.The laws of society are created to control, restrict, and eliminate weeds. Where the qualification of a weed is at the discretion of the community. One mans weed, can be another's [in a different communities] flower, depending on their customs and practise, which adds great richness to the tapestry of our common humanity.

Spiritual education is a function of culture, where it is the development of the community that decides. Well established cultures that have proven long term endurance have long term proven values. Whereas new cultures such as for example Hitler did not have long term, nor proven values.Thus Confucianism is basing itself on the long term proven values of traditions, culture, methods of reasoning and so on. However you would never have solved the Nazi's by explaining to them the values of Confucius. Thus cultures and communities are bound with principles of which to qualify for inclusion one is required to act in what is deemed the "correct manner".However, looking for one "worldwide, one size fits all" system is futile, because that does not exists. That is because there is variety and diversity in all things.

I am minded of the boot-camp sub-genre of war films.In the 1982, double-Oscar-winning (7 nominations), feel-good film "An Officer and a Gentleman", Richard Gere plays Zack Mayo, an aloof, taciturn man who aspires to be a navy pilot. Once he's arrived at training camp for his 13-week officer's course, Mayo runs afoul of abrasive, no-nonsense drill sergeant Emil Foley. Mayo --or "Mayonnaise," as he is dubbed by the irascible Foley -- is an excellent cadet, but a little cold around the heart. Foley rides Mayo mercilessly, sensing that the young man would be prime officer material if he weren't so self-involved. Zack's affair with working girl Paula (Debra Winger) is likewise compromised by his unwillingness to give of himself. Only after Mayo's best friend commits suicide over an unhappy romance does Zack come out of his shell and mature into a real human being. Richard Gere, of course, wins through to become an Officer and a Gentleman... and get the girl.Compare this with Stanley Kubrick's 1987 (only one Oscar-nomination) film "Full Metal Jacket". This film crystallizes the de-humanizing experience of the Vietnam War by concentrating on a group of raw Marine volunteers. The film's first half details the volunteers' harrowing boot-camp training under the profane, power-saw guidance of drill instructor Sgt. Hartman (R. Lee Ermey, a real-life drill instructor whose performance is one of the most terrifyingly realistic on record). Part two takes place in Nam, as seen through the eyes of the now thoroughly indoctrinated marines.However, I am not so sure about your assertion that:> Good behaviour is a conscious choice.The difficulty of resisting evil socialization processes is a point brought out even in the trailer for the Oscar winner "Taxi to the Dark Side" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WX0MPcN08ZcPhilip Zimbardo tells us we should hold the rotten-apple barrel-makers to account. http://video.mit.edu/watch/the-lucifer-effect-understanding-how-good-people-turn-evil-9241/I was delighted to see Mark Carney (governor of the Bank of England) using this vocabulary today: http://www.theguardian.com/business/2014/nov/17/banking-culture-overhaul-mark-carney-bankers-payKind regardsGeoffrey

re: "the ÒpositiveÓ elements of our natures are frailer, require more attention for their full development" --- We humans have been working within our nature for millennia to see what we can expect from conscious thought and action. Teachings have played a decided and important linguist and memory-developing role in human life over the centuries [both oral and written]. The driving force may not be socialization and ethical behavior, but strength in the face of loss, sickness and despair. Death is natural. Strength and courage are as much a part of human history as "serenity, kindness and creativity."  I find that the internal, martial part of qi - not just the healing part - is as much a predictor of human moral development as calmness and cooperative behavior. ~~ t'ai chi practitioner
