Thank you for you comment - making me to think.  I am not quite sure about all of what you wrote.  I shared your comment with one of my friends and here is her general understanding...Human rights and the call for justice and all that implies is a spiritual concept, not an ideal or a concept - but a spiritual reality.  Already there are general moral and ethical principles upon which people of the world have already agreed, for example the UN charters, declarations, and agreed upon rights of humanity, children, and women. All of these can be expressed in the context of the various cultures, although those local cultural practices that violate human rights, for example, female circumcision and marrying off young girls with or without their consent, will have to be forgone to guarantee human rights for all members of the society.  We can see this same pattern already practiced in federations of states like the USA or EU which have their regional laws but give up certain prerogatives to the larger overarching governing council.  That's also the idea of the UN itself, though humanity is still striving to reach the level of maturity required to make it work effectively.  Looking at our achievements historically give reason for hope.  We have far to go, but historical precedent gives hope.  Additionally, a close examination of the diverse Baha'i international community demonstrates a highly successful working model in progress that applies these moral and ethical principles enshrined in the various charters and declarations.  ---Regarding longtime proven values - I agree with this, how longtime values help create well established cultures.  But what kind of culture are you talking about?  Do you mean cultures that have kept their history alive?    I believe new cultures can establish a community based on shared values - these values are the same values from long ago but with new meaning and potency in this new day.  Love, truthfulness, humility, justice, kindness - these and other values are spiritual realities from time immemorial, eternal in the past, eternal in the future, yet in this new day they all have new meaning.  These virtues or values have always been the basis of culture.  If they are now not a reality of the culture, it is because people have lost the way.  It should be understood how the meanings of concepts and values change over time.  For example, to "love the world" today means something very different from 2,000 ago when the world was infinitely smaller than it is today.  So, today we are met with a new challenge in living the value to "love the world".  In the Baha'i experience, followers of the Baha'i way are establishing "unity in diversity" - universal values that apply to all people and cultures while preserving the beauty of the varying peoples and cultures.  It is a fact that in every culture there are good things that should stay and be kept alive and there are not-good things that should go and be forgotten.  As for the human being, together we share an essential reality - the spiritual reality of our oneness.  The other part - the customs, the language, the tastes, colors and textures of culture - this diversity is precious and what brings beauty to the world.  The people of the world, the different culture in all its diversity can be compared to a beautiful garden with infinite variety and diversity in its make-up.  Yet we all, the myriad different flowers receive the same life-growing energy from the same Source of life.  I'm not sure if this response was quite the point needed, but share with you...

Great question, LoraleeM.  To me, it confirms Mengzi's point that the 'good' sprouts are not the only ones growing in the garden. If a person sees something precious on the sidewalk, he may on some days feel an urge to take it, or on other days be inclined to turn it in to the authorities.  Some may be almost always inclined to do one, others almost always to do the other. Others may be split about 50/50, but influenced by what they saw someone else do 3 days ago, or read about someone doing in the newspaper, or by what their friend did last month.In my case, my father was a very moral person.  He was also very happy whenever he found money on the sidewalk!  Two years ago, I saw two $20 bills on the sidewalk.  I rationalized that if I did not take them, someone else would, and they would never find their way to their owner.  So I took and kept them . . . and also thought with pleasure of my father.   <not meant as an example of filial piety, by the way>

I understand that we like to think that because we have choices we have free will, but if our choices are influenced by what we are born with and what we have been taught by others, how do those choices reflect free will?  For example, the psychopath has no ability to feel empathy, and he didn't choose to not feel empathy.  This inhibits him from making choices that take into consideration other people's feelings.  He is not free.  He is slave to his preexisting inability.

There is a beautiful scene in the Iliad which relates to what Mencius said about extending the love one felt for one's father and extending it to other fathers.  In the very last book of the Iliad, Priam, the father of Hector, steals away from the walls of Troy, sneaks into the Aegean camp, and finds his way to Achilles' tent to beg Achilles to return Hector's body.  Priam comes in unseen and he immediately grasps Achilles' legs and kisses Achilles' hands, the way a man begging for his life would do in Ancient Greek times.  Priam then says:"Achilleus like the gods, remember your father, one who is of years like mine, and on the door-sill of old age...surely he, when he hears of you and that you are still living, is gladdened within his heart and all his days he is hopeful that he will see his beloved son come home from the Troad." (Book 24, lines 486-492)He then tells Achilles of the pain he has suffered after losing so many of his sons, and begs Achilles to return the body of Hector.  Priam ends his speech by calling on Achilles to "take pity upon [him-Priam] remembering [his-Achilles'] father."This stirs Achilles' heart, causing him to "grieve for his own father" and he and Priam begin to weep, each for his own sorrows.  This causes Achilles to feel pity for Priam, and he finally relents and returns the body of Hector, after washing it and anointing it, taking care to keep Hector's body out of Priam's sight, so as not to upset and anger Priam.Achilles finally regains his humanity after Priam calls upon him to think of his own father and then take his love for his own father and extend it to Priam.

I would like to raise this interesting thought that crossed my mind while watching the videos in this section.If the Daodejing claims that "saying something means what is being said loses its meaning", then can we say that what the primitivists or the followers of Daodejing are doing is actually contradicting the very thought that they are promoting?For example, when they say that what confucianism proposes is wrong and that they are ruining the very nature of humans, then does it not mean that the thought loses its essence then and there and what remains is that both confucianism and daodejing have their own places and that none is better than the other?I kind of see this as like a mathematical formula where if we actually implement the thought it feels like the circle completes itself and we end up chasing our own tails.Thanks.

column25: http://archive.org/stream/LeoStraussOnEsotericismExotericism/StraussLeoOnAForgottenKindOfWriting_djvu.txtThank you N19 for Strauss. Which took me to *"On a Forgotten Kind of Writing"*, is even richer....and explains a lot.

> "To respect opinions is something entirely different from accepting> them as true.  Philosophers or scientists who hold this view about the> relation  of philosophy or science and society are driven to employ a > peculiar manner of writing which would enable them to reveal  what> they regard as the truth to the few, without endangering  the> unqualified commitment of the many to the opinions on  which society> rests. They will distinguish between the true  teaching as the> esoteric teaching and the socially useful teaching  as the exoteric> teaching; whereas the exoteric teaching is meant  to be easily> accessible to every reader, the esoteric teaching discloses itself> only to very careful and well-trained readers after  long and> concentrated study". Strauss...and then from that point onward, which is not restricted only to science and philosophy, but also to classics, one that "understands" does what?Because what seems universal is the manner of exchange, between those *"very careful and well-trained readers"*.
This is basically going to be Xunzi's argument against both Mencius and Zhuangzi. Wait till Module 7.

Yes, this is an issue several have raised, and that I addressed in the Module 5 Q&A. It's empirically probably more plausible that, alongside the "moral" sprouts, we've got plenty of less pleasant sprouts, including desires to dominate, perhaps to inflict violence, etc. Mencius's only response would be that, if you introspect, you'll see that the moral sprouts are the better and stronger part of you. Not necessarily convincing to your version of the evil king. He certainly wouldn't retreat to a cold cognition argument, since he doesn't think that has much to do with the foundations of morals.

Good example.  I think virtually everyone would take the money found lying on the sidewalk, because there's no visible person you're stealing the money from.  I hate to say it, but this seems to point to some sort of watcher--call it God, conscience, whatever--that can see our actions and can judge us.  In the case of the money on the sidewalk, there's no way to judge because no one knows whose money it is.  So the watcher is satisfied and doesn't bug us about it, and we get to keep the money without feeling guilt.  In fact, I've found money in the street and kept it and felt real elation at being $20 richer.

That's right - he is not free; he is a slave to his lower nature.  But he has the potential to reach to higher ground, and, in fact, that is his purpose in life, and his choice - whether he realizes it or not.  But, if he is so low, so far into his dark selfishness and so chained by his lower nature, then no doubt he wouldn't be able to become free without help.  He would need help to see and move away from his lower self, freed from his enslaved nature. Maybe this help would take years, but if he came to "see" and "understand" by the time of his last breath, then...victory.That is the case with all of us - think of the worse times of our own lives, our own selfishness, our own deadened heart, the most terrible spots we've ever been in.  How did we become freed?  Someone, something helped us - a person, a book, an experience, something.  And we had to make the choice to move in a different direction.I understand and believe that he is ultimately responsible for his choices, regardless of his capacity to feel or not feel empathy, regardless of whether he is cognizant of his behavior.  It could be...not until the next life that he would be made known of this. We don't know what this experience is after we die, but we do have lots of texts in both science and religion that give us some picture of what we may experience.

Professor Slingerland and his staff (i.e., videographer and others) are doing a splendid and spectacular job.  They should be commended and acknowledged accordingly.I have completed as many MOOCs as any student that you are likely to find on both Coursera and edX platforms.  This course is among the best I have taken.  The course is well-thought out.  The videos are very professionally done and clearly have taken a substantial amount of time to film, to edit, and to finalize.  (Kudos to the videographer!!)  The material is clear, both through the on-screen outlines and bullets in the videos, as well as the various episodes and outlines for each module. I particularly appreciate the time that Prof. Slingerland and others have taken to provide an annotated bibliography for additional reading or resources, or just studies mentioned in the lectures.  The quiz questions help to reinforce the learning from the readings and the lectures.  And to top it off the class is fun.  I appreciate the instructor's humor and the videographer's wit in including, for instance, outtakes the first couple of weeks.I know that this required (and still does require) a significant amount of time by all involved.  (Heck, I imagine that the time involved might make some graduate students' or other staff's compensation less than minimum wage!)  I would not hesitate to take another course from this instructor and team in the future.  So here's to hoping that they are not completely burnt out after doing such a good job on this course.

Hi LizHaving also lost a couple of lengthy comments on this platform I now draft them first in Word (with a spell checker!)... when I remember.What is particularly impressive about Sue Perkins is that as a woman talking to women she seems to bond far more quickly and deeply with the people she meets than, say, Michael Palin. She perfectly embodies your point: "regarding the stranger as worthy of the kind of care that you have within your [emotional and economic] power to give". The downside is that she immediately discovers the complexity of the issues and the inadequacy of our instant Western judgements. The cost and benefit to her is a life-changing experience she was not prepared for.I am a white person born in Central Africa, and brought up by African nannies (my mother declared she was "not interested in children until they could conduct an intelligent conversation with her") and have subsequently travelled a lot. I guard against the hardening of the heart and so find the ubiquity of real human tragedy in places like Africa particularly challenging.Sorry about all the links. I much prefer "Wu-wei" to "the emergence of Collective Intelligence". I do think that our philosophical ruminations have to be grounded - and that is one the many things I find so excellent about this MOOC. For example, The Guardian, a left-wing newspaper in the UK has just started using very short plays to dramatise contemporary issues, aka water the sprouts of moral imagination http://www.theguardian.com/stage/video/2014/nov/17/britain-isnt-eating-microplay-guardian-royal-court-videoKind regardsGeoffrey

youngbear ~ for me, Mencius' 'ox mountain,' a place stripped of vegetation, is a mind severely deprived and left to erode. In a similar metaphor of earth:brain Mencius said: ÒThe tendency of man's nature to good is like the tendency of water to flow downwards.Ó For me [philosopy major Univ. of Connecticut '68/student of Joel Kupperman http://www.amazon.com/Learning-Asian-Philosophy-Joel-Kupperman/dp/019512832X ], 'modern science' has elucidated mysteries of human behavior in a way that philosophy never could. Ethical training can minimize the erosion, but if there is a serious neurological flaw, it will never get the job done.

Anticipating Lecture 9, I think 'learning' has been equated [at least in the western world] to executive function, but in reality, learning will not 'take' without the brain in 'resting phase.'  I know this deeply from yoga and t'ai chi.  I also think the immense increase in ADD/ADHD in children reflects this increasing prejudice that 'learning' is frontal cortex. No.  It is both/and and each is in requirement for learning to sift into long-term memory.

Shastagirl14:Yes, I [a "road" scholar from 69'--74'/said in the spirit of not taking myself too seriously] do understand your link from Ox Mountain to a mind left to erode. I feel that any philosophy should take science into serious consideration if the philosophy is to be a viable working application. I feel the same way about science taking philosophy or a working spirituality into consideration. I agree that how much philosophical/perceptual training can minimize the psychological effects of serious neurological erosion is dependant on the quality of training and the seriousness of erosion. The question for me is present in the lines that blur around quality (I said that) and seriousness (you said that).I feel that both philosophy and science are guilty of often attempting control rather than harmony or as Mencius teaches, trying to push water uphill where we want it to go instead of accepting the downward natural journey of water.Shastagirl14, corresponding with you has been my pleasure. Have a great holiday!

lichungchang:  Isn't this where a virtue ethicist would say that if we have internalized virtue by a good upbringing and education (cultivation of the moral sprouts) we would automatically do the right thing?I'm not sure, however, how this fits with the psychologists who tell us that our behaviour is very much modified by the situation in which we find ourselves.  Our morality may be challenged when we come under pressure, and the first priority, for most people at least, would be to ensure the survival of our family and ourselves.

His emphasis on deconstructing language and loosening up the mind through word play sounds very similar to something Jacques Derrida would embrace. And his extreme suspicion of theoretical commitments, analytic logic and the ability of "counterculture" to be really "counter" all resonate with postmodernist thought...

I can see a link between Zhuangzi and the way how B-schools train their MBAs.   MBAs and even seasoned managers are good at analysis but not in synthesis.  In synthesizing strategies and executing them, one has definitely to take a stand to define what is right and wrong.  On the other hand, one can always criticize in analysis without offering anything substantial or commitment to any ideas.   By remaining flexible and never commit to one way or other, a lot of "professional" managers can find their ways to survive in the corporate world.

I have recently had first hand experience of this. In coaching three ten year olds in speed phrases at 3 different levels, they are asked to read as many of 90 2 to 5 word phrases as they can in 1 minute. On reaching a level of proficiency they move on to the next level. One student was particularly quick at progressing and even read with repetition up to 100 phrases but as soon as it became important to him to maintain that level, his number dropped to the 90s. Each week for three weeks he has been keen to get back to 100 but has just not made it. Alternatively the girls when distracted by conversation have done better initially but soon lose their level of attainment when it becomes important to better it. It's a fine line between developing a skill and then maintaining it against 'trying too hard".

A paradox: Zhuangzi is advocating getting rid of human nature. But he is presented as one who accepts confucian society more than Laozi. He describes butchers and carpenters as sages. So I think it is wrong to say Zhuangzi advocated that all of human nature is wrong. I think he is just against an aspect of our nature, our logic maybe, our judgments, mental distinctions, our *bian* debates. Viewing Zhuangzi with a positive aproach: maybe, in contrast with Laozi, he is not advocating a returning to a previous "primitive" state, but he believes in evolving to some better state of mind in the future.

Combining your first and last thoughts, namely a male leaving his instinctive moral values, the study could explore the behaviour of the male, the acceptance of the female, and the seemingly disproval from society. I say "seemingly" since over the years the male/female pattern grows (as shown by court cases, males thrown in jail, and female hospital visits and deaths)É or perhaps it remains the same and a percentage of the females (and health care workers and enforcement) are like the baby who is now overtly showing concern and disapproval.

Is Zhuangzi a relativist in that he does not believe in absolutes? Seems to me going with the shen, flow, also means blowing in the wind.

Carl Jung once said ÒThe pendulum of the mind oscillates between sense and nonsense, not between right and wrong.Ó We are meaning makers, so our psychological energy is guided to make sense whan we receive stimuli. And he advocated that this sense should come from the Self (inner psychological orientation system) and not from the ego, that he defined as a psychological function of identity building, a kind of manager between outer reality and inward reality.

Know hope Daoists... hmmmm...Isn't Daoism as a tradition alive and real. Those who use the DaoDeJing as some way of rationalizing a return to nature aren't Daoists, so to speak, right? I was impressed by the DDJ, but who are Daoists? Don't they have large hats?
How many things can you do with a paper clip?

I would be very interested in listening to what today's butchers all over the world thought about this concept of Butcher Ding, as I imagine them experiencing the very same process: 1. as apprentices seeing the ox as a whole and being overwhelmed 2. with more experience having learned to see its parts and cutting accordingly 3. as masters doing the work without thinking about it as it comes simply naturallyOn the other hand I were not quite sure if they all would connect their skills with a spirit, but rather with years of training. If they then did it with a "proper" attitude those butchers might want to agree to Confucius' teachings instead; if just doing what needs to be done, possibly Mozi.

column25: >If the Daodejing claims that "saying something means what is being said loses its meaning", then can we say that what the primitivists or the followers of Daodejing are doing is actually contradicting the very thought that they are promoting?Your argument is  within the framework of logic and reason. You could say that Laozi is criticizing language, and hence logic as a tool, in his "soteriological strategy". I am 90% sure that whoever(s) wrote the DaoDeJing (and the Zhuanzi) are fully aware of the limitations of logic, language, linguistics etc. So the fictitious Laozi would say that this argument is focusing on the finger and not at the moon that its pointing to, or was that Bruce Lee?
I was surprised Tian came up. It seems counter to Mozi's business model - lol, if we can call it that.  Mozi would have a serious field day on expediting environmental rejuvenation.

Although it happened a lot of times that I felt as if being in a flow when e.g. doing design or animation work or programming on a computer, I still find it much easier to switch off my mind and letting go when for instance digging out a tree stump. My hands might be covered with weals or torn open afterwards and the back hurting but this manual labour gives a very rewarding feeling and time surprisingly flies.This is why I can understand people who search for new ways in their lives to experience that special feeling more. It would be nice to learn to get to this point with every kind of work, and especially with boring routine.
column35: Gardening Compared With Working at the Computer

column25: Is it possible that Zhuangzi's words about beginning are more that just word play, that he's actually trying to make a point about the nature of time? Contemporary cosmologists are now exploring the possibility of no beginning: that there is no start, that the idea of a beginning or a start is a projection of a binary human mind, that in fact, the origins of things is more mysterious than our conceptual frameworks could possibly project. Of course there is the idea of creation and destruction, the idea of universes coming into being and passing out of existence. But when did *that* process begin? Is there an empty eon, a time when it appears that there is nothing?  But even though it might it appear that in a given eon there is nothing, there is this vital energy of movement, of impermanence.  The whole idea of beginning implies there is an ending, or something prior to beginning and that "beginning" is a particular moment in time.  But whatÕs before that? Another beginning?  And before that? Yet another beginning? It doesn't make sense. There is only movement and we exist here, now, in this moment because that movement has never ceased.

I'm a late comer to this EdX course, but I also feel that the prof leans towards Confucianism. At first I was a bit snarky feeling in my heart about it, but after this lecture in this module, I think his view (up till now) is pretty spot on. Showing that Confucius and Laozi are both teetering on the horns of the internal vs. external dilemma, sorta, sorry for the pun, balances things out and makes me feel like he's not so biased... not SO biased that I don't like the guy. I was a bit skeptical up until this point, what can I say?Naturally (can I not help it with these puns?) I wanted the Daoists to win, but I have to admit, based off of my experience abroad and in Daoism groups, that the dark side of Daoism does exist. There's a wild and wacky tension in Daoism groups, and I'm pretty sure if you brought up the 'theoticy problem' in them, you'd get a hard 'thwomp' with a uncarved (and heavy) block on the ego. Let's say that I would know.Although it seems that in the future lectures that the prof will argue that Zhuangzi just says "go with the flow", which to me doesn't capture the sophistication and beauty of the book, really in the end isn't too off. I think that ZZ does attempt to straddle the internal vs. external dilemma and ride the bull off to wherever he's going, to the beach or wall-street or wherever. In a way you can say someone who is labeled as a Daoist (Zhuangzi) does a pretty good job of dealing with the dilemma (or is it the editor, Guo Xiang, of the ZZ that should get the credit?) and the Daoists can let out a sigh of relief. But is 'going with the flow' really the 'salvation' that most people drawn to the DaoDeJing want? Is that what the OG hippies and new-school hippies are hoping for? lol. Doubtful, but what I've said is doubtful too. haha.

**Catching Monkeys**> And, one story, **I don't know if this is true**, whenever I hear the swallow story, I think about possibly apocryphal tale about some tribe somewhere that hunted monkeys.And the way they try to catch monkeys is they go into the middle of a clearing and they stake down this gourd, and they put some food, some rice or some grain, in there.And the gourd is picked to be just the right size so that a monkey got its hand in like this, but when it grabs the grain and tries to pull it out, it can't take its fist out.There is a scene in the documentary (or rather docutainment) film "Animals are Beautiful People" (1974) showing how San People (I think) in the Kalahari desert use a similar method to catch baboons. Here melon seeds are put into a hole of a termite nest, to let a most curious baboon focussing on getting them out afterwards. The monkey can be caught easily and then be fed with salt until it gets very thirsty. The baboon, who normally would never be that careless, when released runs directly to a hidden source of water, and the bushmen follow to get water, too.You can find that scene under https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YAy8LUmXPmo.**Zhuangzi and Social Problems**> So the Zhuangzi has got **no story about when it comes to if they're** [sic] **structural social problems**.Maybe he did not need to have such a story. When everybody just had followed his teachings, maybe in his eyes society's problems would simply have dissolved.

Interesting!Its rigidity which causes pain, it would appear that I would rigidly argue for, not the fact that we are human and have discerning minds. Isn't there something about transformation in the inner chapters? Perhaps transformation is a skill which one can bring into the 'hot' mind so that you in effect become a hot liquid mind of awesomeness which can transform because you have learned the skill of nothingness, The skill of being formless and thus you can fit into whatever situation and fulfill whatever your duty may be.*Meh*... or it can be just the fasting of humanness or whatever, like the teacher says.

Some of the questions you're trying to ask become complicated when realising that everything you perceive is result of your brain. The grammatical errors take away from your response. Understanding is inherently restricted to the brain that constructs the reality you perceive. I think you touch on this when you mention ''the origins of things is more mysterious than our conceptual frameworks could possibly project''.

column25: I thought the exact same, that Derrida and Zhuangzi seem to share a lot of ideas.

Agreed. I believe Zhuangzi would say that whether time has a beginning or not, it doesn't really matter anyway. He might also agree that though there may be many conceptions of the good, they are all independent of the nature of time. I have read about what cosmologists call "bubble nucleation," which is the concept that a space existed in which the big bang occurred. Obviously we can't observe how long this outer space bubble existed, because there is no light beyond the event horizon. I would say that this discussion of physics is as far removed from what Zhuangzi would consider important as we might reason it is.

First I would like for you to explain exactly what you mean by "accepts Confucian society" with regard to Zhuangzi. You are on the mark when it comes to the distinction between "nature" and "essence." As Anthony mentions, there are a number of references in the *Zhuangzi* to a rejection of the "cold" cognitive judgments that we make and use to shape our behavior. From this we can infer that there is present in the *Zhuangzi* a preference for "hot" cognitive behavior similar to that of the *Daodejing*.

This may have been made more clear in the Zhuangzi lecture where it was mentioned that Zhuangism picked up a lot of "shamanistic" practices as it evolved, especially because of it's southern roots.  This might have also happened with Daoism. But then, my questions are never answered.

I too see it as contradictory that butchers are sages but we need to get rid of human essence (read: ordinary life, like cutting up animals).  Without his butcher essence, the butcher would be just another human believing he knew what was right and wrong--i.e., right and wrong ways to cut up an animal.  Can this contradiction be resolved?

Maybe this is a bit not related to the lecture, but it is. What is the point of having that guy talking in the video? He is not a specialist on the topic? The sound is really bad, he looks like he just woke up, and his explanations are nothing special really.Just wondering what is the need of having him talking. I would rather have Professor Slingerland or one of the members of the great China 300x Team talking about it.Just my thoughts though.

column25: How can it serve someone's understanding to hold ideas as both this/that and right/wrong. I can see how ideas of complexity, such as the imperfect procedural justice of criminal trials in the United States, can have a right/wrong sort of subjectivity. But the feature of right/wrong is inherent in imperfect procedural justice because there is no particular process that guarantees the desired outcome, and so sometimes the process fails to bring about the desired outcome.My question is how can an idea, like not killing innocent people, seem to be inherently right, but it some way be wrong?

So would you agree that when Yan Hui got rid of "Hui" he was leaving his ego behind? The Self as described by Jung seems to be the system by which we "match up" perceived information and reality as we learned in the lecture. That is an interesting note.

>My question is how can an idea, like not killing innocent people, seem to be inherently right, but it some way be wrong?This class and professor are startlingly thoughtful...I don't think that Zhuangzian ethics have any say in inherent rights or wrongs. Nor would they want to, otherwise he falls into the trap of being like everybody else and he most certainly isn't like everybody else. Its like a kind of intensely creative situationalism, but that would be understating it. I would say that Zhuangzi recognizes law, rules, ethics, etc., around him as natural to humanity and probably wouldn't argue that there *seem* to be universal ethics (e.g. don't murder), but rather than arguing with them, he molds himself to them like water molds to the shape of a vessel. People kill others in war all the time. Its stupid, right? Animals murder the be-jeezus out of each other on the reg, bro. lol. Buddhists make it a point of not willy-nilly killin people. Who is right and who is wrong?Anyway, that's my thoughts. Someone wiser and more awesome-er I'm sure will come along. ;)

Well Russell Brand is sort of a famous person these days, and since Brand has taken an interest in what Dr. Slingerland has done, such that he would record a video and send it to our Professor, Slingerland figured it would be entertaining for the audience to see it. I found it entertaining, though Russell Brand spoke almost too quickly to be understood properly, but not quickly enough to adjust the speed down to 0.50x. Furthermore, as Dr. Slingerland said in the video, Brand's reaction to the butcher story was exactly the sort of reaction Zhuangzi expected from people in his time. To think that you could find spiritual perfection in such disfavored positions seems to be counter intuitive. Zhuangzi shows us that it really isn't. I wonder how Russell Brand would argue against the objection that his conception of animal cruelty inherent in butchery could be shown to be wrong by Zhuangzi. I mean that thinking that butchering animals is wrong, and maintaining that view so rigidly seems to suggest that, as we discussed earlier, even the tenets of  the counter-culture can be wrong.

Nothing against our esteemed Professor who is too enlightened to search for or want fame, but I was actually asking the opposite question of Randall's. Why would Russell Brand take the time to make a video for this course??!!

Personally I find that sometimes I can arrive at interesting philosophical ideas while I work my warehouse operations job. At other times, while working, I have come up with ideas for new songs. I certainly agree distraction can help, but my situation certainly ins't ideal, because I can't choose to leave work and fully develop the creative ideas that I get there.

"The Outsider" or "The Stranger" (French: "LÕƒtranger") is a novel by Albert Camus published in 1942. CamusÕs protagonist, Meursault, displays traits that resemble those of Zhuangzi's philosophy, like a passive state of being, perception without preconception and a life where there is no right/wrong distinctions. The protagonist after attending his mother's funeral, apathetically kills a man. In January 1955, Camus said, "I summarized The Stranger a long time ago, with a remark I admit was highly paradoxical: 'In our society any man who does not weep at his mother's funeral runs the risk of being sentenced to death.' I only meant that the hero of my book is condemned because he does not play the game.". We can argue if "the stranger" is really in Wu-Wei or rather in a state of inertia, passivity, apathy or laziness. But putting this aside, Camus's novel explores the experience of believing in nothing beyond a person's freedom of action and the moral implications of that way of thinking.

I suppose that Zhuangzi would not have talked about social problems, because doing so requires making right-claims. In order to identify and work on social problems it is necessary to make this, not that judgments.

Interesting study I came acrosshttp://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/04/25/creativity-walking-_n_5205918.htmlShows walking on a treadmill improved peoples performance on the creative/novel uses for objects test. Walking outside made no difference, it was the act of walking.Maybe walking is down regulating the pre frontal cortex in the same way as alcohol? Could walking be a type of 'moving meditation'? And shows they were onto something in the post Physiological turn era, that exercise and movement help the mind become more flexible.

Isn't Zhuangzi pointing out the limits of language, and trying to break out of dualistic thinking that results in beginning and ends, right & wrong, this & that? And we have to use the non logical part of our mind to grasp that.He could also be asking the question in the way quantum physics asks it - what came before the beginning of everything? Or in a the way a koan would frame it- what did your face look like before your parents were born.Or maybe he wasn't doing any of these things?!

***My question is how can an idea, like not killing innocent people, seem to be inherently right, but it some way be wrong?***As an absolute prohibition this rule may be challenged. For example, a strict utilitarian may ask - What if a billion lives could definitely be saved by killing one innocent person?

Great questions but, arguably, non-human animals do not ***murder***, though obviously they kill. Gorillas, for example, are intelligent but arguably cannot conceptualise murder; for example, they have no malice aforethought.(There may, however, be ETs out there who do commit murder.)

Perhaps it's an issue of reframing the question.  The monkey thinks, "Three for breakfast--that's not enough!  I can't get a good start on my day's work unless I have four . . ."  And the training, intuiting this, says, in effect, yes, you are right, you need four in the morning.  So he reframes his response and says, "Yes, of course, four in the morning and three in the evening."  The monkey's initial worry is assuaged, and the trainer keeps to his budget.  True, the monkey hasn't made any gains; but one of his worries is taken care of.  Likewise, a parent might say, bedtime at 7:30, but the child wants to stay up later.  Well, so the parent says, okay, let's make it 8:30 on Friday and Saturday.  That solves part of the kid's problem, and the parent isn't stinting on the child's schoolnight sleep.  Many people want more upfront, and this example illustrates how such reasoning might convince them to accept a bargain that doesn't really do them any good.But I think the real issue is whether one can rethink one's situation or options.  A Confucian can't, Zhuangzi seems to be saying, nor can a Mohist.

I'm also puzzled about how you can function in society, while at the same time not adhering to or espousing society's values.  I suppose it's possible, but very difficult.  Wouldn't it in fact *make* you a bit of an outsider, if not an outcast?

Wondering whether this means just getting into a state of wu-wei -  meaning that  wu-wei is a 'religious' state in which we are in touch with heaven according to Zhuangzi?  But if you thought you were in touch with heaven, might you not also think you were right; or is it beyond right and wrong? Or is heaven simply a part of us - the natural part, uncorrupted by society? Sorry, I think I'm getting a bit confused here.

I don't think hypo-frontality is the only solution to why koans can be so effective as landing us somewhere new, beyond where our rationality can take us.Koans and similar techniques that get us "lost", cognitively speaking, seem to create a brain state called meta-stability. During such a state, there are a number of stable "concepts" being held simultaneously. By (briefly) holding so many simultaneous possibilities, the networks seem to ultimately collapse into a different place that integrates the network activity in ways we could not have predicted.A good source for these ideas is Kelso and Engstrom's [The Complementary Nature][1].We don't have to create a state of hypo-frontality to create meta-stability, although it's possible meta-stability produces hypo-frontality to some degree.For example, I had a client who was struggling with leaving or staying with a partner. They did a "squiggle" exercise of the type Engstrom describes (leaving ~ staying) and ended up massively decluttering their home. Initially they thought there was nothing from the exercise, although it was "interesting". They didn't see the connection between the careful sorting of what was important to them and the discarding of things that did not serve until describing it later to me.   [1]: http://thecomplementarynature.com/

Much more recently, and not in China, it has been said: "He who begins with certainties will end with doubts [and he who begins with doubts will end with certainties].Zhuangzi teaches that there are no certainties.  (He's surely conscious of the fact that even this is stated as a certainty!  Which is one reason for the emphasis on contradictions.)Of course he opposes "logic," because logic is almost entirely about certainties, assertions which have "truth values."Corollary to this he's against systems which posit any particular "way" or goal of "the good," because identifying such a value implies certainty.Now he turns to all the illustrious philosophers available to him, as well as the people around him.  They're all hung up on one kind of certainty or another--Confucius, Mencius, Mozi...  (Except maybe the Daoists.)It follows from this observation that fastening on certainties can be seen as the hitherto-elusive common elements, inborn essence, that strings together the butcher, Confucius, and everybody else.There is a wonderful coherence to this thinking.

Its also too bad politicians can't seem to make a difference in steering a healthy perspective or actually attaining serious environmentally (as an example) healthy goals.  That's why voting for the most sensible for the times makes sense. Well, lets toast to those who try..
Indeed, wonderful thoughts and ideas are one thing, to be able to make something out of it is another.
You are right. I did not think about that aspect when writing my response. But of course it makes sense.

Aren't they simply friends? And I think the  professor has made very clear in his lectures that he is very much in touch with  'popular culture', and quite far from confucian style elitism. (Would I dare to say that he is kind of a hippie himself? Oups, sorry, said it :p)

I have done my 3 gradings. I noticed that week 8 slot shows my mark. I guess that is how it works. As long as I get credit I am fine. I put a lot of work into it. It WAS a good exercise to review the three philosophies.

I confess I'm one of those confused by the appearance of a Confucius at times saying things that, as I understand it, Confucius would have disagreed with. As Professor Slingerland points out, we need to take this figure as a mouthpiece for Zhuangzi, but if the intention is to enlist Confucius' prestige in support of the text, it seems a bit clumsy and unlikely to have fooled a genuine literati audience. Is there a better explanation?
Because his Way is self-publicity devoid of all content?

I agree with most of this, although I wouldn't say that Zhuanzi shows that Russel's objection is wrong. I'm splitting hairs, but the difference is important (to me). Zhuangzi doesn't go about saying people are *wrong* per se, not very socially fluid right?, he attacks the fact that rigid persepctives, including his own, lead to a loss of qi. So I would imagine that if Zhuangzi was having a bad day, was low on qi or whatever and wanted to be a jerk and tells Russel he's wrong, Russel would probably react the way almost every single human on the planet reacts when you try to show them they are wrong. Defensive, right? Are you feeling defensive? I am. haha

There has also been some (unpublished?) research into the effects of mindfulness on young people with various emotional problems.  The benefit seems to be, not that the mindfulness necessarily alleviated their mental distress, but that it made it easier for them and helped them to cope with their (emotional) pain.
This is a good point. Its not wu-wei that allows for survival, but flexibility.
What's Derrida's point? Zhuangzi is emphasizing that there is some utility in a "loosened" mind, not "looseness" floating around in world without consequences or meaning.

" Great words are clear and limpid; little words are shrill and quarrelsome.Day after day they use their minds in strife,  sometimes grandiose, sometimes sly, sometimes petty. .  . They bound off like an arrow or a crossbow bolt,certain they are arbiters of right and wrong. They cling to their position as though they had sworn before the gods,sure that they're holding on to victory. "This wonderful passage had me thinking repeatedly of Abraham Lincoln in 1861-65, and the way he strode with great effectiveness through the righteousness, ambition and noise of lesser politicians of all stripes, leaving behind the great words of the Second Inaugural and the Gettysburg Address. He was in addition remarkable for his ability to change, for being open to the opinions of others, for not taking himself too seriously, for avoiding the lingo of good and evil, and for seeing the folly of trying to change others by condemning them as wrongdoers.

Zhuangzi recognises that it is a problem that people are overly confident in their own convictions about the "truth", and seems to advocate a healthy dose of skepticism towards anyone who tries to proselytise a viewpoint.  And yet, Zhuangzi says not that there is no right and wrong, but rather that we are mistaken about what is actually right.  If someone actually discovers the Truth, though, they are unable to communicate it to anyone else, and anyway we should always be suspicious of others' opinions.In that case, is there no way for the Truth to be taught, and can we only discover the Truth by our own efforts?  And is there no way to evaluate which person is closer to the Truth?  That seems like a really lonely and bleak view of human social relations.  And that seems like modern moral relativism to me - which is a surprising thing to discover in ancient Chinese philosophy.

When Zhuangzi says that the right and the wrong are so tied together that they can't be distinguished, or that the "this" and the "that" are so closely linked that they are the same thing, is he thinking more of an existence claim rather than a normative claime?  I.e. does he say "right is the same as wrong" or "this is the same as that", or rather does he say "the right is" and "the wrong is also" and "this is" and "that is also" (simplified: "it is what it is")?  Perhaps what he is getting at is that we should just recognise reality for what it is, rather than to recognise it through what we value in it.

Actually I like Brand's ruminations on various things and I think using this video was spot on. It also resonated with me particularly because way back in the day when I was a teenager and still ate meat, my brother and I used to catch a tram (a long time ago in Sydney Australia) to a butcher where we could get a side of yearling lamb very cheaply (we were members of a large family). We had to wait while the butcher cut up the side into the pieces for cooking, and although he wouldn't have been as much in the flow as Butcher Ding, there was something numinous about his quick skill. We would both watch entranced - it was the highlight of our trip.Since becoming a vegetarian I have often wondered why I wasn't ashamed of this once joyful experience. Now I know, so thanks again for the insight. I still think that unless you can kill and butcher the meat you eat you shouldn't be eating it, and I can date the sprout of this feeling back to that fortnightly trip. So I guess that makes me more of a Zhuangzian than a Mencian. Even as a vegetarian, I can see the 'rightness' in qi-driven butchering, but certainly not in the buying a styrofoam package of meat that denies the cruelty of the animal's life and death due to factory-farming and industrial butchering.
All of these thinkers are very "this-worldly", in the sense that there is no afterlife goal or end of the world they are preparing for, it's all about living a better life in this world.

I actually wrote an essay in grad school on Zhuangzi, Derrida and Foucault on language, and I think there's a lot of work on this out there now in the secondary literature. There are a lot of similarities, the difference is that Zhuangzi is a realist, in the sense he thinks that there is a real world we can get in touch with, whereas Derrida and Foucault see humans as embedded at a very fundamental level in language/culture.
Very interesting and good illustration of this point.

This lecture reminded me of Don Juan's way of teaching Castaneda, where in the first two books he talked about using drugs in order to become a sorcerer and 'stop the world', and then in the third book, 'Journey to Ixtlan', said that he'd concentrated on the use of drugs at first because this was the best way to help Castaneda get away from relying on his conscious mind.I wasn't into drugs and so the first Castaneda book I read was 'Ixtlan' - on the recommendation of my mother, who without much formal education worked almost always from her qi. I found its message of having to 'jump off the world' incredibly powerful but in the end frightening. So it wasn't life-changing - just a case of 'if only I could . . .'. Zhuangzi's skill-stories (as well as a few favourite Zen koans, e.g. the Parable of the Strawberry') are less frightening and have therefore spoken more directly to me.

Hi folksThis is yet another wonderful lecture. Perhaps I can contribute a painful experience that illustrates the power of such ideas.My daughter was damaged at birth and grew up awkward in her actions and unable to maintain eye contact without moving her head. She was very bright. As parents, we tended to minimise her disability by saying "everybody is different, you might seem a bit clumsy but you are off-the-scale when it comes to smarts". When she hit puberty, ignorant kids at school labelled her spastic. This came as a blow and she became anorexic. The  " undergrowth in the head" says "if you can control your appetite then you can control anything". And it sort of works as hunger drives other thoughts out of the brain. Of course, anorexia leads to all sort of ills as the body shuts down and eventually dies.At one level, the cure is easy: "eat your food and you will feel better". But just try telling an anorexic this and they will start throwing things at you.We ended up at The Priory, the UK's pre-eminent clinic for this sort of thing. After various treatments that only seemed to make things worse, we met with the family therapist who attempted the reframing of the "monkey trainer". He interviewed us separately then he brought us back together and said: "I have been listening to Alice (not her real name) and it seems to me that the problems she is describing are the problems of a teenager not the problems of an anorexic. So my question to you is: do you think that she is first-and-foremost a teenager or first-and-foremost an anorexic?" Naturally we answered "teenager". I don't want to minimize the huge effort that followed  but this marked a turnaround ("pivot") in her condition. Anorexic no more, Alice married one of her therapists, has two lovely children and is currently completing a PhD dissertation on eating disorders.Kind regardsGeoffrey

If the aim is to go with the flow of reality, then is there space for agency to operate? When Yan Hui sings or shuts up as appropriate, he seems to do so not through an analytical process where he weighs the environmental factors according to some schema and then concludes the best course of action, but rather by being in tune with the flow, which simply nudges him to produce the appropriate reactions. No decisions seem to be made. What, then, is the purpose of free will and agency in such a setup? Is agency something to be avoided and purged, since it only seems to be capable of getting in the way of us being in the flow?

This is a poem from my recently completed poetry collection called, *Zen Essentials* for which I will be doing a book launch on December 11.**Dokusan***Roshi wears a mala on her wrist.I give her eyes and ears; she gives me seven strips of blank paper, invites me to write one ego role per strip. ÔMonk, poet, teacher, student,lesbian, married, gardener.Õ ÒCrumple them all,Ó she says.ÒDrop them to the floor.ÓÒNow IÕm nobody going nowhere,Ó I say.She whacks me with her awakening stick.ÒYouÕre far too ambitious.Ó *spiritual counselling

Reference to sudden and gradual stories of achieving wu-wei reminded me of research done on damping down the default mode network (DMN) and neurofeedback.  Here is a link to an interesting talk by Judson Brewer, who describes how novices to meditation can quickly learn how to damp down the DMN by neurofeedback provided by an fMRI scanner.  http://www.umassmed.edu/cfm/about-us/people/meet-our-research-team/brewer-judson/videos/The talk is quite long (50minutes +).  Judson Brewer relates the findings to mindfulness and Buddhist meditation, and includes some detail about the brain, particularly the posterior cingulate cortex.  Although I realise there were no fMRI scanners in Zhuangzi's time (!), it does seem to tie in pretty well in many ways with what we're learning.(In the first part of the talk, he describes work done on nicotine addiction, among other things.  The neurofeedback part starts from around 30 minutes into the talk.)

column25: DanielLeong,I love your questions,  Here are a few of my thoughts on the matter:There is nothing that cannot be looked at that wayThere is nothing that cannot be looked at this way.But that is not the way I see things;Only as I know things myself do I know them.(Zhuangzi, 2)Within the immutable Origin a whirling entity, immense and void.  The Hollow immensity fused into a single body, one and the same.  This single tumultuous body was closed, healed over itself, a humid foggy dream Ð no light.  Spiritual subtlety filled everything.  In the quintessential calm, no light shone.  No action, no movement.  The ten thousand things had not yet formed.  The great whirlwind is ineffable.Heaven did not cover.  Earth did not bear.  And nevertheless, it was already there: the primordial Tao, more subtle than the infinitely small, more vast than the infinitely large.(Four Canons of the Yellow Emperor, Canon Four, The Original Way, trans, Jean Levi(into French), trans. Jody Gladding(from French into English), Inner Traditions, Rochester, VT, 2009, 175)Voix GlauqueNow that bird of life                with its bouche avare         makes as if to devour usExcept it cannot do it               as long as we keep singing                                  and making love          for this sets up vibrations                              in its throat               which make it impossible                                   to swallow usIt is the dead bird               in the heart                     that kills usAs on this Sunday afternoon                   sky grey over Les Halles  from the fifth floor balcony           I see stick figures lost below                 the mute singers and the walking dead       and one pigeon walks about silent               and one or two                       fly through the heavy airIt does not matter that the sky                             is made of lead            or that no bells toll	                                 anywhereInside ourselves is the song                        as an oboe dÕamoreIt sounds in us so distantly                           so insistently             a distant singing                              a far crying           so faintly echoing Ð                               glaucous voices                           beyond our little turning worldIt is life itself singing                 its exultant harmonies           and stretching over us                          its darkling wings(Over All The Obscene Boundaries, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, New Directions, NY, 1984, 30 Ð 31)Much elaboration here, so defeats the end by acknowledging the method.  Start with Ferlingetti: how can a voice be glaucous?  Glaucous: (1a) of a pale yellow-green color, (1b) of a light bluish grey or bluish white color (2) having a powdery or waxy coating that gives a frosted appearance and tends to rub off.  (Webster Ninth New Collegiate Dictionary).  Investigating still further we find that it also refers to the ÒGlaucous,Ó a gull but also as ÒGlaucus,Ó to a fish. Glaucous and Glaucus have same origin from the Greek via Latin (OED, 1985).  In this we see the color is an uncertain blending from one into another.  The Tao gives birth to the One, the One to the Two, the Two to the Three: from the Three are born the ten thousand beings (Daode ching, 42). The Voix Glauque, oboe dÕamore sounds distantly insistently, a distant, far, faint echoing that provides an exultant harmony that stretches over us.  It is both pale and bright far and yet here holding all.  The one is the involved observer; the two are the observer and the observed which are three in that  they together birth a new awareness.  Only for the original observer are is this awareness transmissible?  Only if the receiver knows the thing, him or her self. From the four Canons:  The Primordial Tao as such cannot be known without giving birth to another, the two who then generate the three and finally the ten thousand. But in this knowing lies the secret to unknowing. But the knowing/unknowing is dependent on the singular autonomy of the self as such.  In that moment, there lies no need for a normative for it simply is/is not.

To me, this is where Mozi's lack of emphasis on the internal becomes a problem and where his activism and fairness emphasis benefit from attention to the internal.Why don't we all act on what seems fair and just? I think this is addressed to some degree by the material covered in earlier chapters and in the article by Russell Brand - where we need to play some head games with ourselves or where there are cultural head games (e.g., marketing) to make disparities "all right".But I think underlying all these is the notion of values, and in particular, competing values. And that often our competing values are largely unexamined and/or the cultural pressures (aka cultural values) make it hard to (or at a minimum, don't support) to act on some "smaller" personal values more consistently.There is plenty of evidence to show we mimic people around us and that they mimic us. We may believe we don't need such a big house or such an expensive wine, but we will have competing values for social connection -- to "fit in" -- with our social networks. So, if we are going to choose to "deny" one value, we need a support structure to maintain it and that support structure is often sadly lacking in north american cultures. There aren't many of us that would turn away from existing social structures to create a different social network that would support the competing value. If we pay attention to the "value" issue - the internal part of the equation -- I think we can have had a stronger impact than the external focus alone or the internal focus alone.
Zhuangzi

The discussion on small understandings vs. great understandings reminds me of a model that was discussed in a class on complex systems. Imagine that you are in a landscape and you want to get to the highest point. You choose to act according to the strategy of always heading upwards. Using this, you arrive at a peak, but to your dismay you see that there are higher peaks around you that you had not noticed before because of your obsession with heading upwards.Now think of the height of the hills as a measure of understanding, and the heading-upwards rule as a doctrine. In this way, people trying to arrive at a global maximum may become trapped at local maxima if they don't abandon their doctrine. It seems to me Zhuangzi's method was about realizing that your local maximum may not be the global maximum , that your maximizing strategy may not be effective, and indeed that there are other ways to locate and obtain the global maximum.

Zhuangzi's theodicy problem is indeed a serious one, as it seems to be a logical inconsistency within his conceptualisation of human nature. I reckon that one way out of this problem is for Zhuangzi to demonstrate that a sage can't be made a priori, but has to emerge through a process of becoming. Perhaps sagedom is like a good aged wine: you can't make an aged wine from scratch, but you can only put in some raw ingredients and then let it sit and become what it is meant to be over time. Through this process, the mixture of raw ingredients will lose some of their essential qualities (eg. The sugars in the grape juice will be fermented away) and other qualities will emerge to become essential qualities of the resultant wine.

column25: i'm a practitioner of flow at work (writing software), however, i remember reading a concert pianist's account of his mentor's emphasis that during performance, he should not lose himself and the importance of being in control.... for butcher maybe it's possible, but for many complicated tasks we perform today we need hot/cold cognition to work together...

I do wish that Prof Slingerland would distinguish between the two schools of Chan/Zen Buddhism in his lecture. He discusses the Lin-chi (Japanese - Rinzai) school as if it represents the whole of Zen, but, in fact there is also the Caodong (Japanese - Soto)school which de-emphasizes koan practice and places greater emphasis on sitting meditation. (zazen). This approach to Zen also relates back to Taoism, as well as to the practices of ancient Hindu and Buddhist practitioners in India, and is described well in the text, "Original Tao."

in addition to the lack of the claims on supernatural beings, the lack of salvation  seems to be a bigger problem... i reviewed module 1.2 on professor Slingerland's talk on thoughts/religions and their definitions, although i agree that basically all philosophies are some forms of religion, does the absence of salvation, especially the transcendental ones (irrational, like building equities in next life instead of this life) mean all these thoughts are basically utilitarian? in that they're still about maximizing some utility functions in this life, for this society, just different choices of such functions, e.g. peaceful society, more population, more food on the table, etc...the french writer, george bataille, in his book "the accursed share", advocate the importance of "irrational squander", that we cannot accrued profits indefinitely, in the end we must squander without any purpose, the only choices we have is gloriously (churches, clergy, art, music...) or catastrophically (war, famine, disease, overpopulation/poverty...).. lacking a clear (irrational) salvation strategy seem to leave Zhuangzi and others thoughts wanting...
Hi Raffaella: I study Chinese, practice taiji and qi gong, but my passion is Chinese traditional medicine.

i guess this should be a question in module one, it seems so far all the thoughts we've covered have very rational soteriological claims (salvation), in Zhuangzi it's becoming a better butcher, or a carpenter, etc, or the reward is in the pursuit itself (a.k.a. flow). There's no promise for eternal life, after life, next life, no bonus points for helping others, etc... like early Buddhism? If yes, is there a real difference between Zhuangzi, Mozi, Mencius, Confucius, i.e. if they all try to achieve a more productive society and happier individuals, just different ways of how to get there? If yes, are they all utilitarians and rational?Are irrational (and unprovable) claims the necessary conditions for philosophy? be it the Way, the Ritual, the Dharma, the Happiness, etc? or GDP, infant mortality rate, high school drop out rate, big data can also qualify as salvation?

I met Russell Brand in the course of my book tour back in April in the UK. He'd apparently read my Trying Not to Try (we share the same UK publisher and they'd sent him a copy), and contacted me through my publicist when he heard I was in London because he wanted to interview me. So we did this crazy, rambling hour and a half interview at his house that has, unfortunately, never seen the light of day (or, rather, has been shown by Brand a couple times at events but never posted on-line). Anyway, we actually covered a lot of very MOOC-relevant material that day, which we were hoping to get a hold of, and Brand has also been reading from my book and commenting on it in his podcasts ("The Trews"), so we thought throwing in some of this footage would help liven things up a bit, relieve the tedium of listening to me non-stop, and inject a bit of humor into the course. Unfortunately we never got a hold of the interview footage (my impression is that Russell does not run the most efficient of ships, it may actually just be lost somewhere...), so we've just ended up putting in a few clips of him reading from Trying Not to Try on his podcast (he didn't record this personally and send it to me, it's just sampled from his podcast). As I said in the beginning of the course, he's helpful as a kind of ersatz lecture audience member, reacting with a very contemporary perspective to this early Chinese material, plus I think he's pretty funny.
Yep, I talk a lot about Soto at the end of this module, please hang in there.

Yes, agency in that sense is to be eliminated, which is why Yan Hui says, "There is no more Hui" after the fasting of the mind. Your normal self is no longer in charge and some more impersonal, heavenly force inside you takes over.

I wouldn't call Zhuangzi an atheist, he has a deep faith in the power of Heaven (although Heaven is mostly an impersonal force for him). We will meet an early Chinese atheist, or the closest we'll get to one, in Module 7: Xunzi.

What I thought of re the mention of using the face to detect poseurs was something called the Duchenne smile. Duchenne did research to explore the facial musculature differences between authentic and simulated smiles. There are indeed differences which are detectable -- not just consicously, but also outside of awareness. Here's a fun brief little [discussion][1]:    [1]: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u-lSQj-gswQ

Yes, but for Camus there is no Heavenly-derived "spirit" inside of us to take over when we enter the state of passivity, it's just ultimately meaningless drifting, except for what meaning we can impose on it through an arbitrary act of human will. So despite the superficial similarities, I think that the existentialism of Camus couldn't be farther from the Zhuangzi.

Of all the readings so far, the Zhuangzi is the funniest. There are so many passages that made me smile. For example, in chapter 4, Yan Hui is explaining his plan to help the lord of Wei and Kongzi responds with "Sheesh! You're just going to get yourself hurt." Something about this ancient and revered teacher saying "sheesh!" was very unexpected. Or the story in chapter 7 of Whish and Whoosh "helping" their friend All-full by drilling holes in his head. It ends with the matter-of-fact, "Each day they drilled a hole. And in seven days, All-full died." And throughout, many of the characters have silly names. Is all this purely a matter of translation, or is the tone of the original also this funny? I'm assuming it is since so much of the material is a little off-the-wall. I wonder if this humorous tone has helped or hurt how this work has been viewed over the ages. It seems like it would stand in sharp contrast with something like the Mozi which takes a more rational approach.
Metaphor = censorship

> If you accumulate enough earth to form a mountain, then wind and rain> will arise from it. If you accumulate enough water to form a deep> pool, then dragons will come to live in it. Xunzi *Readings in Classical Chinese Philosophy, page 249*> > > ...it reveals the text and the mystery that lies beneath it, and so at> one and the same time exercises the wise with the one and encourages> the simple with the other, producing openly that wherewith to give> children suck and reserving in secret that wherewith it holds the> minds of sublime students suspended with admiration. Wherefore it> seems to be, so to speak, a river both shallow and deep, wherein the> little lamb may wade with its feet and the great elephant may swim> with ample space. *Boccaccio's Life of Dante*Metaphor is it seems a common matter of early summer and early autumn.Where clarity is circular, a twinkle in a mothers eye.For in this regard there seems a perfect marriage of east and west.And this is the wind in the north.Yet few seem to comment? Are they elephants or lambs?And how precisely does one find the other elephants?

QiFrom the Neiye, two translation from the guanzi text:Section 1: The essential qi  It is the essence of things that gives life to them. Below, it gives birth to the five grains; above, it is the ranks of stars. Flowing between heaven and earth: we call these ghosts and spirits. Stored within the breast: we call these sages.  This qi isSo bright! As though climbing to heaven. So dark! As though entering the abyss. So broad! As though permeating the sea. So compact! As though residing within oneself.  This qi Cannot be detained through physical force, but may be brought to rest by force of virtue.  It may not be summoned by means of sound, but may be received through oneÕs thoughts.  To guard it alertly without fail, this is called perfect virtue. When virtue is perfected wisdom emerges and all the things of the world are graspedThe Nei-yeh (Inner Cultivation or Inward Training)Anonymous - Mid 4th Century BCETranslated by Harold RothOneThe vital essence of all things: It is this that brings them to life.It generates the five grains belowAnd becomes the constellated stars above.When flowing amid the heavens and the earthWe call it ghostly and numinous.When stored within the chests of human beings,We call them sages.TwoTherefore this vital energy is:Bright! - as if ascending from the heavens;Dark! - as if entering an abyss;Vast! - as if dwelling in an ocean;Lofty! - as if dwelling on a mountain peak.Therefore this vital energyCannot be halted by force,Yet can be secured by inner power [Te].Cannot be summoned by speech,Yet can be welcomed by awareness.Reverently hold onto it and do not lose it:This is called "developing inner power."When inner power develops and wisdom emerges,The myriad things will, to the last one, be grasped. The two translations are provided by scholars who maintain differing perspectives re the origin of this text: The first translation provided is the work of a scholar who maintains that this work resulted the master scholars residing at the Jixia Academy.  The second translation is work of a scholar who feels that the poetic structure suggests that it was a part of an existing oral tradition dating it from a much earlier period.Brief summary concerning the Neiye:A long-overlooked text of classical times, the Neiye ("Inner Cultivation" or "Inner Development") is a text of some 1600 characters, written in rhymed prose, a form close to that of the Daode jing. It sometimes echoes that text and the Zhuangzi, but it lacks many of the concerns found in those works. Generally dated to 350-300 BCE, it is preserved in the Guanzi (ch. 49), along with two later, apparently derivative texts, Xinshu, shang and xia (ch. 36-37). The Neiye had extremely profound effects on Taoism and Chinese culture. It seems to have influenced (1) the form, and certain contents, of the Daode jing; (2) the self-cultivation beliefs and practices of many later Taoists (from the Huainanzi and Taiping jing to the 20th-century); and (3) certain fundamental concepts of traditional Chinese medicine. It may also have influenced Neo-Confucian ideals of self-cultivation, by way of Mencius' teachings on cultivating the heart/mind (xin) and building up qi (Mengzi 2A.2).The Neiye seems to be the earliest extant text that explains and encourages self-cultivation through daily, practiced regulation of the forces of life. Those forces include *qi ("life-energy" the universal force that gives life to all things); and *jing ("vital essence" one's innate reservoir of qi). (There is no trace here of the much later Chinese concept that jing referred to reproductive fluids.) Like Mencius, the Neiye suggests that the xin was originally as it should be, but now needs rectification (zheng). The xin becomes agitated by excessive activity, which leads to dissipation of one's jing, resulting in confusion, sickness, and death. To preserve one's health and vitality, one must quieten (jing) one's xin. Then one can then attract and retain qi, and other vaguely interrelated forces, such as shen ("spirit" or "spiritual consciousness"), and tao (a vague term, apparently interchangeable with shen and ch'i). (Such concepts are explained more intelligibly in passages of the Huainanzi: see Roth 1991)."Hope this info is helpful re your understanding of Qi.A ÒscientificÓ way of understanding qi may be indicated by the first chapter: The vital essence of all things: It is this that brings them to life. It generates the five grains below Ð Ask yourself what is the basic form of cellular respiration? The Krebs cycle.The citric acid cycle Ð also known as the tricarboxylic acid cycle (TCA cycle), or the Krebs cycle,[1][2] Ð is a series of chemical reactions used by all aerobic organisms to generate energy through the oxidation of acetate derived from carbohydrates, fats and proteins into carbon dioxide and chemical energy in the form of adenosine triphosphate (ATP). In addition, the cycle provides precursors of certain amino acids as well as the reducing agent NADH that is used in numerous other biochemical reactions. Its central importance to many biochemical pathways suggests that it was one of the earliest established components of cellular metabolism and may have originated abiogenically.[3]The name of this metabolic pathway is derived from citric acid (a type of tricarboxylic acid) that is consumed and then regenerated by this sequence of reactions to complete the cycle. In addition, the cycle consumes acetate (in the form of acetyl-CoA) and water, reduces NAD+ to NADH, and produces carbon dioxide as a waste byproduct. The NADH generated by the TCA cycle is fed into the oxidative phosphorylation (electron transport) pathway. The net result of these two closely linked pathways is the oxidation of nutrients to produce usable chemical energy in the form of ATP.In eukaryotic cells, the citric acid cycle occurs in the matrix of the mitochondrion. In prokaryotic cells, such as bacteria which lack mitochondria, the TCA reaction sequence is performed in the cytosol with the proton gradient for ATP production being across the cell's surface (plasma membrane) rather than the inner membrane of the mitochondrion.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Citric_acid_cycleThis cycle of energy production is so basic to life on earth that it is common to both plants and animals. Indeed it would be hard to imagine a more subtle energy than the one elaborated as the Krebs cycle and yet more basic to life itself. The danger in looking at qi in this way is that it delimits its form and function and so remains an incomplete elaboration of it.

'Qi is empty and waits on external things.' (Chapter 4, p.228)  Is Zhuangzi perhaps not so much a relativist as a fatalist?'To serve your own mind, so that sorrow and joy aren't constantly revolving in front of you, knowing what you can't do anything about and accepting it as though it were destiny, is the perfection of Virtue.' (p.230)So here he (Kongzi/Zhuangzi) does say 'as though it were destiny', not since it *is* destiny.'So the sage wanders in what exists everywhere and can't be lost.  He likes growing old and he likes dying young.' (p.236)This seems like accepting everything that life throws at you, and not trying to change anything.

In the same Chapter 2, right after that paragraph on beginnings, he writes:"There is nothing in the world bigger than the tip of an autumn hair, and Mount T'ai is tiny. No one has lived longer than a dead child, and P'eng-tsu died young. Heaven and earth were born at the same time I was, and the ten thousand things are one with me." (Burton-Watson's translation)He doesn't seem to be questioning beginnings or ends, I'm not sure he'd be at all interested in the the Big Bang. Relativism makes him quite confident.

column25: Moving meditation is movement that is rhythmic, repetitive, and mindless.Chopping wood and carrying water are classic examples.Running (runner's high, altered state of consciousness) is a classic modern example.Walking, ironing, doing dishes, folding laundry, knitting, juggling, and many other activities can also be meditative activities, which induce mildly altered states of consciousness.
