Hi takh, AnthonyGood point. The most famous critique of Business Schools is J Sterling Livingstone's "The myth of the well-educated manger" which argues that business schools place far to much emphasis on the rational, analytical task of taking the "right" decision, and undervalue the practical task of making the decision you take work (after all, any worthwhile decision will be based on insufficient data or else it is a no brainer). https://hbr.org/1971/01/myth-of-the-well-educated-managerSeason's greetingsGeoffrey

Hi folksYet again a fascinating lecture that I can relate directly to my life experience: I have two sons both, in their very different ways, brilliant. My first son always did well at school (came top in every subject for the last seven years). He played trumpet and violin and was a very fine artist. His art teachers particularly liked his work because through successive sketches and drafts they could see his ideas gradually emerge to become more and more refined. He went on to Oxford got a first in Maths and Philosophy and eventually a PhD in maths, discovering a couple of equations in complexity science significant enough to be named after him. After that he won a top apprenticeship in the Advertising industry, a sort of latter-day Don Draper... and for the first time in his life failed at a self-appointed task.My second son did well, but not so well, at school. He is an artist. His core skill is photography (he picked up a camera at age 5 and never looked back), but also a very good painter and stone carver. However he fell out with his art teachers because they could never see his work develop. He would go into internal search, frustrate them by giving them no intermediate studies to mark, then suddenly  pop out a brilliant completed work at the very last minute. Consequently they forecast him a B grade in A-level art ("for not trying hard enough", sic). The English University Entrance System goes on forecasts not actual grades as the exams are marked too late. So he failed to get into Oxford to read fine arts, even though his eventual grade was an A: he would have had to wait a year for admission. Instead he went to the National Film and Television School, their youngest ever student by years, their first David Lean scholar, and graduated with an MA in cinematography with distinction from the Royal College of the Arts in just two years. And, as we only learnt ten years later, he got the highest marks (99%) ever awarded for A-level art. He has gone on to found an extraordinarily successful Advertising-Agency/Production-Company in the Branded Content arena. In an industry famed for big egos and self-promotion, my second son is extremely self-effacing and quite happy to let his work go unattributed believing it has to speak for itself, the cognoscenti will surely know who produced it. He is superstitious about the roots of his success and hates it when I point them out to him. Basically, as a shooter-director, he is so unobtrusive and so observant that his subjects eventually forget that he is there and he quickly is able to capture those unguarded moments that touch their souls. Here is a tiny example http://jamesmh.net/1447/20981/films/andreas-blank I love the look of devotion of Andreas Blank's dancer.Season's GreetingsGeoffrey

Zhuangzi in taking no stands in right & wrong, this & that. In being not judgmental means you're not emotional involved in these (earthly) human things. You keep your distance. And you will not take action to get involved. Also, what you consider wrong (small knowledge), may be a right seen from an other perspective (big knowledge), or maybe it is a wrong as we see it, but hey - it is the Way it is. And if it's the Way it is, why you question (or resist) the Way, instead of excepting and following the Way (Dao)?But a paradox: Zhuangzi had problems with applying this way of thinking form himself: he is judgmental and got these normative claims.

That is the question: what does Zhuangzi mean with Heaven?If Heaven is an impersonal force for Zhuangzi (as we see in our text), so just a (cosmic?) force, then there is no Theos. Would you not consider him an atheist? But you say "mostly an impersonal force", so there are writings that point out situations where Zhuangzi thinks a Theos is involved? Where in the Zhuangzi can we find this?
So again I ask, what's the self-publicity element in appearing for five minutes on this MOOC reading someone else's work? I just don't see it.
Thanks, Robin!M

Not sure if it is relevant but I seem to recall that it turned out that the Castaneda books were pure fiction. But maybe we should judge the message even if the source is not what it purports to be.This seems in keeping with the questionable nature of Margaret Meads suggestions about the nature of polynesia life, Roots as an authentic account of the history of a slave family and in recent years there was a book purporting to tell the story of a survivor of a concentration camp whose contents were fictitious.Maybe since we cannot pinpoint the exact authors of Laozi and Zhuangzi we should be as sceptical about them as the above ?????

I guess the obvious question here is how Chinese philosophy develops after the Warring States? I know roughly that Buddhism influenced Chinese philosophy a lot and rulers often alternated between endorsing Buddhism, Confucianism, Taoism or a combination of the three. And there is a big Neo-Confucianist movement in the Song Dynasty.However apart from the new philosophical concepts from Buddhism (impermanence/illusion, reincarnation and karma), I don't feel like I spotted any significantly novel philosophical concepts in later Chinese philosophy? Neo-Confucianism doesn't seem all that different from the Confucianism presented in this course. It seems there were lots of political, economic and technological innovations, but from the point of view of philosophy, I don't see it? Or maybe I'm just too lazy to see it...

The lack of interest among Warring States philosophers in the afterlife is fascinating. At the same time Confucius and some of his successors often refer to their ancestors. It would seem that to them, as to generations of Chinese thereafter, the afterlife of ancestors is remarkably similar to ordinary life, but none of the philosophers speculate about what happens when we die. Is this just like Homer's Hades, just generally accepted as existing with nobody much questioning it, or are there examples of speculation by Warring States' philosophers I'm missing?

I want to share some insight into my personal understanding of 'xin' and 'qi' in order to clarify these concepts in our discussions as we see these ideas further applied and refined through the Warring States.  I am also curious what Professor Slingerland thinks of my ideas with respect to both the classical materials we are studying, and current definitions of these concepts.I am trained as a Chinese medical practitioner in the United States and as such have both Eastern training and Western training.  These ideas come up often in our education, and are familiar to anyone who studies the classical Chinese medical texts, which interestingly enough, come out of the Warring States period.  The question Òwhat is qi?Ó is commonly asked throughout the medical education process as well as by patients in the medical office who wish to understand this concept in the context of their treatments, specifically acupuncture and medical diagnosis.  Practitioners and students of Chinese medicine, in the United States at least, often come up with explanations or definitions of ÔqiÕ which may or may not be accurate, helpful, or appropriate. In the words of Xunzi, ÒLearning must never stop,Ó which is why I want to share what I have learned over the years of my studyI want to start by sharing my insight into 'qi' as it may help others more easily understand integrate this sometimes enigmatic and amorphous word/concept in the context of human neurophysiology and mind-body connections related to this course.  I want to preface this by saying that this is only an explanation of qi in the context of neuropsychology and physiology.  I understand and appreciate that qi is a broad term that has far wider definitions and applications.One helpful explanation and illustration of 'qi' is the simple pointing the amazing yet easily neglected fact that our body is constantly ÔdoingÕ things with or without our conscious effort.  This is ÔqiÕ in a general sense Ð observed activity with apparent intelligent patterns.  You want to experience your ÔqiÕ?  Just consciously move your arm, or open and close your eyes.  This is ÔqiÕ.  Want to experience ÔqiÕ that you are not directly controlling Ð close your eyes and feel your heart beating, your blood circulating.  This is also ÔqiÕ.While this may seem overly simplistic, I believe it illustrates how universal the concept of ÔqiÕ is and also explains why it is so easy to misconstrue it for something magical or beyond normal human understanding.  It also explains why the Chinese related it to concepts such as water, air/wind, cosmic energy, ghosts, steam, vapor, and the like.Another way to understand ÔqiÕ, particularly in a neurophysiological sense, is to think of ÔqiÕ as information.  Take cellular and wireless technology as a metaphor to illustrate that information is transmitted that cannot be seen, but can be measured/sensed and which triggers changes on either end of the pathway/channel/nerve.ÔQiÕ is, in a most general sense, the information and interaction of information-systems.  Whether it is a mechanical system, a biological system, or an electrical system, information is being transmitted, which can affect change or other information to respond.  In medicine, we apply techniques (acupuncture, massage, pharmacology) to the body Ð we intentionally apply information to generate a response from the body, which we measure by the bodyÕs response, based on our ability to notice changes in the body (e.g. pulses, skin response, pain reduction, etc.).When Xunzi talks of Òcontrolling the qiÓ Ð he is speaking of consciously applying the heart/mind (xin) to affect change within the emotional system of our body.  Xunzi also describes the xin as, ÒThe heart dwells in the central cavity so as to control the five facultiesÑ this is called oneÕs ÒHeavenly ruler.Ó (Xunzi Ch17).  Xunzi, uses similar descriptions of the mind as the central leader of other aspects of mental processes as governed by the organ systems.  This brings us to the discussion of ÔxinÕ and its definition in the context of Chinese medicine.Xin has been translated in our course text as ÔheartÕ but this same character, we Prof. Slingerland mentioned earlier in the course, also can be translated as ÔmindÕ.  This definition points to the classical Chinese understanding that the mind and body are interrelated and as such aspects of mental processes are associated with physical organs and physiological processes and systems.  For Xunzi and surely some of his medical contemporaries, the mind was ÔseatedÕ in the heart and played part in the physiological process of blood circulation, cognitive control, memory and conscious experience.  For Xunzi, the heart was the guiding, leading aspect of human mental processes, both conscious and unconscious.  This idea continues into current day Chinese medical theory and understanding of the body which looks at the mind-body as an integrated functional overlay of systems with distinct and interrelating information and processes.Without totally going off an complete tangent, I find this very intriguing and hope I have given some insight into these concepts that contribute to our discussions.  I am primarily curious about my shared explanation of qi in the context of neuropsychology as well as philosophically.  I will leave it at that.
Any idea when the second wave of lectures will be released.

Take cellular and wireless technology as a metaphor to illustrate that information is transmitted that cannot be seen, but can be measured/sensed and which triggers changes on either end of the pathway/channel/nerve.ÔQiÕ is, in a most general sense, the information and interaction of information-systems.  Whether it is a mechanical system, a biological system, or an electrical system, information is being transmitted, which can affect change or other information to respond.  In medicine, we apply techniques (acupuncture, massage, pharmacology) to the body Ð we intentionally apply information to generate a response from the body, which we measure by the bodyÕs response, based on our ability to notice changes in the body (e.g. pulses, skin response, pain reduction, etc.).When Xunzi talks of Òcontrolling the qiÓ Ð he is speaking of consciously applying the heart/mind (xin) to affect change within the emotional system of our body.  Xunzi also describes the xin as, ÒThe heart dwells in the central cavity so as to control the five facultiesÑ this is called oneÕs ÒHeavenly ruler.Ó (Xunzi Ch17).  Xunzi, uses similar descriptions of the mind as the central leader of other aspects of mental processes as governed by the organ systems.  This brings us to the discussion of ÔxinÕ and its definition in the context of Chinese medicine.Xin has been translated in our course text as ÔheartÕ but this same character, we Prof. Slingerland mentioned earlier in the course, also can be translated as ÔmindÕ.  This definition points to the classical Chinese understanding that the mind and body are interrelated and as such aspects of mental processes are associated with physical organs and physiological processes and systems.  For Xunzi and surely some of his medical contemporaries, the mind was ÔseatedÕ in the heart and played part in the physiological process of blood circulation, cognitive control, memory and conscious experience.  For Xunzi, the heart was the guiding, leading aspect of human mental processes, both conscious and unconscious.  This idea continues into current day Chinese medical theory and understanding of the body which looks at the mind-body as an integrated functional overlay of systems with distinct and interrelating information and processes.Without totally going off an complete tangent, I find this very intriguing and hope I have given some insight into these concepts that contribute to our discussions.  I am primarily curious about my shared explanation of qi in the context of neuropsychology as well as philosophically.  I will leave it at that.
column35: Xin guiding the Qi - The mind-body connection.

column25: I found it interesting that Prof. Slingerland ended 7.6 discussing qi and how it is a progressing concept that can be adapted to our experience but retains some sort of cultural memory.It is particularly fascinating to me to observe the development of the concept of qi and it's functioning as a source domain that evolves as we develop culturally.  It is an idea that has an evolutionary history that is shaped by our culture and also shapes our culture as it moves through human experience and cultural evolution.With this in mind, I continue to look to idea that qi is 'information' or 'data' in the sense that it is the interaction of systems which we observe through our senses.  In a self-referential sort of way, we can watch the concept of 'qi, as meme or idea, move through culture, like a vaporous non-substance, and find usefulness or application in various areas of culture, whether it be medicine, martial arts, dance, cooking, fine art, neurology, electricity, spirituality, etc.What I find useful and relevant about qi is that it a modular concept that explains the general way in which information moves in both physical and abstract ways.

If Xunzi believe that humans are born like a computer without software, and we can download some program (thru education) that becomes our mind, then who is to decide how the program is written? Who is to decide "You shall never hurt human"?

There seems to be quite a range of similarities with the Greek writers. Aristotle seems to "discover" a number of concepts that were already well versed in China.What is more, is that metaphors in Chinese and Greek writing are often very similar. This must lead one to consider that the esoteric aspect of the Greek, incorporated Chinese systems. Thus perhaps there is a lot more to the marriage of east and west than we read in Homer, or that esoterically it is what we read in Homer?Yet in academic circles some go to great lengths to deny such. Whilst others such as Puett, Harvard, advocates a need to dig deeper, and discount a range of established thoughts.> Plutarch claims that the second, less popular category of AristotleÕs> writings concerns:> > *the secret [aporrata, not to be spoken] and deeper things, which men> call by the special term acroamatic and epoptic and do not expose for> the many to share*. Ð Plutarch, Alexander 7.3Ð5, in Lives (unpublished> translation by Jenny Strauss Clay)> > He continues that when Alexander the Great, AristotleÕs former pupil,> heard that his teacher had decided to publish some of the acroamatic> discourses, he wrote to him in protest. Aristotle then replied in the> following letter, which is featured in AndronicusÕ edition of his> writings, and which Plutarch carefully describes and Gellius quotes in> full:   *Aristotle to King Alexander, prosperity. You have written me> about the acroatic discourses, thinking that they should be guarded in> secrecy. Know, then, that they have been both published and not> published.* For they are intelligible only to those who have heard us.> Ð Gellius, Attic Nights 20.5.12., translated by Lorraine Pangle in> Aristotle and the Philosophy of Friendship, 9.> > While the authenticity of this letter is questionable, it may still> present an informed account of the character of AristotleÕs writings.> What we do know is that a thinker and historian of the stature of> Plutarch finds the content of the letter accurate in light of his own> personal reading of Aristotle. For, as he goes on to explain:> > *To say the truth, his books on metaphysics are written in a style> which makes them useless for ordinary teaching, and instructive only,> in the way of memoranda, for those who have been already conversant in> that sort of learning.* Ð Plutarch, Alexander 7.3Ð5 in Lives. All> sourced from Prof. Melzer's [Michigan] Esoteric Appendix.In some Greek esoteric writing, then in Latin, then in for example Dante, they are clearly using Chinese Bagua [Trigram] metaphors, which produce a double meaning.You make reference to Dante in the video:> *the text and the mystery that lies beneath it. Thus, it simultaneously> challenges the intellect of the wise while it gives comfort to the> minds of the simple. It possesses openly something to give children> nourishment and yet reserves in secret something to hold with> fascinated admiration the minds of the deepest meditators. Therefore,> it is like a river, so to speak, both shallow and deep, in which the> little lamb may wade with its feet and the great elephant may swim> freely.Giovanni Boccaccio, Life of Dante*Melzer in his recent books cites an intentional error by Machiavelli, to alert the informed reader to esoteric aspects of his work. Such is the nature of "errors".The practical reality being that ancient Chinese knowledge has been a method of esoteric discourse in the west from ancient times.The question then being once one understands such, and can read it in part, how does one develop it, and communicate about such with others that understand the matter? How does one put such understanding to good use in productive, practical application?> >

Presumably he'd think that the machine had to have an operating system programmed into its hardware, and that system would be the accumulated culture surrounding the new-born child. Specifically he'd no doubt answer that he himself, following Confucius, should be the one to write it.Dawkins also has the concept of the meme, the self-replicating cultural idea which functions a bit like a gene, but in the cultural sphere. Presumably the meme for not hurting humans is a pretty persistent one.

The modern "scientific" consensus would be that culture is a crucially important determinant of behavior.  See today's NYT on "rice vs. wheat farmers"--which goes beyond the treatment of "rice farmers" in an earlier segment of ChinaX, but is consistent with it.  These differences haven't had time to get into the genome--supposedly.  (But note that "science" gives other examples where, epigenetically or otherwise, inherited behavior patterns can be changed profoundly in only 15-20 generations.)Apes favor cooperation.  Apes resent "unfair" behavior by a fellow ape.  I'm not aware of studies showing differences in "ape cultures"--probably because "we" haven't yet conceded that apes could have a "culture."So, was there a base level of antecedent "German culture" that was favorable to Nazism?  That will be argued for a long time to come--and might even eventually be resolved by science.

Xunzi's belief that we have in us the propensity to do bad things simply because they're there seems to have a real echo in modern life.  My guess is that virtually every American once stole something from a drugstore just to say s/he had done it, or to get something s/he wanted but couldn't buy.  I certainly did, and I experienced that little thrill of having done something bad and gotten away with it.  (The thrill wasn't large enough to overcome the huge anxiety that accompanied the deed, so I never did it again.  Aversion therapy, anyone?)  We have even coined new words to describe this tendency in human beings.  Sociopath, for instance.  So it seems modern culture adopts Xunzi's view as a correct one.

And badness doesn't even need to be illegal. Sometimes I just drop a plastic bottle into the general rubbish rather than the recycling just to prove to myself I can take individualistic transgressive decisions. Sociopath or saddo? I usually end up retrieving them so it probably shows Xunzi is right.
Thanks.

Confucius said when he's 70 he can do whatever he wants without crossing the boundary of propriety, by following ritules, is Xunzi offering any more efficient route, i.e. by being careful in redefining the hypothesis of mind and w/ more convincing arguments?What's the modern sciences/philosophies' take on the program-ability of mind? if we figure out how the mind can be programmed and re-programmed, what's the end goal of such program? The day when the connectome in our brain is fully mapped out, and we realized all parts of it can be reconfigured much faster thru download than relying on culture evolution which takes eons, will we all behave like borg in StarTrek in order to maximize our aggregate benefit and get rid of free will?

During the discussion on Xunzi's cultural evolution, I was reminded of Edmund Burke's political philosophy. Speaking out against the French Revolution, Burke condemned the wholesale overthrow of any government because political and cultural institutions are the culmination of generations of collected wisdom; rather he advocated for incremental change building on top of past traditions. Xunzi's account of how the sage kings created ritual, as well as actual anthropological findings, seem to correlate with Burke's vision of incremental institutions.

Today while plastering my ceiling I had a sudden insight: Xunzi would like Butcher Ding.  Butcher Ding is born bad: he doesn't mind killing things.  But his training in butchering puts an overlay over that badness, and it becomes good insofar as it is done with his spirit.  He can achieve wu wei despite himself.

You make a good point, but sometimes I think there is more to the "bad" the acts committed by young people; sometimes the primary motive seems to be not doing something bad for badness sake, but doing something to act out the strong urge to show independence - you can't tell me what to do--I'll do something else. I think this is one reason younger people are so attracted to libertarianism. Also, I think the sociopath label is a lot more serious than just doing bad things--it seems to stem from an inability to empathize with others so that the "bad" actions are essentially uncontrollable.

It is an interesting question. It asks whether and how Xunzi's strategy of self-cultivation can deal away with the hunter/forager tendency in contemporary sexual relations. It depends on the contents of Xunzian rituals. If the ritual is about sexual relations and forbids promiscuity, then by practicing it, people can reshape their desire into something new that belittles promiscuity. So it depends on what the contents of ritual are in the Xunzian sense.

It strikes me that Xunzi believes that we can all be socialised, ie we can all learn the rites and rituals. Once learned and applied, preferably through hot responses, a spontaneous knowing of the right thing to do, we are totally responsible for our fates. We now know what to do and how to live in our world and whatever happens is not due to the influence of any other being. Following the right rituals seems to be a fairly common necessity in any culture to survive well within it. Xunzi applies it to the cosmos rather than just locally. That suggests that local truths become the absolute truths and that there is no bigger picture in his perspective that would allow tolerance of opposing views, say other cultures or peoples whose rituals differed.
All is well now. Thanks!

i'm bit confused about morality after all the internalization vs. externalization debate: is the reason we have such debate because morality is easy, and there are many ways to get there? or morality is hard, and we haven't gotten there yet, therefore are still debating?Did we commingle many different qualities (like state craft) into morality? i mean if you take out the part about God in the 10 Commandments, there're only 6 left, i.e. i have friends and coworkers who are atheists + libertarians, i.e. they would never write a check to charities, or help others at their own expenses, yet they are perfectly moral in the sense that they don't steal, don't kill, do their work and abide by law, etc... Such qualities seem so trivial that the debating internal vs. external seem like debating different ways to, say, toast a piece of perfect bread.However, when it comes to sacrificing oneself to save strangers, or writing checks to the poor when we ourselves are in need, are these 'noble' qualities the morality that Mencius/Xunzi were debating? outside of individual qualities, it seems the Invisible Hand or culture evolution theories could easily take care of why we cooperate.

The Huainanzi also has a few chapters on Chinese astrology and numerology, for those who are interested in such things.There is [a great translation][1] available relatively recently.  [1]: http://www.amazon.com/The-Huainanzi-Practice-Government-Translations-ebook/dp/B007H9GTYI

Dear Professor Slingerland,I very much appreciated the course as I am very interested in philosophy in general and I took the course to get a perspective different from but also in part overlapping with Western philosophy (Artistotele, Kant, etc.). Also the point that you were making about the broader concept of religion (in the Introduction) and that it is not equivalent to believing in God but having a certain worldview and a corresponding value system made me think a lot. Thanks for that.But I do NOT agree with your point of view in 7.10. when it comes to moral relativism and (provided I have understood you correctly) that one cannot objectively gauge whether one or another worldview is superior. Your made reference to the Afghan village elder and his view of women's/girl's rights. That view is pathetic and despicable and the reason is that it causes other people (in this example human beings who by accident of birth happen to not have a Y chromosome) harm (physical or otherwise) for no reason and makes him superior (for being male). How pathetic. If I, as a WEIRD white male would say to him that he has less (human) rights because I am white and he is not that would be equally pathetic. I also DO think that humanity in general has made significant progress over the last centuries in terms of becoming more humane, e.g. you made reference to Steven Pinker who describes how the death penalty some hundred years ago was applied for even minor transgressions, after some time "only" for capital crimes and by now has been abolished in many countries.The general rule to compare different worldviews and their corresponding (mis)values to me is whether unnecessarily harm is inflicted on another person. And from that angle the Afghan elder is simply pathetic for upholding repression of women's rights.

Maybe it isn't a case of abandoning the desire for one's neighbor's wife; maybe it's a case of abandoning the desire to realize that desire.  And where are women in this?  Do they too desire their neighbor's wife?  If so, why haven't I heard of this?

Of course the same thing is true of much western science, e.g. the gradual abandonment across the world of small-scale family farming of local foods in favour of the adoption of industrial agriculture dependent on fossil fuels, herbicides, pesticides, cash crops from imported seeds and centralised marketing systems.

And not just American politics (by which I assume you mean US politics). In Australia we currently have a political party in power that is particularly fond of stretching the meaning of words to absurd lengths, e.g. talking about the Age of Entitlement being over (I think they got the phrase from the US) but applying it only to the poor and the lower middle-class. The entitlements of the wealthy, e.g. to accumulate as much wealth and pay as little in taxes as they want, are still very much in place.

**The Sky Doesn't Care**The sky doesn't care who wins elections/or which flowers grow in my garden,/ or about Nigerians dying by savagery./ The sky doesn't care how many/ Somalians starve to death, or/how many Shiite Muslims die for freedom./But I am not the sky.  I care about war-ravaged Afghans/dehydrated Chinese peasants/ rotting corpses in Burma./  I care about melting glaciers/ about vanishing polar bears/about seal pup blood in the snow/about the gutted mouse on the hermitage trail,/ about each mite that feeds on my eyelashes. I care because I know that big mind/ lies nestled in the palm of small mind.

Hi Geoffrey. I must have missed your earlier post. Thank you so much for introducing me to Tom Malone, and through linking to various other websites etc. I love the idea of social intelligence as the key to collective intelligence, and, as opposed to Xunzian thought, I see social intelligence as part of human nature, or at least as a Mencian 'sprout'. This is because it is what we have evolved with, prompted by the disproportionate size of the human brain that makes us born so uniquely dependent on others for such a long time.I also love T J Dawe's warning that the internet allows collective stupidity to emerge as well - because of the tendency towards dualistic thinking among people commenting on posts etc.All in all you've helped me to clarify quite a lot of my thoughts.Very kind regards back,Liz

Completely agree, too! This has been the best MOOC I've participated in, and although I haven't posted as many comments and thoughts as I would have liked to, I've learned so much over the past few weeks. I definitely plan to further my study in the areas that have been introduced. Thank you!!

Thank you! This is one of the most amazing classes on edx and i can't help but imagine if 1.3b chinese were able to access these classic values unimpeded by their government, what china would become, i'm (literally) praying that day will come (sorry can't help it, i'm a christian).

While Xunzi's model of learning is pretty plausible, particularly for skills that one may not have a natural affinity or preference for, it faces the usual theodicy problem: how did the first teacher learn the tricks of the trade if there was no one else around to teach? Did that teacher just accidentally stumble upon the Way, similar to how fire may have been harnessed accidentally in the beginning?Of course, you only need to discover the Way once and then you can establish transmission through teaching, but how was the Way originally discovered? Or did the Confucians regard this as an unimportant question, because they were more concerned with the contemporary problem of establishing the Way in chaotic times?

I have enjoyed the course, finding it challenging and enlightening. It has been good to get a clear explanation of the different schools of thought. My interest was in the Dao in particular. I feel I have a much more informed appreciation of that work. I was fascinated by the links to modern empirical evidence along the way. There is certainly much to be admired in these philosophies.

This is the subject of meta-ethics, how you decide what your guiding ethical principles should be (rather than moral psychology, which is about how people reason about ethics). Xunzi thinks the "software" is the Confucian Way, cobbled together by wise sages over a long period of time.

Xunzi believes that we can genuinely and completely replace our "tribal" desires with our new, cultivated, proper desires. This may be overly optimistic, but it seems an accurate description of his views.

This is one of the central tensions in Xunzi's thought, as I argue. His picture seems to be that these genius sages kind of stumbled on pieces of the Way through trials and error, and accumulated them until this body of knowledge eventually became the perfect Confucian Way. Now it's so complex that no one individual could ever reproduce the steps on their own, and so we need teachers. But you still have the problem of how, if our nature is bad, these original "teachers" were ever motivated to come up with something different.
I completely agree. One of the best MOOC I have ever taken. Thanks a lot! I hope there will be other courses from Prof. Slingerland in the future. I have become a fan!

According to Pinker women are looking to settle on a reliable provider who will support mother and child, while at the same time women are keeping their eyes open to extract the genes from any more alpha male who may appear. I'm sure I traduce his argument, but he is seeking to confront feminist ideas. He spends a lot longer explaining male promiscuity than female behaviour.

Hi Geoffrey,Interesting! There are some important implications if Wu-Wei really is an emergent property of compl city dynamics. That means that a state of Wu-Wei, though normally understood as a personal experience, cannot be obtained by an individual in isolation but must arise through a social setting. Also, that may mean that entire groups can be in a state of Wu-Wei too (though it boggles my mind what that may actually look like in real life!). As a sociologist, this viewpoint is very attractive! Thanks for making the connection.

i think it is the faith/ motivation that leads us where we are, even for Confucius. it will propel us to learn (classics/ odes/ etc.) to become a real ren. and yes, i agree that if we are too critical of ourselves; the Goodness may be reduced because of to much trying. we will then be harsh on others too.

Hi folksAnother thoughtful lecture. "Truth" doesn't lie in dogma or scepticism but the tension between the two (Ioan Tenner's fun "critical thinking is disobedient, not correct" http://wisdom.tenner.org/critical-thinking-is-disobedient-not-correct.html ).So, to become more moral, do we have to improve the quality of the discourse? Think Habermas's Discourse Ethics, maybe: strive to make our conversations more articulate, more symmetrical and more authentic? Or would that only make us more correct?Will the Internet raise its ugly head? Our contemporary, sovereign-tool for discourse management: for shaping who talks to whom, what they talk, about, how they talk about it, who else knows, and why they should even be talking to each other at all.I saw "emergent" creep by :-)Why so few comments? Too rich?Kind regardsGeoffrey
column35: Critical thinking is disobedient, not correct

column25: Dear Prof Slingerland"I point this out because it's one of the interesting ways in which these Guodian texts are changing the way we think about and understand the received texts. And also just because it's kind of cool. Maybe I'm kind of dorky. I think this stuff is neat." Lecture 7.2It is neat. So if you apologise then you come over as disingenuous."Be what you is not, what you ain't. 'Cause if you is what you ain't then you ain't what you is." And all that.You are an academic and proud.If you really must have something to apologise for, then apologise for presenting "Trying Not to Try" as a self-help book. It doesn't belong in that schlocky company. If you lie down with dogs you get up with fleas. What fleas? Well, your neuroscience starts to sound like Molly Crockett's neurobollocks for a start. Your greedy publishers led you badly astray there. Ironically, the mistake lies in trying too hard to make complicated things simple.Fortunately, this MOOC fits you like a glove.  Now a joint course with Hebrew University's Ivan Segev that would be something indeed ( https://www.coursera.org/course/bluebrain )."Constructive criticism between friends is the sincerest kindness", "I only tell my enemies what they want to hear... that way they never improve", and so on. So make no mistake, I really, really appreciate your course. And very special thanks to the China 300x Team for the images and clips, too.Kind regardsGeoffrey

Your standard about unnecessary harm is not objective in logic. I'd go with it as a good principle in general (though it would rule out most military action so no state would), but we are better able to affect or mitigate the Afghan elder's attitudes if we understand their cultural background and don't insultingly assert our superiority before we begin. He might even have attributes we could learn from. Or would you prefer we just shoot him in accordance with the prevailing historical cultural norm of Europeans/westerners relating to Afghans?

You complain that no-one is commenting on your posts, so in the context of your reproof to Professor Slingerland for in effect 'dumbing down', I offer my reasons for reticence. I did the course out of an interest in China primarily, and my background is basically literary, with an interest in politics and current affairs. I have never heard of Ioan Tenner, and though I have a hazy notion of Habermas, your reference to his Discourse Ethics as if that were sufficient explanation for me to get your meaning is off-putting. I could research it but I have no way of guessing whether that would be worth my time. I haven't a clue what your penultimate sentence refers to. Plainly you know a lot more than I do in this area and I have nothing to offer without a much less elliptical explanation of your points. Meanwhile I'm much more likely to be pursuing Professor Slingerland's recommendations. I found his self-deprecatory reference to his 'dorkishness' engaging and I didn't for a moment think he was disrespecting his subject, but what he was talking about was arcane, as I'm sure everyone signing up for the course would have expected aspects of it would be. You're not beyond a joky tone yourself.No offence meant - I just think your posts assume a body of knowledge or experience many of us won't have and don't have the time to pursue.
Me too! Whereas we all know it's more complex than that. I think the idea of cultural accumulation is rather a breakthrough though.

By no means did I even allude to shooting the Afghan elder so I would appreciate it if you did not insinuate that. And the principle I brought up to not cause unnecessary harm DOES also hold up in military action provided it is of DEFENSIVE nature. In this case of course you could raise the question about preemptive strikes but as the current hegemon shows time and again this is just a bold faced lie to further geopolitical interests (I am drifting off - but from the last sentence you can at least deduce that I am anything but West = superior in all aspects of life , all others = inferior).I am always open to learn from whoever and it could very well be that the Afghan misogynist has an attitude towards something that I would share.But in general, extremists of all kinds (be their pseudo line of reasoning any religion, socialism, Nazism, you name them) are pretty repulsive to me and I cannot see why I would have to try hard to find the way he is coming from to justify any barbaric attitude and practice. This moral relativism becomes most ironic when it is brought forward by agnostics/atheists, women, gay and other "lower" forms of life (NOT MY POV!) in the comfort of their armchair in a setting which not only does not hold their "attitude" against them but considers them of equal worth deserving the same rights. I tip my hat to those moral relativists who put their money where their mouth is and spend some time over there and see whether upon return it really did make a difference to hear the inherently nonsensical "reasoning" why women, atheists, Jews, etc. are inferior.

Sorry to have enraged you further: I wasn't intending to 'insinuate' anything about you, merely pointing to the sort of interaction Afghans must have come to expect from outsiders.I would argue that since bombing of civilians began, there has been no war where 'necessary' harm has been done to civilians. Nations just prefer to safeguard their own soldiers rather than send them into close combat.I think Professor Slingerland selected the caricature Afghan child-murderer as a topical example in the current mood of anti-Muslim hysteria. I think there are very few people in the world who would wish to justify such a practice. Of course such things do happen and like you I find them appalling, but if we know the social basis they spring from, perhaps we can mobilise to get a more humane system.Meanwhile I shall return to my armchair.

Strict laws, strictly and impartially implemented; we could do with Feizi in Brazil.He is surely right too, about mindless worship of past glories and past solutions.On historical investigation the past glories are likely to dissolve, as least as glories. Then too, as the wonderful story of the rabbit illustrates, past solutions may not be applicable to new problems.

Thank you, Professor Slingerland and staff. After each lecture, I thought, this just can't get better. Too bad other obligations made forum posting impossible.This was a feast of knowledge, insight, wit, and unexpected turns. Ancient Chinese Philosophers, brought into the here and now, modern cognitive science and linguistics brought into the there and then. Sparks fly! And while the Charles Taylor moment at the start of the course was strong, 7.10 climaxed in a phenomenal manner. Infuriating, scary, deeply perceptive. The footage of enlightened atheist Professors getting religiously defensive was even funnier than Russel Brand. In a way, Professor Slingerland, your thinking seems a logical consequence of that now mainstream generation of thinkers - asking questions that unsettle questions that have settled into rigid, self-righteous answers.Thank you, thank you, thank you. One day I hope to be able to come to Vancouver to listen to you in person, and maybe ask questions, too. Your students, whether there, or around the rest of the globe, are lucky to benefit from your insight, learning, generosity, and kindness.
column35: Who said it couldn't get better?

column25: Actually, the so-called anti-theodicy problem doesn't seem so serious to me. Although in the beginning human nature may be bad on average and the average person may revel in chaos, you could imagine that natural variability among the population would eventually produce individuals who would "abberantly" regard chaos as disgusting. These outliers could have then developed institutions and cultural practices to bring order to their communities. Thus ordered, those communities would have secured collective abilities that conferred competitive advantages on them against other communities. Other communities would then be forced to adopt similar cultural practices and institutions to keep up. Thus, these cultural practices only need to be invented once and then the world would not be the same afterwards. This is in some way similar to how the linguistic and physiological turns forever changed Chinese philosophy after they were invented.
column35: A Simple Solution to the Anit-Theodicy Problem?

Undeclared Religion?Dr Slingerland, thank you for the stimulating course. You did not explicitly declare your own religion -( science )- but in your lectures, scientific observation provides implicit validation for other beliefs. Scientific observation validates taboos; prefrontal neurology legitimates religious/philosophical attempts to exert rational control over emotional reflexes. You may not think of science as a religion, but consider this:If you believe that matter/energy cannot be created or destroyed and that entropy must always increase, if you believe that the only truths are those observations that can be integrated with the fundamental precepts of thermodynamics, if you believe rigorously in these truths alone, you will be vested with amazing and terrible powers Ðyou will be able to build iPhones, magnetic resonance imaging cameras and atom bombs. I recall a visiting Chinese scholar at the Woods Hole laboratory (MBL) circa 1975 explaining the Needham Question. His premise was that science could not have arisen in the East. ÒEastern religion/philosophy is polytheistic and eclectic,Ó he said, Òall phenomena are recognized, recorded and classified. Western science is a child of monotheistic religions; nothing is admitted that falls outside the dogma.Ó
Chicken soup for a cold, honey for a sore throat, alcohol for all else. What more can I say.

When thinking about the 'perennial debate', I have to confess that I caught myself tending to think along the following lines.Whereas *I myself*, and others who think like me of course, fit the Mencian model Ð I can look at a situation and make a moral judgement; my internal intuitions trump external standards, which I know have often been 'wrong' in the past and may still be so Ð *others*, whether due to a different upbringing/culture/religion etc. fit the Xunzian model, since they *cannot* be relied on to make correct moral judgements.  They, therefore, should *not* be left to rely on their moral resources, their internal intuitions, but rather need a moral code to be imposed; which should naturally be as close as possible to my own!

To anon,Regarding moral relativism, I think it's important to realize that it is on the one hand possible to be a descriptive moral relativist, and on the other hand still uphold modern western liberal values. I think it's possible to realize that such values are ultimately founded on a particular type of faith, and yet still adhere and promote those values anyway based on that very same faith. This insistence that *our* moral values are rooted in objective universal truths and others are not isn't really a necessary step for holding onto what we believe, and in fact the insistence on rationalism as a necessary component of morality is itself a moral value borne of the enlightenment tradition. *Prescriptive* moral relativism, the claim that *no* moral claims are superior to others because they're all ultimately faith based, and that therefore we shouldn't judge or that we should just leave other countries alone to practice whatever they care to, is itself a moral stance. We can oppose prescriptive moral relativism and non-interventionalism and still keep our beliefs internally consistent if we make explicit our *faith* commitment to metaphysical beliefs in gender equality, the dignity of individuals, and the affirmation of ordinary life.On more pragmatic terms, rationalist arguments for one's own values that bottom out at "well mine are self evidently rational and yours are just pathetic" can be a satisfying form of self affirmation, but tend not to be very persuasive for people who don't share your values. Sam Harris showing pictures of women in burkas and insisting that there just has to be something objectively wrong with people who promote that is not going to convince wahhabists any more than a fundamentalist cleric swearing up and down that female university students wearing shirts and jeans just has to be objectively wrong is ever going to convince western liberals. Yet if all morality is ultimately founded on faith, then at some level of rationalist debate such arguments for self-evidentness become unavoidable. So again pragmatically, if you're on the ground in Afghanistan and you want the local populace to support your vision of western liberal morality and not be constantly at your throat because they think you've brought about hell on earth, then avoiding the pitfalls of rationalist rhetoric and reaching out to actually change the minds of people like that "pathetic" village elder become a life or death matter of foreign policy.  It's here that acknowledging the relative nature of morality, studying how it forms historically and culturally in similar and different ways, what it's grounded in structurally, how it's enacted and embraced, how people are, and are not, converted and persuaded to new points of view, what does and doesn't work in moral instruction, and how people can extend their moral imagination into new directions and come to value what they didn't previously, can directly benefit high stakes foreign policy and save lives. For a powerful and I believe tragic depiction of how such invaluable research can be carried out, but also tends to get ignored by policy makers who favor of the kind of self evident gut reaction you espoused, I recommend Scott Atran's excellent *Talking to the Enemy: Religion, Brotherhood, and the (Un)Making of Terrorists*. His work on how selectively catering to sacred values, as opposed to focusing on rational self interest, actually opens up dialogue between bitterly ideologically opposed groups is really eye opening.

I think you read too much into the Professor's argument. What I understood is that the village elder and the WEIRD liberal both believe they're right, but have no "rational" argument, only their respective faith into their normative framework. The village elder is not condoning honor killings because he's evil, but because he has faith into a normative framework (which each of us think evil, I'm sure) that tells him they're right.This """moral relativist""" view has at least an advantage, it gives back some humanity to that village elder, and thus, some hope of... rehabilitation? Mind-opening? I wonder what he thinks now that he sees happier people around him, maybe he changed his mind?

Could it be that the differences we see between different cultures emerge from our familiarity with human cultures and a Martian or other extraterrestrial would be likely to see all our cultures as pretty much the same. The same concern comes up in the search for extraterrestrial life-would we be able to recognize it as life if we stumbled across it? Its just that we see everything from through our own tunnel view (Plato's cave and the shadows on the cave wall) until we learn how to see something we couldn't see before. Not to say we should not keep trying, but should be aware that every search or journey still ends with a question mark (John Cleese).  This reminds me of the presentation on cumulative cultural evolution--its so easy not to see the relevant aspects of something.

Thank you very much for this post fyang3. I agree with you, and of course Professor Slingerland, that recognising the importance of our emotional response in what we may think is a rational decision is the only basis for conducting a cross-cultural dialogue, especially in view of recent neurological evidence that a 'thought' shows up in brain activity before we give it words. There is also this insight from Spanish writer/philosopher, Miguel Unamuno (1864 Ð 1936): > ÔYour neighbourÕs vision is as true for him [or her] as your own> vision is for you.'Now that our 'neighbours' include people from very different cultures, we are foolish if we ignore these words and their corollary: 'What you see as superior moral decisions are related to beliefs accumulated over time in your culture in the same way as are your neighbour's'.

As a reader of the early 19th century sociologists such as Durkheim and Weber, I find Han Feizi's institutional model of organizing society very plausible. In the context of the 19th century sociologists, they were studying how society could continue to stay cohesive and functional even though the old fundamentals of clan and religious solidarity were being undermined by the new social ties and economic forces of industrialization. They focused on bureaucracy as the only organizational form capable of handling the emerging complexity of large scale urban industrial societies - an insight that Han Feizi seemed to grasp in ancient China.Of course, even today we have people who seem to exercise De in leadership (eg. Religious leaders or CEOs), but the vast majority of social order is in fact maintained by bureaucracy. And Weber pointed out an important insight: because bureaucracy is so effective in organizing large scale societies and unleashing powerful collective abilities, other societies were forced to bureaucratize as well In order to compete effectively. Bureaucracy only needed to be invented once to spread throughout the world and to become the dominant mode of social organization.

This lecture was fascinating, and raises a question that I was wondering about since the first week, which is whether there can be such a thing as group-level Wu-Wei. Han Feizi seemed to think that group-level wu-Wei was basically obtained through a perfect, self-regulating institutional arrangement that freed people from having to constantly tweak it, which led to a rather dark view of group-level wu-Wei as a survival tactic. But can group-level wu-wei be achieved through the alignment of the hot cognition of multiple people? I'm thinking of how some sports teams seem to work together seamlessly, as if they were all part of one mind and can anticipate each other's decisions. Would that be considered wu-Wei as well?

I noticed that the crux of the Beyond Belief debate was on the extent to which reason can shape human morality, and if it's normatively a good thing or not. I just finished reading *Primates and Philosophers* by Frans de Waal, which featured a debate between de Waal and a bunch of philosophers largely over whether human reason and culture is actually that radical  a shift in human thinking. (I got the sense that de Waal's intuitionism made him a closet virtue ethicist, not least because of him favourably citing Mencius's willows and cups metaphor). De Waal argued against an admittedly strawman "Veneer Theory" where culture and reason were overlain on top of an evil human nature (think Lord of the Flies); instead, he argues that we evolved with empathy, and culture, reason, and ethics are only something like upper onion layers to this empathetic core. In response, the philosophers (an evolutionary theorist, a Kantian, a pragmatist, and a consequentialist (Peter Singer)) all agreed that reason was a radical singularity point that decisively divides humanity from everything else. Indeed, Singer's own work elsewhere suggested that we can rebel against nature using reason.So I see many parallels between this book and the one Professor Slingerland got himself into at the Beyond Belief conference. The crux of the argument is the same: must we stick to our naturalist intuitions, and is reason that decisive a break from nature--if not whether reason save us from nature? Obviously the New Atheists all argued for an empowered reason, although I found their arguments to be weak (especially if they argued on pragmatic grounds), and obviously our professor argued for sticking to what's naturally plausible. But from both that book and this course, I had new takeaway points. Whereas before I believed that Western thinkers were pessimists and Chinese thinkers were optimists vis a vis human nature (not even Han Fei could rival the pessimism of Original Sin), I now think that in addition to this optimism/pessimism foundational premise about human nature, it is the Enlightenment thinkers who are optimists and virtue ethicists and Waalian intuitionists who are pessimists insofar as how humanity can break from nature. Virtue ethicists may begin optimistically about the neutral or even good nature of human nature, but their conclusions are pessimistic about reason--we can only stick to reforming our nature, not defy it. Rationalists may be pessimistic about human nature and its inherent irrationality, but they are optimistic about reason's ability to free humanity to new heights. This is definitely not a traditional conservative-liberal divide, that's for sure.Anyway, this MOOC was one of the best I've taken (and I'm a veteran of way too many), and it's gotten me interested in moral psychology. Many thanks to Prof Slingerland for his insightful synthesis of virtue ethics and cognitive science, and for convincing me that perhaps an empirically-based virtue ethics has a chance in the 21st century. PS: I strongly recommend Prof Slingerland to read de Waal's book if he hasn't already.

column25: Just because they are atheists doesn't mean they are existentialist. Many (if not all) of them take human existence and the concept of 'self' as given. Han Feizi's anti-traditionalism seems to come into conflict with the rigidity of fixed standards under his Legalist system. To expand on his own example, a king who dies from a fatal chill because his minister of hats refused to overstep his bounds would be a failed king who could not retain power, even if one of his ministers was a better Legalist. Now I supposed the ideal king would not act on his desires to go hunt in the first place, but that still leaves open the question of how kings and ministers would deal with laws that are no longer fitting current conditions. To overturn outdated laws is to no longer obey them. If it is necessary, then how does one know of the correct circumstances to do that?  I'm not sure about the historical veracity of the Daze Xiang Uprising, but from what I understand the story goes that several hundred Qin soldiers were unavoidably delayed by rain in reporting to their new post. Since the penalty for such delay was without exception death, and the penalty for rebellion was also death, then it made sense for the soldiers to rebel and at least fight for however slim a chance to overturn the state and thus defy its laws. This then led to significant chaos and many more deaths than just the initial few hundred rebels. In ideal circumstances the penalty against tardiness seems the perfect Han Feizian law, in that it's clear, inflexible, and backed by harsh punishment. It's even bureaucratically "wu wei" in that the delayed troops immediately knew to take the only logical course of action open to them, without need for correspondence or intervention from the capitol. The only problem is that the consequence of such inflexible laws encountering the outlying circumstances of bad weather is without exception rebellion and chaos.  Did Han Feizi or other Legalist authors attempt to address this tension of simple and inflexible laws being ill suited for governing in complex and changing times?
column35: How would the Legalist sage overturn a bad law created by his own state?

This would be the Confucian critique of Legalism, that you need flexibility in interpreting laws, and excessive rigidity leads to trouble. But I think Hanfeizi's worry is that as soon as you open the door to interpretation, it's a slippery slope straight to chaos.

Sorry for the very late question here. I've been traveling this week and regret not posting earlier.This video has the conservative-liberal divide backwards! Xunzi sounds conservative because his focus on tradition is more apparent, but he doesn't  believe in Tian! You yourself compared him to Durkheim, who was not a religious practitioner but an outsider, a scholar. This is why Xunzi was easily displaced in the Chinese tradition-- he was like a modern academic endorsing it from the outside.Mencius was a conservative, because he conserved Confucianism from this scholarly tendency. Zhu Xi was an analytic philosopher like Xunzi who lacked the faith needed for action, and Wang Yangming was a conservative military general whose Tian-based fundamentalism inspired radical, extremist rightist currents in modern Japan.

Dear Professor Slingerland and the China 300x TeamThank you for including the video of the Beyond Belief conference from 2007, Salk Institute. Of course, our moral view reflects our social worlds. For example, most North Americans are unable to comprehend that some (possibly most?) Muslim women might actually like their role in Muslim society. A great allegory on this is Arranged, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uUALZ81S1ak Thomas Kuhn told us that we couldn't see beyond our frames of reference. But Ioan Tenner points out: paradox is a Òdetector of the UnknownÓ or an Òexposure of unexamined certaintiesÓ. In Kierkegaard's words: ÒThe thinker without a paradox is like a lover without feelingÓSo thank you for sharing your paradox, and meditations upon it, so generously.Kind regardsGeoffrey

I notice in the Xunzi readings that Mozi gets bashed quite a bit. Lines like this in chapter 2: "If your bearing is arrogant and obtuse and your heart is stubborn and deceitful, if your method is to follow Mozi and your truest essence is polluted and corrupt, then you may wander across the whole world, and even if you reach every corner of it, no one will not consider you base." Wow, tell us how you really feel, Xunzi!Now as someone used to western philosophy, I felt I could relate more to Mozi's rationality than the conservative Confucius or the anti-intellectual streak in Daoist thought. I also found something admirable in the way his followers tried to live by their principles of "universal love/concern" by supposedly taking up arms to defend weak states from invaders. But the readings that have followed Mozi have typically included statements specifically in reaction against Mozi and I get the feeling Xunzi was particularly dismissive. Was Mohist thought considered a serious threat to whatever sagely "establishment" existed back then? Did people like Xunzi try to stamp it out, or at least strongly discourage it? Was this just because it was a rival school or because Mozi's teaching opposed the rituals (Xunzi seems particularly galled at Mozi denouncing music in chapter 20) or something else? I feel the Daoists also could be viewed as objectionable for these reasons but they seem to receive far less scorn.

Hi AndrewI have taken quite a few MOOCs, too. And I'd certainly agree with you that this is one of the very best. I'd also agree with you that "captious criticisms are trivial and unworthy"... that is almost the definition of captious.However, I regret that you see my criticism that way. This is always the danger with criticism, as my friend Ioan puts it: "Like hunting, criticism feels as a noble sport or an assassination; depends on which side of the gun you are." see http://wisdom.tenner.org/blog/there-are-three-kinds-of-criticism-iI was attempting Ioan's "friendly criticism" - obviously not successfully in your view. And yet merely telling people how wonderful they are is not always the most helpful thing to do, either.Anyone attempting wu-wei walks a tightrope over disingenuousness by implying things are easy that are not, and maybe it is unkind to point out their wobbles. Nevertheless, in the case of an academic seeking to raise their game in popularising their thinking, there are certainly good and less good models. I have pointed out both. On the good side, I have referenced Sir Ken Robinson who reminds us that if you seek to inform you must first entertain. His  TED video on "How schools kill creativity" is surely an object lesson in wu-wei ( http://www.ted.com/talks/ken_robinson_says_schools_kill_creativity?language=en ), both popular (over 30 million hits) and carrying a deadly serious message. Notice how he, also, flirts with humility: "...the whole purpose of public education throughout the world is to produce university professors. Isn't it? They're the people who come out the top. And I used to be one, so there."Among less-good models, I have cited Dan Coyle's execrable "The Talent Code", also hugely popular but for all the wrong reasons, a self-help book that was effectively picked apart on a Coursera/Duke University English Composition I MOOC that I took. Coyle is a cynical snake-oil vendor, telling us what we desperately want to hear to encourage us to part with our money. Not good company for our Professor.This is not a trivial point. I respect Professor Singerland enough to believe he is capable of taking it in the spirit intended.Kind regardsGeoffrey

I wonder if you have considered the neuroscience of 'stories' as the human being bringing reality into view, working with moral equivalents against different examples or stories, the repetition, the engaged imagination. I live in Rochester NY and we have a well-known writer and storyteller in our community, Rafe Martin: http://blog.storynet.org/traditional-tales-and-the-modern-teller He says: "All stories syncopate against or play with ancient structural patterns. There are no new tales, just new ways to tell the patterns already woven into our psyches."I feel that it is only the anthropomorphic evolution of storytelling that has aided human linguistic development sufficiently to write 'law' and to consider 'propositions', etc. -- to 'think.'  Our brains' architechture responded to the experiential basis of memory, telling, imagining, reasoning, metaphorical thinking, etc.  Hot cognition preceded cold.

Yes and no, Daniel. One could argue that individuality is also an emergent quality of our complex brain (where the neurons and glia are the "people"). So there is, perhaps, a personal form of we-wei as well as collective family forms (family members as the agents), neighbourhood forms (families as the agents), country forms (regions as the agents), etc., in a kind of fractal self-similarity. The quality of the different emergent forms might be different, but related. And for me, this makes the "human nature" and the "cultural" arguments compatible rather than at odds - as presented in this lecture. The "human nature" emergence of wu-wei would be the "unexplainable" incremental change based on brain~body learning just as the cultural incremental changes lead to "unexplainable" changes in a societal form of wu-wei.

I second that emotion !I only discovered this course in passing whilst I was also studying a lot of other MOOCs but the over all premise & introduction video drew me in, I've always been interested in Daoism so it looked good. I was immediately impressed by the engaging presentational style of you Prof Slingerland, the extremely high production values (way above any other MOOC I've seen) & the depth of insight combined with a very broad intellectual reasoning, thankfully presented with a self depreciatingly humourous approach which really helped promoting understanding of the topics covered.It wasn't long before I realised I'd bitten off more than I could chew however. By week three or four (I was doing around 4 Coursera MOOCs too remember)... (Oh & another EdX) I was missing deadlines & I'm afraid that pretty soon I settled on just 'auditing' the course, Heaven knows how you guys managed to keep up with all the reading materials & assignments too... phew!)But you know, I think I can unequivocally state that this course has really raised the barÉ IMHO it is the best MOOC that I have taken part in!Now I'm going to try to download all the videos , reading & reference materials & try to get stuck into it in the hope that this course is run again the same time next year. And when it is I will do my best to clear the decks for a couple of months & really give it the attention & dedication it deserves.The amount of work Prof Slingerland & his team put into this must have been great indeed & yet it truly was always presented with 'effortless mastery'.Wu Wei to go !   ;)(PS, I am posting this again as a different thread cos I really want you to seer itÉ I Hope thatÕs OK)

Hi my name is Howie.  (Took my title from the Mikado, Gilbert & Sullivan).I'm from Brooklyn.  I'm a patent lawyer by trade, although I'd much rather be doing something else.  Being a lawyer in general, and a patent lawyer in particular, is very much off the track of De and Wu-Wei.  I have a passing and superficial knowledge of Confucianism and Daoism, and a much greater acquaintance with Buddhism.  Part of my attraction to learning more about Chinese thought is that I find it more positive (less depressing) than Buddhism and related Indian thought. In particular while both have a soteriological aspect, Chinese thought seems to point to a "natural" way to get in tune, seemingly different from the stricter Middle Way in Buddhism, although they may have underlying similarities at a deeper level.Great course so far.
Many thanks to all... I've rated it (5 stars, of course) on CourseTalk.

I do not agree with the above association of the fast and slow modes of cognition:Why would costly cold, rational cognition have evolved if it was slow relatively to hot, fast, bidily / sensory cognition? ... Exactly! No evolutionary advantage here - so something must be wrong about this conceptualization and imho it is that hot is relatively slow because it builds on a combination of innate responses and learned experience , which actually takes considerable time to build up e.g. through adolescence or experiences we even make as adults in the course of our lives.
Funny, I had the same thought a while ago... that smoking is so fascinating because it represents a visualization of the invisible prana, qi, etc.
